salmon.eng_def: a medium-sized silver-coloured fish that lives in the sea or rivers and swims up rivers to produce its eggs. Its pink flesh is eaten as a food.

saloon.eng_def: a public bar, especially in the past in the western US
a car with seats for four or five people, two or four doors, and a separate area at the back for bags, boxes, and suitcases
saloon.chi_def: 三廂式四門（或雙門）轎車，小轎車

salt.eng_def: a common white substance found in sea water and in the ground, used especially to add flavour to food or to preserve it
a chemical substance that is a combination of a metal or a base with an acid
salt.eg: Potassium nitrate and potassium chloride are potassium salts.

salt.eng_def: to add salt to or put salt on something
salt.eg: Don't forget to salt the potatoes.

salt.eng_def: abbreviation for  speech and language therapy
salt.chi_def: 言語和語言治療（speech and language therapy 的縮寫）

salt.eng_def: abbreviation for  speech and language therapist
salt.chi_def: 言語和語言治療（speech and language therapy 的縮寫）

salt.eng_def: abbreviation for Strategic Arms Limitation Talks: a series of discussions between the US and the USSR that took place from 1969 to 1979 and aimed to limit the number of nuclear weapons
salt.chi_def: （美蘇）限制戰略武器會談（Strategic Arms Limitation Talks的縮寫）

salty.eg: This bacon is too salty for me.

salute.eng_def: (especially of people in the armed forces) to make a formal sign of respect to someone, especially by raising the right hand to the side of the head
salute.eg: Whenever you see an officer, you must salute.

salute.eng_def: to honour or express admiration publicly for a person or an achievement
salute.eg: On this memorable occasion we salute the wonderful work done by the association.

salute.eng_def: a sign of respect made to someone by raising the right hand to the side of the head
salute.eg: The soldier gave a salute and the officer returned it.

salute.eng_def: an action, such as firing a gun, done to show respect to someone
salute.chi_def: 致敬（如鳴禮炮等，以示對某人的尊敬）
salute.eg: Full military honours and a 21-gun salute (= 21 guns fired at the same time) marked his funeral.

salute.eng_def: an action or sign to honour or show your admiration for a person or achievement

salvation.eng_def: (a way of) being saved from danger, loss, or harm
salvation.chi_def: 救助（途徑）； 解救（辦法）
salvation.eg: After the diagnosis, getting to know Mary was his salvation.

salvation.eng_def: In the Christian religion, salvation of a person or their spirit is the state of being saved from evil and its effects by the death of Jesus on a cross
salvation.eg: The Gospel message is one of personal salvation.

same.eng_def: exactly like another or each other
same.eg: My twin sister and I have the same nose.

same.eng_def: not another different place, time, situation, person, or thing
same.eg: My brother and I sleep in the same room.
People say I look just the same as my sister.
After all these years you look exactly the same - you haven't changed a bit.

same.eng_def: not another different thing or situation
same.chi_def: 同樣的事物；同樣的情況
same.eg: I'm terrible at physics, and it's the same with chemistry - I get it all wrong.
"Was that Marion on the phone?" "The (very) same."
We treat all our children the same.

sample.eng_def: a small amount of something that shows you what the rest is or should be like
a small amount of a substance that a doctor or scientist collects in order to examine it
sample.chi_def: （醫生或科學家檢測用的）樣本，試樣

sample.eng_def: a group of people or things that is chosen out of a larger number and is asked questions or tested in order to get information about the larger group
a small part of a song that has been recorded and used to make a new piece of music
sample.chi_def: （用於新樂曲中的）選錄的歌曲片段

sample.eng_def: to taste a small amount of food or drink to decide if you like it
sample.eg: As the food looked so good, he decided to sample a little from each dish.

sample.eng_def: to experience a place or an activity, often for the first time
sample.eg: So you're going to sample the delights/pleasures of the new restaurant?

sample.eng_def: to record part of a song and use the recording to make a new piece of music
sample.chi_def: 節錄，選錄（歌曲片段，用於新的樂曲中）
sample.eg: This song has been heavily sampled.

sanction.eng_def: an official order, such as the stopping of trade, that is taken against a country in order to make it obey international law
sanction.eg: Many nations have imposed sanctions on the country because of its attacks on its own people.

sanction.eng_def: a strong action taken in order to make people obey a law or rule, or a punishment given when they do not obey
sanction.chi_def: （爲維護法律或規定而採取的）強硬措施；（對違反法律或規定者進行的）懲罰，處罰
sanction.eg: Without realistic sanctions, some teachers have difficulty keeping order in the classroom.

sanction.eng_def: approval or permission, especially formal or legal
sanction.chi_def: （尤指正式或法律認可的）批准，許可
sanction.eg: They tried to get official sanction for the plans.

sanction.eng_def: to formally give permission for something
sanction.eg: The government was reluctant to sanction intervention in the crisis.

sanctuary.eng_def: protection or a safe place, especially for someone or something being chased or hunted
sanctuary.chi_def: 庇護，保護；避難所，庇護所
sanctuary.eg: Illegal immigrants found/sought/took sanctuary in a local church.

sanctuary.eng_def: a place where birds or animals can live and be protected, especially from being hunted or dangerous conditions
the most holy part of a religious building

sand.eng_def: a substance that consists of very small grains of rock, found on beaches and in deserts
large flat areas of sand near the sea
to make something smooth by rubbing it with something rough, especially sandpaper (= strong paper with sand attached to it)
sand.eg: Sand the door (down) thoroughly before starting to paint.

sandal.eng_def: a light shoe, especially worn in warm weather, consisting of a bottom part held onto the foot by straps

sandwich.eng_def: two pieces of bread with cheese, salad, or meat, usually cold, between them
a cake consisting of two thin, round layers with a filling such as cream between them

sane.eng_def: having a healthy mind and not mentally ill
sane.chi_def: 心智健全的，神智正常的；頭腦清醒的
sane.eg: In the doctor's opinion he was sane at the time of the murder.
It was a sane decision and one we all respected.

sanitation.eng_def: the systems for taking dirty water and other waste products away from buildings in order to protect people's health
sanitation.eg: Many illnesses in these temporary refugee camps are the result of inadequate sanitation.

satellite.eng_def: a device sent up into space to travel around the earth, used for collecting information or communicating by radio, television, etc.
satellite.eg: The World Cup was transmitted around the world by satellite.

satellite.eng_def: a natural object moving around a larger object in space
a country controlled by or depending on a more powerful country

satisfaction.eng_def: a pleasant feeling that you get when you receive something you wanted, or when you have done something you wanted to do
satisfaction.eg: She looked at the finished painting with satisfaction.

satisfaction.eng_def: a way of dealing with a complaint or problem that makes the person who complained feel happy
satisfaction.chi_def: （對投訴或問題的）妥善處理；賠償，補償
satisfaction.eg: You've sold me a defective product and I demand satisfaction (= you must return my money or give me a new product).

satisfaction.eng_def: the act of fulfilling (= achieving) a need or wish
satisfaction.eg: the satisfaction of one's sexual desires

satisfaction.eng_def: in a way that a particular person can believe or accept
satisfaction.chi_def: 使（某人）確信；使（某人）接受
satisfaction.eg: The boy explained to the satisfaction of the court why he had lied.

satisfaction.eng_def: in a way that a particular person feels pleased or satisfied with
satisfaction.chi_def: 令（某人）滿意；使（某人）滿足
satisfaction.eg: He won't get paid until he completes the job to my satisfaction.

satisfactory.eng_def: good or good enough for a particular need or purpose
satisfactory.chi_def: 令人滿意的；使人滿足的；夠好的
satisfactory.eg: The teachers seem to think his work is satisfactory.

satisfy.eng_def: to please someone by giving them what they want or need
satisfy.eg: They have 31 flavours of ice cream - enough to satisfy everyone!

satisfy.eng_def: to have or provide something that is needed or wanted
satisfy.chi_def: 達到條件／滿足需要／符合要求
satisfy.eg: She satisfies all the requirements for the job.

satisfy.eng_def: to make someone believe that something is true

sauce.eng_def: a thick liquid eaten with food to add flavour

sauce.eg: He's been on the sauce (= drinking too much alcohol) again.

sauce.eng_def: remarks that are rude or show no respect
sauce.eg: That's enough of your sauce, my girl!

saucer.eng_def: a small, curved plate that you put a cup on

sausage.eng_def: a thin, tube-like case containing meat that has been cut into very small pieces and mixed with spices

savage.eng_def: If an animal savages someone, it attacks them violently and causes serious injuries.
savage.eg: The child was savaged by a dog.

savage.eng_def: a person whose way of life is at a very early stage of development
savage.eg: Twelve thousand years ago, our ancestors were primitive savages living in caves.

save.eng_def: to stop someone or something from being killed, injured, or destroyed
save.eg: Wearing seat belts has saved many lives.

save.eng_def: to stop someone from being killed
save.chi_def: 使（某人）免遭殺害；救（某人）的性命

save.eng_def: to help someone escape from a difficult or unpleasant situation
save.chi_def: 幫助（某人）脫離困境（或窘境）
save.eg: Thanks for helping me with that report - you saved my life!

save.eng_def: to keep something, especially money, for use in the future
save.eg: Tom's been saving his pocket money every week.

save.eng_def: to put information into a computer's memory or onto a computer disk
save.chi_def: 將（電腦上的資料）存檔，保存
save.eg: Don't forget to save your work regularly.

save.eng_def: to prevent time, money, or effort being wasted or spent
save.eg: You'll save time if you take the car.

save.eng_def: in football and similar games, to stop the ball from going into the goal when a player on the other team has kicked or hit it
save.chi_def: （足球等球類運動中）救（球），阻止對方得（分）

save.eng_def: in football or similar games, when a player stops the ball from going into the goal when it is hit or kicked by a player from the other team
save.chi_def: （足球等球類運動中）救（球），阻止對方得（分）
save.eg: The goalkeeper made a great save in the last minute of the game.
They found all the lost documents save one.

saving.eng_def: the money that you keep in an account in a bank or similar financial organization
saving.eg: He spent all his savings on an expensive car.

saving.eng_def: an amount of money that you do not need to spend
saving.eg: You can make huge savings (= save a lot of money) by buying food in bulk.

saving.eng_def: making it possible to use less of the stated thing

saw.eng_def: to cut wood or other hard material using a saw
saw.eg: They sawed the door in half.

saw.eng_def: to move something backwards and forwards as if using a saw
saw.eg: He was sawing away at his violin, making a terrible noise!

saw.eng_def: a tool with a long or round blade and a row of sharp points along one edge, used for cutting hard materials such as wood or metal

say.eng_def: to pronounce words or sounds, to express a thought, opinion, or suggestion, or to state a fact or instruction
say.eg: Small children find it difficult to say long words.

say.eng_def: to give (as) an opinion or suggestion about something
say.eg: "Who do you think will get the job?" "I'd rather not say."

say.eng_def: to show what you think without using words
say.eg: The look on his face said (= showed) (that) he knew what had happened.

say.eng_def: When something or someone is said to be a particular thing, that is what people think or believe about it, him, or her.
say.eg: It is said (that) Latin is a difficult language to learn.

say.eng_def: to give information in writing, numbers, or signs
used to express surprise or pleasure, or to attract attention to what you are about to say
say.chi_def: （用以表示驚訝、驚喜或喚起聽話人的注意）哎呀
say.eg: Say, that's really good of you!

say.eng_def: (the right to give) an opinion about something
say.eg: Keep quiet for a minute and let me have my say.

scale.eng_def: a set of numbers, amounts, etc., used to measure or compare the level of something
the relation between the real size of something and its size on a map, model, or diagram
the size or level of something, especially when this is large
scale.eg: We don't yet know the scale of the problem.

scale.eng_def: a device for weighing things or people

a weighing device with two containers connected to a metal bar that is free to move up and down about its fixed central point. An object of known weight is put in one container and the thing to be weighed is put in the other.
a set of notes played or sung in order, going up or down
one of the many very small, flat pieces that cover the skin of fish, snakes, etc.
scale.chi_def: （魚、蛇等動物皮膚表層的）鱗，鱗片

scale.eng_def: a hard, white or grey layer of material that forms on the inside of pipes or containers that heat water
to climb up a steep surface, such as a wall or the side of a mountain, often using special equipment
scale.eg: The prisoner scaled the high prison wall and ran off.

scale.eng_def: to remove tartar (= hard white substance) and plaque (= soft substance in which bacteria breed) from teeth
scale.eg: The dentist scaled and polished my teeth last week.

scan.eng_def: to look at something carefully, with the eyes or with a machine, in order to get information
scan.eg: She anxiously scanned the faces of the men leaving the train.

scan.eng_def: to look through a text quickly in order to find a piece of information that you want or to get a general idea of what the text contains
scan.eg: I scanned through the booklet but couldn't find the address.

scan.eng_def: to use a machine to put a picture of a document into a computer, or to take a picture of the inside of something
scan.chi_def: 掃瞄（使用機器，將某一檔的圖片輸入到電腦中，或拍攝某物內部的圖片）
scan.eg: I'll just scan the article into the computer.

scan.eng_def: If a poem or part of a poem scans, it follows a pattern of regular beats.
scan.eg: This line doesn't scan - it has too many syllables.

scan.eng_def: a careful or quick look through something
scan.eg: I gave the book a quick scan, and decided not to buy it.

scan.eng_def: a medical examination in which an image of the inside of the body is made using a special machine

scandal.eng_def: (an action or event that causes) a public feeling of shock and strong moral disapproval
reports about actions or events that cause shock and disapproval
scandal.eg: Some magazines contain nothing but scandal and gossip.

scandal.eng_def: a situation that is extremely bad
scandal.eg: It's a scandal (that) children are treated in this way.

scar.eng_def: a mark left on part of the body after an injury, such as a cut, has healed
a sign of damage to a person's mental state
scar.eg: His early years in the refugee camp left a deep psychological scar.

scar.eng_def: a sign of physical destruction in a place
scar.eg: Every village bears the scars of war .
He was scarred as a result of the fire.

scarce.eng_def: not easy to find or get
scarce.eg: Food and clean water were becoming scarce.
I could scarce believe my eyes.

scarcely.eg: I was scarcely able to move my arm after the accident.

scarcely.eng_def: used to say that something happened immediately after something else happened
scarcely.eg: I had scarcely sat down/Scarcely had I sat down to eat when the phone rang.
I'd scarcely have done it if I didn't think it was absolutely necessary!

scare.eng_def: to (make a person or animal) feel frightened
scare.chi_def: （使）驚恐，（使）害怕；受驚嚇，感到害怕

scare.eng_def: a sudden feeling of fear or worry
scare.eg: I got/had a scare (= I was very worried) when I looked at my bank statement this morning!

scare.eng_def: an occasion when a subject receives a lot of public attention and worries many people, often when there is no real danger
scare.chi_def: （往往不必要的）擔憂；人心惶惶

scarecrow.eng_def: a model of a person dressed in old clothes and put in a field of growing crops to frighten birds away

scarf.eng_def: a strip, square, or triangle of cloth, worn around the neck, head, or shoulders to keep you warm or to make you look attractive
to eat something quickly and eagerly
scarf.eg: Lunch is usually scarfed down in five minutes before they run out to play.

scatter.eng_def: to (cause to) move far apart in different directions
scatter.eg: The protesters scattered at the sound of gunshots.

scatter.eng_def: to cover a surface with things that are far apart and in no particular arrangement
scatter.eg: Scatter the powder around the plants.

scene.eng_def: a part of a play or film in which the action stays in one place for a continuous period of time
a view or picture of a place, event, or activity
a place where an unpleasant event has happened
scene.chi_def: （不愉快事件發生的）現場，地點
scene.eg: The police arrived to find a scene of horrifying destruction.

scene.eng_def: a particular area of activity and all the people or things connected with it
an expression of great anger or similar feelings, often between two people, or an occasion when this happens

scenery.eng_def: the general appearance of the natural environment, especially when it is beautiful
the large painted pictures used on a theatre stage to represent the place where the action is

scenic.eng_def: having or allowing you to see beautiful natural features
scenic.eg: an area of outstanding scenic beauty

scent.eng_def: a smell produced by an animal that acts as a signal to other animals
scent.eg: The hounds had lost the scent of the fox near the river.

scent.eng_def: a pleasant-smelling liquid that people put on their skin
If an animal scents something or someone, it knows that person or thing is there because it can smell it, him, or her.
If a person scents something, they have a feeling that they are about to experience it.
scent.eg: Halfway through the game, the team could already scent victory.

schedule.eng_def: a list of planned activities or things to be done showing the times or dates when they are intended to happen or be done
a list of the times when events are planned to happen, for example the times when classes happen or when buses, etc. leave and arrive
schedule.eg: The class schedule is available on the website.
We expect the building work to be completed ahead of schedule.

schedule.eng_def: to do less work than you planned to do by a particular point in time
to arrange that an event or activity will happen at a particular time
schedule.eg: The meeting has been scheduled for tomorrow afternoon.

scheme.eng_def: an organized plan for doing something, especially something dishonest or illegal that will bring a good result for you
scheme.eg: He has a hare-brained/crazy scheme for getting rich before he's 20.

scheme.eng_def: an officially organized plan or system
scheme.eg: Under the current marking/mark scheme, you need 90 percent to get an A.

scheme.eng_def: to make clever, secret plans that often deceive others
scheme.eg: All her assistants were scheming against her.

scholar.eng_def: a person who studies a subject in great detail, especially at a university
someone who is intelligent or good at learning by studying
scholar.chi_def: 聰穎好學者；善於學習者
scholar.eg: David's never been much of a scholar.

scholarship.eng_def: an amount of money given by a school, college, university, or other organization to pay for the studies of a person with great ability but little money
scholarship.eg: He got/won a scholarship to Harvard.

school.eng_def: a place where children go to be educated
the period of your life during which you go to school, or the teaching and learning activities which happen at school
school.chi_def: 上學期間，讀書階段；上學
school.eg: Most children start/begin school at the age of five.

school.eng_def: the time during the day when children are studying in school
all the children and teachers at a school
school.eg: The whole school is/are delighted about Joel's success in the championships.

school.eng_def: a part of a college or university specializing in a particular subject or group of subjects
school.eg: the School of Oriental and African Studies

school.eng_def: a place where people can study a particular subject either some of the time or all of the time
a college or university or the time that a student spends there
school.eg: We first met in graduate school (= while doing a second or third university degree).

school.eng_def: a group of painters, writers, poets, etc. whose work is similar, especially similar to that of a particular leader
a large number of fish or other sea creatures swimming in a group
to train a person or animal to do something
school.eg: It takes a lot of patience to school a dog/horse.
Her children are well schooled in correct behaviour.

science.eng_def: (knowledge from) the careful study of the structure and behaviour of the physical world, especially by watching, measuring, and doing experiments, and the development of theories to describe the results of these activities
science.chi_def: 科學；自然科學；科學知識

science.eng_def: a particular subject that is studied using scientific methods

scientific.eng_def: relating to science, or using the organized methods of science
scientific.chi_def: 科學的；應用科學方法的

scientific.eng_def: careful and using a system or method
scientific.eg: We will have to adopt a more scientific approach in the future.

scientist.eng_def: an expert who studies or works in one of the sciences

scissors.eng_def: a device used for cutting materials such as paper, cloth, and hair, consisting of two sharp blades that are joined in the middle, and two handles with holes to put your fingers through

scold.eng_def: to speak to someone angrily because you disapprove of their behaviour
scold.eg: His mother scolded him for breaking her favourite vase.

scoop.eng_def: a tool with a deep bowl-shaped end that is used to dig out and move a soft substance or powder
the amount held by a scoop
scoop.eg: Just one scoop of mashed potato for me, please.

scoop.eng_def: a story or piece of news discovered and published by one newspaper before all the others
scoop.chi_def: 搶先報導的新聞；獨家新聞
scoop.eg: The paper managed to secure a major scoop and broke the scandal to the world.

scoop.eng_def: to move something with a scoop or with something used as a scoop
scoop.eg: He scooped the sand into a bucket with his hands.

scoop.eng_def: to get a large number of votes or prizes
scoop.eg: The party is expected to scoop up the majority of the working-class vote.

scoop.eng_def: to be the first newspaper to discover and print an important news story
scoop.eg: Just as we were about to publish the story, we were scooped by a rival paper.

scope.eng_def: the range of a subject covered by a book, programme, discussion, class, etc.
scope.eg: I'm afraid that problem is beyond/outside the scope of my lecture.
There is limited scope for further reductions in the workforce.

scope.eng_def: used to form nouns that refer to devices for looking at or discovering and measuring things
scope.chi_def: （構成名詞，表示「觀看」、「觀察」、「測量」等用的儀器）

score.eng_def: to win or get a point, goal, etc. in a competition, sport, game, or test
score.eg: Tennant scored (a goal) in the last minute of the game.

score.eng_def: to succeed in an activity or to achieve something
score.eg: She has certainly scored (a success) with her latest novel.

score.eng_def: to record the number of points won by competitors
score.eg: We need someone to score for tomorrow's match.
I managed to score a couple of tickets to the World Cup final.
She tried to score some dope in a nightclub.

score.eng_def: to have sex with someone that you have usually just met
score.chi_def: （通常指與新認識的人）發生性關係
score.eg: Did you score last night, then?

score.eng_def: to make a mark or cut on the surface of something hard with a pointed tool, or to draw a line through writing
score.eg: If you score the tile first, it will be easier to break.

score.eng_def: to write or change a piece of music for particular instruments or voices
score.eg: This piece is scored for strings and woodwind.

score.eng_def: the number of points, goals, etc. achieved in a game or competition
a piece of written music showing the parts for all the instruments and voices
the music written for a film, play, etc.

score.eg: He lived to be three score years and ten (= until he was 70 years old).
People are leaving the organization by the score.

score.eng_def: a lot of things or people
score.eg: Sean received cards from scores of local well-wishers.

score.eng_def: about the thing or subject that has just been mentioned
score.eg: I'll let you have the money, so there's nothing to worry about on that score.

scorn.eng_def: a very strong feeling of no respect for someone or something that you think is stupid or has no value
scorn.eg: She has nothing but scorn for the new generation of politicians.

scorn.eng_def: to show scorn for someone or something
scorn.eg: So does he respect the press and media, or does he secretly scorn them?

scorn.eng_def: to refuse advice or an offer because you are too proud
scorn.eg: She scorned all my offers of help.

scout.eng_def: a person, especially a soldier, sent out to get information about where the enemy are and what they are doing
a person employed to look for people with particular skills, especially in sport or entertainment
scout.chi_def: （尤指體育或娛樂界的）人才發掘者，星探

scout.eng_def: a quick look around a place or area, especially in order to find something
scout.chi_def: （尤指爲尋找某物而）掃視，快速查看
scout.eg: I had a quick scout around the house to check everything was okay.

scout.eng_def: to go to look in various places for something you want
scout.eg: He's scouting about/around for somewhere better to live.

scout.eng_def: a boy or girl who is a member of the Scouts
an international organization that encourages young people of all ages to take part in activities outside and to become responsible and independent

scramble.eng_def: to move or climb quickly but with difficulty, often using your hands to help you
scramble.eg: She scrambled up the steep hillside and over the rocks.

scramble.eng_def: to compete with other people for something there is very little of
scramble.eg: People are scrambling to buy property before prices rise even further.

scramble.eng_def: to put things such as words or letters in the wrong order so that they do not make sense
scramble.chi_def: 打亂（單詞或字母使之不再有任何含義）
scramble.eg: He had a habit of scrambling his words when excited.

scramble.eng_def: to mix eggs with a little milk and mix again as they are being fried
to change a radio or phone signal so that it can only be understood using a special device
scramble.chi_def: 對（無線電或電話信號）作擾頻（或倒頻）處理（使只有透過專門設備才能接收）

scramble.eng_def: to (cause a plane to) take off very quickly
scramble.eg: A helicopter was scrambled within minutes of the news.

scramble.eng_def: a climb that is difficult so that you have to use your hands to help you
scramble.eg: It was a real scramble to the top of the hillside.
As soon as the plane landed there was a mad/wild scramble to get out.

scramble.eng_def: a hurried attempt to get something
scramble.eg: After the death of the dictator there was an unseemly scramble for power among the generals.
We're planning a scramble through the forest next weekend.

scramble.eng_def: a dish of eggs and other foods such as potatoes that are mixed as they are being fried
scramble.eg: a Mexican scramble (= eggs with hot peppers, etc.)

scrap.eng_def: to not continue with a system or plan
scrap.eg: They're considering scrapping the tax and raising the money in other ways.

scrap.eng_def: to get rid of something that is no longer useful or wanted, often using its parts in new ways
scrap.eg: Hundreds of nuclear weapons have been scrapped.

scrap.eng_def: to have a fight or an argument
old cars and machines or pieces of metal, etc. that are not now needed but have parts that can be used to make other things
a small piece of something or a small amount of information
scrap.eg: Do you have a scrap of paper I could write on?

scrap.eng_def: small pieces of food that have not been eaten and are usually thrown away
scrap.eg: We give all our scraps to our cat.

scrap.eng_def: a fight or argument, especially a quick, noisy one about something not important
scrap.chi_def: （尤指瑣事引發的短暫而吵鬧的）打架，吵架
scrap.eg: A couple of kids were having a scrap in the street.

scrape.eng_def: to remove an unwanted covering or a top layer from something, especially using a sharp edge or something rough
scrape.eg: Scrape your boots clean before you come in.

scrape.eng_def: to (cause to) rub against a surface so that slight damage or an unpleasant noise is produced
scrape.eg: Jackie fell over and scraped her knee (on the pavement).

scrape.eng_def: to succeed in getting or achieving something, but with difficulty or by a very small amount
scrape.chi_def: 勉強獲得；費盡千辛萬苦
scrape.eg: Her grades weren't great, but she scraped into university.

scrape.eng_def: a difficult or slightly dangerous situation that you cause by your own silly behaviour
scrape.chi_def: （由於自身愚蠢而招致的）困境，危境
scrape.eg: She's always getting into silly scrapes - I wish she'd think before she does things.

scrape.eng_def: a slight injury or an unpleasant noise produced by rubbing against a surface
scrape.eg: "It's just a scrape," said the boy looking down at his bleeding knee.

scratch.eng_def: to cut or damage a surface or your skin slightly with or on something sharp or rough
scratch.eg: We scratched the wall trying to get the bed into Martha's room.

scratch.eng_def: If you scratch something on or off a surface, you add it or remove it by scratching.
scratch.eg: People have been scratching their names on this rock for years.

scratch.eng_def: If an animal scratches, it rubs something with its claws (= sharp nails).
scratch.eg: The dog's scratching at the door - he wants to be let in.

scratch.eng_def: to rub your skin with your nails
scratch.eg: He was scratching (at) his mosquito bites.

scratch.eng_def: to remove yourself or another person or an animal from a competition before the start
scratch.eg: The world champion scratched from the 800 metres after injuring herself the day before.

scratch.eng_def: to decide not to do something you had planned to do
scratch.eg: We had to scratch our plans when I lost my job.
Her legs were covered in scratches and bruises after her walk through the forest.
That dog is having a good scratch. It must have fleas.

scratch.eng_def: a group of people brought together in a hurry in order to play together on a particular occasion
scratch.chi_def: 臨時拼湊起來的隊伍／派別／管弦樂隊

scream.eng_def: to cry or say something loudly and usually on a high note, especially because of strong emotions such as fear, excitement, or anger
scream.chi_def: （尤指因恐懼、興奮、憤怒等強烈情緒而）尖叫，驚呼
scream.eg: A spider landed on her pillow and she screamed.

scream.eng_def: If a vehicle screams, it moves very quickly making a loud high sound.
scream.eg: The cars screamed round the bend/past the spectators.

scream.eng_def: to make a loud, high sound
scream.eg: The ambulance raced round the corner with its tyres screaming.

scream.eng_def: If a word or image screams (out), it gets attention because it is very big or easy to notice.
scream.eg: "Latest Plane Disaster!" screamed the newspaper headlines the next day.

scream.eng_def: a loud, high sound you make when very frightened, excited, or angry
a person, thing, or situation that is very funny
scream.chi_def: 令人捧腹大笑的人（或事物、情景）
scream.eg: Jane's such a scream - her jokes have me in stitches.

screen.eng_def: a flat surface in a cinema, on a television, or as part of a computer, on which pictures or words are shown

screen.eg: He's made several films for the small screen.
So this is your first appearance on the big screen?

screen.eng_def: a vertical structure that is used to separate one area from another, especially to hide something or to protect you from something unpleasant or dangerous
screen.eg: The nurse pulled a screen around the bed so that the doctor could examine the patient in private.

screen.eng_def: an activity that is not dangerous or illegal but is used to hide something that is
screen.chi_def: （危險或不法活動的）庇護（所），掩蔽（物）
screen.eg: That café's just a screen for their criminal activities.

screen.eng_def: to test or examine someone or something to discover if there is anything wrong with him, her, or it
screen.eg: Women over 50 should be screened for breast cancer.

screen.eng_def: to delay your decision to answer the phone until you know who is calling you
screen.chi_def: 過濾來電（以決定是否接聽）
screen.eg: I always screen my calls while I'm eating dinner.

screen.eng_def: to show or broadcast a film or television programme
screen.eg: The programme was not screened on British television.
She raised her hand to screen her eyes from the bright light.

screen.eng_def: to protect someone by taking the blame yourself
screen.eg: The husband says he's the murderer but we think it was his wife - he's just screening her.

screw.eng_def: a thin, pointed piece of metal with a raised edge twisting round along its length and a flat top with a cut in it, used to join things together, especially pieces of wood
an act of twisting or turning done to fasten or tighten something
screw.eg: Give it another screw to make sure the lid doesn't come off while we're travelling.

screw.eng_def: (a word used especially by prisoners) a prison guard
screw.chi_def: 監獄看守（尤爲犯人用語）

screw.eng_def: the act of sex, or a sexual partner
screw.eg: I never feel like a screw when I wake up in the morning.

screw.eng_def: to fasten something using a screw
screw.eg: Screw this piece of wood to the wall.

screw.eng_def: to fasten something using an object similar to a screw
screw.chi_def: （用類似螺絲的東西）固定，旋緊
screw.eg: We'll have to screw a hook into the wall.

screw.eng_def: If something screws in/together, it fits or fastens together by being turned.
to tighten the muscles of your face or part of your face into a particular expression, especially one of disapproval or pain
screw.chi_def: （尤指出於不贊同或疼痛）扭曲（面部）
screw.eg: He screwed his eyes tight shut against the bright light.

screw.eng_def: to twist and crush something, especially paper or cloth, roughly with your hands
screw.eg: She screwed the bag up and threw it in the bin.

screw.eng_def: to fasten something by turning it or twisting it
screw.eg: Screw the lid firmly on to the jar and shake well.
It was only after we'd had the car for a few days that we realized we'd been screwed by the dealer.
They say he's screwing the boss's wife.

screwdriver.eng_def: a tool for turning screws, consisting of a handle joined to a metal rod shaped at one end to fit in the cut in the top of the screw

script.eng_def: the words of a film, play, broadcast, or speech
script.chi_def: 電影劇本；劇本；廣播稿；講稿
script.eg: Bruce Robinson wrote the script for "The Killing Fields".

script.eng_def: a set of letters used for writing a particular language

script.eg: The invitation was written in beautiful italic script.

script.eng_def: a type of language for programming computers that is used for finding and showing websites on the internet
an answer paper written by a student in an exam
script.eg: Don't forget to write your name at the top of your script.

script.eng_def: a piece of paper on which a doctor writes the details of the medicine or drugs that someone needs
to write the words of a film, play, broadcast, or speech
script.chi_def: 為（電影、戲劇、廣播或演講等）寫稿

scroll.eng_def: a long roll of paper or similar material with usually official writing on it
scroll.eg: The ancient Egyptians stored information on scrolls.

scroll.eng_def: a decoration that looks like a roll of paper
scroll.eg: The tops of the marble pillars were decorated with scrolls.

scroll.eng_def: to move text or other information on a computer screen in order to see a different part of it
scroll.eg: Scroll to the end of the document.

scrub.eng_def: to rub something hard in order to clean it, especially using a stiff brush, soap, and water
scrub.chi_def: （尤指用硬刷、肥皂和水）擦洗，刷洗
scrub.eg: She scrubbed (at) the mark on the wall for a long time, but it wouldn't come off.

scrub.eng_def: to decide not to do something you had planned to do
scrub.eg: We had to scrub our plans when I lost my job.

scrub.eng_def: (an area of land covered with) short trees and bushes, growing on dry ground of low quality
the act of rubbing something hard in order to clean it, especially using a stiff brush, soap, and water
scrub.chi_def: （尤指用硬刷、肥皂和水）擦洗，刷洗
scrub.eg: Kids, give your hands a good scrub and come and get your dinner!

scrub.eng_def: a substance that you use to clean your skin and make it softer, especially one that is slightly rough and will remove old skin
loose clothes worn by doctors and nurses in a hospital
scrub.eg: I saw a photo of her in doctor's scrubs.

scrub.eng_def: covered with short trees and bushes

sculptor.eg: Henry Moore, who died in 1986, is one of Britain's best-known sculptors.

sculpture.eng_def: the art of forming solid objects that represent a thing, person, idea, etc. out of a material such as wood, clay, metal, or stone, or an object made in this way
sculpture.chi_def: 雕塑，雕刻；塑像，雕塑品，雕刻品
sculpture.eg: Tom teaches sculpture at the local art school.

sea.eng_def: the salty water that covers a large part of the surface of the earth, or a large area of salty water, smaller than an ocean, that is partly or completely surrounded by land
a large amount or number of something
sea.eg: The teacher looked down and saw a sea of smiling faces.

sea.eng_def: (of a ship) to leave a port and start a journey
sea.eg: The boats will put (out) to sea on this evening's high tide.

sea.eng_def: one of the large, flat areas on the moon that in the past were thought to be seas
sea.chi_def: 海（指月球表面的廣闊平坦地區，過去被認爲是海）

seagull.eng_def: a bird that lives near the sea and has short legs, long wings, and white and grey feathers

seal.eng_def: a large mammal that eats fish and lives partly in the sea and partly on land or ice
something fixed around the edge of an opening to prevent liquid or gas flowing through it
seal.eg: Clean the seal on/around the fridge door regularly so that it remains airtight.

seal.eng_def: a thin piece of material such as paper or plastic that covers the opening of a container and has to be broken in order to open the container and use the contents
an official mark on a document, sometimes made with wax, that shows that it is legal or has been officially approved
seal.eg: The lawyer stamped the certificate with her seal.

seal.eng_def: to close an entrance or container so that nothing can enter or leave it
to cover a surface with a special liquid to protect it
seal.eg: This floor has just been sealed (with varnish), so don't walk on it!

seal.eng_def: to close a letter or parcel by sticking the edges together
to make an agreement more certain or to approve it formally
seal.eg: The two leaders sealed their agreement with a handshake.

seal.eng_def: in the US and some other countries, a member of an elite (= especially good and highly trained) force within the navy that deals with special operations that involve water. SEAL is an abbreviation for Sea, Air, and Land Team.
seal.chi_def: （美國或其他國家的）海軍三棲特種部隊，海豹突擊隊（Sea, Air, and Land Team 的縮寫）
seal.eg: The 23-year-old from Massachusetts wants to become a Navy SEAL.

search.eng_def: to look somewhere carefully in order to find something
search.eg: The police searched the woods for the missing boy.

search.eng_def: to try to find the answer to a problem
search.eg: Philosophers have searched for millennia but they haven't found the meaning of life.

search.eng_def: A police officer who searches you or your possessions looks for something you might be hiding
search.eg: The men were searched for drugs and then released.

search.eng_def: to look for information on a computer, the internet, etc.
search.eg: I searched the internet for the best deal.

search.eng_def: an attempt to find someone or something
search.eg: After a long search, they eventually found the missing papers.

search.eng_def: an attempt to find an answer to a problem
an attempt to find information on a computer, on the internet, etc.
search.eg: I did a search for yoga clubs in my area.
She was shot by a sniper when she went out in search of firewood.

season.eng_def: one of the four periods of the year; spring, summer, autumn, or winter
the period of the year when something that happens every year happens
season.chi_def: （每年中某件事固定會發生的）時節，季
season.eg: How long does the dry/hurricane/monsoon season last?

season.eng_def: the period of the year during which a particular sport is played
season.eg: The British football season begins in August.

season.eng_def: the period when most people take their holidays, spend time with their families, go to visit places, or take part in an activity outside work
season.eg: Air fares are more expensive during the holiday season.

season.eng_def: one of several series of television programmes with the same title and the same characters
a period when a set of programmes, plays, or musical events are broadcast or performed
season.chi_def: （一組節目、戲劇或音樂活動的）播出期，上演期；演出季
season.eg: There will be more documentaries and fewer quiz shows in the autumn season on TV.

season.eng_def: If fruit and vegetables are in season, they are being produced in the area and are available and ready to eat.
season.eg: Fruit is cheaper when it's in season.

season.eng_def: at the time of year when many people want to travel or have a holiday
season.eg: Hotel rooms are more expensive in season.

season.eng_def: A female animal that is in season is ready to have sex and able to become pregnant.
An animal that is in season can be hunted legally during a particular period of time.
If fruit and vegetables are out of season, they do not grow in the area during that time.
season.eg: In Europe, tomatoes are out of season in winter.

season.eng_def: during the period when fewer people want to travel or have a holiday
during the period when it is not legal to hunt animals
to improve the flavour of savoury food by adding salt, herbs, or spices when cooking or preparing it
season.eg: Drain the rice, stir in the salmon and season to taste (= so that it has the taste you like).

season.eng_def: to make wood hard by drying it gradually, in order to make it ready for use

seat.eng_def: a piece of furniture or part of a train, plane, etc. that has been designed for someone to sit on
seat.eg: Chairs, sofas and benches are different types of seat.

seat.eng_def: the part of a piece of furniture or clothing on which a person sits
seat.eg: I've spilled some coffee on the seat of the armchair.

seat.eng_def: an official position as a politician or member of a group of people who control something
seat.eg: She has a seat on the board of directors.

seat.eng_def: the place in an office where a particular person sits
seat.eg: I'm sorry - he's not in his seat right now.

seat.eng_def: a place on a course to study something
seat.eg: On receipt of the tuition fees, the college will issue a letter confirming your seat on the course.

seat.eng_def: a place that acts as a base or centre for an important activity
seat.eg: The seat of government in the US is in Washington, DC.

seat.eng_def: to arrange for someone to have a particular seat
seat.eg: The waiter greeted me with a big smile and seated us by the window.
"I'm so glad to see you!" she said, seating herself between Eleanor and Marianne.

seat.eng_def: (of a building, room, table, or vehicle) to have enough seats for the stated number of people
seat.eg: The new concert hall seats 1,500 people.

seat.eng_def: with enough seats for the particular number of people

second.eng_def: immediately after the first and before any others
second.eg: Is Carla her first or second child?

second.eng_def: the position in which a person finishes a race or competition if they finish immediately behind the winner
second.eg: First prize is two weeks in Barbados and second prize is a weekend in Rome.

second.eng_def: Second is used to show that only one thing is better, bigger, etc. than the thing mentioned
second.eg: St Petersburg is Russia's second (biggest/largest) city.

second.eng_def: another
second.eg: She is often described as a second Marilyn Monroe.

second.eng_def: happening only once out of every two possible times
second.eg: We've decided to hold the conference every second year.

second.eng_def: after the first and before any others
second.eg: Robertson won the race and Cameron was/came/finished second.

second.eng_def: used to introduce the second thing in a list of things you want to say or write
second.eg: There are two good reasons why we can't do it. First, we can't afford it, and second, we don't have time.

second.eng_def: a short unit of time that is equal to a 60th of a minute
second.eg: There are 60 seconds in a minute.

second.eng_def: a very short period of time
second.eg: "Come on, hurry up!" "I'll just/only be a second - I need to close the window."

second.eng_def: as soon as
second.eg: The second I saw him, I knew he was going to be a star.

second.eng_def: the second person or thing to do or be something, or the second person or thing mentioned
second.eg: This is the second of the four tests.

second.eng_def: an extra amount of food that is given after the first amount has been eaten
second.eg: Would anyone like seconds of ice cream?

second.eng_def: the smallest unit used for measuring an angle
second.eg: There are 3,600 seconds in a degree.

second.eng_def: a product that is sold cheaply because it is damaged or not in perfect condition
a person who takes care of someone who is fighting in a boxing competition or, in the past, in a duel (= organized fight)
second.chi_def: （拳擊比賽或舊時決鬥中的）助手

second.eng_def: in a vehicle, the gear that combines power with limited speed and is used when increasing or reducing speed
second.eg: You'll have to change (down/up) into second.

second.eng_def: an undergraduate degree from a university in the UK and some other countries that is a good degree but not the best possible
→  second base
to make a formal statement of support for a suggestion made by someone else during a meeting so that there can be a discussion or vote
second.eg: The motion was proposed by the club's chairwoman and seconded by the secretary.

second.eng_def: to send an employee to work somewhere else temporarily, either to increase the number of workers or to replace other workers, or to exchange experience or skills
second.eg: During the dispute, many police officers were seconded from traffic duty to the prison service.

secondary.eg: Her health is what matters - the cost of the treatment is of secondary importance.

secondary.eng_def: developing from something similar that existed earlier
secondary.eg: The drug is not very effective against AIDS, though it may be used to treat secondary viral infections.

secondary.eng_def: relating to the education of children approximately between the ages of 11 and 18 years old

secret.eng_def: a piece of information that is only known by one person or a few people and should not be told to others
secret.eg: Why did you have to go and tell Bob about my illness? You just can't keep a secret, can you?

secret.eng_def: a fact about a subject that is not known
the particular knowledge and skills needed to do something very well
secret.eg: So what's the secret of being a good cook?

secret.eng_def: If something is secret, other people are not allowed to know about it.
secret.eg: The president escaped through a secret passage underneath the parliament building.

secret.eng_def: used to refer to someone who has a particular habit, hobby, or feeling but does not tell or show other people that they do
secret.chi_def: （習慣或愛好）不爲人知的，秘而不宣的；隱瞞感覺的

secretary.eng_def: someone who works in an office, writing letters, making phone calls, and arranging meetings for a person or for an organization
secretary.eg: My secretary will phone you to arrange a meeting.

secretary.eng_def: the member of a committee of an organization, club, etc. who keeps records of meetings, sends letters, emails, etc.
secretary.eg: The three elected members of the committee are the chair, secretary, and treasurer.

secretary.eng_def: an official who has responsibility for the general management of an organization
secretary.chi_def: （負責機構整體管理的）幹事，文書
secretary.eg: The company secretary has written to all the shareholders to apologize for the mistake.

secretary.chi_def: （英國）國務大臣（同 Secretary of State）

secretary.eng_def: the head of a government department, chosen by the president and not a member of a law-making group
secretary.eg: the Secretary of Health and Human Services

section.eng_def: one of the parts that something is divided into
section.eg: the sports section of the newspaper

section.eng_def: a cut made in part of the body in an operation
an operation in which a woman's uterus is cut open to allow a baby to be born
a very thin slice of a part of an animal, plant, or other object made in order to see its structure
section.eg: Each section is mounted on a slide and examined under the microscope.

section.eng_def: a drawing or model that shows the structure of something by cutting part of it away
section.chi_def: （顯示結構的）切面圖（或模型），斷面圖（或模型）
section.eg: This vertical section of the soil shows four basic soil layers.

section.eng_def: the shape of a flat surface that is produced when an object is cut into separate pieces
showing what something would look like if the surface was cut away and you could see inside
section.eg: The first diagram is a view of the building from the street, and the second shows it in section.

section.eng_def: to officially force someone who has mental health problems to stay in a hospital and receive treatment because they might harm themselves or other people
section.eg: He was sectioned under section 4 of the Mental Health Act.

sector.eng_def: one of the areas into which the economic activity of a country is divided
sector.chi_def: （一國經濟活動的）部門，領域，行業
sector.eg: In the financial sector, banks and insurance companies have both lost a lot of money.

sector.eng_def: an area of land or sea that has been divided from other areas and is controlled by a particular country
sector.eg: What is the total oil output from the British sector of the North Sea?

secure.eng_def: positioned or fixed firmly and correctly and therefore not likely to move, fall, or break
secure.eg: That ladder doesn't look very secure to me.

secure.eng_def: A secure place is one that it is difficult to get out of or escape from
secure.chi_def: （地方）守衛森嚴的，插翅難逃的
secure.eg: He killed the man just a month after his release from a secure mental hospital.

secure.eng_def: likely to continue and not fail or be lost
secure.eg: Her promotion has made her position in the company more secure.

secure.eng_def: (especially of objects, situations, etc.) able to avoid being harmed by any risk, danger, or threat
secure.eg: Car manufacturers ought to produce vehicles that are more secure against theft.

secure.eng_def: not doubting or being worried about yourself and your personal relationships
secure.eg: Children need to feel secure in order to do well at school.

secure.eng_def: to get something, sometimes with difficulty
secure.eg: He was disappointed by his failure to secure the top job with the bank.

secure.eng_def: to make certain something is protected from danger or risk
secure.eg: The building has only one main entrance and would be easy to secure (against/from intruders).

secure.eng_def: to make certain that money that has been lent will be paid back, by giving the person who lends the money the right to own property belonging to the person who borrows it, if the money is not paid back
to fasten one object firmly to another
secure.eg: The gate won't stay open, so we'll have to secure it to that post.

security.eng_def: protection of a person, building, organization, or country against threats such as crime or attacks by foreign countries
security.eg: The station was closed for two hours because of a security alert.

security.eng_def: the group of people responsible for protecting a building
security.eg: You'll need to notify security if you want to work late in the office.

security.eng_def: the fact that something is not likely to fail or be lost
security.eg: If it's a choice between higher pay and job security, I'd prefer to keep my job.

security.eng_def: property or goods that you promise to give to someone if you cannot pay what you owe them
security.eg: She used her shares in the company as security against a $23 million bank loan.

security.eng_def: investment in a company or in government debt that can be traded on the financial markets and produces an income for the investor
the feeling of being confident in one's family and relationships
security.chi_def: （在家庭或一段關係中）安全感；安心
security.eg: Most children need the security of a stable family life.

seduce.eng_def: to make someone feel attracted to you and want to have sex with you, often someone younger or less experienced
seduce.eg: He felt that she was trying to seduce him.

seduce.eng_def: to persuade or cause someone to do something that they would not usually consider doing by being very attractive and difficult to refuse
seduce.eg: I wouldn't normally stay in a hotel like this, but I was seduced by the fabulous location.

seduce.eng_def: If you are seduced by something, you like it because it seems attractive.
seduce.eg: Almost every visitor to Edinburgh is seduced by its splendid architecture.

see.eng_def: to be conscious of what is around you by using your eyes
see.eg: Turn the light on so I can see.

see.eng_def: to watch a film, television programme, etc.
see.chi_def: 看，觀看（電影、電視節目等）
see.eg: Did you see that documentary on Channel 4 last night?

see.eng_def: to be the time or place when something happens
see.chi_def: 是…的發生時間（或地點）；見證
see.eg: This summer has seen the end of water restrictions in the area thanks to a new reservoir.

see.eng_def: said to mean that more surprising or exciting things are likely to happen

see.eg: I see (that) the club is organizing a theatre trip next month.

see.eng_def: to meet or visit someone, or to visit a place
to have a romantic relationship with someone
see.eg: How long has she been seeing him?

see.eng_def: to consider or think about, especially to think about someone or something in a particular way, or to imagine someone doing a particular activity
see.eg: She didn't see herself as brave.

see.eng_def: to take someone somewhere by going there with them
see.eg: He saw his visitors to the door.
Will you see if you can get anyone to help?

see.eng_def: to make certain that something happens
see.eg: The receptionist said he'd see (that) she got the message.

see.eng_def: a place where there is a cathedral and where a bishop or archbishop has authority

seed.eng_def: a small, round, or oval object produced by a plant and from which, when it is planted, a new plant can grow
seed.eg: Sow the seeds (= put them in the ground) about three centimetres deep.

seed.eng_def: If a food plant goes or runs to seed, it produces flowers and seeds because it has not been picked early enough.
seed.chi_def: （食用植物未及時採摘而）開花結籽
seed.eg: In hot weather lettuces can suddenly run to seed.

seed.eng_def: If a person or place goes or runs to seed, their physical appearance becomes worse because no one takes care of them.
seed.chi_def: （人）變得不修邊幅；（地方）變得破敗
seed.eg: After he retired, he really went to seed.

seed.eng_def: the cause of a feeling or situation, or the early stages of it
seed.eg: From these early seeds of their friendship, they grew into lifelong companions.

seed.eng_def: especially in tennis, a good player who is given a place on the list of those expected to win games in a particular competition because of the way they have played in the past
seed.eg: Turner's opponent in the quarter-finals is the number one seed.
The plants have seeded themselves (= their seeds have fallen) into the cracks between the paving stones.

seed.eng_def: to remove the seeds from a fruit or vegetable
seed.eg: Wash, seed, and cut the pepper into small pieces.

seed.eng_def: to make a player a seed
seed.eg: Jones, seeded second, has won her last ten matches.

seek.eng_def: to try to find or get something, especially something that is not a physical object
seek.chi_def: 尋找；尋求（尤指非物質的東西）
seek.eg: "Are you actively seeking jobs?" she asked.

seek.eng_def: to ask for advice, help, approval, permission, etc.
seek.eg: Legal advice should be sought before you take any further action.
They sought to reassure the public.

seem.eng_def: to give the effect of being; to be judged to be
seem.eg: He's 16, but he often seems (to be) younger.

seesaw.eng_def: a long board that children play on. The board is balanced on a central point so that when a child sits on each end they can make the board go up and down by pushing off the ground with their feet.
to change repeatedly from one emotion, situation, etc. to another and then back again
seesaw.chi_def: （情緒、局勢等）搖擺不定，不斷反覆，交替
seesaw.eg: His mind seesawed between hope and despair all through those weeks.

segment.eng_def: one of the smaller groups or amounts that a larger group or amount can be divided into
segment.eg: People over the age of 85 make up the fastest-growing segment of the population.

segment.eng_def: part of a circle that is divided from the rest by a line, or part of a sphere that is divided from the rest by two planes
one of the small parts that a fruit such as an orange is naturally divided into
segment.eg: The salad was decorated with segments of orange.

segment.eng_def: a short piece of film that forms part of a television or radio programme, or that is broadcast on the internet
segment.chi_def: （電視、廣播或互聯網節目的）節，段
segment.eg: CNN last week broadcast a segment on homicides in the city.

segment.eng_def: to divide something into different parts
segment.eg: The market is segmented by price into three general categories.

seize.eng_def: to take something quickly and keep or hold it
seize.eg: I seized his arm and made him turn to look at me.
The rebels have seized ten soldiers to use as hostages.

seize.eng_def: If the police or other officials seize something, they take possession of it with legal authority.
seize.eg: Customs officers at Heathrow have seized 60 kilos of heroin.

seize.eng_def: If a strong emotion or pain seizes you, you feel it suddenly.
seize.eg: I was suddenly seized by/with a feeling of great insecurity and loneliness.

seldom.eg: Now that we have a baby, we seldom get the chance to go to the cinema.

select.eng_def: to choose a small number of things, or to choose by making careful decisions
select.eg: There was a choice of four prizes, and the winner could select one of them.

select.eng_def: of only the best type or highest quality, and usually small in size or amount
select.eg: It's a very select club - I've been trying unsuccessfully to join it for years.

selection.eng_def: the act of choosing someone or something
a choice or range of different types of something
selection.eg: Most schools would have a good selection of these books in their libraries.

selection.eng_def: a person or thing that has been or will be chosen
selection.chi_def: 被選中的東西（或人）；入選者
selection.eg: Their music was a mix of old stuff and selections from the new album.

selective.eng_def: intentionally choosing some things and not others
selective.chi_def: 有選擇性的；嚴格篩選的
selective.eg: As a teacher she was very selective, accepting only a small number of exceptionally gifted pupils.

self.eng_def: the set of someone's characteristics, such as personality and ability, that are not physical and make that person different from other people
self.eg: The hero of the movie finally finds his true self (= discovers what his true personality and feelings are).

self.eng_def: interest only in your own advantage
self.eg: Her reply was typical of her constant regard for self.

self.eng_def: of or by yourself or itself

selfish.eng_def: Someone who is selfish only thinks of their own advantage
selfish.eg: The judge told him: "Your attitude shows a selfish disregard for others."

sell.eng_def: to give something to someone else in return for money
sell.eg: I sold him my car/I sold my car to him for $600.

sell.eng_def: to be bought in the way or quantities that are mentioned; to be sold at the price mentioned
sell.chi_def: 被以（…方式／數量／價格）購買
sell.eg: These baskets sell well (= a lot of them are bought).

sell.eng_def: to persuade someone that an idea or plan is a good one and likely to be successful
sell.eg: My boss is very old-fashioned and I'm having a lot of trouble selling the idea of working at home occasionally.

semester.eng_def: one of the periods into which a year is divided at a college or university, especially in the US and Australia
semester.chi_def: （尤指美國和澳大利亞大學的）學期

seminar.eng_def: an occasion when a teacher or expert and a group of people meet to study and discuss something
seminar.eg: I attended practically every lecture and seminar when I was a student.

senator.eng_def: a politician who has been elected to a Senate
senator.eg: Only two senators voted against the bill.

send.eng_def: to cause something to go from one place to another, especially by post or email
send.eg: I'll send her a letter/email/parcel/postcard next week.

send.eng_def: to cause or order someone to go and do something
send.eg: We're sending the kids to stay with my parents for a couple of weeks.

send.eng_def: to cause someone or something to do a particular thing, or to cause something to happen
send.eg: The explosion sent the crowd into a panic.

senior.eng_def: older and more experienced than the other members of a team
senior.chi_def: 比其他成員年長的；比其他成員更有經驗的
senior.eg: The Dragons head coach praised his senior players in the 23-16 win.
The more senior students are given some extra responsibilities.

senior.eng_def: used after a man's name to refer to the older of two people in the same family who have the same name
senior.chi_def: （置於姓名後，表示同一家人中同名的兩人中的年長者）老，大
senior.eg: Hello, may I speak to Ken Griffey senior, please?

senior.eng_def: someone who is high or higher in rank
senior.eg: It's important to impress your seniors if you want to be promoted.
She married a man 20 years her senior.
Seniors are entitled to a reduction of around 10%.

senior.eng_def: a student in their final year of high school or university

sensation.eng_def: the ability to feel something physically, especially by touching, or a physical feeling that results from this ability
a general feeling caused by something that happens to you, especially a feeling that you cannot describe exactly
sensation.eg: I had the odd sensation (that) someone was following me.

sensation.eng_def: something very exciting or interesting, or something that causes great excitement or interest
sensation.chi_def: 轟動的事件；極有趣之物

sense.eng_def: an ability to understand, recognize, value, or react to something, especially any of the five physical abilities to see, hear, smell, taste, and feel
sense.chi_def: 官能；感覺；知覺（尤指視覺、聽覺、嗅覺、味覺和觸覺）
sense.eg: With her excellent sense of smell, she could tell if you were a smoker from the other side of the room.
Did you get any sense of how they might react?

sense.eng_def: the ability to enjoy life and not be too serious
sense.eg: Don't be angry - it was just a joke - where's your sense of fun?

sense.eng_def: your ability to understand funny things
sense.eg: She has a really good sense of humour.

sense.eng_def: the feeling people have when there is a very important event or celebration
sense.chi_def: 隆重的氣氛；節慶的氣氛
sense.eg: The decorations, flowers, and crowds gave the town a real sense of occasion.

sense.eng_def: the characteristic of having good judgment, especially when it is based on practical ideas or understanding
sense.chi_def: （尤指基於切實的想法或理解的）理智，明智
sense.eg: I hope they'll have the (good) sense/have enough sense to shut the windows before they leave.

sense.eng_def: the ability to use good judgment
sense.eg: Have you taken leave of/lost your senses? (= Have you lost your ability to make a good judgment?)

sense.eng_def: one of the possible meanings of a word or phrase
sense.eg: They are not immigrants, at least not in any sense that I understand.
It's a book which is, in every sense, about different ways of seeing the world.

sense.eng_def: thinking about something in one way, but not in every way
sense.eg: She claims that the system is at fault and she's right, in a sense (= she is partly right).
We are in no sense obliged to agree to this.

sense.eng_def: to feel or experience something without being able to explain exactly how
sense.eg: Although she said nothing, I could sense her anger

sensible.eng_def: based on or acting on good judgment and practical ideas or understanding
Sensible clothes or shoes are practical and suitable for the purpose they are needed for, rather than being attractive or fashionable
sensible.eg: It could be cold and wet so pack some sensible clothes.

sensible.eng_def: having an understanding of a situation
sensible.chi_def: 意識到的；知道的；覺察到的
sensible.eg: He did not appear to be sensible of the difficulties that lay ahead.

sensitive.eng_def: easily upset by the things people say or do, or causing people to be upset, embarrassed, or angry
sensitive.chi_def: 神經過敏的；易被冒犯的；敏感的
sensitive.eg: Her reply showed that she was very sensitive to criticism.

sensitive.eng_def: A sensitive subject, situation, etc. needs to be dealt with carefully in order to avoid upsetting people
sensitive.chi_def: （話題、形勢等）敏感的，須謹慎對待的
sensitive.eg: Sex education and birth control are sensitive issues.

sensitive.eng_def: understanding what other people need, and being helpful and kind to them
sensitive.chi_def: 善解人意的；體貼的；體諒的
sensitive.eg: Representatives of the company claim their plan will be sensitive to local needs.

sensitive.eng_def: easily influenced, changed, or damaged, especially by a physical activity or effect
sensitive.eg: Some people's teeth are highly sensitive to cold.

sensitive.eng_def: Sensitive equipment is able to record small changes
sensitive.eg: The patient's responses are recorded on a sensitive piece of equipment which gives extremely accurate readings.

sensitivity.eng_def: an ability to understand what other people need, and be helpful and kind to them
sensitivity.eg: The police showed commendable sensitivity in their handling of the case.

sensitivity.eng_def: the quality of being easily upset by the things people say or do, or causing people to be upset, embarrassed, or angry
sensitivity.chi_def: 神經過敏；易被冒犯；敏感
sensitivity.eg: I should have warned you about her sensitivity to criticism.

sensitivity.eng_def: the fact of a situation, subject, etc. needing to be dealt with carefully in order to avoid upsetting people
sensitivity.eg: Such is the sensitivity of the information that only two people are allowed to know it.

sensitivity.eng_def: having a strong physical reaction to something
sensitivity.eg: One of the side effects of the drug is an increased sensitivity to sunlight.

sensitivity.eng_def: the ability to record small changes in weight, temperature, etc.
sensitivity.chi_def: 靈敏度（感應重量、溫度等的微小變化的能力）
sensitivity.eg: The sensitivity of the machine provides us with extremely accurate data.

sentence.eng_def: a group of words, usually containing a verb, that expresses a thought in the form of a statement, question, instruction, or exclamation and starts with a capital letter when written
sentence.eg: He's very impatient and always interrupts me mid-sentence.

sentence.eng_def: a punishment given by a judge in court to a person or organization after they have been found guilty of doing something wrong
sentence.eg: He got a heavy/light sentence (= he was severely/not severely punished).

sentence.eng_def: (of a judge) to say officially what a punishment will be
sentence.eg: The judge will pronounce sentence on the defendant this afternoon.

sentence.eng_def: to decide and say officially what a punishment will be
sentence.eg: He was sentenced to life imprisonment.

sentiment.eng_def: a thought, opinion, or idea based on a feeling about a situation, or a way of thinking about something
sentiment.eg: Nationalist sentiment has increased in the area since the bombing.

sentiment.eng_def: gentle feelings such as sympathy, love, etc., especially when considered to be silly or not suitable
sentiment.chi_def: （尤指愚蠢的或不合適的）溫情，傷感
sentiment.eg: The film is flawed by cloying sentiment.

sentimental.eng_def: A sentimental person is strongly influenced by emotional feelings, especially about happy memories of past events or relationships with other people, rather than by careful thought and judgment based on facts.
sentimental.chi_def: 多愁善感的；感情用事的
sentimental.eg: Why be sentimental about that old coat? There's no point in keeping it just because you were wearing it when you first met me.

sentimental.eng_def: too strongly influenced by emotional feelings

separate.eng_def: existing or happening independently or in a different physical space
separate.eg: The art department and the music department are in two separate buildings.
The north and south of the country are separated by a mountain range.

separate.eng_def: to make people move apart or into different places, or to move apart
separate.eg: At school they always tried to separate Jane and me because we were troublemakers.

separate.eng_def: to consider two people or things as different or not related
separate.chi_def: 分開考慮；認爲（兩者）不相關
separate.eg: You can't separate morality from politics.

separate.eng_def: If a liquid separates, it becomes two different liquids.
to start to live in a different place from your husband or wife because the relationship has ended
separate.eg: My parents separated when I was six and divorced a couple of years later.

separation.eng_def: a situation in which two or more people or things are separated
separation.eg: During the war many couples had to endure long periods of separation (= not being together).

separation.eng_def: an arrangement, often legal, by which two married people stop living together as a couple
separation.eg: Couples may agree to divorce each other after a separation.

sequence.eng_def: a series of related things or events, or the order in which they follow each other
sequence.chi_def: 一連串；一系列；順序，次序
sequence.eg: The first chapter describes the strange sequence of events that led to his death.

sequence.eng_def: a part of a film that shows a particular event or a related series of events
sequence.eg: The movie's opening sequence is of a very unpleasant murder.

sequence.eng_def: to combine things in a particular order, or discover the order in which they are combined
sequence.chi_def: 安排…的順序；發現…的順序
sequence.eg: They discussed how to sequence the steps in the plan.

sequence.eng_def: to discover the order in which nucleotides (= chemical substances) are combined within DNA
sequence.eg: Researchers sequenced the full genome of a rat.

serene.eng_def: peaceful and calm; worried by nothing
serene.eg: She has a lovely serene face.

sergeant.eng_def: in the UK and some other countries, a police officer whose rank is above constable and below inspector, or, in the US, a police officer whose rank is below a captain
sergeant.chi_def: （英國或其他國家的）巡佐；（美國的）警佐

series.eng_def: a number of similar or related events or things, one following another
series.eg: There has been a series of sexual attacks on women in the area.

series.eng_def: a number of games played one after another by two teams against each other
series.eg: The Yankees have a four-game series against the Orioles at home.

series.eng_def: Parts of an electrical system that are in series are arranged in a single line so that the current flows through each part, one after another.
a set of television or radio broadcasts on the same subject or using the same characters but in different situations
series.eg: The star is to host a television series on extreme sports.

series.eng_def: a set of books published by the same company that deal with the same subject
series.eg: They do a series on architecture throughout the ages.

serious.eng_def: not joking or intended to be funny
serious.eg: Please don't laugh - I'm being serious.

serious.eng_def: A serious person is quiet, thinks carefully about things, and does not laugh a lot.
serious.eg: I remember her as a very serious child.

serious.eng_def: determined to follow a particular plan of action
serious.eg: Is she serious about going to live abroad?

serious.eng_def: If two people who have a loving relationship are serious about each other, they intend to stay with each other for a long time and possibly marry.
serious.eg: She's had a lot of boyfriends but Simon's the only one she's been serious about.

serious.eng_def: needing or deserving your complete attention
serious.chi_def: 需要（或值得）認真對待的
serious.eg: That's an interesting job offer - I'd give it some serious consideration if I were you.
We did some fairly serious walking over the weekend.
This is a serious wine, Belle, you have to try some.

sermon.eng_def: a part of a Christian church ceremony in which a priest gives a talk on a religious or moral subject, often based on something written in the Bible
sermon.eg: The Reverend William Cronshaw delivered/preached the sermon.

sermon.eng_def: a long talk in which someone advises other people how they should behave in order to be better people
sermon.eg: I really don't think it's a politician's job to go delivering sermons on public morality.

servant.eng_def: a person who is employed in another person's house, doing jobs such as cooking and cleaning, especially in the past
a person who works for the government

serve.eg: Do they serve meals in the bar?

serve.eng_def: to work for; to do your duty to
serve.eg: He served in the army for 22 years.

serve.eng_def: to help achieve something or to be useful as something
serve.eg: An official investigation would not serve any useful purpose.

serve.eng_def: to provide with something that is needed
serve.eg: The report says the police are out of touch with the communities that they serve.

serve.eng_def: in a shop, restaurant, or hotel, to deal with a customer by taking their order, showing or selling them goods, etc.
to spend a period of time doing something
serve.eg: He served four years in prison for robbery.
He's serving time for drug offences.

serve.eng_def: in sports such as tennis, to hit the ball to the other player as a way of starting the game
serve.eg: Whose turn is it to serve?

serve.eng_def: to give a legal document to someone, demanding that they go to a law court or that they obey an order
serve.eg: Less than two weeks ago Gough finally served a writ on Slater, claiming damages for alleged loss of royalties.

serve.eng_def: in sports such as tennis, the act of hitting the ball to the other player to start play

server.eng_def: a central computer from which other computers get information
a large spoon, etc. that is used for serving food
a person who serves food in a restaurant

service.eng_def: a government system or private organization that is responsible for a particular type of activity, or for providing a particular thing that people need
service.chi_def: 公共服務系統；公共事業
service.eg: the postal service

service.eng_def: the fact that a system is working
service.eg: There is a very limited bus service on Sundays.

service.eng_def: a place at the side of a large road at which fuel, food, drink, and other things that people want on their journey are sold
service.eg: We stopped at the services to get fuel.

service.eng_def: the act of dealing with customers in a shop, restaurant, or hotel by taking their orders, showing or selling them goods, etc.
service.eg: The only trouble with this café is that the service is so slow.

service.eng_def: an amount of money charged for serving a customer in a restaurant, often paid directly to the waiter
service.eg: There is a ten percent service charge included in the bill.

service.eng_def: work that someone does or time that someone spends working for an organization
service.eg: These teenagers all do community service in their free time.

service.eng_def: a business that offers a particular type of help or work
service.eg: Why don't you call the babysitting service?

service.eng_def: a government department that is responsible for a particular area of activity
service.eg: the diplomatic service

service.eng_def: the particular skills that someone has and can offer to others
service.eg: I may be needing the services of a surveyor soon, as I'm buying a house.

service.eng_def: in use
service.eg: The battleship has been in service since 1965.

service.eng_def: to be employed as a servant
service.eg: Her mother was in service.

service.eng_def: (work in) the armed forces
service.eg: He joined the air force in 1964 and spent ten years in the service.

service.eng_def: the army, navy, and/or air force
service.eg: a career in the services

service.eng_def: fighting in a war
service.eg: He was the first member of his regiment to die while on active service.

service.eng_def: a formal religious ceremony
service.eg: A memorial service is being held on Sunday for victims of the explosion.

service.eng_def: in sports such as tennis, the act of hitting the ball to the other player to start play
service.eg: She has a very fast service.

service.eng_def: a set of objects such as plates, cups, or other things that are used in providing and eating food
service.eg: a 24-piece dinner service

service.eng_def: a check and repair of a vehicle or machine that is done after regular periods
service.eg: She took the car in for a service yesterday.

service.eng_def: to examine a machine and repair any damaged parts
service.eg: I'm taking the car in to have it serviced this afternoon.

service.eng_def: to make payments to pay back a debt
service.eg: The country is still spending $3 million a week servicing debt.

serving.eng_def: employed at the present time in a particular organization, especially the armed forces
serving.chi_def: 目前任職的；（尤指）現役的

serving.eng_def: an object used for holding food before it is put onto plates, or for putting food onto plates
an amount of one type of food that is given to one person
serving.eg: The quantities given in the recipe should be enough for four servings.

session.eng_def: a formal meeting or series of meetings of an organization such as a parliament or a law court
session.chi_def: （議會等機構的）會議；（法庭的）開庭
session.eg: The parliamentary session is due to end on 27 May.

session.eng_def: a period of time or meeting arranged for a particular activity
session.chi_def: （從事某項活動的）一段時間（或集會）；一場；一節
session.eg: The 21-year-old runner twisted his ankle in a training session last Friday.

session.eng_def: at a college, any of the periods of time that a teaching year or day is divided into, or the teaching year itself
session.eg: He taught a class during the summer session.

set.eng_def: to put something in a particular place or position
set.chi_def: 放，置；使處於（指定的地方、位置）
set.eg: He set a vase of flowers on the table.

set.eng_def: If a story, film, etc. is set in a particular time or place, the action in it happens in that time or place.
set.eg: "West Side Story" is set in New York City in the late 1950s.

set.eng_def: to cause something or someone to be in the stated condition or situation
set.eg: It is believed that the building was set alight/ablaze/on fire deliberately.

set.eng_def: to cause someone or something to start doing something
set.eg: His remarks set me thinking.

set.eng_def: to give someone work to do
set.eg: I was set to work dusting the bookshelves.
