set.eng_def: to establish or decide something
set.eg: The school has been criticized for failing to set high standards for its students.

set.eng_def: to get something ready so that it comes into operation or can be used
set.eg: The heating is set to come on at 5 p.m.

set.eng_def: to put furniture and other things on a stage so that it represents the time and the place in which the action of a play, film, or television programme is going to happen
set.chi_def: 設置，佈置（戲劇、電影或電視節目的佈景）
set.eg: During the interval the stage was set for the second act.

set.eng_def: to fix or make certain
set.eg: Has a date/time been set for the meeting yet?

set.eng_def: If a precious stone is set in/into a piece of jewellery, or a piece of jewellery is set with a precious stone, the stone is fixed firmly to the piece of jewellery.
set.eg: a gold ring with a diamond set into it

set.eng_def: When a doctor sets a broken bone, he or she puts it into the right position so that it will heal.
set.chi_def: 固定（斷骨）；接（骨）；把（斷骨）重定

set.eng_def: When a broken bone sets, it heals in a particular position.
If you have your hair set, you have it arranged while it is wet so that it will be in a particular style when it is dry.
If you set a part of your body, you tighten the muscles around it in order to show that you are determined about something.
set.chi_def: 繃緊（身體部位）；使顯出堅定的表情
set.eg: "I'm never going back to him," she said, setting her jaw firmly.

set.eng_def: If a liquid or soft material sets, it becomes firm or hard.
set.eg: Leave the jelly in the fridge to set.

set.eng_def: to give someone a piece of school work or homework to do
set.eg: My science teacher always sets a lot of homework.

set.eng_def: to give someone a particular task to do
set.eg: Harry set them to work painting the walls.

set.eng_def: to write or provide music for a poem or other words so that they can be sung
set.eg: poems set to music

set.eng_def: (of the sun, moon, or planets) to go down below the horizon (= the line at which the earth seems to join the sky)
set.chi_def: （太陽、月球或行星）降於地平線之下，下落
set.eg: We sat on the beach and watched the sun set.

set.eng_def: a group of similar things that belong together in some way
set.eg: We bought Charles and Mandy a set of cutlery as a wedding present.

set.eng_def: a number of objects or pieces of equipment needed for a particular activity, especially playing a game
set.eg: a chess/train/chemistry set

set.eng_def: In mathematics, a set is a group of objects with stated characteristics.
a group of people who have similar interests and ways of living
set.eg: the fashionable set

set.eng_def: the place where a film or play is performed or recorded, and the pictures, furniture, etc. that are used
set.eg: a movie set

set.eng_def: a part of a game of tennis or volleyball
set.eg: They won in straight sets (= they won every set).

set.eng_def: a musical performance that forms part of a concert, especially one of pop music or jazz
set.chi_def: （尤指流行音樂或爵士音樂會上的）一段表演
set.eg: The band's opening set lasted 45 minutes.

set.eng_def: the position in which you hold a part of your body
set.eg: I could tell from the set of his jaw that he was angry.

set.eng_def: the act of having your hair set
set.eg: a shampoo and set

set.eng_def: a television
set.eg: We need a new television set.

set.eng_def: ready and prepared
set.eg: Shall we go now - is everyone set?

set.eng_def: likely or in a suitable condition
set.chi_def: 可能的；在適當條件下的
set.eg: He looks set to become world champion again this year.

set.eng_def: always the same, never changing
set.eg: My parents say I have to be home by a set time.

set.eng_def: a phrase in which the words are always used in the same order
a set book is one that must be studied for a particular course
set.eg: The students are reading "Lord of the Flies" as one of their set books/texts this year.

setback.eng_def: something that happens that delays or prevents a process from developing
setback.eg: Sally had been recovering well from her operation, but yesterday she experienced/suffered a setback.

setting.eng_def: the position of a house or other building
setting.eg: Their house is in an idyllic country setting.

setting.eng_def: the time and the place in which the action of a book, film, play, etc. happens
setting.chi_def: （小說、電影、戲劇等的）情節背景
setting.eg: The play has its setting in a wartime prison camp.

setting.eng_def: a position on the controls of a piece of equipment
setting.eg: My hairdryer has three settings - high, medium, and low.

setting.eng_def: the piece of metal in a ring, or other piece of jewellery, into which a precious stone is fixed
setting.chi_def: 安置寶石的底座；鑲嵌底座
setting.eg: a single diamond in a plain gold setting

setting.eng_def: music written or provided for a poem or other words so that they can be sung
setting.eg: He sang Schubert's setting of a Goethe poem.

settle.eng_def: to reach a decision or an agreement about something, or to end a disagreement
settle.chi_def: 確定；決定；解決，結束（爭端等）
settle.eg: Good, that's all settled - you send out the invitations for the party, and I'll organize the food.
The details of the contract have not yet been settled.

settle.eng_def: to relax into a comfortable position
settle.chi_def: （使）（舒舒服服地）坐下；安頓下來
settle.eg: After dinner we settled in front of the television for the evening.

settle.eng_def: to go and live somewhere, especially permanently
settle.eg: After they got married, they settled in Brooklyn.

settle.eng_def: to arrive, especially from another country, in a new place and start to live there and use the land
settle.chi_def: （尤指從別國）移居殖民地；殖民
settle.eg: America was first settled by people who came across from Asia over 25,000 years ago.

settle.eng_def: to move to a lower level and stay there; to drop
settle.eg: The house had been empty for years, and dust had settled on all the surfaces.

settle.eng_def: to pay, especially money that you owe
settle.chi_def: 支付（尤指欠款或被索款項）；償付；結算
settle.eg: Please settle your account/bill without further delay.

settle.eng_def: to become quiet and calm, or to make something or someone do this
settle.eg: The weather is expected to settle towards the end of the week.

settle.eng_def: to reach and remain at a certain level or in a certain state
settle.eg: The pound rose slightly against the dollar today, then settled at $1.53.

settlement.eng_def: an official agreement that finishes an argument
settlement.eg: It now seems unlikely that it will be possible to negotiate/reach a peaceful settlement of the conflict.

settlement.eng_def: an arrangement to end a disagreement involving a law having been broken, without taking it to a law court, or an amount of money paid as part of such an arrangement
a place where people come to live or the process of settling in such a place
settlement.eg: A large Roman settlement has been discovered just outside the French town.

settlement.eng_def: the action of paying money to someone
settlement.eg: The settlement of his debts took him several months.

settlement.eng_def: the process of the slow sinking of a building or the ground

settler.eng_def: a person who arrives, especially from another country, in a new place in order to live there and use the land
settler.chi_def: （尤指來自別國的）移居者，定居者；殖民者

seven.eg: The restaurant opens for dinner at seven (o'clock).

seventeen.eg: I'm nearly seventeen so I should be able to do what I want.

several.eng_def: some; an amount that is not exact but is fewer than many
several.eg: I've seen "Gone with the Wind" several times.
We are striving to reach an agreement which will satisfy the several interests of the parties concerned.

severe.eng_def: causing very great pain, difficulty, worry, damage, etc.; very serious
severe.chi_def: 非常嚴重的；劇烈的；慘重的

severe.eg: This will be a severe test of our strength.

severe.eng_def: not kind or showing sympathy; not willing to accept other people's mistakes or failures
severe.chi_def: 不和善的；冷酷的；嚴厲的；苛刻的
severe.eg: The headteacher spoke in a severe voice.

severe.chi_def: 不加裝飾的，樸素的，簡樸的
severe.eg: She wore a severe black dress, and plain black shoes.

sew.eng_def: to join two pieces of cloth together by putting thread through them with a needle
sew.eg: My grandmother taught me to sew.

sew.eng_def: to make a piece of clothing by joining pieces of cloth together by putting thread through them with a needle
sew.eg: She sews all her children's clothes.

sew.eng_def: to use a needle and thread to join up the edges of a cut in the skin or other part of the body
sew.eg: The muscle layer needs to be sewn first.

sewer.eng_def: a large pipe, usually underground, that is used for carrying waste water and human waste away from buildings to a place where they can be safely got rid of
a channel for carrying away waste water and waste from the human body that is above the ground and is not covered

sex.eng_def: the state of being either male or female
all males considered as a group, or all females considered as a group
sex.eg: She seems to regard all members of the male sex as inferior.

sex.eng_def: physical activity between people involving the sexual organs
sex.chi_def: 性活動；（尤指）性行爲，性交
sex.eg: Sex before/outside marriage is strongly disapproved of in some cultures.

sex.eng_def: to discover if an animal is male or female

sexual.eng_def: relating to the activity of sex
sexual.eg: Most people remember their first sexual experience.

sexual.eng_def: relating to the production of young living things by the combining of a cell from a male with a cell from a female
relating to being male or female
sexual.eg: Sexual equality will not be achieved until there is more provision for childcare.

sexy.eng_def: used to describe something that attracts a lot of interest and excitement
sexy.eg: For most people, grammar isn't a very sexy subject.

shabby.eng_def: looking old and in bad condition because of being used for a long time or not being cared for
shabby.eg: He wore a shabby old overcoat.

shabby.chi_def: 不光彩的；不公正的；不能接受的
shabby.eg: She spoke out about the shabby way the case had been handled.

shade.eng_def: slight darkness caused by something blocking the direct light from the sun
shade.eg: The sun was hot, and there were no trees to offer us shade.

shade.eng_def: a covering that is put over an electric light in order to make it less bright
shade.eg: The lamps all had matching purple shades.

shade.eng_def: the parts of a picture or painting that the artist has made slightly darker than the other parts
shade.eg: A good artist can produce a very realistic effect using only light and shade.
She was wearing a black leather jacket and shades.

shade.eng_def: a piece of material fixed onto a wooden or metal roller that can be pulled down to cover a window
a type or degree of a colour
shade.eg: Their kitchen is painted an unusual shade of yellow/an unusual yellow shade.

shade.eng_def: something that is slightly different from other, similar things
shade.eg: They are hoping to satisfy all shades of public opinion.
Don't you think those trousers are a shade too tight?

shade.eng_def: said to mean that something or someone makes you remember something or someone similar
shade.chi_def: 像（過去某人或某物）的樣子
shade.eg: In his speech he said - shades of Martin Luther King Jr. - that he had a dream.

shade.eng_def: to prevent direct light from shining on something
shade.eg: I shaded my eyes from the glare of the sun.
At sunset, the sky shaded from pink into dark red.

shadow.eng_def: an area of darkness, caused by light being blocked by something
shadow.eg: The children were playing, jumping on each other's shadows.

shadow.eng_def: an area of darkness in which people and things cannot be seen
shadow.eg: Someone jumped out of the shadows and grabbed my handbag.

shadow.eng_def: a small dark area of skin under your eye
shadow.eg: She put on some make-up to cover the dark shadows under her eyes.

shadow.eng_def: to be very close to a larger building or place
shadow.chi_def: 離（某個大的建築物或場所）很近
shadow.eg: His workshop was in the shadow of the great church of San Paolo Maggiore.

shadow.eng_def: to be in a situation in which something unpleasant either seems likely to happen and to have a bad effect on your life, or is already having a bad effect on your life
shadow.eg: We are all living under the shadow of war.
It is a tragic story, but there is a shadow of hope.

shadow.eng_def: If something is true beyond a shadow of a doubt, there is no doubt that it is true.
shadow.eg: This is without a shadow of a doubt the best movie I've seen all year.

shadow.eng_def: someone who follows another person everywhere
shadow.chi_def: 跟蹤者，盯梢者；形影不離的人
shadow.eg: "I think we have a shadow on our tail," muttered the detective.

shadow.eng_def: a person who follows someone else while they are at work in order to learn about that person's job

shadow.eg: The police think that the robbers shadowed their victims for days before the crime.

shadow.eng_def: to follow someone else while they are at work in order to learn about that person's job
shadow.chi_def: （爲了解某人的工作而）跟隨見習
shadow.eg: Your first week in the job will be spent shadowing one of our more experienced employees.
We came across a glade shadowed by large trees.

shadow.eng_def: to make a person unhappy or to make their life less happy
shadow.eg: Mental illness had shadowed him for more than a decade.

shadow.eng_def: used in the title of important politicians in the main opposition party (= the party not in government)
shadow.chi_def: （用於主要反對黨的要員的頭銜中）影子的

shady.eng_def: sheltered from direct light from the sun
shady.eg: We sat on the shady grass for our picnic.

shady.chi_def: 不老實的；不正當的；非法的
shady.eg: They know some very shady characters.

shake.eng_def: to move backwards and forwards or up and down in quick, short movements, or to make something or someone do this
shake.eg: A young boy climbed into the apple tree and shook the branches so that the fruit fell down.

shake.eng_def: If you are shaking, your body makes quick short movements, or you feel as if it is doing so, because you are frightened or nervous.
shake.eg: She was shaking as she opened the letter.

shake.eng_def: If your voice shakes, it makes you sound nervous or frightened.
shake.eg: Her voice shook as she talked about the person who attacked her.

shake.eng_def: to hold someone's hand and move it up and down, especially when you meet them for the first time or when you make an agreement with them
shake.chi_def: （尤指初次見面或達成協定時）握（某人的）手
shake.eg: "Pleased to meet you," he said, shaking my hand.

shake.eng_def: If two people shake hands, they greet each other or say goodbye by briefly joining hands and moving them slightly up and down.
shake.eg: The Princess was photographed shaking hands with AIDS victims.

shake.eng_def: If two people shake (hands) on something, they make an agreement by briefly joining hands and moving them slightly up and down.
shake.eg: It seems that we have a deal, so let's shake (hands) on it.

shake.eng_def: to move your head from side to side, in order to express disagreement, sadness, or that you do not want or believe something
shake.chi_def: 搖頭（表示不同意、悲傷、不想要或不信）
shake.eg: I asked Tim if he'd seen Jackie lately but he shook his head.

shake.eng_def: to hold your hand up in the air with your fingers and thumb bent, and move it forcefully backwards and forwards, to show that you are angry
shake.eg: He shook his fist at the driver who pulled out in front of him.

shake.eng_def: to cause to feel upset and worried
shake.chi_def: 使煩惱；使心緒不定；使震驚
shake.eg: The child seemed nervous and visibly shaken.

shake.eng_def: to make something less certain, firm, or strong
shake.eg: What has happened has shaken the foundations of her belief.

shake.eng_def: to get rid of or escape from something
shake.eg: It's very difficult to shake the habit of a lifetime.
She gave the box a shake to see if there was anything inside it.

shake.eng_def: short, quick movements from side to side that your body makes because you are ill, are frightened, or have drunk too much alcohol
shake.eg: I watched her hands as she prepared coffee and she definitely had the shakes.

shall.eng_def: used instead of "will" when the subject is "I" or "we"
shall.chi_def: （用於在主語爲 I 或 we 時替代 will）
shall.eg: If you do that one more time, I shall be very angry.

shall.eng_def: used, with "I" or "we", to make a suggestion
shall.chi_def: （與 I 或 we 連用，表示建議）

shall.eng_def: used to say that something certainly will or must happen, or that you are determined that something will happen
shall.chi_def: （表示某事肯定或必須發生，或表示決心）
shall.eg: Don't worry, I shall be there to meet the train.

shallow.eng_def: having only a short distance from the top to the bottom
shallow.eg: The stream was fairly shallow so we were able to walk across it.

shallow.eng_def: breathing in which you only take a small amount of air into your lungs with each breath
not showing serious or careful thought
shallow.eg: I thought the film was pretty shallow.

shallow.eng_def: the shallow part of an area of water

shame.eng_def: If something is described as a shame, it is disappointing or not satisfactory.
shame.eg: It's a (great/real) shame that the event had to be cancelled.

shame.eng_def: an uncomfortable feeling of guilt or of being ashamed because of your own or someone else's bad behaviour
shame.eg: He said he felt no shame for what he had done.
He thinks there's great shame in being out of work and unable to provide for his family.
It puts me to shame that I still haven't replied to David's letter.
To my shame, I never wrote and thanked Mary for her present.

shame.eng_def: used to tell someone that they should feel sorry for something they did
shame.eg: Shame on you for being so mean.

shame.eng_def: to make someone or something seem not good by comparison
shame.eg: Your cooking puts mine to shame.

shame.eng_def: to make someone feel ashamed, or to make someone or something lose honour and respect
shame.chi_def: 使感到羞愧；使丟臉；羞辱
shame.eg: It shames me that I treated her so badly.

shame.eng_def: to cause someone to do or not to do something by making them feel ashamed
shame.chi_def: 使（某人）感到羞愧而做／不做…
shame.eg: The city council was shamed into taking action after criticism in the national and local media.

shame.eng_def: to be so much better than something else that the other thing seems of a low standard by comparison
shame.eg: The school's exam results shame those of the other schools in the area.

shame.eng_def: used to express disapproval of something that a public speaker is saying
shame.chi_def: （用於表示不贊同演講者所說的話）可恥
shame.eg: To cries of "Shame!", the minister announced that taxes were being increased.

shameful.eng_def: deserving blame, or being a reason for feeling ashamed
shameful.eg: I couldn't see anything shameful in what I had done.

shampoo.eng_def: a liquid used for washing hair, or for washing particular objects or materials
an act of washing something, especially your hair, with shampoo
shampoo.chi_def: （用洗髮精或洗滌劑）洗；（尤指）洗髮
shampoo.eg: My hair/The rug/The dog needs a shampoo.

shampoo.chi_def: 用洗髮精洗；用洗滌劑洗
shampoo.eg: Duncan shampooed my hair and then Tracy cut it.

shape.eng_def: the particular physical form or appearance of something
shape.eg: Clay can be moulded into almost any shape.

shape.eng_def: an arrangement that is formed by joining lines together in a particular way or by the line or lines around its outer edge
the physical form or appearance of a particular person or thing
shape.eg: In the story, Faust is tempted by the Devil, who has taken the shape of a man.

shape.eng_def: a person or object that you cannot see clearly because it is too dark, or because the person or object is too far away
shape.eg: I could see a dark shape in the street outside.
We sell all shapes and sizes of teddy bear.

shape.chi_def: 任何類型的；任何形式的
shape.eg: I'm opposed to war in any shape or form.

shape.eng_def: the way something is organized, or its general character or nature
shape.eg: Technological developments have changed the shape of industry.
He bought up businesses that were in bad/poor shape, and then sold them off piece by piece.

shape.chi_def: 良好的結構（或身體狀況）
shape.eg: It's taken us five years to get our house into shape.

shape.eng_def: to decide or influence the form of something, especially a belief or idea, or someone's character
shape.chi_def: 決定（或影響）（尤指信仰或思想）的形式；決定，影響（性格）
shape.eg: Many people are not able to shape their own destinies.

shape.eng_def: to make something become a particular shape
shape.eg: The skirt has been shaped so that it hangs loosely.

shape.eng_def: to make an object from a physical substance
shape.eg: Early humans shaped tools out of stone.

share.eng_def: to have or use something at the same time as someone else
share.eg: She's very possessive about her toys and finds it hard to share.

share.eng_def: to divide food, money, goods, etc. and give part of it to someone else
share.eg: Will you share your sandwich with me?

share.eng_def: If two or more people share an activity, they each do some of it.
If two or more people or things share a feeling, quality, or experience, they both or all have the same feeling, quality, or experience.
share.chi_def: 有同樣的感覺（或性質、經歷）
share.eg: We share an interest in sailing.

share.eng_def: to tell someone else about your thoughts, feelings, ideas, etc.
share.eg: He's not very good at sharing his worries.

share.eng_def: a part of something that has been divided between several people
share.eg: The total bill comes to €80, so our share is €20.

share.eng_def: a part of something that several people are involved in
share.eg: She's not doing her share of the work.

share.eng_def: one of the equal parts that the ownership of a company is divided into, and that can be bought by members of the public
share.eg: The value of my shares has risen/fallen by eight percent.

shark.eng_def: a large fish that has sharp teeth and a pointed fin on its back
a dishonest person, especially one who persuades other people to pay too much money for something
shark.eg: People who need a place to live can often find themselves at the mercy of local property sharks.

sharp.eng_def: having a thin edge or point that can cut something or make a hole in something
sharp.eg: a knife with a sharp edge/blade.

sharp.eng_def: producing or describing a quick, strong pain that makes you feel like you have been cut
sharp.eg: She nudged me with a sharp elbow, to tell me to be quiet.

sharp.eng_def: used to describe a part of someone's face that is very pointed
sharp.eg: a thin face with a sharp nose

sharp.eng_def: If someone is sharp or makes a sharp statement, they speak or act in a severe and angry way that can hurt other people.
sharp.eg: He was a little sharp with me when I asked him to help.

sharp.eng_def: clear; easy to see or understand
sharp.eg: This TV gives a very sharp picture.

sharp.eng_def: intelligent or quick to notice things
sharp.eg: Birdwatchers need to have sharp ears and eyes.
Tony is a very sharp dresser.
After the church, turn sharp left/right.
The performance will start at 7.30 sharp.

sharp.eng_def: higher than the correct or stated musical note
sharp.eg: The E string on my guitar is a bit sharp.

sharp.eng_def: (a symbol for) a note that is a semitone higher than the stated note

sharpen.eng_def: to make something sharp or sharper
sharpen.eg: My pencil is blunt - I'll have to sharpen it.
Recent changes have sharpened competition between the airlines.
I hope this course will help me sharpen my computer skills.
How do you sharpen the focus on this camera?

sharpen.eng_def: to make something play a higher musical note
sharpen.chi_def: 使提高音調；使提高半音
sharpen.eg: You need to sharpen the A string on your violin.

shatter.eng_def: to (cause something to) break suddenly into very small pieces
shatter.eg: The glass shattered into a thousand tiny pieces.

shatter.eng_def: to end or severely damage something
shatter.eg: The book shattered all her illusions about the Romans.

shave.eng_def: to remove hair from the body, especially a man's face, by cutting it close to the skin with a razor, so that the skin feels smooth
shave.eg: John has to shave twice a day.

shave.eng_def: the act of shaving, especially a man's face

shaver.eng_def: an electric device for shaving hair from someone's face or body

shed.eng_def: a small building, usually made of wood, used for storing things
shed.chi_def: （通常爲木質、存放物品用的）棚子，小屋

shed.eng_def: a large, simple building used for a particular purpose
(often used in newspapers) to get rid of something you do not need or want
shed.eg: 900 jobs will be shed over the next few months.

shed.eng_def: to lose a covering, such as leaves, hair, or skin, because it falls off naturally, or to drop something in a natural way or by accident
shed.eg: The trees shed their leaves in autumn.

shed.eng_def: to produce tears, light, blood, etc.
shed.eg: She shed a few tears at her daughter's wedding.
She'd found the answer, at last.
She'd be a great managing director, don't you think?

sheep.eng_def: a farm animal with thick wool that eats grass and is kept for its wool, skin, and meat
sheep.eg: The farmer has several large flocks (= groups) of long-haired sheep.

sheer.eng_def: used to emphasize how very great, important, or powerful a quality or feeling is; nothing except
Sheer clothing or material is so thin, light, and delicate that you can see through it.

sheer.eg: I thought the boats were going to collide, but one sheered off/away at the last second.

sheet.eng_def: a large piece of thin cloth used on a bed for sleeping on or under
sheet.eg: I've put clean sheets on the bed.

sheet.eng_def: a large, thin, flat, usually rectangular piece of something
a piece of paper with something printed on it
sheet.eg: The tourist office provides a weekly information sheet about things that are happening in the town.

sheet.eng_def: a large, wide mass of something such as fire or ice
sheet.eg: A sheet of flame shot up into the air immediately after the explosion.
The rain was coming down in sheets.
We can't go out yet, it's sheeting down outside.

shelf.eng_def: a long, flat board fixed horizontally, usually against a wall or inside a cupboard so that objects can be stored on it
shelf.chi_def: （通常指固定在牆上或櫥櫃中的）架子

shelf.eng_def: a flat area of rock underwater or on a cliff
If a product can be bought off the shelf, it does not need to be specially made or asked for.
shelf.eg: It's often cheaper if you buy wallpaper off the shelf, rather than having to order it.

shelf.eng_def: When a shop removes something from its shelves, that product stops being available for sale there.

shell.eng_def: the hard outer covering of something, especially nuts, eggs, and some animals
shell.eg: Brazil nuts have very hard shells.

shell.eng_def: the basic outer structure of a building or vehicle, especially when the parts inside have been destroyed or taken or have not yet been made
shell.chi_def: （尤指內部遭破壞、被去除或尚未建成的建築物、車輛的）框架，骨架
shell.eg: the shell of a burned-out farmhouse

shell.eng_def: a container, usually with a pointed end, that is filled with explosives and shot from a large gun
shell.eg: Artillery and mortar shells were landing in the outskirts of the city.

shell.eng_def: a type of boat used for racing, driven by people using oars (= poles with flat ends)
a company that is used to hide illegal activities
shell.eg: The shell advertised bonds for sale to investors, but this offering was essentially a fraud because no bonds ever existed.

shell.eng_def: to remove peas, nuts, etc. from their shells or their natural covering

shell.eg: They were under orders to shell the hospital and the town hall.

shelter.eng_def: (a building designed to give) protection from bad weather, danger, or attack
to protect yourself from bad weather, danger, or attack
shelter.eg: We took shelter for the night in an abandoned house.

shelter.eng_def: to protect yourself, or another person or thing, from bad weather, danger, or attack
shelter.eg: We were caught in a thunderstorm, without anywhere to shelter.

shelter.eng_def: to give someone a secret hiding place so that they will not be caught by the army, police, etc.
shelter.eg: Local people risked their own lives to shelter resistance fighters from the army.

shelter.eng_def: If you shelter income, you legally avoid paying taxes on it.
shelter.eg: Their accountant suggested some novel ways of sheltering their retirement income.

shepherd.eng_def: a person whose job is to take care of sheep and move them from one place to another
to make a group of people move to where you want them to go, especially in a kind, helpful, and careful way
shepherd.eg: He shepherded the old people towards the dining room.

shepherd.eng_def: to move sheep from one place to another
shepherd.eg: The dogs shepherded the sheep into the pens.

sheriff.eng_def: in the US, an official whose job is to be in charge of performing the orders of the law courts and making certain that the laws are obeyed within a particular county
in England and Wales, a person who represents the king or queen in a particular county, and whose duties are mainly in official ceremonies
the most important judge of a county in Scotland

shield.eng_def: in the past, a large, flat object made of metal or leather that soldiers held in front of their bodies to protect themselves
a large, flat object made of strong plastic that police officers hold in front of their bodies to protect themselves
shield.eg: The police held up their riot shields against the flying rocks and bricks.

shield.eng_def: something or someone used as protection or providing protection
shield.eg: The anti-personnel mines were laid as a protective shield around the town.

shield.eng_def: a flat object with two straight sides, a rounded or pointed lower edge, and usually a straight top edge, on which there is a coat of arms
an object shaped like a shield that is used as a symbol or badge
shield.eg: The blazer has a shield sewn on the pocket.

shield.eng_def: an object shaped like a shield that is given as a prize
shield.eg: Our school won the county basketball shield this year.
She held her hand above her eyes to shield them from the sun.

shield.eng_def: in football, to keep your body between an opponent and the ball, with your back to the other player, to prevent them from getting the ball
shield.eg: We teach young players how to step in front of the defender and use their body to shield the ball.

shift.eng_def: to (cause something or someone to) move or change from one position or direction to another, especially slightly
shift.eg: She shifted (her weight) uneasily from one foot to the other.

shift.eng_def: (of an idea, opinion, etc.) to change
shift.eg: Society's attitudes towards women have shifted enormously over the last century.

shift.eng_def: to move the gears of a vehicle into different positions in order to make it go faster or slower
shift.eg: In cars that are automatics, you don't have to bother with shifting gears.

shift.eng_def: to leave your home in order to live in a new one; move house
to get rid of something unwanted, or to sell something
shift.eg: Modern detergents will shift most stains.

shift.eng_def: a group of workers who do a job for a period of time during the day or night, or the period of time itself
shift.eg: As the night shift leave/leaves, the day shift arrive/arrives.

shift.eng_def: a change in position or direction
a simple dress that hangs straight from the shoulders

shilling.eng_def: a unit of money used in Britain until 1971, equal to twelve old pence
shilling.chi_def: 先令（英國1971年前使用的一種貨幣單位，合12舊便士或5新便士）

shilling.eng_def: the standard unit of money used in Kenya, Somalia, Tanzania, and Uganda
shilling.chi_def: 先令（肯亞、索馬利亞、坦桑尼亞和烏幹達使用的標準貨幣單位）

shine.eng_def: to send out or reflect light
shine.eg: Is that light shining in your eyes?

shine.eng_def: If a person's eyes or face shine with a quality, you can see that quality in them very strongly.
to point a light in a particular direction
shine.eg: The policeman walked along the street, shining a torch into every car.

shine.eng_def: to make something bright by rubbing it
shine.eg: Guy ironed his shirt and shined his shoes for the interview.

shine.eng_def: to be extremely good at an activity or skill, in an obvious way
shine.eg: She's terrible at languages, but she shines at/in science.

shine.eng_def: the fact that something is bright from reflected light on its surface

shiny.eng_def: A shiny surface is bright because it reflects light

ship.eng_def: a large boat for travelling on water, especially across the sea
to send something, usually a large object or a large quantity of objects or people, to a place far away
ship.eg: We ship books out to New York every month.

ship.eng_def: having the rank, position, skill, or relationship of the stated type

shirt.eng_def: a piece of clothing worn, especially by men, on the upper part of the body, made of light cloth like cotton and usually having a collar and buttons at the front

shiver.eng_def: When people or animals shiver, they shake slightly because they feel cold, ill, or frightened.
shiver.chi_def: （因寒冷、疾病或恐懼而）輕微顫抖，發抖

shiver.eng_def: the act of shaking slightly because you are frightened, cold, or ill
shiver.chi_def: （因受驚、寒冷或生病而出現的）顫慄；顫抖
shiver.eg: I felt/gave a shiver as I looked out at the dark expanse of sea.

shiver.eng_def: a condition in which you shiver because you are ill
shiver.eg: She's aching and she has the shivers, so I've sent her to bed.

shiver.eng_def: a feeling of being frightened of someone or something
shiver.eg: I don't like him - he gives me the shivers.

shock.eng_def: (the emotional or physical reaction to) a sudden, unexpected, and usually unpleasant event or experience
shock.chi_def: 令人震驚的事件（或經歷）；驚愕，震驚
shock.eg: Her mother's death came as a great shock - it was so unexpected.

shock.eng_def: an unpleasant feeling that you experience when something new or unusual happens
shock.chi_def: （新的或不常見的事物）讓人感到難以應對（或不快）
shock.eg: It's really hard getting back to work after three months off - it's quite a shock to the system.
Ow! - I got a shock from that lamp!

shock.eng_def: a medical condition caused by severe injury, pain, loss of blood, or fear that slows down the flow of blood around the body
shock.eg: Several passengers from the wrecked vehicle were taken to hospital suffering from shock.

shock.eng_def: the effect of one object violently hitting another, causing damage or a slight movement
shock.eg: For running on hard roads, you need shoes with extra cushioning to absorb (= reduce) the shock.

shock.eng_def: a feeling of being offended or upset by something you consider wrong or unacceptable
shock.eg: You should have seen the look of shock on her face when he started swearing!

shock.eng_def: a large and noticeable mass of hair
shock.eg: The baby had a shock of bright red hair.

shock.eng_def: to offend or upset someone by doing or saying something that they consider is immoral or unacceptable
shock.eg: The advertisements were designed to shock - that was the whole point of the campaign.

shock.eng_def: to make someone feel upset or surprised
shock.eg: The photographs of starving children shocked people into giving money.

shocked.eng_def: (the emotional or physical reaction to) a sudden, unexpected, and usually unpleasant event or experience
shocked.chi_def: 令人震驚的事件（或經歷）；驚愕，震驚
shocked.eg: Her mother's death came as a great shock - it was so unexpected.

shocked.eng_def: an unpleasant feeling that you experience when something new or unusual happens
shocked.chi_def: （新的或不常見的事物）讓人感到難以應對（或不快）
shocked.eg: It's really hard getting back to work after three months off - it's quite a shock to the system.
Ow! - I got a shock from that lamp!

shocked.eng_def: a medical condition caused by severe injury, pain, loss of blood, or fear that slows down the flow of blood around the body
shocked.eg: Several passengers from the wrecked vehicle were taken to hospital suffering from shock.

shocked.eng_def: the effect of one object violently hitting another, causing damage or a slight movement
shocked.eg: For running on hard roads, you need shoes with extra cushioning to absorb (= reduce) the shock.

shocked.eng_def: a feeling of being offended or upset by something you consider wrong or unacceptable
shocked.eg: You should have seen the look of shock on her face when he started swearing!

shocked.eng_def: a large and noticeable mass of hair
shocked.eg: The baby had a shock of bright red hair.

shocked.eng_def: to offend or upset someone by doing or saying something that they consider is immoral or unacceptable
shocked.eg: The advertisements were designed to shock - that was the whole point of the campaign.

shocked.eng_def: to make someone feel upset or surprised
shocked.eg: The photographs of starving children shocked people into giving money.

shoe.eng_def: one of a pair of coverings for your feet, usually made of a strong material such as leather, with a thick leather or plastic sole (= base) and usually a heel
If you shoe a horse, you nail a horseshoe (= a curved piece of metal) to one or each of its feet.

shoot.eng_def: to fire a bullet or an arrow, or to hit, injure, or kill a person or animal by firing a bullet or arrow at him, her, or it
shoot.chi_def: 開（槍），射（箭）；發射；射中，射傷，射殺
shoot.eg: If he's not armed, don't shoot.

shoot.eng_def: to try to score points for yourself or your team, in sports involving a ball, by kicking, hitting, or throwing the ball towards the goal
shoot.eg: He shot from the middle of the field and still managed to score.

shoot.eng_def: to move in a particular direction very quickly and directly
shoot.eg: She shot past me several metres before the finishing line.

shoot.eng_def: to move through or past something quickly
shoot.eg: He shot three sets of traffic lights (= went past them when they gave the signal to stop) before the police caught him.

shoot.eng_def: to use a camera to record a video or take a photograph
shoot.eg: We shot four reels of film in Egypt.

shoot.eng_def: to play a game of pool or craps
shoot.chi_def: 打（撞球）；玩（雙骰子、賭博遊戲）

shoot.eng_def: to take an illegal drug by injecting yourself with it
shoot.eg: By the time he was 16, he was shooting heroin twice a day.

shoot.eng_def: the first part of a plant to appear above the ground as it develops from a seed, or any new growth on an already existing plant
shoot.eg: Two weeks after we'd planted the seeds, little green shoots started to appear.

shoot.eng_def: an occasion when photographers take a series of photographs, usually of the same person or people in the same place
shoot.chi_def: （通常指同一人在同一地點的）系列拍攝，組照
shoot.eg: We did a fashion shoot on the beach, with the girls modelling swimwear.

shoot.eng_def: an occasion on which a group of people go to an area of the countryside to shoot animals
used to tell someone that they should speak
shoot.chi_def: （交談時指示對方開始說話）說吧
shoot.eg: "Dad, I need to talk to you." "Shoot."

shop.eng_def: a place where you can buy goods or services
the act of shopping, especially of shopping for food and other things needed in the house
shop.chi_def: 購物；（尤指食品及其他日常用品的）採購
shop.eg: I usually do the weekly shop on a Monday.
His latest novel will be in the shops by Christmas.

shop.eng_def: a place where a particular type of thing is made or repaired
shop.eg: He runs a car repair shop.
I like to shop at Gap for clothes.

shop.eng_def: to give the police information about a criminal
shop.eg: His ex-wife shopped him to the police.

shop.eng_def: to offer something for sale, especially to several different companies in the hope that one of them will buy it
shop.eg: Your script gets shopped to literary agents and movie studios.

shore.eng_def: the land along the edge of a sea, lake, or wide river
shore.eg: You can walk for miles along the shore.

shore.eng_def: on the land and not in a ship
shore.eg: We waited until we were on shore before repairing the sails.

shore.eng_def: a country or continent with a coast
shore.eg: In 1992, Britain played host to the first multi-racial South African team to visit these shores.

short.eng_def: small in length, distance, or height
used to say that a name is used as a shorter form of another name
short.eg: Her name's Jo - it's short for Josephine.

short.eng_def: being an amount of time that is less than average or usual
Short books, letters, and other examples of writing do not contain many words and do not take much time to read.
short.eg: It's a very short book - you'll read it in an hour.

short.eng_def: to not have enough of something
unable to breathe very well, for example because you have been running or doing some type of energetic exercise
short.chi_def: 喘不過氣，上氣不接下氣
short.eg: She's always short of breath when she climbs the stairs.

short.eng_def: to be few or not enough in number
short.eg: Free desks are in short supply in this office.

short.eng_def: to not have something, especially when it is something you need in order to live
short.eg: My parents didn't have much money, but they made sure we didn't go short (of anything).

short.eng_def: saying little but showing slight impatience or anger in the few words that you say
short.chi_def: （說話時）簡短不耐的，簡短慍怒的
short.eg: I'm sorry if I was a bit short with you on the phone this morning.

short.eng_def: a drink of spirits (= type of strong alcohol) without water or any other liquid added
short.eg: She only drinks shorts, never wine or beer.

short.eng_def: a short film, especially one made for showing before the main film at a cinema
short.chi_def: （尤指正片播映之前播放的）電影短片

short.eg: The plumber shorted the washing machine.

short.eng_def: before the arranged or expected time or place
short.eg: We wanted to explain the plans fully, but the chairman stopped us short, as there were other important matters to discuss.

short.eng_def: used with adjectives ending in -ed formed from nouns to describe something with a short part
short.chi_def: （與以 -ed 結尾、由名詞變化而來的形容詞連用）短…的
short.eg: a short-haired dog (= a dog with short hair)

shortage.eng_def: a situation in which there is not enough of something
shortage.eg: There's a shortage of food and shelter in the refugee camps.

shortcoming.eng_def: a fault or a failure to reach a particular standard
shortcoming.eg: Whatever his shortcomings as a husband, he was a good father to his children.

shorten.eng_def: to become shorter or to make something shorter
shorten.eg: As you grow older, your spine shortens by about an inch.

shortly.eg: We will shortly be arriving in King's Cross Station.

shortly.eng_def: a short time after or before something
shortly.eg: Shortly after you left, a man came into the office looking for you.

shorts.eng_def: trousers that end above the knee or reach the knee, often worn in hot weather or when playing a sport
shorts.chi_def: （常在熱天或運動時穿的）短褲

shortsighted.eng_def: Someone who is nearsighted cannot see objects clearly that are far away.

shot.eng_def: past simple and past participle of shoot
a kick, hit, or throw of the ball that is intended to score points in a sport such as cricket, football, tennis, or golf
shot.chi_def: （板球、足球、網球或高爾夫球中旨在得分的）攻擊，擊打
shot.eg: And that was a great shot by Márquez!

shot.eng_def: the action of firing a gun or another weapon
shot.eg: He fired four shots at the car as it drove off.

shot.eng_def: someone who is skilled/not skilled at aiming and firing a gun
an attempt to do or achieve something that you have not done before
shot.eg: I thought I'd have a shot at making my own wine.
I got/took some really good shots of the harbour at sunset.

shot.eng_def: a short piece in a film in which there is a single action or a short series of actions
a small amount of an alcoholic drink
the amount of a drug that is put into the body by a single injection
shot.eg: The doctor gave him a shot of morphine.

shot.eng_def: a heavy metal ball thrown in a sports competition
a mass of small metal balls that are shot from a gun
(of silk) having small threads of a colour in it, so that the main colour appears to change depending on the angle at which the cloth is seen
shot.chi_def: （絲綢）呈虹色的，顔色會隨著觀看角度閃變的
shot.eg: Her evening dress is made of green shot silk.
It's no good - these gears are shot.

shot.eng_def: to get rid of or free of something, or to leave something
shot.eg: I can't wait to get shot of this office for a week.

shoulder.eng_def: one of the two parts of the body at each side of the neck that join the arms to the rest of the body
shoulder.eg: I rested my head on her shoulder.

shoulder.eng_def: the top part of a person's back
shoulder.eg: He was about six feet tall with broad shoulders.

shoulder.eng_def: the parts of a piece of clothing that cover the wearer's shoulders
shoulder.eg: The shoulders look a little tight. Do you want to try a larger size?

shoulder.eng_def: the part of a bottle that curves out below its opening
shoulder.chi_def: 瓶肩（瓶頸下面擴大的部分）

shoulder.eng_def: used to refer to the responsibility that someone has or feels for something
shoulder.eg: A huge burden was lifted from my shoulders (= I became much less worried) when I told my parents about my problem.

shoulder.eng_def: a piece of meat that includes the upper part of an animal's front leg
shoulder.chi_def: （動物身上包括前腿上半部的）肩肘肉，前腿肉
shoulder.eg: I've bought a shoulder of lamb for Sunday lunch.

shoulder.eng_def: an area along the side of a main road where cars can stop
shoulder.chi_def: 路肩，（大路兩側的）緊急停車道
shoulder.eg: There were tire tracks left in the soft shoulder (= area of dirt or grass by the road).

shoulder.eng_def: to accept that you are responsible for something bad or difficult
shoulder.chi_def: 承受譴責／承受重負／承擔職責／承擔費用（等等）
shoulder.eg: It is women who mainly shoulder responsibility for the care of elderly and disabled relatives.

shoulder.eng_def: to put something on your shoulders to carry it
shoulder.eg: Shouldering her pack, she strode off up the road.

shoulder.eng_def: to push something with one of your shoulders
shoulder.eg: She was carrying two suitcases and had to shoulder the door open.

shout.eng_def: to speak with a very loud voice, often as loud as possible, usually when you want to make yourself heard in noisy situations, or when the person you are talking to is a long way away or cannot hear very well
shout.eg: There's no need to shout, I can hear you.

shout.eng_def: to express strong emotions, such as anger, fear, or excitement, or to express strong opinions, in a loud voice
shout.chi_def: （因憤怒、恐懼或激動等而）吼叫，大聲叫嚷
shout.eg: Dad really shouted at me when I broke the window.

shout.eng_def: to try to attract attention in a loud voice
shout.eg: I heard them shouting for help, but there was nothing I could do.

shout.eng_def: to buy a drink for someone
the act of saying something very loudly or making a very loud sound with your voice
shout.eg: Her speech was interrupted by angry shouts from the audience.

shout.eng_def: a set of drinks for a group of people, or a particular person's turn to buy them
shout.chi_def: 請客的酒；輪到買酒請客
shout.eg: Would you like another drink? It's my shout since you bought the last ones.

shove.eng_def: to push someone or something forcefully
shove.eg: She was jostled and shoved by an angry crowd as she left the court.

shove.eng_def: to put something somewhere in a hurried or careless way
shove.eg: I'll just shove this laundry in the washer before we go out.

shove.eng_def: to move your body to make space for someone else
shove.chi_def: 移動身體，挪動身體（以騰出地方）
shove.eg: Shove over/along, Lena, and make some room for me.

shove.eng_def: the action of shoving someone or something
shove.eg: Would you help me give the piano a shove?

shovel.eng_def: a tool consisting of a wide, square metal or plastic blade, usually with slightly raised sides, attached to a handle, for moving loose material such as sand, coal, or snow
a similar part on a large machine, for picking up and holding loose material
the amount of something that can fit on a shovel
shovel.eg: Should I put another shovelful of coal on the fire?

shovel.chi_def: 鏟起；用鏟子移動（或移開）
shovel.eg: Would you give me a hand shovelling the snow away from the garage door?

show.eng_def: to make it possible for something to be seen
show.eg: Let me show you this new book I've just bought.

show.eng_def: to record or express a number or measurement
show.chi_def: 記錄，顯示（數字或測量值）
show.eg: The right-hand dial shows the temperature, and the left-hand one shows the air pressure.

show.eng_def: to explain something to someone, by doing it or by giving instructions or examples
show.eg: Can you show me how to set the DVD player?

show.eng_def: to prove something or make the truth or existence of something known
show.eg: She has shown herself (to be) a highly competent manager.

show.eng_def: to express ideas or feelings using actions or words
show.eg: He finds it difficult to show affection.

show.eng_def: to be easy to see or notice
show.chi_def: 顯眼；容易看到（或注意到）
show.eg: "Oh no, I've spilled red wine on my jacket!" "Don't worry, it doesn't show."

show.eng_def: to look as old as you really are
show.chi_def: 顯出老態；顯出真實年齡
show.eg: Recently, he's really starting to show his age.

show.eng_def: to make an artist's work available for the public to see
show.chi_def: 展出，展覽，陳列（藝術作品）
show.eg: Our aim is to make it easier for young unknown artists to show their work.

show.eng_def: If a cinema or television station shows a film or programme, or if a film or programme is showing somewhere, you can see it there.
show.eg: It's the first time this movie has been shown on television.

show.eng_def: to  show up informal
to take someone somewhere by going there with them
show.eg: Could you show Dr Sanchez into the living room?

show.eng_def: to fail to hide something, or to make it possible to see or know something that is not intended to be seen or known
show.eg: Your shirt's so thin that it shows your bra.

show.eng_def: to make someone understand something by directing their attention to it
show.eg: Can you show me where it hurts?

show.eng_def: a theatre performance or a television or radio programme that is entertaining rather than serious
show.eg: a radio/television/stage show

show.eng_def: an event at which a group of related things are available for the public to look at
show.eg: a fashion/flower show

show.eng_def: Something that is on show has been made available for the public to look at.
show.eg: Her sculptures will be on show at the museum until the end of the month.

show.eng_def: an action that makes other people know what your feelings, beliefs, or qualities are
show.eg: In a show of solidarity, the management and workers have joined forces to campaign against the closure of the factory.

show.eng_def: an activity or piece of work that appears to be done with great, little, etc. effort
show.eg: She may not have won, but she certainly put up a good show.

show.eng_def: an appearance of something that is not really sincere or real
show.eg: Despite its public show of unity, the royal family had its share of disagreements just like any other.

show.eng_def: Something that is for show has no practical value and is used only to improve the appearance of something else.
show.eg: Do the lights on this phone have any useful function or are they just/only for show?

show.eng_def: an activity, business, or organization, considered in relation to who is managing it
show.eg: Who will run the show when Meg retires?

show.eng_def: a small amount of blood and mucus (= thick liquid) that comes out of the vagina at the start of labour (= the process of giving birth)
show.eg: the bloody show

shower.eng_def: a device that releases drops of water through a lot of very small holes and that you stand under to wash your whole body
shower.eg: The shower is broken - you'll have to have a bath.

shower.eng_def: an acting of washing using a shower
shower.eg: Do I have time to have a shower before we go out?

shower.eng_def: a place, usually in a bathroom, where a shower is situated
shower.eg: He's in the shower at the moment. Do you want him to call you back?

shower.eng_def: a short period of rain or snow
shower.eg: showers of rain, hail and sleet

shower.eng_def: a lot of small objects or drops of liquid coming through the air
shower.chi_def: 一大批，一連串（從天而降的小顆粒物或液滴）
shower.eg: There was a bang and a shower of sparks.
She received a shower of praise from her colleagues.

shower.eng_def: a party held for a woman just before she gets married or gives birth to a child, when she is given presents for her future home or baby
shower.chi_def: （爲即將結婚或分娩的婦女舉行的）送禮會
shower.eg: I bought the cutest baby clothes to take to Jacey's baby shower.

shower.eng_def: to fall down or come out in a shower, or to make something do this
shower.eg: I heard a massive explosion, and seconds later fragments of glass were showering (= falling) down on us.

shred.eng_def: a very small amount of something
shred.eg: There's still a shred of hope that a peace agreement can be reached.

shred.eng_def: a very small, thin piece that has been torn from something
shred.eg: Cut the radishes into shreds to garnish the plates.
My shirt was in shreds when I took it out of the washer.
The report has left the CEO's reputation in shreds.

shred.eng_def: to cut or tear something roughly into thin strips
shred.chi_def: 把…切（或撕）成細條；切碎；撕碎
shred.eg: Shred the lettuce and arrange it around the edge of the dish.

shred.eng_def: to destroy a document by tearing it into strips, especially in a machine
shred.eg: He ordered his secretary to shred important documents when government inspectors started investigating his business affairs.

shrewd.eng_def: having or based on a clear understanding and good judgment of a situation, resulting in an advantage
shrewd.eg: He was shrewd enough not to take the job when there was the possibility of getting a better one a few months later.

shriek.eng_def: a short, loud, high cry, especially one produced suddenly as an expression of a powerful emotion

shriek.eg: We shrieked with laughter when we realized how stupid we'd been.

shrimp.eng_def: a very small sea creature similar to a prawn but smaller, or its flesh eaten as food
a small sea creature with a shell and ten legs, that can be eaten

shrine.eng_def: a place for worship that is holy because of a connection with a holy person or object
shrine.eg: Islam's most sacred shrine is at Mecca in Saudi Arabia.

shrine.eng_def: a special place in which you remember and praise someone who has died, especially someone famous
shrine.eg: She's turned her bedroom into a shrine to the dead pop star and covered the walls with pictures of him.

shrink.eng_def: to become smaller, or to make something smaller
shrink.eg: Your sweater will shrink if you wash it at too high a temperature.

shrink.eng_def: to move away from someone or something because you are frightened
shrink.eg: The child shrank behind the sofa as his father shouted at him.
I was so depressed that I ended up going to see a shrink.

shrub.eng_def: a large plant with a rounded shape formed from many small branches growing either directly from the ground or from a hard stem, grown in gardens
shrub.eg: She planted some roses and other flowering shrubs.

shrug.eng_def: to raise your shoulders and then lower them in order to say you do not know or are not interested
shrug.chi_def: （表示不知道或不感興趣）聳（肩）
shrug.eg: "Where's Dad?" "How should I know?" replied my brother, shrugging.

shrug.eng_def: the action of raising and lowering your shoulders to express something
shrug.eg: "I'm afraid there's nothing I can do about your problem," she said with a shrug.

shrug.chi_def: （女式）短套領衫（一種女式短羊毛衫）

shudder.eng_def: to shake suddenly with very small movements because of a very unpleasant thought or feeling
shudder.chi_def: （因有令人不快的想法或感覺而）戰慄，發抖
shudder.eg: The sight of so much blood made him shudder.

shudder.eng_def: When something shudders, it shakes violently and quickly.
shudder.eg: I heard a massive explosion and the ground shuddered beneath me.
He gave a slight shudder as he considered how close he had come to death.

shun.eg: She has shunned publicity since she retired from acting.

shun.eng_def: to ignore someone and not speak to that person because you cannot accept their behaviour, beliefs, etc.
shun.eg: After the trial he was shunned by friends and family alike.

shut.eng_def: to (cause to) stop operating or being in service, either temporarily or permanently
shut.eg: The shops shut at eight o'clock on Wednesday evenings.
I suspected something was wrong when I noticed her curtains were still shut at lunchtime.

shutter.eng_def: the part of a camera that opens temporarily to allow light to reach the film when a photograph is being taken
a wooden cover on the outside of a window that prevents light or heat from going into a room or heat from leaving it
shutter.eg: Shutters usually come in pairs and are hung like doors on hinges.

shutter.eng_def: a metal covering that protects the windows and entrance of a shop from thieves when it is closed

shuttle.eng_def: a vehicle or aircraft that travels regularly between two places
shuttle.chi_def: 穿梭運行的車輛，接駁車;穿梭航班
shuttle.eg: To get across town, you can take the shuttle from Times Square to Grand Central.

shuttle.eng_def: in weaving, a device that is used to carry the thread that goes across the cloth between the threads that go down the cloth
to travel or take people regularly between the same two places
shuttle.eg: A bus shuttles constantly between the terminal and the runways.

shy.eng_def: nervous and uncomfortable with other people
shy.eg: He was too shy to ask her to dance with him.
We're only $100 shy of the total amount.

shy.eng_def: (of a horse) to suddenly move sideways or backwards, especially because of fear
shy.eg: The horse shied at the fence.

shy.eng_def: to throw something suddenly, often in a sideways movement
shy.eg: Two small boys were shying stones at a tree.

shy.eng_def: avoiding or not liking the thing mentioned

sick.eng_def: physically or mentally ill; not well or healthy
sick.chi_def: 生病的，患病的，不舒服的

sick.eng_def: feeling ill as if you are going to vomit
sick.eg: Lucy felt sick the morning after the party.
She was sick after she ate too much chocolate.

sick.eng_def: feeling strong unpleasant emotions, especially anger or disgust
sick.eg: I'm sick at (= unhappy about) not getting that job.
Joan was not amused by the sick joke her brother told.
It's better for the sick to be cared for at home rather than in hospital.
a pool of sick on the floor

side.eng_def: a flat outer surface of an object, especially one that is not the top, the bottom, the front, or the back
side.eg: The names of ships are usually painted on their sides.

side.eng_def: an edge or border of something

side.eg: I have a small table at/by the side of (= next to) my bed.

side.eng_def: in a restaurant, an extra dish of food, for example vegetables or salad, that is served with the main dish, sometimes on a separate plate
side.eg: I’ll have a side of onion rings.

side.chi_def: 肩並肩地；一個挨一個地
side.eg: The children sat side by side on the sofa watching television.

side.eng_def: a part of something, especially in relation to a real or imagined central line
side.eg: He likes to sleep on the right side of the bed.

side.eng_def: the part of the body from under the arm to the top of the leg
side.eg: I have a pain in my side.

side.eng_def: from left to right and from right to left
side.eg: The curtains were swinging from side to side in the breeze.

side.eng_def: half of an animal's body, considered as meat
side.eg: She bought a side of lamb from the butcher.

side.eng_def: one of two or more opposing teams or groups
side.chi_def: （多個相互對立的團隊中的）一方
side.eg: This is a war which neither side can win.

side.eng_def: to support one person or group rather than another, in an argument or war
side.chi_def: （在爭論或戰爭中）表明立場，支持一方
side.eg: My mother never takes sides when my brother and I argue.

side.eng_def: to support someone in an argument
side.eg: My mother always takes my father's side when I argue with him.

side.eng_def: an opinion held in an argument, or a way of considering something
side.eg: There are at least two sides to every question.

side.eng_def: a part of a situation, system, etc. that can be considered or dealt with separately
side.chi_def: （某一情形或系統中可單獨處理的）一部分
side.eg: She takes care of the financial side of things.
She seems quite fierce, but actually she has a gentle side.

side.eng_def: not in or at the centre or main part of something
side.eg: We parked the car on a side street/road (= a small road, especially one that joins on to a main road).

sidewalk.eng_def: a path with a hard surface on one or both sides of a road, that people walk on
sidewalk.eg: Keep on the sidewalk, Rosie, there's a good girl.

siege.eng_def: the surrounding of a place by an armed force in order to defeat those defending it
siege.eg: The siege of Mafeking lasted for eight months.

sigh.eng_def: to breathe out slowly and noisily, expressing tiredness, sadness, pleasure, etc.
sigh.eg: She sighed deeply and sat down.

sigh.eng_def: If the wind sighs, it makes a long, soft sound as it moves through trees.
sigh.eg: I lay on my back, listening to the sound of the wind sighing in the trees.
He leaned back in his seat with a sigh.

sight.eg: If your sight is poor, you should not drive a car.

sight.eng_def: something that is in someone's view
sight.eg: The flowers at the annual flower show were a beautiful sight.

sight.eng_def: places of interest, especially to visitors
sight.eg: We spent a week in Rome looking at all the sights.
I never buy anything sight unseen.
Food is a darn/damn sight more expensive than it used to be.

sight.eng_def: a part of a gun or other device through which you look to help you aim at something
sight.eg: Make sure you line up the sights before you fire the gun.

sight.eng_def: to suddenly see something or someone
sight.eg: After days at sea, the sailors finally sighted land.

sightseeing.eng_def: the activity of visiting interesting places, especially by people on holiday
sightseeing.eg: We did some sightseeing in Paris.

sign.eng_def: to write your name, usually on a written or printed document, to show that you agree with its contents or have written or created it yourself
in sport, to make a legal written agreement to employ a player
sign.eg: The team has just signed a new player.

sign.eng_def: to give an order or information, or make a request, using hand and body movements
sign.eg: He signed for/to the waiter to bring him another drink.

sign.eng_def: to use sign language (= language used by people who cannot hear or talk)
a notice giving information, directions, a warning, etc.
a movement of the body that gives information or an instruction
sign.eg: She pointed to her watch as a sign that it was getting late and she wanted to leave.

sign.eng_def: something showing that something else exists or might happen or exist in the future
sign.eg: His inability to handle the situation is a sure sign of weakness.

sign.eng_def: a written or printed mark that has a standard meaning

signal.eng_def: an action, movement, or sound that gives information, a message, a warning, or an order
signal.eg: When she gave (them) the signal, they all cheered.

signal.eng_def: a series of electrical or radio waves that are sent to a radio or television in order to produce a sound, picture, or message
signal.chi_def: （用於傳輸聲音、圖像或其他資訊的）電波信號

signal.eng_def: something that shows that something else exists or is likely to happen
signal.eg: The loss is a clear signal of his deteriorating confidence.

signal.eng_def: equipment, especially on the side of a railway or road, often with lights, that tells drivers to stop, continue, or go more slowly
signal.chi_def: （尤指鐵路或公路上的）號誌燈

signal.eng_def: to make a movement, sound, flash, etc. that gives information or tells people what to do
signal.eg: Flashing lights on a parked car usually signal a warning (to other drivers).

signal.eng_def: to show that you intend or are ready to do something
signal.eg: The union has signalled that the workers will strike.

signature.eng_def: your name written by yourself, always in the same way, usually to show that something has been written or agreed by you

significance.eg: The discovery of the new drug is of great significance for/to people suffering from heart problems.
Do you think that look he gave you had any significance?

significant.eg: There has been a significant increase in the number of women students in recent years.
She looked at him across the table and gave him a significant smile.

signify.eng_def: to be a sign of something; to mean
signify.eg: Nobody really knows what the marks on the ancient stones signify.

signify.eng_def: to make something known; to show
signify.eg: She signified her agreement by nodding her head.

signify.eng_def: to have importance or to matter
signify.eg: Don't worry about being late - it doesn't signify.

silence.eng_def: a period without any sound; complete quiet
silence.eg: A loud crash of thunder broke the silence of the night.

silence.eng_def: a state of not speaking or writing or making a noise
silence.eg: The soldiers listened in silence as their captain gave the orders.

silence.eng_def: a period of time in which there is complete quiet or no speaking
silence.eg: Their conversation was punctuated by uncomfortable silences.

silence.eng_def: a state of refusing to talk about something or answer questions, or a state of not communicating
silence.chi_def: 拒絕談論（某事）；拒絕回答問題；不進行交流
silence.eg: My request for help was met with silence (= I received no answer).

silence.eng_def: to make someone or something be quiet
silence.eg: The teacher raised his voice to silence the class (= to make them stop talking).

silence.eng_def: to prevent someone from expressing their views or from criticizing or opposing someone
silence.chi_def: 阻止（某人）表達意見；壓制批評
silence.eg: Big companies file lawsuits to silence their critics.

silent.eg: The empty house was completely silent.
She whispered a silent prayer that her wounded brother would not die.

silent.eng_def: a setting on an electronic device that stops it from making a noise when it receives a message
silent.eg: The show's about to start so I'm putting my phone on silent.

silicon.eng_def: a grey chemical element that is found in rocks and sand and is used in making computers and other electronic machines

silk.eng_def: a delicate, soft type of cloth made from a thread produced by silkworms, or the thread itself
the brightly coloured shirts worn by jockeys (= people who ride horses in a race)
silk.chi_def: （騎手在賽馬時穿的）彩色絲綢賽馬服

silk.eng_def: a  QC : a lawyer of high rank in some countries

silkworm.eng_def: a type of caterpillar (= a form of young insect that is small, long, and has many legs) that produces threads of silk from which it makes a cocoon (= a covering for its body)

silly.eg: Don't do that, you silly boy!

silly.eng_def: embarrassed; afraid that people will laugh at you
silly.chi_def: 尷尬的；擔心被他人嘲笑的
silly.eg: I feel silly in this dress.

silly.chi_def: 不重要的；不嚴肅的；不實際的
silly.eg: She gets upset over such silly things.

silver.eng_def: a chemical element that is a valuable shiny, white metal, used for making cutlery (= knives, spoons, etc.), jewellery, coins, and decorative objects
silver.eg: We gave them a dish made of solid silver as a wedding present.

silver.eng_def: a small disc of silver, or a metal that looks like silver, that is given to the person who comes second in a competition, especially in a sport
silver.eg: Great Britain won (a) silver/a silver medal in the javelin.

silver.eng_def: made of silver, or of the colour of silver
to cover something, especially glass, with a thin layer of silver-coloured material in order to make a mirror
silver.chi_def: 給（窗戶等）鍍上銀色物質

similar.eng_def: looking or being almost, but not exactly, the same
similar.eg: My father and I have similar views on politics.

similarity.eng_def: the fact that people or things look or are the same
similarity.eg: I can see the similarity between you and your mother.

simmer.eng_def: to cook something liquid, or something with liquid in it, at a temperature slightly below boiling
simmer.eg: Leave the vegetables to simmer for a few minutes.

simmer.eng_def: If a disagreement or negative emotion simmers, it grows slowly stronger over a period of time and could become more serious at any moment.
simmer.eg: The strike has been simmering for weeks.

simple.eng_def: easy to understand or do; not difficult
simple.eg: The instructions were written in simple English.

simple.eng_def: used to describe the one important fact, truth, etc.
simple.eg: We didn't go swimming for the simple reason that the water was too cold.
I like simple food better than fancy dishes.

simple.eng_def: having or made of only one or a few parts
simple.eg: A hammer is a simple tool.

simple.eng_def: ordinary; traditional or natural rather than modern and complicated
simple.eg: He was just a simple fisherman.

simple.eng_def: A simple person does not have a normal level of intelligence.

simplicity.eng_def: the fact that something is easy to understand or do
simplicity.eg: The advantage of the plan is its simplicity.

simplicity.eng_def: the fact that something is ordinary, traditional, or natural, and not complicated
simplicity.eg: The old people led a life of great simplicity (= with few possessions and little money).

simplicity.eng_def: the fact that something is plain and has no decoration

simplify.eng_def: to make something less complicated and therefore easier to do or understand

simply.eng_def: completely or as much as possible
simply.eg: You look simply (= really) beautiful in that dress.
I don't like my job - I simply do it for the money.
He explained it as simply as he could, but the class still didn't understand.

simultaneous.eng_def: happening or being done at exactly the same time
simultaneous.eg: There were several simultaneous explosions in different cities.

sin.eng_def: the offence of breaking, or the breaking of, a religious or moral law
sin.chi_def: （違反宗教戒律或道德規範的）罪，罪過

sin.eng_def: to break a religious or moral law
sin.eg: Forgive me, Father, for I have sinned.

sin.chi_def: （加拿大）社會保險號（Social Insurance Number的縮寫）

since.eng_def: from a particular time in the past until a later time, or until now
since.eg: Emma went to work in New York a year ago, and we haven't seen her since.

since.eng_def: from a particular time in the past until a later time, or until now
since.eg: He hasn't won a game since last year.
Since we've got a few minutes to wait for the train, let's have a cup of coffee.

since.eng_def: from a particular time in the past until a later time, or until now
since.eg: I've been very busy since I came back from holiday.

sincere.eng_def: (of a person, feelings, or behaviour) not pretending or lying; honest
sincere.chi_def: （人、感情或行爲）真誠的，誠實的

sincerity.eg: The priest was a man of deep sincerity.

sing.eng_def: to make musical sounds with the voice, usually a tune with words
sing.eg: The children sang two songs by Schubert at the school concert.

sing.eng_def: to make or be filled with a (high) ringing sound
sing.eg: A bullet sang past the top of the soldier's head.

singer.eg: Bryn Terfel is a famous singer from Wales.

single.eg: He knocked his opponent down with a single blow.

single.eng_def: not married, or not having a romantic relationship with someone
considered on its own and separate from other things
single.eg: Patience is the single most important quality needed for this job.

single.eng_def: A baseball player singles by hitting a ball that allows him to reach first base.
a record or CD that has a main song and usually a small number of other songs on it
single.eg: Have you heard Lady Gaga's new single?

single.eng_def: in baseball, a hit that allows the player to reach first base
a game, especially in tennis, played between one player on one side and one on the other
people who are not married and do not have a romantic relationship with someone
a ticket for a journey to a place, but not for the return
single.eg: May I have a single to London, please.

singular.eng_def: of or relating to the form of a word used when talking or writing about one thing
of an unusual quality or standard; noticeable
singular.eg: It was a building of singular grace and beauty.

singular.eng_def: the form of a word used when talking or writing about one thing

sink.eng_def: to (cause something or someone to) go down below the surface or to the bottom of a liquid or soft substance
sink.eg: The Titanic was a passenger ship which sank (to the bottom of the ocean) in 1912.

sink.eng_def: to (cause something or someone to) fall or move to a lower level
sink.eg: The sun glowed red as it sank slowly below the horizon.

sink.eng_def: to hit a ball into a hole or pocket, especially in golf or snooker
sink.chi_def: （尤指在高爾夫球或撞球運動中）擊（球）進洞

sink.eng_def: to dig a hole in the ground, or to put something into a hole dug into the ground
sink.chi_def: 挖，掘（洞）；把…插入，把…埋入（洞裡）
sink.eg: Sinking more wells is the best way of supplying the population with clean drinking water.

sink.eng_def: to cause something to fail or be in trouble
sink.eg: This rain could sink our plans for the barbecue.

sink.eng_def: a bowl that is attached to the wall in a kitchen or bathroom in which you wash dishes or your hands, etc.
sink.chi_def: （廚房的）水槽，洗碗槽；（浴室的）洗臉盆

sip.eng_def: to drink, taking only a very small amount at a time
sip.eg: This tea is very hot, so sip it carefully.

sir.eng_def: used as a formal and polite way of speaking to a man, especially one who you are providing a service to or who is in a position of authority
sir.eg: Would you like to see the menu, sir?

sir.eng_def: sometimes used by children to address or refer to teachers who are men
sir.chi_def: （孩子對男性教師的稱呼）老師
sir.eg: Can I go to the toilet, sir?

sir.eng_def: used after the name of a man, especially one who is in a position of authority, in order to be polite or show respect
sir.chi_def: （用於男性、特別是權威人士的名字之後，用以表示禮貌或尊敬）先生

sir.eng_def: used to begin a formal letter to a man whose name you do not know. "Dear Sirs" is an old fashioned way of beginning a letter to a company.
sir.chi_def: 尊敬的先生（用於正式信函中稱呼不知姓名的男性收信人；Dear sirs，即尊敬的各位先生，為正式商務信函的舊式信首稱呼語）

sir.eng_def: used to begin a formal letter when you do not know if the person you are writing to is a man or a woman
sir.chi_def: 尊敬的先生或女士，敬啓者（用於正式信函中稱呼不知性別的收信人）

sir.eng_def: used as the title of a knight (= a man who has been given a rank of honour by a British king or queen), with a first name or with both first and family names, but never with just the family name
sir.chi_def: 爵士（用於名前或姓名前，但不只跟姓連用）

sister.eng_def: a girl or woman who has the same parents as another person
a girl or woman who treats you in the kind way that a sister would
sister.eg: Lynn's such a good friend - she's like a sister to me.

sister.eng_def: a woman who shares an interest with you, especially that of improving women's rights
sister.chi_def: （尤指在改善婦女權利方面）志同道合的姐妹

sister.eng_def: a female member of a religious group, especially a nun
a female nurse who is in charge of a department of a hospital
sister.eg: The sister told us that visiting hours were over.

sister.eng_def: belonging to a pair or group of similar and related things, such as businesses, usually owned or operated by the same person or organization

sit.eng_def: to (cause someone to) be in a position in which the lower part of the body is resting on a seat or other type of support, with the upper part of the body vertical
to be a model for a painter, photographer, etc.
sit.eg: Monet's wife sat for him many times.

sit.eng_def: (of an animal such as a dog) to move into a position with its back legs bent and its tail end on the ground
sit.eg: We're trying to train our dog to sit.

sit.eng_def: If a bird sits on its eggs, it covers them with its body to keep them warm before they hatch.
to stay in one place for a long time and not be used
sit.eg: The encyclopedia sits on my shelf at home, gathering dust.

sit.eng_def: to be in a particular position
sit.eg: The town sits at/in the bottom of a valley.

sit.eng_def: (of clothes) to fit someone in a particular way
sit.eg: That coat sits very well on you.

sit.eng_def: to hold an official meeting of a committee, court, etc.
sit.eg: The court will sit tomorrow morning.

sit.eng_def: to be a member of an official group
sit.chi_def: 成爲（官方組織的）成員；（在…中）任職
sit.eg: I'm going to be sitting on the committee for one more year.
After I've sat my exams, I'm going on holiday.

sit.chi_def: 代人臨時照管孩子，當臨時保姆
sit.eg: I'm sitting my sister's kids this Saturday.

site.eng_def: a place where something is, was, or will be built, or where something happened, is happening, or will happen
site.chi_def: （建築物的）地點，位置；建築工地；（某事發生的）地點，現場

site.eng_def: inside a factory, office building, etc.
site.chi_def: 在（工廠、辦公樓等的）內部
site.eg: There are two restaurants on site.

site.eng_def: the piece of ground on which you can put up a tent, park a caravan, etc.
site.eg: We chose a large, level site for our tent.

site.eng_def: to exist or be built in a particular place
site.eg: The company's head office is sited in Rome.

situation.eng_def: the set of things that are happening and the conditions that exist at a particular time and place

situation.eg: My sister has a good situation as a teacher in the local school.

situation.eng_def: the position of something, especially a town, building, etc.
situation.eg: The house's situation in the river valley is perfect.

six.eg: Look for a bus with a number six on the front of it.

six.eng_def: in cricket, six runs (= points) scored when the player hits the ball to the edge of the playing area without it touching the ground first

sixteen.eg: We have got sixteen (people) coming for lunch.

size.eng_def: how large or small something or someone is
size.eg: We are concerned about the size of our debt.

size.eng_def: one of the standard measures according to which goods are made or sold
a substance like glue that gives stiffness and a hard, shiny surface to cloth, paper, etc.
size.chi_def: （使衣服、紙張等堅挺的）漿料，膠料

size.eng_def: to cover or treat cloth, paper, etc. with size
size.chi_def: 給（衣服、紙張等）上漿，給…塗膠

skate.eng_def: a special boot with a thin metal bar attached to the bottom that you wear to move quickly on ice, or a boot with four small wheels fixed to the bottom so that you can move over a hard surface
a large, flat sea fish that can be eaten as food
skate.chi_def: 鰩魚（一種扁體海魚，可食用）

skate.eng_def: to move, or make a particular movement on a surface, using skates
skate.eg: The ice on the river is thick enough to skate on/across/over.

skeleton.eng_def: the frame of bones supporting a human or animal body
skeleton.eg: We found an old sheep skeleton up on the cliffs.

skeleton.eng_def: the most basic form or structure of something
skeleton.eg: The skeleton of my book is written/My book is in skeleton form - now I just have to add the details.

skeptical.eng_def: doubting that something is true or useful
skeptical.eg: Many experts remain skeptical about/of his claims.

sketch.eng_def: a simple, quickly-made drawing that does not have many details
sketch.eg: My mother made a (pencil) sketch of my brother reading a book.

sketch.eng_def: a short written or spoken story that does not have many details
a short, humorous part of a longer show on stage, television, or radio
sketch.eg: I thought the sketch about celebrity chefs was really funny.

sketch.eng_def: to make a sketch of something
sketch.eg: The art students were told to sketch the landscape.

ski.eng_def: one of a pair of long, flat narrow pieces of wood or plastic that curve up at the front and are fastened to boots so that the wearer can move quickly and easily over snow
to move over snow on skis

skill.eng_def: an ability to do an activity or job well, especially because you have practised it

skilled.eng_def: having the abilities needed to do an activity or job well
skilled.eg: My mother is very skilled at/in dressmaking.
