skilled.eng_def: Skilled work needs someone who has had special training to do it
skilled.chi_def: （工作）需要特殊技能的，需要經過專門訓練的
skilled.eg: Nursing is a highly skilled job.

skilled.eng_def: people who have been trained for a job

skim.eng_def: to move quickly just above a surface without touching it
skim.eg: The birds skimmed (across/along/over) the tops of the waves.

skim.eng_def: to throw a flat stone horizontally over water so that it touches and rises off the surface several times
skim.eg: We watched a child skimming stones across the lake.

skim.eng_def: to read or consider something quickly in order to understand the main points, without studying it in detail
skim.eg: I've only skimmed (through/over) his letter; I haven't read it carefully yet.

skim.eng_def: to remove something solid from the surface of a liquid
skim.eg: Strain the cooking liquid and skim off the fat.

skim.eng_def: to secretly use a piece of equipment that records someone's credit card details in order to use their credit card account illegally

skin.eng_def: the natural outer layer that covers a person, animal, fruit, etc.
the skin of an animal that has been removed from the body, with or without the hair or fur
skin.chi_def: 被剝下的（帶或不帶毛髮的）獸皮
skin.eg: Native Americans used to trade skins .
The bullet pierced the skin of the aircraft.

skin.eng_def: a thin surface that forms on some liquids, such as paint, when they are left in the air, or others, such as heated milk, when they are left to cool
skin.chi_def: （某些液體置於空氣中或冷卻後形成的）膜，薄層

skin.eng_def: the pictures, designs, colours, etc. that appear on the screen of a mobile phone or other device and can be changed by the user
skin.chi_def: 面板（電腦程式的一部分，可隨意改變以在螢幕上顯示不同的圖片、圖案、顏色等）
skin.eg: Many electronic devices let you create your own skins.
We had no umbrellas so we got soaked to the skin in the pouring rain.
I don't worry about what he says - I have a very thick skin.

skin.eng_def: to remove the skin of something
skin.eg: The hunters skinned the deer they had killed.

skinny.eg: You should eat more - you're too skinny.

skinny.eng_def: low in fat; used especially of coffee made with low-fat milk
narrow and fitting closely to the body
the true information about someone or something
skinny.chi_def: （有關…的）確切消息，真實情況，貼身資訊
skinny.eg: Get the skinny on hundreds of celebs in our "People Profiles" section.
A white shirt and skinnies is always a good look.

skip.eng_def: to move lightly and quickly, making a small jump after each step
skip.eg: She watched her little granddaughter skip down the path.

skip.eng_def: to jump lightly over a rope that is held in both your hands, or by two other people, and turned repeatedly under your legs and over your head as exercise or a game
skip.eg: Sports players often train by skipping.

skip.eng_def: to leave one thing or place, especially quickly, in order to go to another
skip.eg: This part of the book isn't very interesting, so I'm going to skip (over) it.

skip.eng_def: to not do or not have something that you usually do or that you should do; to avoid
skip.eg: I'm trying to lose weight, so I'm skipping (= not eating) lunch today.

skip.eng_def: to throw a flat stone horizontally over water so that it touches and rises off the surface several times
skip.eg: We watched a child skipping stones across the lake.

skip.eng_def: a large metal container into which people put unwanted objects or building or garden waste, and which is brought to and taken away from a place by a special truck when people ask for it
a small, light, dancing or jumping step
skip.eg: She gave a little skip of joy.

skirt.eng_def: a piece of clothing for women and girls that hangs from the waist and does not have legs
skirt.eg: She wore a denim skirt and a white shirt.

skirt.eng_def: an outer covering or part to protect particular machines
to go around the edge of something
skirt.chi_def: 位於…的邊緣；環繞…的四周；沿…的邊緣走
skirt.eg: Take the road which skirts (round) the town, not the one which goes through it.

skirt.eng_def: to avoid discussing a subject or problem, usually because there are difficulties that you do not want to deal with
skirt.chi_def: 避開，繞開（某話題或問題）
skirt.eg: The government has been accused of skirting round the issue of torture.

skull.eng_def: the bones of the head that surround the brain and give the head its shape
skull.eg: The soldiers discovered a pile of human skulls and bones.

sky.eng_def: the area above the earth, in which clouds, the sun, etc. can be seen
the sky in a particular state or place
sky.chi_def: （某種天氣狀況下或某地的）天空
sky.eg: For weeks we had cloudless blue skies.

skyscraper.eng_def: a very tall modern building, usually in a city

slam.eng_def: to (cause to) move against a hard surface with force and usually a loud noise
slam.eg: The wind made the door/window slam (shut).
Although the reviewers slammed the play, the audience loved it.
The door shut with a slam.

slang.eng_def: very informal language that is usually spoken rather than written, used especially by particular groups of people
to attack with angry, uncontrolled language
slang.eg: The players started slanging each other in the middle of the game.

slap.eng_def: a quick hit with the flat part of the hand or other flat object
slap.eg: She gave her son a slap for behaving badly.

slap.eng_def: an action that insults or upsets someone
slap.eg: It was a real slap in the face for him when she refused to go out to dinner with him.

slap.eng_def: the action of hitting someone in a friendly way on the back in order to show praise for something they have done
slap.chi_def: 友好地輕拍背部（表示贊許或表揚）
slap.eg: He won - give him a slap on the back.
The police officer gave Minna a slap on the wrist for not wearing her seat belt.
I'm just going to put a bit of slap on.
The football player kicked the ball slap into the middle of the net.

slap.eng_def: to hit someone or something with the flat part of the hand or other flat object

slash.eng_def: to cut with a sharp blade using a quick, strong movement
slash.eg: The museum was broken into last night and several paintings were slashed.

slash.eng_def: to very much reduce something, such as money or jobs
slash.chi_def: 大幅削減，大幅減少（金錢、工作等）
slash.eg: Prices have been slashed by 50 percent!

slash.eng_def: the symbol / used in writing to separate letters, numbers, or words
slash.eg: You often write a slash between alternatives, for example, "and/or".

slash.eng_def: a fast, long movement to hit something
slash.eg: Ben took a wild slash at the ball and luckily managed to hit it.

slash.eng_def: a decorative opening in a piece of clothing, often with a different colour showing through it
slash.chi_def: （衣服上的）裝飾性開叉（常有不同的顏色透過開叉顯示出來）
slash.eg: My new dress is pale blue, with a dark blue slash in the sleeves.

slash.eng_def: the act of going to the toilet and urinating

slaughter.eng_def: the killing of many people cruelly and unfairly, especially in a war
slaughter.eg: Hardly anyone in the town escaped the slaughter when the rebels were defeated.

slaughter.eng_def: the killing of animals for meat
slaughter.eg: The geese are being fattened for slaughter.

slaughter.eng_def: an occasion when one team is very easily defeated by the other
slaughter.chi_def: 一方大敗的比賽，一邊倒的比賽
slaughter.eg: Saturday's game was an absolute slaughter.

slaughter.eng_def: to cruelly and unfairly kill a lot of people
slaughter.eg: Thousands of people were slaughtered in the civil war.

slaughter.eng_def: to kill an animal for meat
slaughter.eg: The animals are slaughtered in spring.

slave.eng_def: a person who is legally owned by someone else and has to work for that person
slave.eg: Black slaves used to work on the cotton plantations of the southern United States.

slave.eng_def: to work very hard at something
slave.eg: We slaved away all week at the report.

slavery.eng_def: the activity of having slaves or the condition of being a slave
slavery.eg: Slavery still exists in many parts of the world.

slay.eng_def: to kill in a violent way
(used especially in newspapers) to murder someone
slay.chi_def: （尤用於報紙新聞報道）謀殺，殺害
slay.eg: He was found slain in an alley two blocks from his apartment.

sled.eng_def: an object used for travelling over snow and ice with long, narrow strips of wood or metal under it instead of wheels. It can be either a low frame, or a vehicle like a carriage pulled by horses or dogs.
to ride or travel on snow using a sled

sledge.eng_def: an object used for travelling over snow and ice with long, narrow strips of wood or metal under it instead of wheels. It can be either a low frame, or a vehicle like a carriage pulled by horses or dogs.
to ride or travel on snow using a sledge

sleep.eng_def: the resting state in which the body is not active and the mind is unconscious
sleep.eg: I must get some sleep - I'm exhausted.
I couldn't get to sleep at all last night I was so worried.
You must be tired after all that driving - why don't you have a little sleep?

sleep.eng_def: a yellowish substance sometimes found in the corners of the eyes after sleeping
to be in the state of rest when your eyes are closed, your body is not active, and your mind is unconscious
sleep.eg: I couldn't sleep because of all the noise next door.

sleep.eng_def: If a vehicle, tent, etc. sleeps a particular number of people, it provides enough space or beds for that number of people to be able to sleep in it.
sleep.chi_def: （車輛、帳篷等）躺得下，可供…睡覺

sleep.eg: I went to bed early and slept like a log.

sleep.eng_def: to delay making a decision about something important until the next day so that you have time to consider it carefully
sleep.chi_def: 把…留到第二天再作決定，延遲對…作出決定
sleep.eg: Can I sleep on it, and tell you my decision tomorrow?

sleep.eng_def: to sleep outside because you have no home and no money
sleep.eg: Hundreds of kids are sleeping rough on the streets of the capital.

sleepy.eng_def: A sleepy place is quiet and without much activity or excitement.
sleepy.eg: They retired to a sleepy little town in the south of Italy.

sleeve.eng_def: the part of a piece of clothing that covers some or all of the arm

sleeve.eg: Can you put the record back in its sleeve, please?

sleeve.eng_def: a tube-shaped covering to protect a part of a machine

sleigh.eng_def: a type of sledge pulled by animals, especially horses or dogs

slender.eng_def: thin and delicate, often in a way that is attractive
slender.eg: He put his hands around her slender waist.
a man of slender means (= without much money)

slice.eng_def: a flat, often thin, piece of food that has been cut from a larger piece
a part of something, such as an amount of money
slice.eg: We agreed before we did the deal that we'd both take an equal slice of the profit.

slice.eng_def: a kitchen utensil with a wide blade, used for serving pieces of food
in tennis, the action of hitting the bottom of the ball so that it does not bounce very high when it hits the ground
slice.eg: That wonderful backhand slice of Maria's sends the ball where her opponent just can't reach it.

slice.eng_def: in the sports of golf and baseball, the action of hitting a ball so that it goes to one side rather than straight in front
slice.chi_def: （高爾夫球和棒球運動中）斜切（球），削（球）

slice.eng_def: to cut something into thin, flat pieces
slice.eg: Slice the mushrooms thinly and fry in butter.

slice.eng_def: to easily cut into or through something with a sharp knife
slice.eg: He screamed as the blade sliced into his leg.

slice.eng_def: in the sports of golf and baseball, to hit a ball so that it goes to one side rather than straight in front
slice.chi_def: （高爾夫球和棒球運動中）斜切（球），削球
slice.eg: Sara sliced the ball, sending it a hundred yards or so to the left.

slice.eng_def: If you slice the ball in a game of tennis, you hit the bottom of the ball so that it does not bounce very high when it hits the ground.

slide.eng_def: to (cause to) move easily and without interruption over a surface
slide.eg: When I was little I used to like sliding on the polished floor in my socks.

slide.eng_def: to go into a worse state, often through lack of control or care
slide.eg: The dollar slid against other major currencies.

slide.eng_def: a sudden movement of a large mass of mud (= wet earth) or rock down a hill
a structure for children to play on which has a slope for them to slide down and usually a set of steps leading up to the slope
a part that moves easily backwards and forwards on an instrument or machine
the process of moving into a worse state, often through lack of control or care
slide.chi_def: （通常因為缺乏管理或關注而）不知不覺陷入（惡劣的狀態）
slide.eg: The government must take measures, he said, to halt the country's slide into recession.

slide.eng_def: a small piece of photographic film in a frame that, when light is passed through it, shows a larger image on a screen or plain surface
a small piece of glass on which you put something in order to look at it through a microscope
short form of hair slide UK
slide.chi_def: (女子戴的）小髮卡（hair slide 的簡稱）

slight.eg: "Does it worry you?" "Not in the slightest."
Like most long-distance runners she is very slight.

slight.eng_def: to insult someone by ignoring them or treating them as if not important
slight.eg: I felt slighted when my boss thanked everyone but me for their hard work.

slight.eng_def: an action that insults a person because someone fails to pay attention to them or to treat them with the respect that they deserve
slight.eg: I regarded her failure to acknowledge my greeting as a slight.

slim.eg: They only have a slim chance of winning (= it's unlikely that they will win).

slim.eng_def: to try to get thinner by eating less food and doing more exercise
slim.eg: You don't have much lunch - are you slimming?

slim.eng_def: East African for AIDS (= a serious disease that destroys the body's ability to fight infection)
slim.chi_def: 瘦病，愛滋病（東非對該種疾病的稱呼）

slip.eng_def: to move out of the correct position
slip.eg: Her hat had slipped over one eye.

slip.eng_def: to go somewhere or put something somewhere quickly, often so that you are not noticed
slip.chi_def: 溜走；迅速地做；悄悄地做
slip.eg: Just slip out of the room while nobody's looking.

slip.eng_def: to go into a worse state, often because of lack of control or care
slip.eg: Productivity in the factory has slipped noticeably in the last year.

slip.eng_def: to get free from, leave, or escape something

slip.eg: The dollar slipped against the Japanese yen.
She's made one or two slips - mainly spelling errors - but it's basically well written.

slip.eng_def: an act of falling or sliding
slip.eg: One slip meant a long tumble to the rocks below.

slip.eng_def: an occasion when something becomes worse
slip.eg: A slip in the value of the U.S. dollar helped push prices higher.

slip.eng_def: a piece of underwear for a woman or girl that is like a dress or skirt
a place where a boat or ship can be parked, between two piers
slip.chi_def: 兩座碼頭之間可停船的水面

slip.eng_def: small and thin, usually because of being young
slip.eg: I knew her when she was a slip of a girl.

slip.eng_def: to escape from someone who is following or chasing you

slipper.eng_def: a type of soft, comfortable shoe for wearing inside the house

slippery.eng_def: If something is slippery, it is wet or smooth so that it slides easily or causes something to slide.
Someone who is slippery cannot be trusted.
slippery.eg: He's as slippery as an eel - you can never get a straight answer out of him.

slogan.eng_def: a short easily remembered phrase, especially one used to advertise an idea or a product

slope.eng_def: a surface that lies at an angle to the horizontal so that some points on it are higher than others
slope.eg: The roof is at a slope (= at an angle to a horizontal surface) of 30°.

slope.eng_def: (part of) the side of a hill or mountain
to be at an angle to the horizontal
slope.eg: The path slopes up/down to the house.

sloppy.eng_def: (of a substance) more liquid than it should be, often in a way that is unpleasant
sloppy.eg: The batter was a bit sloppy so I added some more flour.

sloppy.eng_def: not taking care or making an effort
sloppy.eg: Spelling mistakes always look sloppy in a formal letter.

sloppy.eng_def: Sloppy clothes are large, loose, and do not look neat.
sloppy.eg: At home I tend to wear big sloppy sweaters and jeans.

sloppy.eng_def: expressing feelings of love in a way that is silly or embarrassing

slot.eng_def: a long, narrow hole, especially one for putting coins into or for fitting a separate piece into
slot.eg: I put my money in the slot and pressed the button but nothing came out.

slot.eng_def: an amount of time that is officially allowed for a single event in a planned order of activities or events
slot.eg: The programme will occupy that half-hour slot before the six o'clock news.

slot.eng_def: to put something into a slot or fit together using slots
slot.eg: The legs of the chair are meant to slot into the holes at the back.

slow.eng_def: moving, happening, or doing something without much speed
used to describe a film, book, play, etc. that does not have much excitement and action
slow.chi_def: （電影、書籍、戲劇等）情節拖泥帶水的，索然無趣的
slow.eg: His films are so slow they send me to sleep.

slow.eng_def: A person might be described as slow if they are not very clever and do not understand or notice things quickly.
slow.eg: I feel so slow when I'm with Andrew - he's so much brighter than me.

slow.eng_def: If a clock or watch is slow, it shows a time that is earlier than the real time.
slow.eg: That clock is ten minutes slow.

slow.eng_def: to reduce speed or activity, or to make something do this
slow.eg: Business development has slowed in response to the recession.

slum.eng_def: a very poor and crowded area, especially of a city
slum.chi_def: （尤指城市中的）貧民窟，棚戶區

slum.eng_def: a very untidy or dirty place
slum.eg: This house would be an absolute slum if I wasn't here to clean it.

slum.eng_def: to spend time in conditions that are much less good than the standard that you are used to
slum.chi_def: 過窮日子，過簡樸的生活
slum.eg: We ran out of money on holiday and had to slum it in cheap hostels.

slump.eng_def: (of prices, values, or sales) to fall suddenly
slump.chi_def: （價格、價值或銷售額）猛跌，突然下降
slump.eg: The value of property has slumped.

slump.eng_def: to sit or fall heavily and suddenly
slump.eg: She slumped into the chair, exhausted.

slump.eng_def: a fall in the price, value, sales, etc. of something
slump.chi_def: （價格、價值、銷售額等的）猛跌，暴跌
slump.eg: There's been a slump in the demand for new cars.

slump.eng_def: a period when an industry or the economy is in a bad state and there is a lot of unemployment

sly.eng_def: deceiving people in a clever way in order to get what you want
sly.eg: He's a sly old devil - I wouldn't trust him with my money.
"You'll find out eventually," said Mary, with a sly smile.

sly.eng_def: If you do something on the sly, you do it secretly because you should not be doing it.
sly.eg: He drives his mother's car on the sly while she's at work.

smack.eng_def: to hit someone or something forcefully with the flat inside part of your hand, producing a short, loud noise, especially as a way of punishing a child
smack.chi_def: （尤指作爲懲戒孩子的方式）掌摑，打

smack.eng_def: to hit something hard against something else
smack.eg: I smacked my head on the corner of the shelf.

smack.eng_def: a hit from someone's flat hand as a punishment
smack.eg: You're going to get a smack on the bottom if you don't stop throwing your toys.

smack.eng_def: a hit given with the fist (= closed hand)
smack.eg: I gave him a smack on the jaw.
She slammed her briefcase down on the desk with a smack.
a big smack on the lips
How long has she been on smack?

smack.eng_def: exactly in a place or a situation
smack.eg: She lives smack in the middle of Shanghai.

smack.eng_def: directly and forcefully, producing a short, loud noise
smack.eg: I wasn't looking where I was going and walked smack into a lamppost.

small.eng_def: little in size or amount when compared with what is typical or average
A small child is a very young child that is older than a baby.
small.eg: Taking care of small children can be very tiring.

small.eng_def: limited in the amount of an activity
small.eg: The government should give more help to small businessmen (= people whose businesses are of a limited size).

small.eng_def: not very important or not likely to cause problems
small.chi_def: 不重要的；不會造成麻煩的
small.eg: She just made a couple of small mistakes in the test.
Talking to her makes me feel small.

small.eng_def: Small letters are not capital letters.
small.eg: The poet e. e. cummings wrote his name with small letters, not capital letters.
The instructions are printed so small I can hardly read them.

small.eng_def: the middle of the lower back
small.eg: I have a pain in the small of my back.

small.eng_def: underwear, especially when being washed or about to be washed
small.eg: Do you have any smalls that need washing?

smallpox.eng_def: an extremely infectious disease that causes a fever, spots on the skin, and often death

smart.eng_def: having a clean, tidy, and stylish appearance
smart.eg: Guy looks very smart in his new suit, doesn't he?

smart.eng_def: A place or event that is smart attracts fashionable, stylish, or rich people.
intelligent, or able to think quickly or intelligently in difficult situations
smart.eg: Maddy's teacher says she's one of the smartest kids in the class.

smart.eng_def: done quickly with a lot of force or effort
smart.eg: She gave him a smart smack on the bottom.

smart.eng_def: A smart machine, weapon, etc. uses computers to make it work so that it is able to act in an independent way.
smart.eg: Until the advent of smart weapons, repeated attacks were needed to ensure the destruction of targets.

smart.eng_def: not showing respect, especially when making a funny remark
smart.chi_def: （尤指在開玩笑時）缺乏尊重的
smart.eg: Don't get smart with me, young lady!

smart.eng_def: to hurt with a sharp pain
smart.eg: My eyes were smarting from the onions.

smart.eng_def: to feel upset and angry because of failure or criticism
smart.chi_def: （因失敗或遭批評而）感到不快，憤怒
smart.eg: The police are still smarting from their failure to prevent the robbery.

smash.eng_def: to cause something to break noisily into a lot of small pieces
smash.eg: Rioters ran through the city, smashing windows and looting shops.

smash.eng_def: to cause something to move with great force against something hard, usually causing damage or injury
smash.chi_def: 猛撞，猛衝，猛擊（通常造成破壞或傷害）
smash.eg: Several boats were smashed against the rocks during the storm.

smash.eng_def: in tennis or volleyball, to hit the ball down towards the ground quickly and forcefully
smash.chi_def: （網球運動中）打高壓球，猛扣（球）

smash.eng_def: to defeat someone or to destroy something completely
smash.eg: The country's government said it would do whatever was necessary to smash the rebellion.

smash.eng_def: to do much better than the best or fastest result recorded previously
smash.eg: Petersen smashed the 400 metres record by over half a second.

smash.eng_def: the sound of something being smashed
smash.eg: I was woken by the smash of glass.

smash.eng_def: the sound of something smashing against something
smash.eg: The cars collided with a loud smash.

smash.eng_def: in tennis or volleyball, a powerful downward hit that sends the ball forcefully over the net
an extremely popular and successful song, play, or film
smash.chi_def: 大獲成功的歌曲（或戲劇、電影）
smash.eg: This CD contains all the latest smash hits.

smell.eng_def: to have a particular quality that others can notice with their noses
to notice or discover something using the nose
to know about or be aware of a situation without having to be told about it
smell.eg: Brenda can smell trouble a mile off (= a long time in advance).

smell.eng_def: to have the ability to notice or discover that a substance is present by using your nose
smell.eg: Humans can't smell as well as dogs.

smell.eng_def: the characteristic of something that can be recognized or noticed using the nose
the particular character or feeling that someone or something has
smell.eg: She's still enjoying the sweet smell (= pleasant experience) of success after her victory in the world championships.

smell.eng_def: the ability to notice or discover that a substance is present by using your nose
smell.eg: Smell is one of the five senses.

smell.eng_def: the act of putting your nose near something and breathing in so that you can discover its characteristics with your nose
smell.eg: Have a smell of this perfume.

smile.eng_def: a happy or friendly expression on the face in which the ends of the mouth curve up slightly, often with the lips moving apart so that the teeth can be seen
smile.eg: Amy had a big/broad smile on her face.

smile.eng_def: to make a happy or friendly expression in which the corners of your mouth curve up
smile.eg: He smiled and shook my hand.

smile.eng_def: to express or say something with a smile
smile.eg: He smiled his congratulations and left without another word.

smog.eng_def: a mixture of smoke, gases, and chemicals, especially in cities, that makes the atmosphere difficult to breathe and harmful for health
smog.eg: Smog is a major problem in Athens.

smoke.eng_def: the grey, black, or white mixture of gas and very small pieces of carbon that is produced when something burns

smoke.eg: Because of the fire, hundreds of houses went up in smoke.

smoke.eng_def: Something that goes up in smoke fails to produce the result that was wanted.
smoke.chi_def: 未達到預期的效果，化爲泡影
smoke.eg: When the business went bankrupt, 20 years of hard work went up in smoke.

smoke.eng_def: the act of smoking a cigarette
smoke.eg: I really enjoy a smoke at the end of a meal.
Would you buy me some smokes while you're out?

smoke.eng_def: any large city, especially London, Sydney, or Melbourne
smoke.chi_def: 大城市（尤指倫敦、雪梨或墨爾本）
smoke.eg: He was a young lad of 16 when he first came to the big smoke.

smoke.eng_def: to breathe smoke into the mouth and usually lungs from a cigarette, pipe, etc.
smoke.eg: Do you mind if I smoke?

smoke.eng_def: to produce smoke as a result of industrial activity or of something such as an electrical fault
smoke.eg: The skyline is dominated by smoking factory chimneys.

smoke.eng_def: to preserve meat, fish, or cheese using smoke from burning wood
smoke.eg: People in Egypt were salting, drying, and smoking fish and meat 6,000 years ago.

smooth.eng_def: having a surface or consisting of a substance that is perfectly regular and has no holes, lumps, or areas that rise or fall suddenly
happening without any sudden changes, interruption, or difficulty
smooth.eg: We had a very smooth flight with no turbulence at all.

smooth.eng_def: having a pleasant flavour that is not sour or bitter
smooth.eg: This coffee is incredibly smooth and rich.

smooth.eng_def: very polite, confident, and able to persuade people, but in a way that is not sincere
smooth.eg: The deputy director is so smooth that many of his colleagues distrust him.

smooth.eng_def: to move your hands across something in order to make it flat
smooth.eg: He straightened his tie nervously and smoothed (down) his hair.

smooth.eng_def: to remove difficulties and make something easier to do or achieve
smooth.eg: We encourage parents to help smooth their children's way through school.

smooth.eng_def: to cover the surface of something with a liquid or soft substance, using gentle rubbing movements
smooth.eg: Pour some oil into the palm of your hand and then smooth it over your arms and neck.

smother.eng_def: to kill someone by covering their face so that they cannot breathe
smother.eg: They threatened to smother the animals with plastic bags.

smother.eng_def: to kill something by covering it and preventing it from receiving the substances and conditions it needs for life
smother.eg: Snow soon smothered the last of the blooms.

smother.eng_def: to stop a fire from burning by covering it with something that prevents air from reaching it
smother.eg: I threw a blanket over the stove to smother the flames.

smother.eng_def: to prevent something from developing or growing freely
smother.eg: The latest violence has smothered any remaining hopes for an early peace agreement.

smother.eng_def: to give someone too much love and attention so that they do not feel independent or free
smother.eg: I think she broke off their engagement because she felt smothered by him.

smuggle.eng_def: to take things or people to or from a place secretly and often illegally
smuggle.eg: She was caught trying to smuggle 26 kilos of heroin out of/into the country.

snack.eng_def: a small amount of food that is eaten between meals, or a very small meal
snack.eg: I had a huge lunch, so I'll only need a snack for dinner.

snack.eng_def: to eat small amounts of food between meals

snail.eng_def: a small creature with a soft, wet body and a round shell, that moves very slowly and often eats garden plants

snake.eng_def: a reptile with a long body and no legs
snake.eg: He's terrified of being bitten by a snake.

snake.eng_def: an unpleasant person who cannot be trusted
to move along a route that includes a lot of twists or bends
snake.eg: The river snakes through some of the most spectacular countryside in France.

snap.eng_def: to cause something that is thin to break suddenly and quickly with a cracking sound
snap.chi_def: 突然折斷，哢嚓一聲折斷
snap.eg: You'll snap that ruler if you bend it too far.

snap.eng_def: to suddenly become unable to control a strong feeling, especially anger
snap.chi_def: 突然無法控制情感，突然發作（尤指動怒）
snap.eg: When she asked me to postpone my trip to help her move to her new house, I just snapped (= got angry).

snap.eng_def: to move into a position quickly, producing a short noise as if breaking
snap.eg: Tendons store elastic energy by stretching and then snapping back into shape like rubber bands.

snap.eng_def: to quickly return to a previous place or condition
snap.eg: After substantial losses last year, the company has snapped back to profitability (= started making profits again).

snap.eng_def: If something snaps shut or is snapped shut, it closes quickly with a sudden sharp sound.
snap.eg: She snapped her book shut and got up to leave.

snap.eng_def: If an animal snaps, it tries to bite someone.
snap.eg: The guard dog was snarling and snapping behind the fence.

snap.eng_def: to say something suddenly in an angry way
snap.eg: There's no need to snap at me - it's not my fault that you lost your wallet.

snap.eng_def: to take a lot of photographs quickly
snap.eg: He was arrested for snapping photos of a military parade.

snap.eng_def: to fasten using two small pieces of metal or plastic, one of which is pushed into the other
snap.chi_def: 把（兩片金屬或塑膠片）扣上

snap.eng_def: a sudden loud sound like something breaking or closing
snap.chi_def: 喀嚓聲；突然折斷（或闔上）的聲音
snap.eg: She broke the stick over her knee with a loud snap.

snap.eng_def: a small piece of metal or plastic used to fasten clothes, with two usually round parts, one of which is pushed into the other
an informal photograph that is not very skilful or artistic
a card game in which the players compete to call out the word "snap" when they see two cards that have the same value
snap.chi_def: 呼「同」牌遊戲（一種紙牌遊戲，玩家搶先看到有兩張相同的牌時呼「同」）

snap.eng_def: something that can be done without any difficulty
snap.eg: "Will you finish on time?" "Sure thing. It's a snap."

snap.eng_def: in American football, the act of passing the ball backward to start play
done suddenly without allowing time for careful thought or preparation
snap.chi_def: 匆忙的；不加思索的；不做準備的
snap.eg: He always makes snap decisions and never thinks about their consequences.

snap.eng_def: "Snap!" is what you say in the game of snap when two cards of the same value have been played.
something that you say when you notice that two things are the same
snap.chi_def: （發現兩件事物相同時所說）太巧了！
snap.eg: Snap! We're wearing the same shirts!

snare.eng_def: a device for catching small animals and birds, usually with a rope or wire that tightens around the animal
a trick or situation that deceives you or involves you in some problem that you do not know about
snare.eg: The legal system is full of snares for those who are not wary.

snare.eng_def: to catch an animal using a snare
snare.eg: We used to snare small birds such as sparrows and robins.

snarl.eng_def: (especially of dogs) to make a deep, rough sound while showing the teeth, usually in anger or (of people) to speak or say something angrily and forcefully
snarl.chi_def: （尤指狗）齜牙低吼；（人）咆哮，吼叫
snarl.eg: The dogs started to snarl at each other so I had to separate them.

snarl.eng_def: to become twisted together and difficult to separate; to make something become twisted together
snarl.eg: The yarn snarled as she unwound it.

snarl.eng_def: a deep, rough sound, usually made in anger
snarl.eg: The dog gave a low snarl so I quickly drew my hand back.

snarl.eng_def: an untidy mass of things that are twisted together
snarl.eg: She tried to comb the snarls out of her daughter's long hair.

snatch.eng_def: to take hold of something suddenly and roughly
snatch.eg: He snatched the photos out of my hand before I had a chance to look at them.

snatch.eng_def: to take something or someone away by force
snatch.eg: The six-year-old girl was snatched from a playground and her body was found two days later.

snatch.eng_def: to do or get something quickly because you only have a short amount of time
snatch.eg: Maybe you'll be able to snatch a couple of hours' sleep before dinner.

snatch.eng_def: the action of trying to take something quickly and forcefully
snatch.eg: I felt someone behind me make a snatch at my bag.
I tried to hear what they were saying, but I only managed to catch a few snatches of conversation.

sneak.eng_def: to go somewhere secretly, or to take someone or something somewhere secretly
sneak.chi_def: 偷偷地走，潛行；偷帶，偷拿
sneak.eg: I managed to sneak in through the back door while she wasn't looking.

sneak.eng_def: to secretly tell someone in authority, especially a teacher, that someone else has done something bad, often in order to cause trouble
sneak.chi_def: 告密；（尤指向老師）打小報告
sneak.eg: She was always sneaking on other kids in the class.

sneak.eng_def: to look at someone or something quickly and secretly
sneak.eg: I noticed him sneak a look at what I was writing.

sneak.eng_def: a person who tells people in authority when someone else does something bad
sneak.eg: You told Mrs Cooper that it was me who tipped the paint over, didn't you - you nasty little sneak!

sneaker.eng_def: a type of light, comfortable shoe that is suitable for playing sports

sneaky.eng_def: doing things in a secret and unfair way
sneaky.chi_def: 偷偷摸摸的；鬼鬼祟祟的

sneaky.eng_def: used to describe something you do, eat, or drink especially when you do it without telling anyone or when you should not really do it
sneaky.eg: She snuck out for a sneaky cigarette.

sneer.eng_def: to talk about or look at someone or something in an unkind way that shows you do not respect or approve of him, her, or it
sneer.eg: You may sneer, but a lot of people like this kind of music.

sneer.eng_def: an unkind expression on your face that shows you do not respect or approve of someone or something
sneer.eg: "How much did you say you earned last year?" she said with a sneer.

sneeze.eng_def: When you sneeze, air and often small drops of liquid suddenly come out of your nose and mouth in a way you cannot control.
sneeze.eg: Cats make him sneeze - I think he's allergic to them.

sneeze.eng_def: an act or sound of sneezing
sneeze.eg: He has all the classic symptoms of a cold - the coughs and sneezes and the sore throat.

sniff.eng_def: to smell something by taking air in through your nose
sniff.eg: He sniffed his socks to see if they needed washing.

sniff.eng_def: to take air in quickly through your nose, usually to stop the liquid inside the nose from flowing out
sniff.eg: You're sniffing a lot - do you have a cold?

sniff.eng_def: to speak in an unpleasant way, showing that you have a low opinion of something
sniff.chi_def: 嗤之以鼻地說，輕蔑地說
sniff.eg: "They didn't even serve wine at dinner!" she sniffed.

sniff.eng_def: a quick breath in through the nose to smell something, or to stop liquid in the nose from coming out
sniff.eg: Take a sniff of this medicine - it smells horrible, doesn't it?

snore.eng_def: to breathe in a very noisy way while you are sleeping
snore.eg: Sometimes my husband snores so loudly, it keeps me awake at night.

snore.eng_def: a very noisy breath while you are sleeping
snore.eg: I could hear loud snores coming from Jim's bedroom.

snort.eng_def: to make an explosive sound by forcing air quickly up or down the nose
snort.chi_def: 噴鼻息，從鼻中噴氣作聲
snort.eg: He did an impression of a horse snorting.

snort.eng_def: to take an illegal drug by breathing it in through the nose
snort.eg: People were snorting cocaine in the toilets.

snort.eng_def: to suddenly express strong feelings of anger, disapproval, or disagreement, either by speaking or in a sound that you make
snort.chi_def: （表示惱怒、反對或不耐煩）哼，氣哼哼地說
snort.eg: "And you call that a first-class service?" snorted one indignant customer.

snort.eng_def: a loud sound made by forcing air through the nose
snort.eg: The candidate's speech drew loud snorts of derisive laughter.

snow.eng_def: the small, soft, white pieces of ice that sometimes fall from the sky when it is cold, or the white layer on the ground and other surfaces that it forms
snow.eg: Outside the snow began to fall.
We haven't had many heavy snows this winter.

snow.eng_def: If it snows, snow falls from the sky.
to be unable to travel away from a place because of very heavy snow
snow.eg: We were snowed in for four days last winter.

snow.eng_def: to deceive or trick someone by talking a lot or by giving them a lot of information
snow.eg: It felt like she was snowing us with statistics.

snowy.eg: We've had a very snowy winter this year.

so.eng_def: very, extremely, or to such a degree
so.eg: The house is so beautiful.

so.eng_def: used before a noun or before "not" to emphasize what is being said
so.chi_def: （用在名詞或 not 前表示強調）
so.eg: Don't wear that - it's so last year (= it was fashionable last year but not now).

so.eng_def: used at the end of a sentence to mean to a very great degree
so.eg: Is that why you hate him so?

so.eng_def: used usually before the verbs "have", "be", or "do", and other auxiliary verbs to express the meaning "in the same way" or "in a similar way"
so.chi_def: （通常用於 have，be，do 等助動詞前）同樣，像這樣
so.eg: "I've got an enormous amount of work to do." "So have I."

so.eng_def: used to avoid repeating a phrase mentioned earlier
so.chi_def: （用於代替先前提到的片語以避免重複）這樣，如此
so.eg: "I hope they stay together." "I hope so too."

so.eng_def: used to say that a situation mentioned earlier is correct or true
so.eg: "Is it true that we're not getting a pay increase this year?" "I'm afraid so."

so.eng_def: used to say that a fact that has just been stated is certainly true
so.eg: "My eyes are slightly different colours." "So they are."

so.eng_def: used instead of repeating an adjective that has already been mentioned
so.chi_def: （用於代替已提到過的形容詞以避免重複）
so.eg: She's reasonable to work with - more so than I was led to believe.

so.eng_def: used, especially by children, to argue against a negative statement
so.eg: "You didn't even see the movie." "I did so!"

so.eng_def: to act in the way mentioned
so.eg: Parents must take responsibility for their children. Failure to do so could mean a fine or a jail sentence.

so.eng_def: in this way, or like this
so.eg: The pillars, which are outside the building, are so placed in order to provide the maximum space inside.

so.eng_def: used when you are showing how something is done
so.eg: Just fold this piece of paper back, so, and make a crease here.

so.eng_def: used when you are representing the size of something
so.eg: "How tall is he next to you?" "Oh, about so big," she said, indicating the level of her neck.

so.eng_def: used at the beginning of a sentence to connect it with something that has been said or has happened previously
so.chi_def: （放在句首，表示和已說過或已發生過的事相聯繫）如此，這樣，那麽
so.eg: So, there I was standing at the edge of the road with only my underwear on ...

so.eng_def: used as a way of making certain that you or someone else understand something correctly, often when you are repeating the important points of a plan
so.eg: So we leave on the Thursday and get back the next Tuesday, is that right?

so.eng_def: used to refer to a discovery that you have just made
so.eg: So that's what he does when I'm not around!

so.eng_def: used as a short pause, sometimes to emphasize what you are saying
so.chi_def: （表示停頓，有時用於強調所說的內容）
so.eg: So, here we are again - just you and me.

so.eng_def: used before you introduce a subject of conversation that is of present interest, especially when you are asking a question
so.chi_def: （表示引出談話內容，尤用於提問）那麽
so.eg: So, who do you think is going to win the election?

so.eng_def: used to show that you agree with something that someone has just said, but you do not think that it is important
so.chi_def: （表示某人所說的內容並不重要）是呀，沒錯
so.eg: So the car's expensive - well, I can afford it.

so.eng_def: and for that reason; therefore
so.eg: My knee started hurting so I stopped running.

so.eng_def: used before you give an explanation for the action that you have just mentioned
so.eg: I deliberately didn't have lunch so (that) I would be hungry tonight.

so.eng_def: in order to
so.eg: I always keep fruit in the fridge so as to keep flies off it.

so.eng_def: in order not to
so.eg: He did not switch on the light so as not to disturb her.

so.eng_def: perfectly tidy and well arranged
so.chi_def: 非常整齊的，井井有條的
so.eg: He's a perfectionist - everything has to be just so.

so.eng_def: the musical note  soh
so.chi_def: 索（大調音階的第五音，同 soh）

soak.eng_def: to make something very wet, or (of liquid) to be absorbed in large amounts
soak.chi_def: 浸濕，把…濕透；（液體）滲入，滲透
soak.eg: The wind had blown the rain in and soaked the carpet.

soak.eng_def: to leave something in liquid, especially in order to clean it, make it softer, or change its flavour
soak.eg: You can usually soak out a stain.

soak.eng_def: a period of time during which something is in liquid
soak.eg: Most dried beans need a soak before they're cooked.

soak.eng_def: a person who is often drunk

soap.eng_def: a substance used for washing the body or other things

soap.chi_def: 連續劇，肥皂劇（同 soap opera）
在…上塗肥皂；用肥皂擦洗
soap.eg: Have you soaped yourself all over, Alice?

soar.eng_def: to rise very quickly to a high level
soar.eg: All night long fireworks soared into the sky.
The highest peak in the range soars 15,771 feet into the sky.

soar.eng_def: (of a bird or aircraft) to rise high in the air while flying without moving the wings or using power
soar.eg: She watched the gliders soaring effortlessly above her.

sob.eng_def: to cry noisily, taking in deep breaths
sob.eg: I found her sobbing in the bedroom because she'd broken her favourite doll.

sob.eng_def: an act or sound of sobbing
sob.eg: I could hear her sobs from the next room.

sob.eng_def: abbreviation for son of a bitch mainly US offensive
sob.chi_def: 狗娘養的，混蛋，雜種（son of a bitch的縮寫）

sober.eng_def: not drunk or affected by alcohol
sober.eg: Are you sober enough to drive, Jim?
In fact the whole wedding was a sober affair - no dancing, just people standing around in groups chatting politely.

sober.eng_def: Clothes or colours that are sober are plain and not bright.
to become more calm and serious, or to make someone do this
sober.eg: News of the tragedy sobered us.

soccer.eng_def: a game played between two teams of eleven people, where each team tries to win by kicking a ball into the other team's goal

sociable.eng_def: Sociable people like to meet and spend time with other people.
sociable.chi_def: 好交際的；善於社交的；合群的
sociable.eg: Rob's very sociable - he likes parties.

social.eng_def: relating to activities in which you meet and spend time with other people and that happen during the time when you are not working
social.eg: I had an active social life when I was at college.

social.eng_def: Social people like to meet and spend time with other people.
social.chi_def: 好交際的；善於社交的；合群的
social.eg: I'm shy, but my brother's very social.

social.eng_def: relating to society and living together in an organized way
an occasion when the members of a group or organization meet informally to enjoy themselves

socialism.eng_def: the set of beliefs that states that all people are equal and should share equally in a country's money, or the political systems based on these beliefs
socialism.chi_def: 社會主義；社會主義制度

socialist.eng_def: a supporter of socialism or member of a socialist political party
socialist.chi_def: 社會主義者（社會主義的支持者或社會主義政黨的成員）
socialist.eg: He was a socialist all his life.

socialist.chi_def: 支持社會主義的；與社會主義有關的

socialize.eng_def: to spend time when you are not working with friends or with other people in order to enjoy yourself
socialize.eg: I tend not to socialize with my colleagues.

socialize.eng_def: to train people or animals to behave in a way that others in the group think is suitable
socialize.chi_def: 使合群；使適應社會生活
socialize.eg: Here at the school we make every effort to socialize these young offenders.

society.eng_def: a large group of people who live together in an organized way, making decisions about how to do things and sharing the work that needs to be done. All the people in a country, or in several similar countries, can be referred to as a society
the part of society that consists of people who are rich, powerful, and fashionable
the state of being together with other people
society.eg: She prefers her own society (= likes to be alone).

society.eng_def: an organization to which people who share similar interests can belong

sociology.eng_def: the study of the relationships between people living in groups, especially in industrial societies
sociology.eg: She has a degree in sociology and politics.

sock.eng_def: a piece of clothing made from soft material that covers your foot and the lower part of your leg
to hit someone with your fist (= closed hand)
sock.eg: He socked the policeman on the jaw/in the eye.

sock.eng_def: in baseball, to hit a ball very powerfully

socket.eng_def: the part of a piece of equipment, especially electrical equipment, into which another part fits
a part of the body into which another part fits

soda.eng_def: any type of sweet fizzy drink (= with bubbles) that is not alcoholic
a type of fizzy water (= with bubbles), often mixed with alcoholic drinks

sodium.eng_def: a soft, silver-white chemical element that is found in salt

sofa.eng_def: a long, soft seat with a back and usually arms, on which more than one person can sit at the same time

soft.eng_def: Soft things, especially parts of the body, are not hard or rough and feel pleasant and smooth when touched.
Someone who is soft is not very healthy and strong
soft.eg: Look at you! You need more exercise. You're going/getting soft.

soft.eng_def: not forceful, loud, or easily noticed
not severe or forceful enough, especially in criticizing or punishing someone who has done something wrong
soft.chi_def: （尤指批評或處罰）力度不夠的，不嚴厲的
soft.eg: She thinks I'm too soft on the kids when they misbehave.
He's got a pretty soft job - he hardly seems to do anything all day.

soft.eng_def: Soft water contains a low level of minerals and allows soap to make bubbles.
soft.chi_def: （水）软的（含礦物度低、能讓肥皂起泡）

soft.eng_def: Soft drugs are illegal drugs that many people think are not dangerous.
soft.chi_def: （毒品）不易上癮的，沒甚麽危害的，軟的

soft.eng_def: In a soft market/economy there are more goods for sale than there are people to buy them, so prices are usually low.

soften.eng_def: to become soft, or to make something soft
soften.eg: You can soften the butter by warming it gently.

soften.eng_def: to become more gentle or less strict, or to make someone do this
soften.eg: The news will upset him - we must think of a way to soften the blow (= make the news less unpleasant for him).

software.eng_def: the instructions that control what a computer does; computer programs
software.eg: He's written a piece of software that does your taxes for you.

soil.eng_def: the material on the surface of the ground in which plants grow

soil.eg: It was the first time we had set foot on foreign/French/American soil (= gone to a foreign country/France/America).
Gardening is a way for city dwellers to return to the soil.

soil.eng_def: to make something dirty, especially with solid waste

solar.eng_def: of or from the sun, or using the energy from the sun to produce electric power
solar.chi_def: 太陽的；來自太陽的；使用太陽能的

soldier.eng_def: a person who is in an army and wears its uniform, especially someone who fights when there is a war

sole.eg: My sole objective is to make the information more widely available.
She has sole responsibility for the project.

sole.eng_def: the bottom part of the foot that touches the ground when you stand or walk, or the bottom part of a shoe that touches the ground, usually not including the heel
sole.eg: a cut on the sole of her foot

sole.eng_def: one of a number of flat, round fish that are eaten as food
to put a new sole on a shoe

solemn.eng_def: an agreement that you make in a serious way and expect to keep

solid.eng_def: hard or firm, keeping a clear shape
completely hard or firm all through an object, or without any spaces or holes
A solid metal or colour is pure and does not have anything else mixed together with it.

solid.eg: Liquid and solid waste is collected in the tank.

solid.eng_def: Solid food is not in liquid form, especially when given to babies or people who are ill.
solid.chi_def: （尤指給嬰兒或病人吃的食物）固體的
solid.eg: That rice pudding was the first solid food he's eaten since his operation.

solid.eng_def: certain or safe; of a good standard; giving confidence or support
solid.chi_def: 確定的；紮實的；可信賴的
solid.eg: This provided solid evidence that he committed the crime.

solid.eng_def: continuing for a period of time without stopping
solid.eg: I slept for eleven solid hours.

solid.eng_def: an object that has a height, width, and length, and is not flat
solid.eg: A cube and a pyramid are both solids.

solid.eng_def: a substance that is not liquid or gas
a food not in liquid form

solidarity.eng_def: agreement between and support for the members of a group, especially a political group
solidarity.eg: The situation raises important questions about solidarity among member states of the UN.

solitary.eng_def: A solitary person or thing is the only person or thing in a place.
solitary.eg: On the hill, a solitary figure was busy chopping down trees.

solitude.eng_def: the situation of being alone without other people

solo.chi_def: 獨自的（地），單獨的（地），單人的（地）

solo.eng_def: a musical performance given by one person alone, or a musical performance in which one person is given special attention

solution.eg: There's no easy solution to this problem.

solution.eng_def: a liquid into which a solid has been mixed and has dissolved

solve.eng_def: to find an answer to a problem

some.eng_def: an amount or number of something that is not stated or not known; a part of something
some.eg: There's some cake in the kitchen if you'd like it.

some.eng_def: a large amount or number of something
some.eg: It'll be some time before we meet again.

some.eng_def: used to refer to a particular person or thing without stating exactly which one
some.eg: Some lucky person will win more than $1,000,000 in the competition.

some.eng_def: used before a noun, especially at the beginning of a sentence to show anger or disapproval, often by repeating a word that was not accurately used
some.chi_def: （用於名詞前，尤用於句首，表示惱火或反對）
some.eg: Some people just don't know when to shut up.

some.eng_def: used before a noun to show how good something or someone is
an amount or number of something that is not stated or not known; a part of something
some.eg: If you need more paper then just take some.
Some have compared his work to Picasso's.

some.eng_def: used before a number to mean approximately; about
some.eg: Some 50 tons of rock are taken from the quarry every day.

some.eng_def: by a small amount or degree; a little
some.eg: She says she's feeling some better.

someday.eng_def: at some time in the future that is not yet known or not stated
someday.eg: Maybe someday you'll both meet again.

somehow.eng_def: in a way or by some means that is not known or not stated
somehow.chi_def: 以某種方法，以某種方式
somehow.eg: It won't be easy, but we'll get across the river somehow.

somehow.eng_def: for a reason that is not clear
somehow.eg: I know what we're doing is legal, but somehow it doesn't feel right.

someone.eng_def: used to refer to a single person when you do not know who they are or when it is not important who they are

something.eng_def: an object, situation, quality, or action that is not exactly known or stated
something.eg: There's something sharp in my shoe.

something.eng_def: a thing for which you are grateful, especially because an unpleasant thing has also happened
something.chi_def: 還算幸運的事；聊以自慰的事
something.eg: We were given five hundred pounds in compensation which isn't much but at least it's something.

something.eng_def: used after a number like 20, 30, etc. to refer to the age of a person who is between 20 and 29, 30 and 39 years old, etc., or to a person who is of this age
something.chi_def: （用於數字後指年齡或某個年齡段的人）…多歲，…多歲的人

sometime.eng_def: at a time in the future or the past that is not known or not stated
(especially of a job or position) in the past but not any longer
sometime.chi_def: （尤指工作或職位）以前的，曾經的
sometime.eg: The new paper will be headed by Rebecca Jones, sometime editor of the "Daily News".

sometimes.eng_def: on some occasions but not always or often
sometimes.eg: Sometimes we take food with us and sometimes we buy food when we're there.

somewhat.eg: The resort has changed somewhat over the last few years.
She was known for being somewhat of a strange character.

somewhere.eng_def: in or at a place having a position that is not stated or not known
somewhere.eg: He was last heard of living somewhere on the south coast of France.
Somewhere between 900 and 1,100 minor crimes are reported in this city every week.

son.eng_def: used as an informal form of address by a man to a boy
son.eg: Come on, son, we don't have all day.

son.eng_def: a man who was born in a particular place
son.eg: that notable son of Württemberg, Martin Brecht

song.eng_def: a usually short piece of music with words that are sung
the act of singing, or singing when considered generally
song.eg: He was so happy he wanted to burst/break into song (= start singing).

song.eng_def: the musical sound that a bird makes

soon.eng_def: in or within a short time; before long; quickly
soon.eg: She'll soon be here./She'll be here soon.

soon.eng_def: at the same time or a very short time after
soon.eg: As soon as I saw her, I knew there was something wrong.

soon.eng_def: If you do something as soon as possible, you do it as quickly as you can.
soon.eg: We need the repairs done as soon as possible.

soothe.eng_def: to make someone feel calm or less worried
to make a part of the body less painful
soothe.eg: I had a long, hot bath to soothe my aching muscles.

sophisticated.eng_def: having a good understanding of the way people behave and/or a good knowledge of culture and fashion
sophisticated.chi_def: 精於世故的，老練的；見多識廣的；很有品味的
sophisticated.eg: She was slim, svelte, and sophisticated.

sophisticated.eng_def: intelligent or made in a complicated way and therefore able to do complicated tasks
sophisticated.eg: I think a more sophisticated approach is needed to solve this problem.

sophomore.eng_def: a student studying in the second year of a course at a US college or high school (= a school for students aged 15 to 18)
sophomore.chi_def: （美國大學或高中的）二年級學生

sore.eng_def: painful and uncomfortable because of injury, infection, or too much use
sore.eg: All the dust has made my eyes sore.

sore.eng_def: angry because you feel you have been unfairly treated
sore.eg: He accused me of being a sore loser (= someone who does not accept defeat well).

sore.eng_def: a painful area on the surface of a body, especially an infected area
sore.eg: The poor dog's back was covered with sores.

sorrow.eng_def: (a cause of) a feeling of great sadness
sorrow.chi_def: 悲痛，傷心，悔恨；傷心事，不幸
sorrow.eg: The sorrow she felt over/at the death of her husband was almost too much to bear.
For years she sorrowed over her missing son.

sorrowful.eg: With a sorrowful sigh she folded the letter and put it away.

sorry.eng_def: feeling sadness, sympathy, or disappointment, especially because something unpleasant has happened or been done
sorry.eg: I'm just sorry about all the trouble I've caused her.

sorry.eng_def: to feel sad because you have a problem and you feel that it is not fair that you are suffering so much
sorry.chi_def: （對自己的遭遇而感到）憤憤不平
sorry.eg: He sounded very sorry for himself on the phone.

sorry.eng_def: used to show that something that must be said causes sadness or disappointment
sorry.eg: I'm sorry to say that the project's funding has been cancelled.

sorry.eng_def: used to say that you wish you had not done what you have done, especially when you want to be polite to someone you have done something bad to
sorry.eg: Oh, I'm sorry - I didn't see you there.

sorry.eng_def: used to show politeness when refusing something or disagreeing
sorry.chi_def: （婉轉地表示拒絕或反對）對不起，抱歉
sorry.eg: I'm sorry, but I think you've made a mistake.

sorry.chi_def: 悲慘的景象／糟糕的狀況／糟糕的事情（等等）
sorry.eg: He was a sorry sight when he got home - soaking and covered in mud.

sorry.eng_def: used to show politeness when refusing something or disagreeing
sorry.chi_def: （婉轉地表示拒絕或反對）對不起，抱歉
sorry.eg: Sorry, you can't go in there.

sorry.eng_def: used when politely asking someone to repeat something or when politely interrupting someone
sorry.chi_def: （表示禮貌地請對方重複或打斷對方的話）你說什麽，沒聽清楚

sort.eng_def: a group of things that are of the same type or that share similar qualities
sort.eg: We both like the same sort of music.

sort.eng_def: the type of thing or person that you like
sort.eg: Hmm, this is my sort of wine!

sort.eng_def: used to show that what you have just said is only an example from a much larger group of things
sort.eg: They sell souvenirs, postcards, that sort of thing.

sort.eng_def: a person having the stated or suggested character
sort.eg: He seemed like a decent sort to me.

sort.eng_def: to put a number of things in an order or to separate them into groups
sort.eg: Paper, plastic, and cans are sorted for recycling.

sort.eng_def: to deal with something by repairing or organizing it
sort.eg: Can you sort the car by tomorrow?

soul.eng_def: the spiritual part of a person that some people believe continues to exist in some form after their body has died, or the part of a person that is not physical and experiences deep feelings and emotions
soul.eg: She suffered greatly while she was alive, so let us hope her soul is now at peace.

soul.eng_def: the quality of a person or work of art that shows or produces deep good feelings
soul.chi_def: 精神；熱情，真摯情感；高尚情操；氣魄
soul.eg: If you can't enjoy this music you've got no soul.

soul.eng_def: a person of a stated type

soul.eg: By the time I arrived there wasn't a soul there.

soul.eng_def: a deep understanding of and being proud of the culture of black people
soul.chi_def: 黑人文化情感（對黑人文化的認同和自豪）

sound.eng_def: something that you can hear or that can be heard
sound.eg: They could hear the sound of a bell tolling in the distance.

sound.eng_def: the activity of recording and broadcasting sound such as from a performance of music or for a film
sound.chi_def: （音樂演出、電影等的）音響錄製和播出，音響製作

sound.eng_def: the volume or quality of the sound of a television or film
sound.eg: Could you turn the sound down/up on the TV?

sound.eng_def: the particular quality of the music that a musician or a group of musicians produce
sound.chi_def: （個人或樂隊的）音樂特色，音樂風格
sound.eg: The band's sound is a distinctive mixture of funk and rap.

sound.eng_def: how something seems to be, from what is said or written
sound.chi_def: …給人的印象（或感覺）；…的言外之意
sound.eg: I like the sound of the beef in red wine sauce.

sound.eng_def: a passage of sea connecting two larger areas of sea, or an area of sea mostly surrounded by land
to seem good, interesting, strange, etc. from what is said or written
sound.chi_def: 聽起來不錯／聽起來有意思／似乎很奇怪（等等）

sound.eng_def: to seem like something, from what is said or written
sound.eg: That sounds like a good idea.

sound.eng_def: to seem angry, happy, rude, etc. when you speak
sound.chi_def: 聽起來很生氣／高興／無禮（等等）
sound.eg: He sounded very depressed when we spoke on the phone yesterday.
If the alarm sounds, leave the building immediately.

sound.eng_def: to cause a noise to be made or say or shout a message to warn people about something
sound.eg: Quick, sound the alarm - there's a fire in the machine room!

sound.eng_def: to measure the depth of a mass of water, such as the sea, usually by sonar
not broken or damaged; healthy; in good condition
sound.chi_def: 無損傷的；完好的；健康的，健全的
sound.eg: It's an old building but it's still structurally sound.

sound.eng_def: showing good judgment; able to be trusted
sound.eg: She gave me some very sound advice.
How sound is her knowledge of the subject?
He was sound asleep within moments of getting into bed.

soup.eng_def: a usually hot, liquid food made from vegetables, meat, or fish

sour.eng_def: having a sharp, sometimes unpleasant, taste or smell, like a lemon, and not sweet
sour.eg: These plums are a bit sour.

sour.chi_def: 不友好的；壞脾氣的，沒好氣的
sour.eg: Overnight, it seemed, their relationship had turned sour.

sour.eng_def: to become sour or to make something become sour
to (cause to) become unpleasant or unfriendly
sour.eg: Her whole attitude to life soured as a result of that experience.

sour.eng_def: a drink made from strong alcohol, lemon, or lime juice, sugar, and ice

source.eng_def: the place something comes from or starts at, or the cause of something
source.chi_def: 來源，出處；發源地；起源，根源

source.eng_def: someone or something that supplies information
source.eg: The journalist refused to reveal her sources (= say who had given the information to her).

source.eng_def: at the place where something comes from
source.eg: Tax is deducted from my income at source.

source.eng_def: to get something from a particular place
source.eg: Where possible the produce used in our restaurant is sourced locally.

south.eng_def: the direction that goes towards the part of the earth below the equator, opposite to the north, or the part of an area or country that is in this direction
south.eg: The points of the compass are north, south, east, and west.

south.eng_def: the southern states of the US
south.eg: The American Civil War was fought between the North and the South partly over the issue of slavery.

south.eng_def: the developing countries of the world, most of which are below the equator
south.chi_def: 南方（指開發中國家，因其大多數位於南半球）

south.eng_def: in or forming the south part of something
a wind coming from the south
to or in the south of a country or region
south.eg: Alice got a job down south.

south.eng_def: (in or to) England, when considered in relation to Scotland
(in or to) Mexico and the other countries south of the US border with Mexico, when considered in relation to the US
south.chi_def: （關係到美國時）墨西哥及以南國家

southern.eng_def: in or from the south part of an area
southern.chi_def: 南方的，南部的；從南面來的

souvenir.eng_def: something you buy or keep to help you remember a holiday or special event
souvenir.eg: He bought a model of a red London bus as a souvenir of his trip to London.

sovereign.eng_def: a British gold coin that was in use in Britain from 1817 to 1914 and was worth £1
sovereign.chi_def: 金鎊（英國於1817-1914年之間使用的面值爲一英鎊的金幣）

sovereign.eng_def: having the highest power or being completely independent
sovereign.chi_def: 至高無上的；完全獨立的
sovereign.eg: Sovereign power is said to lie with the people in some countries, and with a ruler in others.

sovereign.eng_def: an extremely successful way of dealing with a problem
sovereign.eg: Love is a sovereign remedy for unhappiness.

sovereignty.eng_def: the power of a country to control its own government
sovereignty.eg: Talks are being held about who should have sovereignty over the island.

sow.eng_def: to put seeds in or on the ground so that plants will grow
to cause a bad emotion or condition to begin somewhere so that it will grow or continue
sow.eg: Now that you've sown doubts in my mind, I'll never be sure I can trust him.

soy.eng_def: a strong-tasting, dark brown liquid made from fermented soya beans and used especially in Chinese and Japanese cooking

soybean.eng_def: a small bean grown originally in Asia, used as a food for people and animals

space.eng_def: an empty area that is available to be used
space.eg: Is there any space for my clothes in that cupboard?

space.eng_def: the area around everything that exists, continuing in all directions
space.eg: He was absent-mindedly staring/gazing into space (= looking, but seeing nothing).

space.eng_def: the distance between a football, rugby, etc. player and any opposing players
space.chi_def: （足球、橄欖球等球員與對手之間的）活動空間
space.eg: If you give quality players that much space, they will punish you.

space.eng_def: land, especially in a town, that has no buildings on it
space.eg: What I like about this town is that there's so much open space.

space.eng_def: during a period of six weeks, three hours, etc.
space.chi_def: 六個星期／三個小時之內（等等）
space.eg: It all happened in the space of ten minutes.

space.eng_def: the empty area outside Earth's atmosphere, where the planets and the stars are
to arrange things or people so that there is some distance or time between them
space.chi_def: 把…以一定間隔排列；在…中留間隔
space.eg: That page looks badly spaced (= there is too much/too little distance between the lines or words).

spacecraft.eng_def: a vehicle used for travel in space
spacecraft.eg: a manned/unmanned spacecraft (= with/without people inside)

spaceship.eng_def: (especially in stories) a vehicle used for travel in space

spacious.eng_def: large and with a lot of space

spade.eng_def: a tool used for digging especially soil or sand, with a long handle and a flat blade
one of the four suits in playing cards, represented by a black symbol like a pointed leaf with a short stem
a playing card from the suit of spades
an offensive word for a black person

spaghetti.eng_def: pasta made in the form of long, thin strings

span.eng_def: the period of time that sometimes exists or happens
span.eg: He has a short attention/concentration span.

span.eng_def: the length of something from one end to the other
span.eg: huge wings with a span of over a metre

span.eng_def: the area of a bridge, etc. between two supports
span.eg: The bridge crosses the river in a single span.

span.eng_def: to exist or continue for a particular length of time
span.eg: Tennis has a history spanning several centuries.

span.eng_def: If a bridge spans a river, it goes from one side to the other.
span.eg: An old bridge spans the river just outside the town.

span.chi_def: 嶄新的；極整潔的，極乾淨的

spare.eng_def: If something is spare, it is available to use because it is extra.
time when you are not working
spare.eg: I like to paint in my spare time.
He had the spare build of a runner.
The interior is spare, almost minimalist.

spare.eng_def: to get very upset or angry
spare.eg: She goes spare if I'm so much as five minutes late.

spare.eng_def: to not hurt or destroy something or someone
spare.eg: They asked him to spare the women and children.

spare.eng_def: to prevent someone from having to experience something unpleasant
spare.eg: Luckily, I was spared the embarrassment of having to sing in front of everyone.

spare.eng_def: to use a lot of effort, expense, etc. to do something
spare.eg: We will spare no effort to find out who did this.

spare.eng_def: to try as hard as you can to achieve something
spare.eg: She never spared herself in the pursuit of excellence.

spare.eng_def: to give time, money, or space to someone, especially when it is difficult for you
spare.chi_def: （尤指在自己困難的情況下）抽出，撥出，擠出

spare.eng_def: to think about someone who is in a difficult or unpleasant situation
spare.eg: Spare a thought for me tomorrow, when you're lying on a beach, because I'll still be here in the office!

spare.eng_def: left over or more than you need
spare.eg: If you have any woolyarn to spare when you've finished the sweater, can you make me some gloves?

spare.eng_def: an extra thing that is not being used and can be used instead of a part that is broken, lost, etc.
a piece that can be used to replace another similar piece in a car or other device
spare.chi_def: （汽車或其他設備的）備件，配件

spark.eng_def: a very small piece of fire that flies out from something that is burning, or one that is made by rubbing two hard things together, or a flash of light made by electricity
spark.eg: Sparks were flying out of the bonfire and blowing everywhere.

spark.eng_def: a first small event or problem that causes a much worse situation to develop
spark.eg: That small incident was the spark that set off the street riots.

spark.eng_def: a feeling or quality that causes excitement
spark.chi_def: 憤怒／靈感／生命的火花（等等）
spark.eg: They kept running into each other and eventually realized there was a spark between them.

spark.eng_def: to cause the start of something, especially an argument or fighting
spark.chi_def: 引起，導致，觸發（尤指爭論或打鬥）

sparkle.eng_def: to shine brightly with a lot of small points of light
sparkle.eg: The snow/sea sparkled in the sunlight.

sparkle.eng_def: If a person or performance sparkles, they are energetic, interesting, and exciting.
sparkle.chi_def: （人或表演）生氣勃勃，充滿活力
sparkle.eg: Alice is shy and quiet at parties, but her sister really sparkles!

Their latest performance of My Fair Lady really lacked sparkle.

sparrow.eng_def: a small, grey-brown bird that is especially common in towns

speak.eng_def: to say words, to use the voice, or to have a conversation with someone
speak.eg: Would you mind speaking more slowly, please?

speak.eng_def: talking from a particular point of view
speak.chi_def: （表示看問題的角度）大體上說／從歷史的角度看／嚴格地說（等等）
speak.eg: Historically speaking, the island is of great interest.

speak.eng_def: to tell someone that they have done something wrong
speak.eg: The manager promised that she would speak to the person responsible.

speak.eng_def: to (be able to) talk in a language
to give a formal talk to a group of people
speak.eg: Who is speaking in the debate tonight?

speak.eng_def: to show or express something without using words
speak.eg: She was silent, but her eyes spoke her real feelings for him.

speak.eng_def: used to form nouns to mean the special language used in a particular subject area or business
speak.chi_def: （用於構成名詞，指某一領域或行業的特殊用語）…術語，…行話

speaker.eng_def: a person who gives a speech at a public event
someone who speaks a particular language
speaker.chi_def: （說某一特定語言的）說話者；演講人

speaker.eng_def: the part of a radio, television, or computer, or of a piece of electrical equipment for playing recorded sound, through which the sound is played. A speaker can be part of the radio, etc. or be separate from it
speaker.eg: There's no sound coming out of the right-hand speaker.

speaker.eng_def: the person who controls the way in which business is done in an organization which makes laws
speaker.eg: He served for eight years as Speaker of the House of Representatives.

spear.eng_def: a weapon consisting of a pole with a sharp, usually metal, point at one end, that is either thrown or held in the hand
a thin pointed stem or leaf
to push or throw a spear into an animal
spear.eg: They catch the fish by spearing them.

spear.eng_def: to catch something on the end of a pointed tool or object
spear.eg: He speared a meatball with his fork.

special.chi_def: 特殊的，特別的；不尋常的

special.eng_def: especially great or important, or having a quality that most similar things or people do not have
special.chi_def: 格外好的；特別重要的；額外的
special.eg: Could I ask you a special favour?

special.eng_def: a television programme that is made for a particular reason or occasion and is not part of a series
a dish that is available in a restaurant on a particular day that is not usually available
special.chi_def: （餐館通常只在特定日子供應的）特製菜餚
special.eg: Today's specials are written on the board.

special.eng_def: a product that is being sold at a reduced price for a short period
special.eg: Today's specials include T-shirts for only $2.99.

specialist.eng_def: someone who has a lot of experience, knowledge, or skill in a particular subject

specialist.eg: She's a specialist in childhood illnesses.

specialize.eng_def: to spend most of your time studying one particular subject or doing one type of business

specialty.eng_def: a product that is extremely good in a particular place

specialty.eng_def: a subject that someone knows a lot about

species.eng_def: a set of animals or plants in which the members have similar characteristics to each other and can breed with each other
species.eg: Mountain gorillas are an endangered species.

specific.eng_def: relating to one thing and not others; particular
specific.eg: The virus attacks specific cells in the brain.

specify.eng_def: to explain or describe something clearly and exactly
specify.eg: He said we should meet but didn't specify a time.

specimen.eng_def: something shown or examined as an example; a typical example

specimen.eng_def: a small amount of blood or urine used for testing
specimen.chi_def: （用於化驗的）血液樣本，尿液樣本

spectacle.eng_def: an unusual or unexpected event or situation that attracts attention, interest, or disapproval
spectacle.chi_def: 不尋常的事；出人意料的情況

spectacle.eng_def: a public event or show that is exciting to watch; an exciting appearance
spectacle.eg: The carnival was a magnificent spectacle.

spectacular.chi_def: 壯觀的，壯麗的；令人驚歎的
非常大的，巨大的；驚人的

spectacular.eng_def: an event or performance that is very exciting to watch and involves a lot of people

spectator.eng_def: a person who watches an activity, especially a sports event, without taking part

spectrum.eng_def: the set of colours into which a beam of light can be separated, or a range of waves, such as light waves or radio waves

spectrum.eng_def: a range of different positions, opinions, etc. between two extreme points

speculate.eng_def: to guess possible answers to a question when you do not have enough information to be certain
speculate.eg: I don't know why she did it - I'm just speculating.

speculate.eng_def: to buy and sell in the hope that the value of what you buy will increase and that it can then be sold at a higher price in order to make a profit

speech.eng_def: the ability to talk, the activity of talking, or a piece of spoken language
speech.chi_def: 說話能力；說話；談話；言語

His speech was slurred and I thought he was drunk.
Some expressions are used more in speech than in writing.

speech.eng_def: a set of words spoken in a play
speech.eg: Do you know the words to Hamlet's famous speech at the beginning of Act III?

speech.eng_def: a formal talk given usually to a large number of people on a special occasion
speech.eg: I had to give/make a speech at my brother's wedding.

speed.eg: He was travelling at a speed of 90 mph.
I get a real thrill from speed.
We were surprised at the speed of the response to our enquiry.

speed.eng_def: the rate at which light or sound travels
speed.eg: The speed of light is 300 million metres per second.

speed.eng_def: the rate at which a photographic film absorbs or reacts to light
speed.eg: What speed film do I need for taking photographs indoors?

speed.eng_def: the length of time for which part of a camera is open to allow light to reach the film when a photograph is being taken
slang for amphetamine  (= a drug that makes the mind or body more active)
speed.chi_def: 苯丙胺，安非他命（一種興奮劑）
speed.eg: She was on speed at the time.

speed.eng_def: to (cause to) move, go, or happen fast
speed.chi_def: （使）快速移動；（使）快速前行；加速；促進
speed.eg: The train sped along at over 120 miles per hour.

speed.eng_def: to be driving faster than you are legally allowed to do

spell.eng_def: to form a word or words with the letters in the correct order
to cause something bad to happen in the future
spell.chi_def: 意味著災難／會招致麻煩（等等）
spell.eg: The new regulations could spell disaster for small businesses.

spell.eng_def: to do something that someone else would usually be doing, especially in order to allow them to rest
spell.chi_def: （尤指爲讓某人休息而）代替做，替換，輪換
spell.eg: You've been driving for a while - do you want me to spell you?

spell.eng_def: a period of time for which an activity or condition lasts continuously
spell.eg: I lived in Cairo for a spell.

spell.eng_def: a short period of a particular type of weather
spell.chi_def: （特定天氣的）一段短暫持續時間

spell.eng_def: a period when you do something that someone else would usually be doing, especially in order to allow them to rest
spell.eg: If we take spells (with) doing the painting, it won't seem like such hard work.

spell.eng_def: spoken words that are thought to have magical power, or (the condition of being under) the influence or control of such words
spell.eg: The witch cast/put a spell on the prince and he turned into a frog.

spelling.eng_def: forming words with the correct letters in the correct order, or the ability to do this
the way a particular word is spelled
spelling.eg: This dictionary includes both British and American spellings of words.

spend.eng_def: to give money as a payment for something
to use time doing something or being somewhere
spend.eg: I think we need to spend more time together.

spend.eng_def: to use energy, effort, force, etc., especially until there is no more left
spend.chi_def: 消耗，花費（精力等）；（尤指）用盡（全力）
spend.eg: For the past month he's been spending all his energy trying to find a job.

spend.eng_def: the amount of money that is spent on something
spend.eg: The total spend on the project was almost a million pounds.

sphere.eng_def: an object shaped like a round ball
sphere.eg: Doctors have replaced the top of his hip bone with a metal sphere.

sphere.eng_def: a subject or area of knowledge, work, etc.
sphere.chi_def: （知識、工作等的）範圍，領域，圈，界

spice.eng_def: a substance made from a plant, used to give a special flavour to food
spice.eg: Cinnamon, ginger, and cloves are all spices.

spice.eng_def: something that makes something else more exciting and interesting
spice.chi_def: 調劑品；額外的刺激（或趣味）
spice.eg: A scandal or two adds a little spice to office life.

spice.eng_def: to use spice to add flavour to food or drink

spicy.chi_def: 加香料的；用香料調味的；味重的

spicy.eng_def: exciting and interesting, especially because of being shocking or dealing with sexual matters
spicy.chi_def: 刺激的；（尤指）聳人聽聞的，下流的，粗俗的

spider.eng_def: a small creature with eight thin legs that catches insects in a web (= a net made from sticky threads)

spike.eng_def: a narrow, thin shape with a sharp point at one end, or something, especially a piece of metal, with this shape
spike.chi_def: 尖頭，尖刺；（尤指金屬的）尖狀物

spike.eng_def: a set of short, pointed pieces of metal or plastic, attached to the bottom of shoes worn for particular sports, that stop the person wearing the shoes from sliding on the ground, or shoes with these pointed pieces
spike.chi_def: （某些運動鞋上的）防滑鞋釘；釘鞋

spike.eng_def: a very high amount, price, or level, usually before a fall
spike.chi_def: （通常指在下跌前）非常高的數量，價格或程度
spike.eg: If price spikes continue, people will not be able to afford the new houses they want.

spike.eng_def: to decide not to publish an article in a newspaper
spike.chi_def: 拒絕刊登；棄置（文章）不用
spike.eg: The story was deemed too controversial and so they spiked it.

spike.eng_def: to make a drink stronger by adding alcohol, or to add flavour or interest to something
spike.chi_def: 將烈酒摻入（飲料）；使增添風味（或趣味）
spike.eg: She claimed that someone had spiked her drink with whisky.
