spike.eng_def: in the sport of volleyball, to hit the ball so that it goes almost straight down on the other side of the net
to push a sharp point into something or someone
spike.eg: She got badly spiked when one of the runners trod on her heel.

spike.eng_def: to rise to a higher amount, price, or level, usually before going down again
spike.chi_def: （通常指在下跌前）上升至非常高的數量（價格或程度）
spike.eg: The jobless rate in October spiked to a five-year high.

spill.eng_def: to (cause to) flow, move, fall, or spread over the edge or outside the limits of something
spill.chi_def: （使）灑出；（使）流出；（使）濺出； （使）湧出
spill.eg: I spilled coffee on my silk shirt.

spill.eng_def: an amount of something that has come out of a container
spill.eg: a fuel spill on the road

spin.eng_def: to (cause to) turn around and around, especially fast
spin.eg: The earth spins on its axis.

spin.eng_def: If your head or the room spins, you feel as if it is turning around and around, and you cannot balance.
spin.eg: The room started spinning and I felt faint.

spin.eng_def: to make thread by twisting fibres , or to produce something using thread
spin.eg: The final stage of the production of cotton is when it is spun into thread.

spin.eng_def: to tell a story, either to deceive someone or for entertainment
spin.chi_def: （爲騙人或逗樂）杜撰故事，編造故事
spin.eg: He spun some tale about needing to take time off work because his mother was ill.

spin.eng_def: (of a vehicle) to move quickly, or to move quickly in a vehicle
spin.eg: We were spinning along, when suddenly one of our tyres burst.

spin.eng_def: the movement of something turning round very quickly
spin.eg: I hit something on the road, which sent the car into a spin.

spin.eng_def: a way of describing an idea or situation that makes it seem better than it really is, especially in politics
spin.chi_def: （尤指政治上的）傾向描述，導向陳述
spin.eg: They have tried to put a positive spin on the situation.

spin.eng_def: a short journey in a car for pleasure
spin.eg: Rupert took me for a spin in his new car.

spinach.eng_def: a vegetable with wide, dark green leaves that are eaten cooked or uncooked
not very enjoyable but good for you

spine.eng_def: the line of bones down the centre of the back that provides support for the body and protects the spinal cord
spine.eg: She injured her spine in a riding accident.

spine.eng_def: a long, sharp point like a needle growing out of an animal such as a hedgehog or a plant such as a cactus
spine.chi_def: （刺蝟等動物的）刺毛；（仙人掌等植物的）刺

spine.eng_def: the narrow strip where the cover of a book is joined to the pages, usually with the title and writer's name printed on it

spiral.eng_def: a shape made up of curves, each one above or wider than the one before
a situation in which a price, etc. becomes lower, or a situation gets worse and is difficult to control because one bad event causes another
spiral.chi_def: （價格等的）不斷下降；（局面的）迅速惡化；螺旋式惡性下滑
spiral.eg: This year's downward spiral of house prices has depressed the market.

spiral.chi_def: 呈螺旋式上升（或下降）；盤旋上升（或下降）
spiral.eg: With one wing damaged, the model airplane spiralled downwards.

spiral.eng_def: If costs, prices, etc. spiral, they increase faster and faster.
spiral.chi_def: （費用、價格等）急遽成長，急速上升

spiral.eng_def: (of prices, etc.) to become less, at a faster and faster rate
If a situation spirals, it quickly gets worse in a way that becomes more and more difficult to control.
spiral.eg: Violence in the country is threatening to spiral out of control.

spiral.eng_def: shaped in a series of curves, each one above or wider than the one before

spire.eng_def: a tall, pointed structure on top of a building, especially on top of a church tower

spirit.eng_def: a particular way of thinking, feeling, or behaving, especially a way that is typical of a particular group of people, an activity, a time, or a place
spirit.chi_def: 精神；（尤指特定人群、活動、時代或地方的）主導精神
spirit.eg: The players have a very strong team spirit (= loyalty to each other).

spirit.eng_def: the way a person is feeling
spirit.eg: I've been in high/low spirits (= feeling happy/sad) lately.

spirit.eng_def: the principle that a law, rule, etc. was created to make stronger, rather than the particular things it says you must or must not do
spirit.chi_def: 法律／規則等的實質（或精神）
spirit.eg: They followed neither the spirit nor the letter of the law.

spirit.chi_def: 全身心投入；積極熱情地參與
spirit.eg: They went to the tennis club a few times but never really got into the spirit of it.

spirit.eng_def: used to approve or encourage someone's positive attitude (= way of thinking) or action
spirit.chi_def: （用於表示贊同或鼓勵）這就對了，就應該這樣
spirit.eg: "Come on, we can win this game." "That's the spirit."

spirit.eng_def: the characteristics of a person that are considered as being separate from the body, and that many religions believe continue to exist after the body dies
spirit.chi_def: （獨立於肉體的）精神，靈魂；心靈
spirit.eg: Although he's now living in America, I feel he's with me in spirit (= I feel he is present and is influencing me, in a way that is not physical).

spirit.eng_def: the form of a dead person, similar to a ghost, or the feeling that a dead person is present although you cannot see them

spirit.eg: The orchestra performed The Rite of Spring with great spirit.
Vodka is a type of spirit.

spirit.eng_def: Some types of spirit are alcoholic liquids used especially for cleaning, mixing with paint, etc.
spirit.chi_def: （尤用於清潔、混合油漆等的）工業酒精，酒精溶液
spirit.eg: Thin the paint with white spirit.

spirit.eng_def: to move someone or something out of or away from a place secretly
spirit.chi_def: 偷偷帶走；神不知鬼不覺地弄走
spirit.eg: Somehow the prisoners managed to spirit news out to the world outside.

spiritual.eng_def: relating to deep feelings and beliefs, especially religious beliefs
spiritual.chi_def: 精神的，心靈的；（尤指）宗教的
spiritual.eg: Traditional ways of life fulfilled both economic and spiritual needs.

spiritual.eng_def: a type of religious song, originally developed by African Americans in the US
spiritual.chi_def: 靈歌（源自美國黑人的一種宗教歌曲）

spit.eng_def: to force out the contents of the mouth, especially saliva
spit.eg: Bob Ewell spat contemptuously right in the lawyer's face.

spit.eng_def: to say or shout words quickly and angrily
spit.eg: "Get out!" she spat, when Ace appeared in the doorway.

spit.eng_def: If something hot, such as a fire, spits, it produces short, sharp noises and throws out little pieces.

spit.eg: If it's only spitting (with rain), perhaps we don't need waterproofs.

spit.eng_def: a long, thin, metal stick put through a piece of food, especially meat, so that it can be cooked above a fire
spit.chi_def: （用於燒烤食物的）炙叉；（尤指）烤肉叉，烤肉針
spit.eg: Roast the lamb on a spit.

spit.eng_def: a long, thin, flat beach that goes out into the sea
saliva, especially when it is outside the mouth
spit.eg: She used a little spit on a tissue to wipe the mirror clean.

spite.eng_def: (used before one fact that makes another fact surprising) despite
spite.eg: In spite of his injury, Ricardo will play in Saturday's match.

spite.eng_def: used when you do something that you do not intend to do and are trying not to do
spite.eg: She started to laugh, in spite of herself .

spite.eng_def: a feeling of anger towards another person that makes someone want to annoy, upset, or hurt them, especially in a small way
spite.eg: He's the sort of man who would let down the tyres on your car just out of/from spite.

spite.eng_def: to intentionally annoy, upset, or hurt someone
spite.chi_def: 刁難；存心使苦惱；故意傷害
spite.eg: I almost think he died without making a will just to spite his family.

splash.eng_def: If a liquid splashes or if you splash a liquid, it falls on or hits something or someone.
splash.eg: Water was splashing from a hole in the roof.

splash.eng_def: to move in water so that drops of it go in all directions
splash.chi_def: （在水中）濺著水花行走，拍打著水遊
splash.eg: The kids were splashing (about/around) in the shallow end of the swimming pool.

splash.eng_def: to print or show something in a very noticeable way
splash.chi_def: 在顯著位置刊登；顯眼地展示
splash.eg: Several newspapers splashed colour pictures of the star across their front pages.

splash.eng_def: a small amount of a liquid that has fallen or been dropped
splash.chi_def: 濺上的液體；灑上的液體
splash.eg: There were several splashes of white paint on the carpet.

splash.eng_def: the noise of something hitting or moving in water
splash.eg: We heard a splash and then saw that Toni had fallen in the river.

splash.eng_def: something or someone bright or very noticeable
splash.chi_def: 亮色，亮點；引人注目的人（或物）
splash.eg: The little girl in her flowery dress provides the only splash of colour in the picture.

splendid.chi_def: 極佳的，非常好的；華麗的；壯麗的
splendid.eg: We had splendid food/a splendid holiday/splendid weather.

splendor.eng_def: great beauty that attracts admiration and attention
splendor.eg: They bought a decaying 16th-century manor house and restored it to its original splendour.

splendor.eng_def: the beautiful features or qualities of a place, etc.

split.eng_def: to (cause to) divide into two or more parts, especially along a particular line
split.eg: The prize was split between Susan and Kate.
The wooden floor had cracked and split in the heat.

split.eng_def: If the people in an organization or group split, or if something splits them, they disagree and form smaller groups.
split.chi_def: （使）（組織或團體）分裂；（使）産生分歧
split.eg: The childcare issue has split the employers' group.

split.eng_def: If you split the difference, you agree on a number or amount that is exactly in the middle of the difference between two other numbers or amounts.
split.chi_def: （在數字、數量等方面）折衷，妥協

split.eng_def: to tell other people secret and damaging information about someone
split.eg: They knew Josie wouldn't split on them to the teacher.

split.eng_def: a long, thin hole in something where it has broken apart
split.eg: Rain was getting in through a split in the plastic sheeting.

split.eng_def: a situation in which a group of people is divided into smaller groups because they disagree about something
split.eg: There is a widening split between senior managers and the rest of the workforce.

split.eng_def: the action of sitting on the floor with your legs straight out and flat along the floor in opposite directions

spoil.eng_def: to destroy or reduce the pleasure, interest, or beauty of something
spoil.eg: He tried not to let the bad news spoil his evening.

spoil.eng_def: When food spoils or is spoiled, it is no longer good enough to eat.
spoil.eg: The dessert will spoil if you don't keep it in the fridge.

spoil.eng_def: to mark a ballot paper so that it cannot be officially counted as a vote
spoil.eg: Since she supported none of the candidates, she spoiled her ballot paper.

spoil.eng_def: to treat someone very or too well, especially by being extremely generous
spoil.chi_def: （尤指極其慷慨地）寵愛，溺愛，縱容
spoil.eg: When I'm feeling miserable I go shopping and spoil myself - a couple of new dresses always make me feel better.

spoil.eng_def: to allow a child to do or have everything that it wants to, usually so that it expects to get everything it wants and does not show respect to other people
spoil.eg: Mr Harvey, unable for once to do exactly as he wanted, sulked just like a spoiled child.

spoil.eng_def: earth, stones, etc. dug out from a hole in the ground
goods, advantages, profits, etc. that you get by your actions or because of your position or situation
spoil.chi_def: 戰利品，掠奪物；權力地位的連帶利益，獲益
spoil.eg: The spoils of victory/war included mounds of treasure and armour.

spokesman.eng_def: someone who is chosen by a group or organization to speak officially to the public for them

spokesperson.eng_def: a person who is chosen to speak officially for a group or organization
spokesperson.eg: A spokesperson for the airline said that flights would run as scheduled.

spokeswoman.eg: a spokeswoman for the environmental group Greenpeace

sponge.eng_def: a soft substance that is full of small holes and can absorb a lot of liquid, and is used for washing and cleaning
the action of rubbing something or someone with a wet sponge or cloth in order to clean it, him, or her
sponge.eg: Give it a sponge with a damp cloth - that will remove the blood stains.

sponge.eng_def: a soft cake made with eggs, sugar, and flour but usually no fat
to get money, food, etc. from other people, especially in order to live without working
to rub something or someone with a wet sponge or cloth, especially to clean it, him, or her
sponge.chi_def: 用濕海綿（或濕布）擦，擦洗
sponge.eg: Most food stains will come off if you sponge the material with a little detergent.

sponsor.eng_def: to support a person, organization, or activity by giving money, encouragement, or other help
sponsor.eg: The team is sponsored by JVC, so the players wear the letters JVC on their shirts.

spontaneous.eng_def: happening or done in a natural, often sudden way, without any planning or without being forced
spontaneous.chi_def: 自發的；非籌劃安排的；非勉強的
spontaneous.eg: His jokes seemed spontaneous, but were in fact carefully prepared beforehand.

spoon.eng_def: an object consisting of a round, hollow part and a handle, used for mixing, serving, and eating food
an amount held in a particular spoon
spoon.eg: a couple of spoons of sauce

spoon.eng_def: to move something, especially food, using a spoon
spoon.eg: He spooned the mush into the baby's open mouth.

sport.eng_def: a game, competition, or activity needing physical effort and skill that is played or done according to rules, for enjoyment and/or as a job
sport.chi_def: 體育運動；體育比賽；體育競技項目
sport.eg: Football, basketball, and hockey are all team sports.

sport.eng_def: all types of physical activity that people do to keep healthy or for enjoyment
sport.eg: She used to do/play a lot of sport when she was younger.

sport.eng_def: a pleasant, positive, generous person who does not complain about things they are asked to do or about games that they lose
sport.chi_def: 樂觀大度的人；有風度的人；輸得起的人
sport.eg: Oh, Douglas - be a (good) sport and give me a lift to the station.

sport.eng_def: a friendly way of talking to a man or boy
to wear or be decorated with something
sport.eg: Back in the 1960s he sported platform heels and hair down past his shoulders.

sportsman.eng_def: a man who plays sport, especially one who plays it well
sportsman.chi_def: 運動員；體育運動愛好者；（尤指）擅長體育運動者

sportsman.eng_def: someone who plays sport in a way that shows respect and fairness towards the opposing player or team
sportsman.chi_def: 有運動員風範的人；有運動精神的人
sportsman.eg: He'll be remembered both as a brilliant player and as a true sportsman.

sportsmanship.eng_def: behaviour in sport that is fair and shows respect to the other players

sportswoman.eng_def: a woman who plays sport, especially one who plays it well
sportswoman.chi_def: 女運動員；女體育愛好者；（尤指）擅長體育運動的女子

spot.eng_def: a small, usually round area of colour that is differently coloured or lighter or darker than the surface around it
spot.eg: He had a spot of grease on his tie.

spot.eng_def: one of many spots, that form a pattern
spot.eg: I wore that skirt with the green spots.

spot.eng_def: a raised, pale red circle on the skin that is temporary
spot.chi_def: （皮膚上的）丘疹，皰疹，粉刺；青春痘
spot.eg: Teenagers often suffer a lot from spots.
I felt a few spots of rain.
This looks like a nice spot for a picnic.

spot.eng_def: at the place where an event is happening or has recently happened
spot.eg: The police were called and they were on the spot within three minutes.
You can be sacked on the spot for stealing.

spot.eng_def: a short length of time in a show that is given to a particular performer
spot.eg: She's doing a regular five-minute spot on his show.

spot.eng_def: to see or notice someone or something, usually because you are looking hard
spot.eg: I've just spotted Mark - he's over there, near the entrance.

spot.eng_def: used to praise someone who has noticed something
spot.eg: "I've just seen your glasses - they're under the table." "Ah, well spotted!"

spot.eng_def: If you say it's spotting (with rain), you mean that a few drops of rain are falling.

spotlight.eng_def: a lamp whose beam can be directed, or a circle of light produced by such a lamp
(of a person) receiving a lot of public attention
spotlight.eg: The senator has been in the spotlight recently since the revelation of his tax frauds.

spotlight.eng_def: to light something or someone with a spotlight
spotlight.eg: The paintings in the alcove were spotlit from below.

spotlight.eng_def: If something spotlights a particular situation, it directs public attention to it.
spotlight.chi_def: 使大眾矚目；引起大眾關注

spouse.eg: In 60 percent of the households surveyed both spouses went out to work.

sprain.eng_def: to cause an injury to a joint (= a place where two bones are connected) by a sudden movement
sprain.eg: She sprained her ankle playing squash.

sprawl.eng_def: to spread the arms and legs out carelessly and untidily while sitting or lying down
sprawl.eg: I knocked into her in the corridor and sent her sprawling (= knocked her over).

sprawl.eng_def: (especially of a city) to cover a large area of land with buildings that have been added at different times so that it looks untidy
sprawl.chi_def: （尤指城市）雜亂無序地擴展，散亂地延伸
sprawl.eg: The refugee camps sprawl across the landscape.

sprawl.eng_def: a position with the arms and legs spread out carelessly and untidily while sitting or lying down
a large area of land covered with buildings that have been added at different times so that it looks untidy
sprawl.chi_def: （某地建築的）無計畫發展；沒有城市規劃
sprawl.eg: the urban sprawl of South Florida

spray.eng_def: a mass of very small drops of liquid carried in the air
spray.eg: Can you feel the spray from the sea/waterfall?

spray.eng_def: a liquid that is forced out of a special container under pressure so that it becomes a mass of small liquid drops like a cloud
a mass of small drops of liquid spread onto plants and crops, etc. from a special piece of equipment, or the piece of equipment itself
spray.chi_def: （灑在植物、農作物等上的）噴劑；噴霧器
spray.eg: Farmers use a lot of chemical sprays on crops.

spray.eng_def: a single small branch or stem with leaves and flowers on it
spray.eg: All the wedding guests wore sprays of carnations.

spray.eng_def: to spread liquid in small drops over an area

spread.eng_def: to (cause to) cover, reach, or have an effect on a wider or increasing area
spread.chi_def: （使）展開，（使）鋪開；（使）蔓延，（使）擴散
spread.eg: The fire spread very rapidly because of the strong wind.

spread.eng_def: the development or growth of something so that it covers a larger area or affects a larger number of people
spread.eg: The spread of the disease in the last few years has been alarming.

spread.eng_def: the area or range covered by something
spread.eg: The survey found a wide spread of opinion over the proposed new building.

spread.eng_def: a large article or advertisement covering one or more pages in a newspaper or magazine
spread.chi_def: 整版（或橫貫幾版的）文章（或廣告）
spread.eg: There's a double-page spread on the latest fashions.

spread.eng_def: a soft food for putting on bread and biscuits
spread.chi_def: 塗在麵包（或餅乾）上的食物；抹醬

spread.eng_def: a  ranch  or other large area of land or water
a meal, especially one for a special occasion with a lot of different dishes arranged on a table
spread.eg: Sheila laid on (= made) a magnificent spread for us.

spread.eng_def: the difference between two amounts, such as two prices or interest rates
spread.chi_def: 差異，差距；（價格或利率等之間的）差額
spread.eg: The issue was priced at a spread of 115 basis points above Treasury bonds.

spring.eng_def: the season of the year between winter and summer, lasting from March to June north of the equator, and from September to December south of the equator, when the weather becomes warmer, leaves and plants start to grow again and flowers appear
a piece of curved or bent metal that can be pressed into a smaller space but then returns to its usual shape
spring.eg: The children have jumped on the couch so much that they've ruined the springs.

spring.eng_def: something's ability to return to its usual shape after it has been pressed
spring.eg: Over the years the mattress has lost its spring.

spring.eng_def: a place where water naturally flows out from the ground
to move quickly and suddenly towards a particular place
spring.eg: I sprang out of bed to answer the door.
"Where did you spring from? - I didn't see you come in!"

spring.eng_def: (of furniture) using springs (= curved pieces of metal) to give support
spring.chi_def: （傢俱）裝有彈簧的，有彈簧支撐的

sprinkle.eng_def: to drop a few pieces or drops of something over a surface
sprinkle.eg: Sprinkle a few herbs on the pizza./Sprinkle the pizza with a few herbs.

sprinkle.eng_def: a very light fall of rain or snow that lasts only a short time
very small pieces of coloured sugar or chocolate used as a decoration on the top of cakes, etc.
sprinkle.chi_def: （撒在糕餅上用作裝飾的細小）彩糖
sprinkle.eg: Scatter sprinkles over the top of the cake and press on them gently so that they stick to the chocolate.

sprint.eng_def: to run as fast as you can over a short distance, either in a race or because you are in a great hurry to get somewhere
sprint.eg: We had to sprint to catch the bus.

sprint.eng_def: a short and very fast race, such as the 100 metres, or the last part of a longer race that is run as fast as possible
sprint.chi_def: 短跑；（長距離賽跑的）衝刺

sprint.eng_def: a very fast run that someone makes when they are in a great hurry to get somewhere
sprint.eg: He suddenly broke into (= started) a sprint.

spur.eng_def: to encourage an activity or development or make it happen faster
spur.eg: Rising consumer sales have the effect of spurring the economy to faster growth.

spur.eng_def: to push spurs into the side of a horse to make it go faster
spur.eg: He spurred his horse on and shouted "Faster! Faster!"

spur.eng_def: a sharp, wheel-shaped metal object that is attached to the heel of boots worn by people riding horses and is used to encourage the horse to go faster
a high piece of land that sticks out from a mountain or a group of mountains
something that acts as an encouragement for an activity or development
spur.eg: The manager said that the team's win on Saturday would be a spur to even greater effort this season.

spy.eng_def: a person who secretly collects and reports information about the activities of another country or organization
to secretly collect and report information about the activities of another country or organization
spy.chi_def: 搜集情報；從事間諜活動
spy.eg: He was arrested for spying on missile sites.

spy.eng_def: to get knowledge secretly, especially of a place
spy.chi_def: 探清（尤指場所）的情況，查明
spy.eg: I generally like to spy out restaurants before I go to eat in them.

spy.eng_def: to see or notice someone or something usually when it involves looking hard
spy.chi_def: （通常指一番搜尋後）看見，注意到
spy.eg: I think I've just spied Andrew in the crowd.

squad.eng_def: a small group of people trained to work together as a unit
squad.eg: An army bomb squad arrived and defused the bomb.

squad.eng_def: a team in sports from which the players for a match are chosen
squad.eg: Eight of their 24-man squad are injured.

squad.eng_def: In the army, a squad is a small group of soldiers, especially one brought together for drill (= marching, etc.) .

square.eng_def: a flat shape with four sides of equal length and four angles of 90°

square.eg: When cooled, cut the chocolate brownies into squares.

square.eng_def: an area of approximately square-shaped land in a city or a town, often including the buildings that surround it
square.chi_def: （城鎮中的）廣場（常包括周圍的建築）
square.eg: Are they still living at 6 Eaton Square?

square.eng_def: a particular space on a board used for playing games
square.eg: She moved her castle forward three squares.

square.eng_def: a tool for drawing or testing a right angle
a boring person who does not like new and exciting ideas
square.eg: He's a bit of a square.

square.eng_def: the result of multiplying a number by itself
having the shape of a square
square.eg: The recipe recommends that you use a square cake tin.

square.eng_def: used with units of measurement of length to express the total size of an area
square.eg: The floor is 3 m wide by 5 m long, so its total area is 15 sq m.

square.eng_def: Square is used immediately after measurements of length when expressing the length of the four sides of a square-shaped area.
square.eg: So you want carpet for a room that's eight metres square (= eight metres long and eight metres wide).
Could you stand back from these shelves and tell me if they're square (= level)?

square.eng_def: If two people are all square, one of them has paid off a debt to the other and neither now owes or is owed any money.
If two teams or players are (all) square, they have an equal number of goals or points.
square.eg: They're all square at 30 points each.

square.eng_def: used to describe a person who is boring and does not like new and exciting things
square.eg: Do you think my new haircut makes me look a bit square?

square.eng_def: to multiply a number by itself
to pull your shoulders up and back because you feel determined to do something
square.chi_def: （表示決心已定）挺起胸膛，挺直身子
square.eg: He squared his shoulders and took a deep breath before diving into the pool.

squash.eng_def: to crush something into a flat shape
squash.eg: He accidentally sat on her hat and squashed it.

squash.eng_def: to push yourself, a person, or thing into a small space
squash.eg: The room was so full you couldn't squash another person in.

squash.eng_def: to stop something from continuing to exist or happen, by forceful action
squash.eg: Rumours of a possible takeover of the company were soon squashed by the management.

squash.eng_def: a situation when there is not much room
squash.eg: There are over two hundred people coming to the party so it might be a bit of a squash.

squash.eng_def: a game played between two or four people on a special closed playing area that involves hitting a small rubber ball against a wall
a drink made from fruit juice, water, and sugar or sweetener
a type of large vegetable with a hard skin and a lot of seeds at its centre

squat.eng_def: to position yourself close to the ground balancing on the front part of your feet with your legs bent under your body
squat.eg: She squatted on the ground and warmed her hands by the fire.

squat.eng_def: to live in an empty building or area of land without the permission of the owner
squat.chi_def: 擅自佔用（空房或空地）；偷住
squat.eg: They squatted (in) an old house in King's Cross when their money ran out.

squat.eng_def: short and wide, usually in a way that is not attractive
squat.chi_def: 低矮的；矮墩墩的，矮胖的
squat.eg: a row of ugly, squat houses

squat.eng_def: the place that you live in when you are squatting
squat.chi_def: 擅自佔用的地方；偷住的房子
squat.eg: They're living in a damp squat with no electricity.
She shouldn't talk - she doesn't know squat about it.

squeeze.eng_def: to press something firmly, especially from all sides in order to change its shape, reduce its size, or remove liquid from it
squeeze.eg: Cut the lemon in half and squeeze the juice into the bowl.

squeeze.eng_def: If you are squeezed by financial demands, they cause you financial problems.
squeeze.chi_def: 給…帶來財務困難，使陷入財務困境
squeeze.eg: Small businesses are being squeezed by heavy taxation.

squeeze.eng_def: to get in, through, under, etc. with difficulty
squeeze.eg: She squeezed through the crowd and found a seat at the front.

squeeze.eng_def: the act of pressing something firmly
squeeze.eg: She gave the present a quick squeeze and tried to guess what was inside.
The squeeze on profits in the oil industry has led to thousands of redundancies.

squeeze.eng_def: a period in which the supply of money is limited by the government because of economic difficulties
squeeze.eg: The government has imposed a sharp credit squeeze in an attempt to hold down inflation.

squeeze.eng_def: a situation in which people or things are pushed or forced into a small space
squeeze.eg: I can give you a lift, but it'll be a tight squeeze as I'm taking four other people as well.

squirrel.eng_def: a small animal covered in fur with a long tail. Squirrels climb trees and feed on nuts and seeds.

stab.eng_def: to injure someone with a sharp pointed object such as a knife
stab.eg: She was stabbed several times in the chest.

stab.eng_def: to make a short, forceful pushing movement with a finger or a long, thin object
stab.eg: As she spoke she stabbed the air with her finger.

stab.eng_def: the act of pushing a knife into someone, or an injury caused by stabbing
stab.chi_def: （用刀）戳，刺，捅；戳（或刺、捅）的傷口
stab.eg: He was admitted to hospital with stab wounds.

stab.eng_def: a sudden feeling, especially an unpleasant one such as pain
stab.chi_def: 突發的一陣感覺；（尤指）一陣難受，一陣刺痛
stab.eg: She felt a stab of envy when she saw all the expensive presents Zoe had been given for Christmas.

stab.eng_def: an action or remark that attacks someone's reputation
stab.eg: Her criticism of the company's plans was a stab at the chairman himself.

stability.eng_def: a situation in which something is not likely to move or change

stabilize.eng_def: If something stabilizes, it becomes fixed or stops changing.
stabilize.eg: He suffered a second heart attack two days ago but his condition has now stabilized.

stabilize.eng_def: If you stabilize something, you cause it to become fixed or to stop changing.
stabilize.eg: In China, the policy of one child per family was introduced to stabilize the country's population at 1.6 billion.

stable.eng_def: firmly fixed or not likely to move or change
stable.eg: If the foundations of the house aren't stable, collapse is possible.

stable.eng_def: A stable person is mentally healthy.
stable.chi_def: 精神健全的，精神狀態穩定的
stable.eg: She seems more stable these days.

stable.eng_def: A stable substance keeps the same chemical or atomic state.
stable.chi_def: （物質的化學狀態或原子狀態）穩定的

stable.eng_def: a building in which horses are kept
a group of racehorses that are owned or trained by one person
stable.chi_def: （屬同一馬主或馴馬師的）一群賽馬

stable.eng_def: a group of people who perform a similar activity and who are trained by the same person or employed by the same organization
stable.chi_def: （受訓於同一人或受僱於同一機構的）一批人
stable.eg: During the 1950s, Sun Records' stable of singers included Johnny Cash and Jerry Lee Lewis.

stable.eng_def: to keep a horse in a stable

stack.eng_def: a pile of things arranged one on top of another
stack.eg: He chose a cartoon from the stack of DVDs on the shelf.
Don't worry, we've got stacks of time.

stack.eng_def: a set of shelves in a library that are positioned close together so that a lot of books can be stored on them
stack.chi_def: （圖書館中排列密集的）藏書書架；書庫

stack.eng_def: a car accident, especially one that causes damage
to arrange things in an ordered pile
stack.chi_def: 把…放成整齊的一堆；把…放成堆
stack.eg: Once the last few people had left the hall, the caretaker began stacking (up) the chairs.

stadium.eng_def: a large closed area of land with rows of seats around the sides and often with no roof, used for sports events and musical performances
stadium.eg: Thousands of fans packed into the stadium to watch the match.

staff.eng_def: the group of people who work for an organization
staff.eg: There is a good relationship between staff and pupils at the school.

staff.eng_def: a person who works for an organization
a long, strong stick held in the hand that is used as a support when walking, as a weapon, or as a symbol of authority
the five lines and four spaces between them on which musical notes are written
to be or provide the people who work for an organization
staff.chi_def: 成為員工，（為機構）提供人員
staff.eg: Many charity shops in Britain are staffed by/with volunteers.

stage.eng_def: a part of an activity or a period of development
stage.eg: The project is in its final stages and should be completed by August.

stage.eng_def: If you do something in stages, you divide the activity into parts and complete each part separately.
stage.eg: We're decorating the house in stages so it won't be ready for another couple of months.

stage.eng_def: one of the separate parts of a rocket, each part having its own engine
stage.eg: Once its fuel supply runs out, each stage separates from the main part of the rocket and falls back to earth.

stage.eng_def: the area in a theatre that is often raised above ground level and on which actors or entertainers perform
stage.eg: Hamlet is on stage for most of the act.

stage.eng_def: a particular area of public life
stage.eg: The president was extremely popular on the world stage but was disliked in his own country.

stage.eng_def: to go onto the stage and start to perform
to arrange and perform a play or show
stage.eg: The local drama group is staging a production of the musical "Grease".
London staged the Olympic Games in 2012.

stagger.eng_def: to walk or move with difficulty as if you are going to fall
stagger.chi_def: 搖晃；蹣跚；踉踉蹌蹌地走
stagger.eg: After he was attacked, he managed to stagger to the phone and call for help.

stagger.eng_def: to cause someone to feel shocked or surprised because of something unexpected or very unusual happening
stagger.eg: He staggered all his colleagues by suddenly announcing that he was leaving the company at the end of the month.

stagger.eng_def: to arrange things, especially hours of work, holidays, or events, so that they begin at different times from those of other people
stagger.chi_def: 使（尤指工作、假期或事件的時間）錯開；使交錯
stagger.eg: Some countries have staggered school holidays so that holiday resorts do not become overcrowded.

stagger.eng_def: If the start of a race is staggered, the competitors start at different times or in different positions.
stagger.chi_def: （賽跑時）使（起跑時間或起跑位置）錯開

stagger.eng_def: a way of walking or moving in which you almost fall
stagger.eg: He left the bar with a drunken stagger.

stain.eng_def: to leave a mark on something that is difficult to remove
stain.eg: Tomato sauce stains terribly - it's really difficult to get it out of clothes.

stain.eng_def: If a material stains, it absorbs substances easily, causing it to become covered with marks, or coloured by a chemical.
stain.eg: This carpet is ideal for the kitchen because it doesn't stain easily.

stain.eng_def: to change the colour of something using a chemical
stain.eg: She stripped the floorboards and stained them dark brown.

stain.eng_def: to permanently spoil something such as someone's reputation
stain.eg: Several important politicians have had their reputations stained by this scandal.

stain.eng_def: a dirty mark on something that is difficult to remove
a chemical for changing the colour of something
permanent damage to someone's reputation or character
stain.eg: His solicitor said, "He leaves this court without a stain on his character."

stair.eng_def: a set of steps that lead from one level of a building to another
stair.eg: Go up the stairs and her office is on the right.

stair.eng_def: one of the steps in a set of steps that lead from one level of a building to another
stair.eg: The top stair creaked as she went upstairs and the noise woke up her mother.
He climbed the wooden stair and knocked on his grandfather's door.

stake.eng_def: a share or a financial involvement in something such as a business
stake.eg: He holds (= owns) a 40 percent stake in/of the company.

stake.eng_def: If you have a stake in something, it is important to you because you have a personal interest or involvement in it.
stake.chi_def: 對…有強烈的興趣；與…有利害關係
stake.eg: Employers have a stake in the training of their staff.

stake.eng_def: the amount of money that you risk on the result of something such as a game or competition
stake.eg: She spent two weeks in Las Vegas playing high-stakes blackjack at the casinos.

stake.eng_def: In an activity or competition, the stakes are the reward for the person who wins or succeeds in it.
stake.chi_def: （活動或比賽的）獎金，獎品，回報
stake.eg: The team is playing for enormous stakes - the chance to play in the final.

stake.eng_def: used in the names of horse races in which the prize money is provided by all the owners of the horses that are competing in the race
stake.chi_def: （獎金由全部參賽馬主提供的）賽馬

stake.eng_def: a situation where someone is judged on how much of a particular quality they have
stake.eg: The prime minister is not very high in the popularity stakes (= he is not very popular) at the moment.

stake.eng_def: to increase the prize or reward in a competition or any activity in which you are competing
to make a situation more urgent or more difficult to ignore
stake.chi_def: 使情況更緊急；使事態擴大
stake.eg: The stowaways are trying to raise the stakes by refusing to eat until they are given money and aid.

stake.eng_def: a strong stick or metal bar with a pointed end
stake.eg: The stakes are pushed or hammered into the ground and can be used for supporting a plant or forming part of a fence.

stake.eng_def: in the past, a wooden post to which people were tied before being burned to death as a punishment
stake.eg: In medieval Europe, many women were accused of being witches and were burned at the stake.

stake.eng_def: to risk an amount of money
stake.eg: At the roulette table, he staked $10,000 on number 21.

stake.eng_def: to hold up and support something by fastening it to stakes

stale.eng_def: no longer new or fresh, usually as a result of being kept for too long
stale.chi_def: （通常指因久放）不新鮮的，走味的

stale.eng_def: not fresh and new; boring because too familiar
stale.chi_def: 過時的，老套的，沒有新意的

stale.eng_def: used to describe someone who has lost interest in what they are doing because of being bored or working too hard
stale.eg: They had been working together for over five years and they had both become a little stale.

stalk.eng_def: the main stem of a plant, or the narrow stem that joins leaves, flowers, or fruit to the main stem of a plant
stalk.chi_def: （植物的）莖，稈；（葉或果實的）柄，蒂；（花）梗
stalk.eg: She trimmed the stalks of the tulips before putting them in a vase.

stalk.eng_def: a narrow structure that supports a part of the body in some animals
stalk.eg: The eyes of shrimps are on movable stalks.

stalk.eng_def: to follow an animal or person as closely as possible without being seen or heard, usually in order to catch or kill them
stalk.chi_def: 跟蹤，悄悄地靠近（獵物或人）
stalk.eg: The police had been stalking the woman for a week before they arrested her.

stalk.eng_def: to illegally follow and watch someone over a period of time
stalk.chi_def: （在一段時期內）非法跟蹤騷擾
stalk.eg: He had stalked her for several months before he was arrested.

stalk.eng_def: If something unpleasant stalks a place, it appears there in a threatening way.
stalk.eg: When night falls, danger stalks the streets of the city.

stalk.eng_def: to walk in an angry or proud way
stalk.chi_def: 怒氣衝衝地走；趾高氣揚地走
stalk.eg: She refused to accept that she was wrong and stalked furiously out of the room.

stall.eng_def: a large table or a small shop with an open front from which goods are sold in a public place
stall.eg: In the village market, the stalls are piled high with local vegetables.

stall.eng_def: a small closed area within a farm building in which there is space for one animal to be kept
stall.chi_def: （農場建築中圈養單隻牲畜的）隔欄，分隔間

stall.eng_def: a small area of a room that is separated from the main part of the room by walls or curtains
stall.eg: There was one bathroom with a shower stall in the corner.

stall.eng_def: rows of fixed seats in a church, often with the sides and backs connected
stall.chi_def: （邊緣和背部常圍起來的）靠背長排座位

stall.eng_def: the seats on the main floor of a theatre or cinema, not at a higher level
If an engine stalls, or if you stall it, it stops working suddenly and without you intending it to happen.
stall.eg: A car may stall due to the driver braking too suddenly.

stall.eng_def: to delay taking action or avoid giving an answer in order to have more time to make a decision or get an advantage
stall.eg: She says she'll give me the money next week but I think she's just stalling (for time).

stall.eng_def: If you stall a person, you delay them or prevent them from doing something for a period of time.
stall.eg: I managed to stall him for a few days until I'd got enough money to pay back the loan.
Japan's economic growth has stalled, with industrial production contracting in June for the fourth straight month.

stall.eng_def: If you stall an event, you delay it or prevent it from making progress.
stall.eg: Commandos stalled the enemy attack by destroying three bridges.

stammer.eng_def: to speak or say something with unusual pauses or repeated sounds, either because of speech problems or because of fear and anxiety

stamp.eng_def: a small piece of paper with a picture or pattern on it that is stuck onto a letter or package before it is posted, to show that the cost of sending it has been paid
stamp.eg: I stuck a 50p stamp on the envelope.

stamp.eng_def: a tool for putting a mark on an object either by printing on it or pushing into it, or the mark made in this way
stamp.eg: A date stamp inside the front cover of a library book shows when it should be returned.

stamp.eng_def: a small piece of paper worth a particular amount of money that you can buy several of, as a way of paying for something over a period of time
a particular quality in something or someone, or a quality in something that shows it was done by a particular person or group of people
stamp.eg: Although this painting clearly bears the stamp of genius, we don't know who painted it.

stamp.eng_def: an act of putting the foot down on the ground hard, or the noise made in doing so
stamp.chi_def: （常指爲表示生氣）跺（腳）；重踏，重踩
stamp.eg: With a stamp of her foot she stormed out.

stamp.eng_def: to put a mark on an object either by printing on it or pushing into it with a small tool
stamp.eg: It is necessary to stamp your passport.

stamp.eng_def: to put a foot down on the ground hard and quickly, making a loud noise, often to show anger
stamp.chi_def: （常指爲表示生氣）跺（腳）；重踏，重踩
stamp.eg: The little boy was stamping his foot and refusing to take his medicine.

stamp.eng_def: to mark with a particular quality or show that someone has a particular quality
stamp.eg: Our new administrator seems to be trying to stamp her authority on every aspect of the department.

stand.eng_def: to be in a vertical state or to put into a vertical state, especially (of a person or animal) by making the legs straight
stand.chi_def: （使）直立；（使）站立；豎放；（尤指）站起來
stand.eg: Granny says if she stands for a long time her ankles hurt.

stand.eng_def: to be in, cause to be in, or get into a particular state or situation
stand.chi_def: （使）處於，進入（特定狀態或境況）
stand.eg: How do you think your chances stand (= are) of being offered the job?

stand.eng_def: to be put on trial in a law court
stand.eg: Two other men are to stand trial next month for their part in the bombing.

stand.eng_def: to be in, cause to be in, or put into a particular place
stand.eg: The room was empty except for a wardrobe standing in one corner.

stand.eng_def: Vehicles that are standing are waiting.
stand.eg: The train now standing at platform 8 is the 15.17 for Cardiff.

stand.eng_def: used on signs to mean vehicles are not allowed to park, even for short periods of time
stand.eg: The sign by the side of the road said "no standing".

stand.eng_def: to successfully accept or bear something that is unpleasant or difficult
to compete, especially in an election, for an official position
stand.eg: The president has announced she does not intend to stand for re-election.

stand.eng_def: to have a chance of success
stand.eg: She stands a good chance of passing her exam if she works hard.

stand.eng_def: to be a stated height
stand.eg: Even without his shoes he stood over two metres tall.

stand.eng_def: to buy something, especially a meal or a drink, for someone
stand.eg: I couldn't get to the bank, so could you stand me lunch?

stand.eng_def: to have as an opinion
stand.eg: How/Where does he stand on foreign policy issues?

stand.eng_def: a large structure at a sports ground, usually with a sloping floor and sometimes a roof, where people either stand or sit to watch a sports event
a stand
stand.eg: Fighting broke out in the stands five minutes before the end of the match.

stand.eng_def: an opinion, especially one that is public
stand.eg: What's her stand on sexual equality?

stand.eng_def: the place in which a person stands in a law court when they are being asked questions
stand.eg: The witness took the stand (= went to the place in a court where you stand and answer questions).

stand.eng_def: a small shop or stall or an area where products can be shown, usually outside or in a large public building, at which people can buy things or get information
a frame or piece of furniture for supporting or putting things on
an act of opposition, especially in order to defend someone or something
stand.chi_def: 反對；抵抗，抵制；（尤指）捍衛
stand.eg: Environmental groups are making a stand against the new road through the valley.

stand.eng_def: a particular number or period of performances
stand.chi_def: （在某地的）停留演出；停留比賽
stand.eg: The Orioles will be in town for a three-game stand.

standard.eg: This essay is not of an acceptable standard - do it again.

standard.eng_def: a moral rule that should be obeyed
standard.eg: Most people agree that there are standards (of behaviour) that need to be upheld.

standard.eng_def: a pattern or model that is generally accepted
standard.eg: This program is an industry standard for computers.

standard.eng_def: a song or other piece of music that has been popular and often played over a long period of time
standard.chi_def: （經常演唱或演奏的）標準曲目，保留曲目

standard.eng_def: a car with gears that are changed by hand
a flag, especially a long, narrow one ending with two long points
standard.chi_def: 旗；（尤指）末端有兩個尖的窄長旗

standard.eng_def: usual rather than special, especially when thought of as being correct or acceptable
standard.eg: White is the standard colour for this model of refrigerator.

standard.eng_def: Language described as standard is the form of that language that is considered acceptable and correct by most educated users of it
standard.eg: Most announcers on the BBC speak standard English.

standard.eng_def: A standard book or writer is the one that is most commonly read for information on a particular subject
standard.eg: Her book is still a standard text in archaeology, even though it was written more than 20 years ago.

stanza.eng_def: a group of lines of poetry forming a unit

staple.eng_def: a short, thin piece of wire used to fasten sheets of paper together. It has sharp ends that are pushed through the paper and then bent flat by a special device.
a U-shaped piece of metal with sharp ends that is fixed into a surface to hold something, such as a wire fence, in a particular position
staple.chi_def: U 形釘（如 U 形電線卡）

staple.eng_def: a main product or part of something
staple.chi_def: 主要產品；某物的主要部分
staple.eg: Shortages mean that even staples (= basic foods) like bread are difficult to find.

staple.eng_def: basic or main; standard or regular
staple.chi_def: 基本的，主要的；標準的，常規的
staple.eg: The staple diet here is mutton, fish and boiled potatoes.
Would you mind stapling the reports together?

stapler.eng_def: a small device that you can hold in your hand or use on a table to push staples through pieces of paper

star.eng_def: a very large ball of burning gas in space that is usually seen from the earth as a point of light in the sky at night
star.eg: Stars twinkled above them as they lay on the hill.

star.eng_def: a very famous, successful, and important person, especially a performer such as a musician, actor, or sports player
a symbol with five or more points
used to show how good a restaurant, hotel, etc. is
star.chi_def: （用來表示餐館、旅館等的服務水準）兩星/三星（等等）
star.eg: The cheaper two-star hotels are also within the range of the budget traveller.

star.eng_def: a symbol made of metal or cloth worn by particular officials to show their rank
any planet or other object in the sky thought of in astrology as influencing a person's luck
star.chi_def: 星宿，星相，命星（占星術中認爲影響個人運氣的星體）
star.eg: She was born under a lucky/an unlucky star.
I always like to see what the stars say in the newspaper.

star.eng_def: If a film, play, etc. stars someone, or if someone stars in a film, play, etc., they are the main actor in it.
star.chi_def: （電影、戲劇等）由（某人）擔任主演；主演，擔任主角
star.eg: David Oyelowo starred in the movie "Selma".

star.chi_def: 最好的，最出色的；最重要的
star.eg: Natalie is, without a doubt, the star student in this year's ballet class.

star.eng_def: a measurement of quality, usually in numbers from one to five with one being the lowest
star.chi_def: （表示質量等級，一般爲一至五星）…星級
star.eg: A three-star hotel is better than a two-star.

starch.eng_def: a white substance that exists in large amounts in potatoes and particular grains such as rice
starch.eg: Corn starch is used as a thickener in stews.

starch.eng_def: a white substance from potatoes and particular grains, used to make cloth stiff
to make clothes stiff by washing them with starch
starch.eg: She wore a starched white apron over her black dress.

stare.eng_def: to look for a long time with the eyes wide open, especially when surprised, frightened, or thinking
stare.chi_def: （尤指驚訝、害怕或思考時）盯著看，凝視，注視
stare.eg: Don't stare at people like that, it's rude.

stare.eng_def: a long look at something or someone with your eyes wide open
stare.eg: She gave him a long stare but didn't answer his question.

start.eng_def: to begin doing something
start.eg: When do you start your course/your new job?

start.eng_def: If a business or other organization starts, or if someone starts one, it is created and starts to operate.
start.chi_def: （企業或其他機構）開業，開始營運；創辦，開辦
start.eg: She started her own software company.

start.eng_def: to begin to happen or to make something begin to happen
start.eg: A new series about wildlife has started on Monday nights.

start.eng_def: to begin a set of activities with the thing or person mentioned
start.eg: The speaker started with a description of her journey to China.

start.eng_def: to begin to complain or be annoying in some way
start.chi_def: 開始抱怨；開始惹人厭煩
start.eg: Don't start with me - we're not going and that's that!

start.eng_def: to begin
to have your first child
to begin an argument or a fight
start.eg: You could tell the guy wanted to start something, so we just walked away.

start.eng_def: to begin being employed
start.eg: He started work at 16 in a bakery.

start.eng_def: at the beginning, or as the first of several things
start.eg: We only knew two people in Montreal to start with, but we soon made friends.

start.eng_def: to begin at one point and then move to another, in distance or range
start.chi_def: 出發；動身，啟程；開始，（自…）起
start.eg: The run starts at/from the entrance to the park.

start.eng_def: to move your body suddenly because something has surprised or frightened you
start.eg: He started at the sound of the phone.

start.eng_def: to (cause to) begin to work or operate
start.eg: I'm having trouble starting the car.

start.eng_def: the beginning of something
start.eg: We were doubtful about the product's usefulness from the start.

start.eng_def: the act of beginning to do something
start.eg: We need to make a start on (preparing) the brochure next week.

start.eng_def: including all of something, from the beginning to the end
start.eg: The whole party was a disaster from start to finish.

start.eng_def: first, or as the first in a set of things
start.eg: We'll take names and phone numbers for a start, then later on we can get more details.

start.eng_def: used when giving a first example of something
start.eg: This book is better than her last one. For a start, it's shorter.

start.eng_def: an advantage that you have over someone else when you begin something
start.eg: We gave the youngest children a five-second start (= in a race).

start.eng_def: a sudden movement of the body that you make when something has surprised or frightened you

startle.eng_def: to do something unexpected that surprises and sometimes worries a person or animal
startle.chi_def: 使大吃一驚；使受驚，使嚇一跳
startle.eg: She was concentrating on her book and his voice startled her.

starvation.eng_def: the state of having no food for a long period, often causing death
starvation.eg: 20 million people face starvation unless a vast emergency aid programme is launched.

starve.eng_def: to (cause someone to) become very weak or die because there is not enough food to eat
starve.eg: Whole communities starved to death during the long drought.

starve.eng_def: If you are starved of something necessary or good, you do not receive enough of it.
starve.eg: People starved of sleep start to lose their concentration and may hallucinate.

state.eng_def: a condition or way of being that exists at a particular time
state.eg: The building was in a state of disrepair.
The article provides a useful summary of the current state of play in the negotiations.
The drought is worst in the central African states.

state.eng_def: a part of a large country with its own government, such as in Germany, Australia, or the US
state.chi_def: （德國、澳大利亞、美國等的）州，邦
state.eg: Alaska is the largest state in the US

state.eng_def: used to refer to the US
If a king, queen, or government leader does something in state, they do it in a formal way as part of an official ceremony.
state.chi_def: （君主或政府首腦）正式地，隆重地
state.eg: The Queen rode in state to the opening of Parliament.

state.eng_def: to say or write something, especially clearly and carefully
state.chi_def: （尤指清楚謹慎地）陳述，說明，聲明
state.eg: Our warranty clearly states the limits of our liability.

state.eng_def: provided, created, or done by the state (= government of a country)
State events are formal official ceremonies that involve a leader of a country or someone who represents the government.
state.chi_def: 國事的；國事規格的；正式的

statement.eng_def: something that someone says or writes officially, or an action done to express an opinion
statement.eg: The government is expected to issue a statement about the investigation to the press.

statement.eng_def: a record of the amounts of money paid into and taken out of your bank account during a particular period of time

statesman.eng_def: an experienced politician, especially one who is respected for making good judgments
statesman.chi_def: （尤指具有遠見卓識而受人尊敬的）政治家

station.eng_def: a building and the surrounding area where buses or trains stop for people to get on or off
a company that broadcasts radio or television programmes
a building or place used for a particular service or type of work
station.chi_def: （提供某種服務或進行某種工作的）站，所，局

station.eng_def: a building or place used for a particular service or type of work
station.chi_def: （提供某種服務或進行某種工作的）站，所，局

station.eng_def: a large farm with animals in Australia and New Zealand
station.chi_def: （澳大利亞和紐西蘭的）大牧場

station.eng_def: a particular position that someone has been ordered to move into or to stay in
station.eg: The police took up their stations at the edge of the road, holding back the crowd.

station.eng_def: to cause especially soldiers to be in a particular place to do a job
station.eg: I hear your son's in the army - where's he stationed?

stationery.eng_def: the things needed for writing, such as paper, pens, pencils, and envelopes
good quality paper for writing letters on and matching envelopes

statistic.eng_def: information based on a study of the number of times something happens or is present, or other numerical facts
statistic.eg: Statistics show/suggest that women live longer than men.

statistic.eng_def: the science of using information discovered from studying numbers
a fact in the form of a number that shows information about something
statistic.eg: The city's most shocking statistic is its high infant mortality rate.

statue.eng_def: an object made from a hard material, especially stone or metal, to look like a person or animal
statue.chi_def: （尤指石頭或金屬的）雕像，雕塑，塑像

stature.eng_def: the good reputation a person or organization has, based on their behaviour and ability

stature.eg: His red hair and short stature made him easy to recognize.

status.eng_def: an accepted or official position, especially in a social group
status.eg: The association works to promote the status of retired people as useful members of the community.

status.eng_def: the amount of respect, admiration, or importance given to a person, organization, or object
status.chi_def: 尊重程度；仰慕程度；重視程度

status.eng_def: on a social media website, especially Facebook™, a piece of information that you publish about yourself telling people what you are doing, thinking, etc. at a particular time

stay.eng_def: to not move away from or leave a place or situation
stay.eg: They need an assistant who is willing to stay for six months.

stay.eng_def: to continue doing something, or to continue to be in a particular state
stay.eg: Stay away from the edge of the cliff.

stay.eng_def: to live or be in a place for a short time as a visitor
stay.eg: I stayed in Montreal for two weeks then flew home.

stay.eng_def: to sleep somewhere for one night
stay.eg: We've arranged to stay overnight at my sister's house.
I still stay with my parents.

stay.eng_def: a period of time that you spend in a place
stay.eg: She planned a short stay at/in a hotel to celebrate their anniversary.

stay.eng_def: an order by a judge that stops a judgment being performed until new information can be considered
stay.chi_def: 緩期執行死刑／驅逐出境（等等）

steady.eng_def: happening in a smooth, gradual, and regular way, not suddenly or unexpectedly
steady.chi_def: 穩步的；持續的；有規律的
steady.eg: The procession moved through the streets at a steady pace.

steady.chi_def: 固定不動的；穩固的，平穩的
steady.eg: I'll hold the boat steady while you climb in.

steady.eng_def: work that is likely to continue for a long time and for which you will be paid regularly
steady.eg: Owning your own home and having a steady job will help when applying for a loan.

steady.eng_def: used to describe someone who can be trusted to show good judgment and act in a reasonable way
to make something stop shaking or moving
steady.eg: He wobbled around on the bike and then steadied himself.

steady.eng_def: to become calm and controlled, or to make someone do this
steady.eg: Some people say that a drink will steady your nerves.

steady.eng_def: to have a romantic relationship with one person for a long period
steady.chi_def: （和某人）保持穩定的戀愛關係
steady.eg: She's been going steady with Mike for six months.

steak.eng_def: a thick, flat piece of meat or fish, especially meat from a cow
steak.chi_def: 肉排；肉塊；魚排；魚塊；（尤指）牛排

steal.eng_def: to take something without the permission or knowledge of the owner and keep it
steal.eg: She admitted stealing the money from her employers.

steal.eng_def: to do something quickly or without being noticed
steal.eg: She stole a glance at her watch.

steal.eng_def: a product that has a very low price, or a price that is much lower than the original cost
steal.eg: I picked up a new iron in the sale - it was a steal.

steam.eng_def: the hot gas that is produced when water boils
steam.eg: Steam rose from the simmering stew.
The train/ship steamed out of the station/harbour.

steam.eng_def: to use steam to make something softer, especially glue so that something can be removed
steam.eg: Ross steamed open the envelope to see if it was a love letter.

steamer.eng_def: a boat or ship that moves by steam power
a container with holes in the bottom that is put over boiling water in order to cook food in steam, or a machine that cooks food with steam

steel.eng_def: a strong metal that is a mixture of iron and carbon, used for making things that need a strong structure, especially vehicles and buildings
to force yourself to get ready to do something unpleasant or difficult
steel.eg: She steeled herself to jump out of the plane.

steep.eng_def: (of a slope) rising or falling at a sharp angle
A steep rise or fall is one that goes very quickly from low to high or from high to low.
steep.chi_def: （上升或下降）急劇的，大起大落的
steep.eg: There has been a steep increase/rise in prices.

steep.eng_def: (especially of prices) too much, or more than is reasonable
steep.chi_def: （尤指價格）過高的，高得離譜的
steep.eg: They are having to face very steep taxes.

steep.eng_def: to cause to stay in a liquid, especially in order to become soft or clean, or to improve flavour
steep.chi_def: （尤指為軟化、清潔或入味）浸，浸泡
steep.eg: Leave the cloth to steep in the dye overnight.

steer.eng_def: to control the direction of a vehicle
steer.chi_def: 駕駛（交通工具）；掌方向盤
steer.eg: She carefully steered the car around the potholes.

steer.eng_def: If a vehicle steers, it follows a particular route or direction.
steer.chi_def: （交通工具）行駛，沿（特定路線或方向）行進
steer.eg: The ship passed Land's End, in Cornwall, then steered towards southern Ireland.

steer.eng_def: to take someone or something or make someone or something go in the direction in which you want him, her, or it
steer.eg: She steered her guests into the dining room.

steer.eng_def: a young male of the cattle family that has had its sex organs removed, usually kept for meat
to advise someone or give them useful information about something
steer.chi_def: 給予…建議，給予…有用資訊
steer.eg: Here are my questions. Can anyone give me a steer?
The guy at the information office gave me a bum steer - the restaurant was terrible.

stem.eng_def: a central part of something from which other parts can develop or grow, or which forms a support
the stick-like central part of a plant that grows above the ground and from which leaves and flowers grow, or a smaller thin part that grows from the central part and supports the leaves and flowers
the thin vertical part of a glass or similar container that joins the part that holds liquid to the flat bottom part on which it stands
stem.eg: Champagne glasses usually have long stems.

stem.eng_def: the part of a word that is left after you take off the ending
stem.eg: From the stem "sav-" you get "saves", "saved", "saving", and "saver".

stem.eng_def: the small part on the side of a watch that you turn to move the hands (= parts that point to the numbers), or to make the watch operate
the main supporting structure at the front of a ship
to stop something unwanted from spreading or increasing
stem.eg: These measures are designed to stem the rise of violent crime.

stem.eng_def: to stop the flow of a liquid such as blood
stem.eg: She tied a handkerchief around the wound to stem the flow of blood.

stem.eng_def: abbreviation for Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (as subjects of study)
stem.chi_def: 科學、技術、工程和數學（ Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics的縮寫）
stem.eg: We work with schools and colleges to help educators inspire students in STEM.

step.eng_def: to move by lifting your foot and putting it down in a different place, or to put your foot on or in something
step.eg: She stepped backwards and fell over a chair.
What's the next step in the process?

step.eng_def: an action in a series of actions taken for a particular purpose
step.eg: The country is taking its first tentative steps towards democracy.

step.eng_def: dealing with one thing and then another thing in a fixed order
step.chi_def: 逐步地，按部就班地，循序漸進地

step.eng_def: one of the surfaces that you walk on when you go up or down stairs
the act of lifting one foot and putting it down on a different part of the ground, such as when you walk or run
step.eg: Sophie took her first steps when she was eleven months old.

step.eng_def: the distance you cover when you take a step
step.eg: I'd only gone a few steps when I realized I'd forgotten to lock the door.

step.eng_def: the way you move your feet when you are walking or running, which can sometimes show how you are feeling
step.eg: She walked out of the office with a spring in her step (= in a way that showed she was happy).

step.eng_def: a particular movement that you make with your feet when you dance
step.eg: She's teaching me some basic dance steps.

step.eng_def: When people walk in step, they lift their feet off the ground and put them down again at the same time.
used to say that opinions, ideas, or ways of living that are the same as those of other people
step.chi_def: （意見、觀點或生活方式）合拍，協調，一致
step.eg: Television companies need to keep in step with public opinion.

step.eng_def: When someone is out of step, they do not lift the same foot and put it down again at the same time as other people.
step.eg: I'm no good at dancing - I always get completely out of step.

step.eng_def: used to say that opinions, ideas, or ways of living that are different from those of other people
step.chi_def: （意見、觀點或生活方式）不合拍，不一致，不協調
step.eg: The Republicans are out of step with the country, Williams said.

step.eng_def: the difference in pitch between two notes that are next to each other in the western musical scale
related to someone through a second marriage

stepchild.eng_def: the child of your husband or wife from a previous marriage

stepfather.eng_def: the man who is married to someone's mother but who is not their real father

stepmother.eng_def: the woman who is married to someone's father but who is not their real mother

stereo.eng_def: a way of recording or playing sound so that it is separated into two signals and produces more natural sound
stereo.eg: The concert will be broadcast in stereo.

stereo.eng_def: a piece of electrical equipment for playing music, listening to the radio, etc. that sounds very natural because the sounds come out of two speakers (= parts for playing sound)
stereo.chi_def: 立體聲音響，立體聲唱機

stereotype.eng_def: a set idea that people have about what someone or something is like, especially an idea that is wrong
stereotype.chi_def: （尤指錯誤的）刻板印象，老套俗見，成見

stereotype.eng_def: to have a set idea about what a particular type of person is like, especially an idea that is wrong
stereotype.chi_def: 對…形成刻板的看法；（尤指）對…有成見
stereotype.eg: The study claims that British advertising stereotypes women.

stern.eng_def: If something, such as a job, is stern, it is difficult.
stern.eg: The country's president is facing the sternest test of his authority since he came to power five years ago.

stern.eng_def: the back part of a ship or boat

stew.eng_def: a type of food consisting usually of meat or fish and vegetables cooked slowly in a small amount of liquid
stew.chi_def: （通常由肉或魚加蔬菜製成的）燉菜，燜菜

stew.eng_def: to cook meat, fish, vegetables, or fruit slowly and gently in a little liquid

stew.eg: You're not still stewing about what happened yesterday, are you?
With jobs so scarce, many young people spend long hours with little to do but drink and stew.

steward.eng_def: a person whose job it is to organize a particular event, or to provide services to particular people, or to take care of a particular place
steward.chi_def: （特定活動的）組織者，操辦者；服務員；管家；管理員
steward.eg: Stewards will be inspecting the race track at 9.00.

steward.eng_def: a person who serves passengers on a ship or aircraft
a person who organizes the supply and serving of food at a club
steward.chi_def: （俱樂部的）餐飲經理，餐飲主管
steward.eg: He's the steward of the City of Wakefield's Working Men's Club.

stewardess.eng_def: a person whose job it is to organize a particular event, or to provide services to particular people, or to take care of a particular place
stewardess.chi_def: （特定活動的）組織者，操辦者；服務員；管家；管理員
stewardess.eg: Stewards will be inspecting the race track at 9.00.

stewardess.eng_def: a person who serves passengers on a ship or aircraft
a person who organizes the supply and serving of food at a club
stewardess.chi_def: （俱樂部的）餐飲經理，餐飲主管
stewardess.eg: He's the steward of the City of Wakefield's Working Men's Club.

stick.eng_def: a thin piece of wood or other material
stick.eg: The old man was carrying a load of sticks.

stick.eng_def: a long, thin wooden pole that especially old or injured people use to help them walk
stick.chi_def: （尤指長者或傷者用的）手杖，拐杖

stick.eng_def: a long, thin piece of wood used in playing various sports
stick.chi_def: （曲棍球或長曲棍球）球棍；（馬球）球杆

stick.eng_def: a long, thin piece of something
a car with a stick shift

stick.eg: When they got married, they didn't have a stick of furniture.

stick.eng_def: to hit someone or something with a long, thin piece of wood
stick.eg: He said that when he was a boy, his father used to take a stick to him to punish him.
I really got/took stick from my boss about being late for work again.

stick.eng_def: an area in the countryside that is far from a town or city
stick.eg: I'm sick of living in the sticks.

stick.eng_def: to cause something to become fixed, for example with glue or another similar substance
stick.eg: I tried to stick the pieces together with some glue/tape.

stick.eng_def: If a name sticks, it continues to be used.
stick.chi_def: （名字）繼續使用的，保持不變的
stick.eg: Although her name is Clare, her little sister called her Lali, and somehow the name stuck.

stick.eng_def: to put something somewhere, especially in a not very careful way
stick.eg: "Where shall I put these books?" "Oh, just stick them on the table for now."

stick.eng_def: If you tell someone to stick something or where they can stick something, it means that you do not want to keep that thing.
stick.eg: "I've had enough of working here," she said, "You can stick your job!"

stick.eng_def: to push a pointed object into or through something, or (of a pointed object) to be pushed into or through something and stay there
stick.eg: She stuck the needle into my arm.

stick.eng_def: In some card games, if you stick, you say that you do not want to be given any more cards.
to bear or accept something or someone unpleasant
stick.eg: I don't think I can stick this job a day longer.

sticky.eng_def: made of or covered with a substance that stays attached to any surface it touches
sticky.chi_def: 黏性的；黏的；塗有黏膠的

sticky.eng_def: If the weather is sticky, it is very hot and the air feels wet.

sticky.eg: There were a few sticky moments during the meeting, but everything turned out all right in the end.

sticky.chi_def: 持有異議的，抱不合作態度的
sticky.eg: Their bank manager was sticky about lending them the money they wanted to borrow.

sticky.eng_def: used to describe a website or shop where people like to spend a long time
sticky.chi_def: （用來形容人們會停留很長時間的網站或商店）有黏性的
sticky.eg: Big media groups are drawn to social networking sites because of their "sticky" nature.

stiff.chi_def: 不易彎曲的；不易活動的
stiff.eg: The handle on this door is rather stiff.

stiff.eng_def: If you are stiff or part of your body is stiff, your muscles hurt when they are moved.
stiff.chi_def: （人或身體部位）僵硬的，僵直的
stiff.eg: Sitting still at a computer terminal all day can give you a stiff neck.

stiff.eng_def: behaving in a way that is formal and not relaxed
stiff.eg: The general is a tall man with steel spectacles and a stiff, pompous manner.
The athlete was given a stiff punishment for using drugs.

stiff.eng_def: an alcoholic drink that is very strong
stiff.chi_def: 烈性酒／白蘭地／杜松子酒（等等）
stiff.eg: A stiff whisky - that's what I need.

stiff.eng_def: A stiff price is very expensive.
stiff.eg: We had to pay a stiff membership fee to join the health club.

stiff.eng_def: very much, or to a great degree
stiff.eg: I got frozen stiff (= very cold) waiting at the bus stop.

stiff.eng_def: a person of the type described

stiff.eg: They found a stiff in the river.

stiff.eng_def: to not pay someone money that you owe them

still.eng_def: continuing to happen or continuing to be done

still.eg: You may not approve of what he did, but he's still your brother.

still.eng_def: to an even greater degree or in an even greater amount
still.eg: The number of people killed in the explosion is likely to rise still higher.

still.eng_def: staying in the same position; not moving
still.eg: Children find it difficult to sit/stand/stay still for very long.

still.eng_def: A still drink is one that is not fizzy (= with bubbles)
still.eg: Would you like still or sparkling water?

still.eng_def: to make something stop moving or become more calm
still.eg: He tried to still the swaying of the hammock.

still.eng_def: a photograph of a piece of action in a film
a time when it is quiet and calm
still.eg: In the still of the night, nothing moved.

still.eng_def: a piece of equipment used for making alcohol

stimulate.eng_def: to encourage something to grow, develop, or become active
stimulate.eg: The government plans to cut taxes in order to stimulate the economy.

stimulate.eng_def: to make someone excited and interested about something
stimulate.eg: The show was intended to stimulate and amuse.

stimulate.eng_def: to cause part of the body to operate
stimulate.chi_def: 促進（身體某部位）的功能
stimulate.eg: The drugs stimulate the damaged tissue into repairing itself.

stimulation.eng_def: an action or thing that causes someone or something to become more active or enthusiastic, or to develop or operate
stimulation.eg: While she was at home looking after her children, she felt deprived of intellectual stimulation.

stimulus.eng_def: something that causes growth or activity
stimulus.chi_def: 刺激（物），激勵（物）；促進因素
stimulus.eg: Foreign investment has been a stimulus to the industry.

stimulus.eng_def: something that causes part of the body to react
stimulus.chi_def: （使身體部位產生反應的）刺激
stimulus.eg: The tip of the tongue is sensitive to salt and sweet stimuli and the back of the tongue is sensitive to bitter stimuli.

sting.eng_def: If an insect, plant, or animal stings, it produces a small but painful injury, usually with a poison, by brushing against the skin or making a very small hole in the skin.
sting.eg: Do all types of bee sting?

sting.eng_def: to cause sharp but usually temporary pain
If someone's unkind remarks sting, they make you feel upset and annoyed.
sting.eg: She knew he was right, but his words still stung.

sting.eng_def: to charge someone a surprisingly large amount of money for something
sting.eg: The bank stung me for £50 in charges when I got overdrawn.

sting.eng_def: a sudden burning pain in your eyes, on your skin, etc., or the ability to cause such pain
the feeling of being upset by something
a pointed part of an insect, plant, or animal that goes through a person's or animal's skin and leaves behind poison
sting.chi_def: （昆蟲或動物的）刺，蜇刺，蜇針；（植物的）刺毛

sting.eng_def: a carefully planned and complicated plan which deceives people so that criminals can steal something
sting.eg: A bank employee was involved in the sting in which $5 million was stolen.

sting.eng_def: a police action to catch criminals in which the police pretend to be criminals
sting.chi_def: （警方為抓捕罪犯的）臥底（行動）

sting.eng_def: a very short animation (= film using moving drawings) used as a form of advertising for a brand (= product name), TV channel, etc.
sting.chi_def: （用作產品或電視頻道品牌宣傳的）非常短小的動畫

stingy.eg: He's really stingy and never buys anyone a drink when we go out.

stink.chi_def: 散發異味，發出難聞的氣味

stink.eng_def: to be extremely bad or unpleasant
stink.eg: I think her whole attitude stinks.
The stink of rotting seaweed was strong along the seashore.

stir.eng_def: to mix a liquid or other substance by moving an object such as a spoon in a circular pattern
stir.eg: Stir the sauce gently until it begins to boil.

stir.eng_def: to move or to cause something to move slightly
stir.eg: A light breeze stirred the leaves lying on the path.

stir.eng_def: to wake up or begin to move or take action
stir.eg: The alarm clock went off, but she didn't stir.

stir.eng_def: If something stirs you, it makes you feel a strong emotion.
stir.eg: I was deeply stirred by her performance.

stir.eng_def: If an emotion stirs within you, you begin to feel it.
to cause trouble intentionally between other people, especially by telling false or secret information
stir.chi_def: 挑撥離間；（尤指）搬弄是非
stir.eg: There's a lot of gossip about me going around. Have you been stirring?

stir.eng_def: the act of stirring a liquid or other substance in order to mix it
stir.eg: Could you give the soup a quick stir?

stir.eng_def: a lot of interest or excitement
stir.eg: The scandal caused/created quite a stir at the time.

stir.eng_def: an occasion when a group of people march or stand together to show that they disagree with or support something or someone; a demonstration

stitch.eng_def: a piece of thread sewn in cloth, or the single movement of a needle and thread into and out of the cloth that produces this
stitch.eg: Secure the two pieces together with a couple of stitches.

stitch.eng_def: one of the small circles of wool that you make when you are knitting
stitch.eg: He cast on/off a stitch (= added/removed a length of thread from the needle).

stitch.eng_def: a particular type of stitch made in sewing or knitting, or the pattern that this produces
stitch.chi_def: 縫法；針法；編織法；縫製（或編織）的紋樣

stitch.eng_def: a length of special thread used to join the edges of a deep cut in the flesh

stitch.eg: I don't have a stitch to wear (= I do not have anything suitable to wear) for this party tonight.

stitch.eng_def: a sharp pain in the side of your stomach or chest, often caused by not breathing enough when running or laughing
stitch.chi_def: （常因跑步或大笑時呼吸不足引起的）肋部刺痛；岔氣
stitch.eg: I got a stitch after running for the bus.

stitch.eng_def: to sew two things together, or to repair something by sewing
stitch.eg: This button needs to be stitched back onto my shirt.

stitch.eng_def: to make a piece of clothing
stitch.eg: I must discard these old shirts and stitch some before next summer.

stock.eng_def: a supply of something for use or sale
stock.eg: It is now halfway through winter and food stocks are already low.

stock.eng_def: the total amount of goods or the amount of a particular type of goods available in a shop
stock.eg: This shop sells its old stock at very low prices.

stock.eng_def: the amount of money that a company has through selling shares to people
stock.eg: They own 20 percent of the company's stock.

stock.eng_def: part of the ownership of a company that can be bought by members of the public
stock.eg: Stock prices fell yesterday in heavy trading.

stock.eng_def: money that people invest in the government, producing a fixed rate of interest
a liquid used to add flavour to food, made by boiling meat or fish bones or vegetables in water
animals, such as cows or sheep, kept on a farm
the degree to which a person or organization is popular and respected
stock.eg: At present, the prime minister's stock is high/low.

stock.eng_def: the family or group that a person or animal comes from
stock.chi_def: （人的）祖先，血統，家族，世系；（動物的）種，原種
stock.eg: He's an American of Irish stock.

stock.eng_def: the support or handle of a tool, especially the part of a gun that rests against your shoulder
in the past, a wooden frame that was fixed around someone's feet, hands, and sometimes head, so that they were forced to sit or stand for a long time in public as a punishment
stock.chi_def: 手枷，足枷，頭枷（歐洲中世紀的刑具）

stock.eng_def: a garden plant with small pleasant-smelling, brightly coloured flowers
If a shop or factory stocks something, it keeps a supply of it.
stock.eg: Most supermarkets stock a wide range of wines.

stock.eng_def: to fill something such as a cupboard or shelves with food or goods
stock.eg: He has a part-time job stocking shelves in the local supermarket.

stock.eng_def: (of an idea, expression, or action) usual or typical, and used or done so many times that it is no longer original
stock.chi_def: （想法、表達方式或行動）老一套的，陳腐的，一成不變的

stocking.eng_def: one of a pair of tight-fitting coverings for the feet and legs made of thin material and often worn under skirts and dresses

stomach.eng_def: an organ in the body where food is digested, or the soft front part of your body just below the chest
stomach.eg: He was punched in the stomach.

stomach.eng_def: to be able to accept an unpleasant idea or watch something unpleasant
stomach.chi_def: 能夠容忍，承受得住（令人不快的想法或景象）
stomach.eg: He can't stomach the idea that Peter might be the next chairman.
