stone.eng_def: the hard, solid substance found in the ground that is often used for building, or a piece of this
a piece of hard material that can form in some organs in the body and cause severe pain
a unit of weight equal to 14 pounds or 6.35 kilograms, used especially when talking about a person's weight
stone.chi_def: 英石（重量單位，等於6.35公斤或14磅）
stone.eg: I weigh ten and a half stone.

stone.eng_def: a small piece of a hard, valuable substance, such as a diamond, that is found in the ground and used in jewellery
a large, hard seed inside some types of fruit
stone.eg: Peaches, plums, and olives all contain stones.

stone.eng_def: to throw stones at something or someone
stone.eg: Rioters set up barricades and stoned police cars.

stone.eng_def: to kill someone as a punishment by throwing stones at them
to remove the stone from a fruit
stone.eg: Could you stone the cherries for me?

stool.eng_def: a seat without any support for the back or arms
a piece of solid waste from the body
stool.eg: He told the doctor he had been passing bloody stools.

stoop.eng_def: to bend the top half of the body forward and down
stoop.eg: The doorway was so low that we had to stoop to go through it.

stoop.eng_def: If someone stoops, their head and shoulders are always bent forwards and down.
stoop.eg: He's over six feet tall, but the way he stoops makes him look shorter.

stoop.eng_def: a raised flat area in front of the door of a house, with steps leading up to it
stoop.eg: She got home to find the kids sitting on the stoop waiting for her.

stoop.eng_def: a way of standing or walking with the head and shoulders bent slightly forwards and down
stoop.eg: He is a tall man with a slight stoop.

stop.eng_def: to finish doing something that you were doing
stop.eg: Once I start eating chocolate, I can't stop.

stop.eng_def: to not move any more or to make someone or something not move any more
stop.eg: Stop the car, I want to get out!

stop.eng_def: to finish doing something that you do regularly or as a habit
stop.chi_def: 戒除，停止（常做的事或習慣）

stop.eng_def: to pause for a short time while travelling or during an activity
stop.eg: Does this train stop at Finsbury Park?

stop.eng_def: to prevent someone from doing something
stop.eg: If she really wants to leave, I don't understand what's stopping her.

stop.eng_def: to tell your bank not to deal with a cheque that you have written, so that the money is not paid from your bank account

stop.eg: Are you coming with me or are you stopping here?
We stopped (up) the gap with some rags.

stop.eng_def: the act of stopping an activity or journey, or a period of time when you stop
stop.chi_def: 停止，終止；逗留，停留；停留時間
stop.eg: Please remain in your seat until the plane comes to a complete stop.

stop.eng_def: a place where vehicles, especially buses, stop in order to allow passengers to get off and on
short form of full stop UK
a  plosive  (= consonant that is made by completely stopping the flow of air)
to stop an unpleasant, unwanted activity or habit from continuing
stop.eg: He used to smoke in bed when I first got to know him, but I soon put a stop to that!

storage.eng_def: the putting and keeping of things in a special place for use in the future
storage.eg: We've had to build some cupboards to give us more storage space.

storage.eng_def: If things such as furniture are in storage, they are being kept safe in a special building while they are not needed.

store.eng_def: a large shop where you can buy many different types of goods
an amount of something that is being kept for future use
store.eg: He has an impressively large store of wine in his cellar.

store.eng_def: a building in which things are kept until they are needed
to put or keep things in a special place for use in the future
store.eg: The data is stored on a hard disk and backed up on a CD.

storm.eng_def: an extreme weather condition with very strong wind, heavy rain, and often thunder and lightning
storm.eg: A lot of trees were blown down in the recent storms.

storm.eng_def: a very angry reaction from a lot of people
storm.eg: There was a storm of protest when the new tax was announced.

storm.eng_def: to be suddenly extremely successful in a place or with a group of people
storm.chi_def: 在（某處）大獲成功；完全征服（一群人）
storm.eg: Her performance has taken the critics by storm.

storm.eng_def: to attack a place or building by entering suddenly in great numbers
storm.eg: The fortress was stormed by hundreds of soldiers.

storm.eng_def: to express anger in a loud and often uncontrolled way
storm.eg: "Get out and never come back!" he stormed.

storm.eng_def: to enter or leave a place in a way that shows that you are angry
storm.eg: He stormed out of the house, slamming the door as he went.

storm.eng_def: used to form words for particular types of violent weather
storm.chi_def: …風暴的（用於構詞，表示特殊類型的暴烈天氣）

stormy.eng_def: with strong wind, heavy rain, and often thunder and lightning
involving a lot of strong argument and shouting
stormy.chi_def: 猛烈的；激烈的；爭吵的；群情激憤的

story.eng_def: a description, either true or imagined, of a connected series of events
story.chi_def: （真實或虛構的）故事；敘述，描述；小說
story.eg: Will you read/tell me a story, daddy?

story.eng_def: a report in a newspaper or on a news broadcast of something that has happened
story.eg: The main story in the papers today is the president's speech.
He made up some story about having to be at his aunt's wedding anniversary.

stout.eng_def: (especially of older people) fat and solid-looking, especially around the waist
stout.chi_def: （尤指上年紀的人腰部）粗壯結實的
stout.eg: Mrs Blower was the stout lady with the glasses.

stout.eng_def: Stout objects are strongly made from thick, strong materials.
stout.eg: I bought myself a pair of good stout hiking boots.
He needed a stout heart and nerves of steel.

stout.eng_def: a dark, bitter type of beer

stove.eng_def: a piece of equipment that burns fuel or uses electricity in order to heat a place
a large box-shaped device that is used to cook and heat food, either by putting the food inside or by putting it on the top

straight.eng_def: continuing in one direction without bending or curving

straight.eg: Just be straight with her and tell her how you feel.

straight.eng_def: If you tell someone something straight out, you say it directly and honestly, without trying to make what you are saying more pleasant.
straight.chi_def: 直接了當地；不拐彎抹角地
straight.eg: I told her straight out that I didn't love her any more.
I got home and went straight to bed.
I knew straight away what you were thinking.
You know you've had too much to drink when you can't see straight.
It's a straight choice - either you leave him or you stay.

straight.eng_def: level and not sloping to either side
plain and basic, or without anything added
straight.eg: No tonic for me, please, I like my vodka straight.

straight.eng_def: following one after another without an interruption
straight.eg: They're the only team to have won ten straight games this season.

straight.chi_def: 整齊的，整潔的；井井有條的
straight.eg: It only took an hour to get the flat straight after the party.

straight.chi_def: 傳統的，正統的；規矩的；嚴肅的
straight.eg: He was a nice enough guy, but he was so straight - I always felt I had to be on my best behaviour with him.

straight.eng_def: not using illegal drugs or alcohol
straight.eg: He's been straight for five months.

straight.eng_def: neither owing nor owed any money
straight.eg: You bought the tickets, so if I pay for the taxi, we'll be straight.

straight.eng_def: the straight part of a racetrack (= the track on which competitors race)
straight.eg: And the runners are just coming up to the finishing straight.

straight.eng_def: a person who is not gay

straighten.eng_def: to become straight or to make something become straight

straighten.eg: The picture fell while I was trying to straighten it.
She stood up and straightened her clothes.

straightforward.eg: Just follow the signs to Bradford - it's very straightforward.

straightforward.eng_def: (of a person) honest and not likely to hide their opinions
straightforward.eg: Roz is straightforward and lets you know what she's thinking.

strain.eng_def: a force or influence that stretches, pulls, or puts pressure on something, sometimes causing damage
strain.eg: The hurricane put such a strain on the bridge that it collapsed.

strain.eng_def: an injury to a muscle or similar soft part of the body caused by using that part too much
strain.chi_def: （肌肉等軟組織的）損傷，拉傷，扭傷

strain.eng_def: something that makes you feel nervous and worried
strain.eg: She's a lot better than she was but she's still not ready to face the stresses and strains of a job.

strain.chi_def: 類型；品質；個性特點，稟性
strain.eg: A strain of puritanism runs through all her work.

strain.eng_def: an animal or plant from a particular group whose characteristics are different in some way from others of the same group
strain.eg: Scientists have discovered a new strain of the virus which is much more dangerous.

strain.eng_def: the sound of music being played or performed
strain.eg: I could hear the strains of Mozart in the background.

strain.eng_def: to separate liquid food from solid food, especially by pouring it through a utensil with small holes in it
strain.eg: Could you strain the vegetables, please.

strain.eng_def: to become stretched or to experience pressure, or to make something do or experience this
strain.chi_def: （使）緊張，（使）承受壓力；拉緊，繃緊；損傷
strain.eg: I've put on such a lot of weight recently - this dress is straining at the seams.

strain.eng_def: to cause too much of something to be used, especially money
strain.eg: Increases in wholesale oil prices have strained the company's finances.

strait.eng_def: a narrow area of sea that connects two larger areas of sea
a difficult situation, especially because of financial problems
strait.chi_def: （尤指財務問題導致的）窘境，困境
strait.eg: So many companies are in such dire/difficult straits that their prices have come right down.

strand.eng_def: a thin thread of something, often one of a few, twisted around each other to make a string or rope
strand.eg: She tucked a loose strand of hair behind her ears.

strand.eng_def: a part that combines with other parts to form a whole story, subject, or situation
strand.chi_def: （完整故事、主題或情況的）部分，方面
strand.eg: There are so many different strands to the plot that it's hard to follow.

strange.eng_def: unusual and unexpected, or difficult to understand
strange.chi_def: 不尋常的；奇怪的；不可思議的
strange.eg: He has some very strange ideas about women!

strange.eng_def: to feel uncomfortable and not normal or correct
strange.chi_def: 感覺不舒服；感覺不正常
strange.eg: I hope that fish was all right - my stomach feels a little strange .
I don't accept rides from strange men.

stranger.eg: My mother always warned me not to talk to strangers.

stranger.eng_def: A stranger in a particular place is someone who has never been there before
stranger.eg: Do you know the way to the bus station, or are you a stranger here too?

strangle.eng_def: to kill someone by pressing their throat so that they cannot breathe
strangle.eg: She had been strangled with her own scarf and her body dumped in the woods.
For years, the organization was strangled by excessive bureaucracy.

strap.eng_def: a narrow piece of leather or other strong material used for fastening something or giving support
strap.eg: Could you help me fasten this strap around my suitcase?

strap.eng_def: with this meaning as a combining form
a strong strip of material hanging from the roof of a bus, train, or other public vehicle for passengers to hold onto if they are standing
strap.chi_def: （公車、火車或其他公共車輛裡便於站立的乘客抓握的）吊帶

strap.eng_def: to fasten something in position by fastening a narrow piece of leather or other strong material around it
strap.eg: Are the kids strapped into their car seats?

strategic.eng_def: helping to achieve a plan, for example in business or politics
strategic.chi_def: 有助於計劃成功的；戰略（性）的

strategic.eng_def: used to provide military forces with an advantage
strategic.chi_def: （武器、戰爭或地方）戰略性的，有戰略優勢的：
strategic.eg: There are plans to modernize the US strategic forces.

strategy.eng_def: a detailed plan for achieving success in situations such as war, politics, business, industry, or sport, or the skill of planning for such situations
strategy.chi_def: 戰略；策略；計謀；行動計劃；策劃，部署
strategy.eg: The president held an emergency meeting to discuss military strategy with the Pentagon yesterday.

straw.eng_def: the dried, yellow stems of crops such as wheat, used as food for animals or as a layer on the ground for animals to lie on, and for making traditional objects
a thin tube made of plastic or waterproof paper that is used to suck liquid into the mouth
straw.eg: Why don't you drink your milk through a straw?

strawberry.eng_def: a small juicy red fruit that has small brown seeds on its surface, or the plant with white flowers on which this fruit grows

stray.eng_def: to travel along a route that was not originally intended, or to move outside a limited area
stray.chi_def: 偏離原路；越過限定區域
stray.eg: A herd of cattle had strayed into the road.

stray.eng_def: to start thinking or talking about a different subject from the one you should be giving attention to
stray.eg: I think we've strayed too far from our original plan.

stray.eng_def: a pet that no longer has a home or cannot find its home
Stray things have moved apart from similar things and are not in their expected or intended place.
stray.eg: There are still a few stray spots of paint on the window pane.

streak.eng_def: a long, thin mark that is easily noticed because it is very different from the area surrounding it
streak.eg: The window cleaner left dirty streaks on the windows.

streak.eng_def: an often unpleasant characteristic that is very different from other characteristics
streak.eg: Her stubborn streak makes her very difficult to work with sometimes.

streak.eng_def: a short period of good or bad luck
streak.eg: I just hope my lucky streak continues until the world championships.

streak.eng_def: to move somewhere extremely quickly, usually in a straight line
streak.eg: The motorbike streaked off down the street.

streak.eng_def: to run naked through a public place in order to attract attention or to express strong disapproval of something
to have long, thin noticeable lines of a different colour
streak.eg: Doesn't Chris look good with her hair streaked?

stream.eng_def: water that flows naturally along a fixed route formed by a channel cut into rock or ground, usually at ground level
any current of water or liquid
stream.eg: the level of cholesterol in your blood stream

stream.eng_def: the direction in which water is moving
stream.eg: She stopped rowing and let the boat float with the stream.

stream.eng_def: a continuous flow of things or people
stream.eg: There has been a steady stream of phone calls from worried customers.

stream.eng_def: a group of school students with similar ability who are approximately the same age and are taught together
stream.chi_def: （同齡學生依照學習能力編排的）班，組
stream.eg: I'm in the A stream for maths, and the B stream for English.

stream.eng_def: to flow somewhere or produce liquid, quickly and in large amounts without stopping
stream.eg: There were tears streaming down his face.

stream.eng_def: to move continuously in one direction
stream.eg: We were all very excited as we streamed out of our final exam.

stream.eng_def: to listen to or watch sound or video on a computer directly from the internet rather than downloading it and saving it first
to group and teach together school students with similar abilities who are approximately the same age
stream.chi_def: （把同齡學生依照學習能力）編排成班（或組）
stream.eg: We start to stream the children in the third form.

street.eng_def: a road in a city or town that has buildings that are usually close together along one or both sides
street.eg: The streets were strewn with rubbish after the parade.

street.eng_def: When people take to the streets, they express their opposition to something in public and often violently.
street.chi_def: 上街遊行示威，走上街頭
street.eg: Thousands of people have taken to the streets to protest against the military coup.

strength.eng_def: the ability to do things that need a lot of physical or mental effort
strength.eg: She had the strength and stamina to take the lead and win the gold medal.

strength.eng_def: the degree to which something is strong or powerful
strength.eg: If the two parties joined forces, their combined strength would be 127 seats.
She's well aware of her strengths and weaknesses as an artist.

strength.eng_def: the number of people in a group
strength.eg: What's the current strength of the city's police force?
Demonstrators arrived in strength to protest against the military action.

strength.eng_def: If a group is below strength, it consists of fewer people or members than usual.
strength.eg: The office will be below strength in August when a lot of people will be away.

strength.eng_def: at the best level of ability possible
strength.chi_def: 處於最佳狀態；處於能力最強的階段
strength.eg: He is not expected to be at full strength for the rest of the season.

strength.eng_def: with the complete number of people who are usually in a group
strength.eg: Staff cuts have meant that we haven't been working at full strength for a year.

strengthen.eng_def: to make something stronger or more effective, or to become stronger or more effective
strengthen.eg: They have been strengthening their border defences in preparation for war.

stress.eng_def: great worry caused by a difficult situation, or something that causes this condition
stress.chi_def: 緊張，壓力；造成緊張的因素
stress.eg: People under a lot of stress may experience headaches, minor pains, and sleeping difficulties.

stress.eng_def: the way that a word or syllable is pronounced with greater force than other words in the same sentence or other syllables in the same word
stress.eg: The meaning of a sentence often depends on stress and intonation.

stress.eng_def: a force that acts in a way that often changes the shape of an object
stress.eg: Computers work out the stresses that such a craft will encounter in flight.
During his speech, he laid particular stress on the freedom of the press.

stress.eng_def: to give emphasis or special importance to something
stress.eg: He is careful to stress (that) the laboratory's safety standards are the best in the country.

stress.eng_def: to pronounce a word or syllable with greater force than other words in the same sentence or other syllables in the same word, or to play a musical note with greater force than others in a group
stress.eg: In the word "engine" you should stress the first syllable.
Don't stress over it - we'll soon get it sorted out.

stretch.eng_def: to cause something to reach, often as far as possible, in a particular direction
stretch.eg: I tripped on a piece of wire that someone had stretched across the path.

stretch.eng_def: to make your body or your arms and legs straight so that they are as long as possible, in order to exercise the joints (= place where two bones are connected) after you have been in the same place or position for a long time
stretch.eg: "I'm so tired," she said, yawning and stretching.

stretch.eng_def: to spread over a large area or distance
stretch.eg: A huge cloud of dense smoke stretched across the horizon.

stretch.eng_def: to go as far as or past the usual limit of something
stretch.chi_def: 到…的限度；超過…的限度；竭盡
stretch.eg: Many families' budgets are already stretched to breaking point.

stretch.eng_def: to (cause a material to) become longer or wider than usual as a result of pulling at the edges
stretch.eg: an exercise to stretch the leg muscles

stretch.eng_def: If a material stretches, it can become longer or wider when pulled and then return to its original size.
to spread over a long period of time
stretch.eg: The dispute stretches back over many years.

stretch.eng_def: to make a process or task continue for a longer period of time than was originally planned
stretch.eg: I'd like to stretch my mortgage payments out over a longer period if possible.

stretch.eng_def: If jobs or tasks stretch you, they make you learn new things that use your skill and experience more than before.
stretch.chi_def: （工作或任務）使施展本領，對…具有挑戰性
stretch.eg: My present job doesn't stretch me, so I'm looking for something more demanding.

stretch.eng_def: a continuous area of land or water
stretch.eg: This particular stretch of coast is especially popular with hikers.

stretch.eng_def: a stage in a race, or a part of a racetrack
stretch.eg: She looked certain to win as she entered the final stretch.
I always have a good stretch when I get up in the morning.

stretch.eng_def: the fact that something has gone past its usual limits
stretch.chi_def: 超過限度；過分；離譜；破例
stretch.eg: His idea may be a stretch, but it's not outside the realm of possibility.

stretch.eng_def: the degree to which a material can be made longer or wider by pulling
stretch.eg: This fabric doesn't have much stretch in it, does it?
The elderly generally need far less rest than the young, and tend to sleep in several short stretches.

stretch.eng_def: a period of time that a criminal spends in prison
stretch.eg: Her brother's doing a ten-year stretch for armed robbery.
There's no way I could work for ten hours at a stretch.

stretch.eng_def: a job, task , or role that is difficult for someone because it is very different from what they usually do
stretch.chi_def: （演員的）有難度的表演，拓寬戲路的表演
stretch.eg: Playing a budding opera star was not much of a stretch for this classically trained singer.

strict.eng_def: strongly limiting someone's freedom to behave as they wish, or likely to severely punish someone if they do not obey
strict.eg: My parents were very strict with me when I was young.

strict.chi_def: 精確的，完全正確的；嚴謹的
strict.eg: a strict translation of the text

strict.eng_def: used to refer to someone who follows the rules and principles of a belief or way of living very carefully and exactly, or a belief or principle that is followed very carefully and exactly
strict.chi_def: 恪守信條的，嚴格遵循（某種生活方式）的；不折不扣的；（信條或原則）必須恪守的

strict.eng_def: in the most limited meaning of a word, phrase, etc.
strict.eg: These were not funerals in the strict sense of the word; there were no caskets or physical remains.

stride.eg: The West made impressive strides in improving energy efficiency after the huge rises in oil prices during the 70s.

stride.eng_def: a long step when walking or running
stride.eg: She attributes her record-breaking speed to the length of her stride.

stride.eng_def: to walk somewhere quickly with long steps
stride.eg: She strode purposefully up to the desk and demanded to speak to the manager.

strike.eng_def: to refuse to continue working because of an argument with an employer about working conditions, pay levels, or job losses
strike.eg: Democratization has brought workers the right to strike and join a trade union.

strike.eng_def: to cause a person or place to suffer severely from the effects of something very unpleasant that happens suddenly
strike.chi_def: 突然侵襲；使受折磨；使遭受重創
strike.eg: I have a life insurance policy that will take care of my family if disaster strikes.

strike.eng_def: to hit or attack someone or something forcefully or violently
strike.eg: Her car went out of control and struck an oncoming vehicle.

strike.eng_def: to kick a football, especially hard so that it travels a long distance
strike.eg: Beckham struck the ball with precision.

strike.eng_def: When a clock strikes, its bells ring to show what the time is.
strike.eg: The clock was striking ten as we went into the church.

strike.eng_def: When a particular time strikes, a clock's bells ring to tell people what time it is.
strike.eg: Midnight had just struck when I went upstairs to bed.

strike.eng_def: If you strike a match, you cause it to burn by rubbing it against a hard rough surface.
strike.eg: She struck a match and lit another cigarette.

strike.eng_def: to remove something officially from a document
strike.eg: Please strike my name from your mailing list immediately.

strike.eng_def: to take down your tents in preparation for leaving the place where you have been camping
strike.eg: We woke up late and it was ten o'clock before we struck camp.

strike.eng_def: to discover a supply of oil, gas, or gold underground
strike.chi_def: 發現，探測到（地下石油、天然氣或黃金礦藏）
strike.eg: The first person to strike oil in the US was Edwin Laurentine Drake.

strike.eng_def: to reach or make an agreement
strike.eg: Do you think the government should try to strike a deal with the terrorists?

strike.eng_def: to cause someone to have a feeling or idea about something
strike.chi_def: 給人以…感覺；讓…覺得；使產生…想法
strike.eg: Doesn't it strike you as odd that he never talks about his family?

strike.eng_def: If a thought or idea strikes you, you suddenly think of it.
strike.chi_def: （想法或主意）突然閃現在…的腦海；猛然意識到
strike.eg: It's just struck me that I still owe you for the concert tickets.

strike.eng_def: to move your body into a particular position
strike.eg: She may be 67, but she can still strike a sexy pose.

strike.eng_def: to make a metal disc-shaped object such as a coin with a machine that quickly presses a picture into a piece of metal
strike.eg: When was the first pound coin struck?

strike.eng_def: a period of time when workers refuse to work because of an argument with an employer about working conditions, pay levels, or job losses
strike.eg: After last year's long and bitter strike, few people want more industrial action.

strike.eng_def: taking part in a strike
strike.eg: The city's bus drivers have been on strike for three weeks.

strike.eng_def: to start to strike
strike.eg: All 2,500 employees went on strike in protest at the decision to close the factory.

strike.eng_def: a sudden and powerful hit or attack
strike.eg: Lightning conductors protect buildings and tall structures from lightning strikes.

strike.eng_def: a hard kick of a football, especially one that makes it travel a long distance
strike.eg: Garner scored with a 30 -yard strike in the 89th minute.

strike.eng_def: a sudden, short military attack, especially one by aircraft or missiles
strike.chi_def: 軍事攻擊，突襲；（尤指）空襲，飛彈襲擊
strike.eg: The United Nations has authorized the use of air strikes.

strike.eng_def: the discovery underground of a valuable substance
strike.eg: The population and settlement of Colorado expanded after the gold strike of 1858.

strike.eng_def: (in baseball) a ball that has been thrown by the pitcher and not been hit successfully when it should have been
strike.eg: A batter is out after three strikes.

strike.eng_def: a failure, mistake, or disadvantage
strike.eg: California's "three strikes and you're out" bill means that from now on criminals found guilty of three crimes are jailed for life.

string.eng_def: (a piece of) strong, thin rope made by twisting very thin threads together, used for fastening and tying things
a set of objects joined together in a row on a single rope or thread
a series of related things or events
string.eg: What do you think of the recent string of political scandals?

string.eng_def: a thin wire that is stretched across a musical instrument and is used to produce a range of notes depending on its thickness, length, and tightness
the group of instruments that have strings and are played with a bow or with the fingers, or the players in a musical group who play these instruments
string.eg: I prefer his compositions for strings.

string.eng_def: one of the thin plastic strings that are stretched between the sides of the frame of a racket used in sport
a usually short piece of text consisting of letters, numbers, or symbols that is used in computer processes such as searching through large amounts of information
string.eg: If you type in the search string "ing", the computer will find all the words containing "ing".

string.eng_def: consisting of or relating to string instruments
string.chi_def: 由弦樂器組成的；弦樂器的

string.eng_def: to put strings on a musical instrument
string.eg: First you need to learn how to string and tune your guitar.

string.eng_def: to put new strings onto a racket used in sport
string.eg: You ought to have your racket re-strung before the competition.

string.eng_def: to put a string through a number of objects
string.chi_def: 用細繩（或線等）把…串在一起
string.eg: Would you help me string these beads?

strip.eng_def: to remove, pull, or tear the covering or outer layer from something
strip.chi_def: 除去，剝除，撕掉（外皮或表層）
strip.eg: Because of the pollution, the trees are almost completely stripped of bark.

strip.eng_def: to remove your clothing, or to remove all the clothing of someone else
strip.eg: The men were ordered to strip.

strip.eng_def: to remove your clothing as an entertainment
strip.eg: She stripped to pay her way through college.

strip.eng_def: to remove parts of a machine, vehicle, or engine in order to clean or repair it
strip.chi_def: 拆卸，拆開（機器、車輛或引擎 ）
strip.eg: I've decided to strip down my motorbike and rebuild it.

strip.eng_def: to remove the parts of a car, etc. in order to sell them
the clothing worn by a football team that has the team's colours on it
strip.eg: The team will be wearing its new strip at next Saturday's match.

strip.eng_def: an entertainment in which the performer removes all his or her clothing
strip.eg: He jumped up on the table and started to do a strip.

stripe.eng_def: a strip on the surface of something that is a different colour from the surrounding surface
stripe.eg: The zebra is a wild African horse with black and white stripes.

stripe.eng_def: a strip of material that is sewn onto the arm of a military uniform to show the rank of the person wearing it
stripe.chi_def: （軍裝上表示等級的）臂章，軍階條
stripe.eg: By the age of 25 he'd already earned his third stripe and become a sergeant.

strive.eng_def: to try very hard to do something or to make something happen, especially for a long time or against difficulties
strive.chi_def: （尤指長期或不畏艱難地）努力，奮鬥，力爭
strive.eg: Mr Roe has kindled expectations that he must now strive to live up to.

stroke.eng_def: a sudden change in the blood supply to a part of the brain, sometimes causing a loss of the ability to move particular parts of the body
stroke.eg: She suffered/had a stroke that left her unable to speak.

stroke.eng_def: (a line or mark made by) a movement of a pen or pencil when writing or a brush when painting
used in spoken English to mean an oblique or slash symbol
an act of hitting a ball when playing a sport
stroke.eg: She returned the volley with a powerful stroke to win the game.

stroke.eng_def: an act of hitting someone with a weapon
stroke.eg: The punishment was 20 strokes of the lash.

stroke.eng_def: (a particular movement that is usually repeated in) a method of swimming
stroke.eg: What's your best stroke when you're swimming?

stroke.eng_def: something that happens or succeeds suddenly because of luck, intelligence, etc.
stroke.eg: By a stroke of luck, someone else was walking along the trail and heard my shouts for help.
She's been gossiping and hasn't done a stroke (of work) all morning.
Ending negotiations was seen as a bold stroke by many commentators.

stroke.eng_def: one of the sounds that some clocks make at particular times, especially by ringing a bell once for each number of the hour
stroke.chi_def: 鐘聲，鐘鳴；（尤指）整點報時聲
stroke.eg: How many strokes did you count?

stroke.eng_def: an act of moving your hand, another part of the body, or an object gently over something or someone, usually repeatedly and for pleasure
stroke.eg: Don't be frightened, just give the horse a stroke.

stroke.eng_def: to move a hand, another part of the body, or an object gently over something or someone, usually repeatedly and for pleasure
stroke.eg: Stroke the dog if you want, he won't bite.
The batsman stroked the ball effortlessly to the boundary.

stroll.eng_def: to walk in a slow, relaxed manner, especially for pleasure
stroll.eg: We could stroll along the beach after dinner.

strong.eng_def: powerful; having or using great force or control
strong.chi_def: 強有力的，強勁的；強壯的；強烈的
strong.eg: She must be very strong to carry such a weight on her back.

strong.eng_def: effective; of a good quality or level and likely to be successful
strong.eg: We will need strong policies if our economic problems are to be solved.

strong.eng_def: skilled or good at doing something
strong.eg: Without a doubt, she's the strongest candidate we've interviewed for the job.

strong.eng_def: difficult to argue with; firm and determined
strong.chi_def: 堅決的，堅定的，不動搖的
strong.eg: She has strong opinions about religion.

strong.eng_def: If a taste, smell, etc. is strong, it is very noticeable or powerful.
strong.chi_def: （味道、氣味等）濃的，重的，強烈的
strong.eg: A strong light was shining straight in my eyes.

strong.eng_def: difficult to break, destroy, or make sick, or able to support a heavy weight or force
strong.chi_def: 牢固的，強健的；結實的；堅固的
可能性很大的，很有可能的
strong.eg: There's a strong possibility/likelihood of finding the child within the next few hours.

strong.eng_def: having the stated number of people, members, etc.
strong.eg: The crowd had grown to be several hundred strong.

strong.eng_def: A strong acid, alkali, or chemical base produces many ions (= atoms with an electrical charge) when it is dissolved in water.
strong.chi_def: 強的（酸、鹼或某種化學成分）

strong.eng_def: to behave towards another person in a way that is too severe, or that shows a strong sexual interest that the other person does not want
strong.chi_def: 露骨地調情，挑逗；言行過分，過於苛刻
strong.eg: I think you came on a bit strong - it wasn't her fault.

strong.eng_def: to make an extra effort in order to be successful or to have control in a situation
strong.chi_def: （為了成功或控制局面而）額外努力
strong.eg: He came on strong in the early rounds to annihilate the competition.

structural.eng_def: relating to the way in which parts of a system or object are arranged
structural.eg: The political reforms have led to major structural changes in the economy.

structural.eng_def: relating to the structure of a building or similar object
structural.chi_def: （建築物或類似物體）結構上的
structural.eg: Hundreds of houses in the typhoon's path suffered structural damage.

structure.eng_def: the way in which the parts of a system or object are arranged or organized, or a system arranged in this way
structure.eg: the grammatical structure of a sentence

structure.eng_def: something that has been made or built from parts, especially a large building
structure.chi_def: 結構體；（尤指）大型建築物
structure.eg: The proposed new office tower is a steel and glass structure 43 storeys high.

structure.eng_def: an organ in the body, or part of an organ, that does a particular job
to plan, organize, or arrange the parts of something
structure.eg: We must carefully structure and rehearse each scene.

struggle.eng_def: to experience difficulty and make a very great effort in order to do something
struggle.eg: The dog had been struggling to get free of the wire noose.

struggle.eng_def: to move somewhere with great effort
struggle.chi_def: 沿…艱難行進／奮力通過／艱難地從…中掙扎出來（等等）
struggle.eg: He struggled along the rough road holding his son.

struggle.eng_def: to be in danger of failing or being defeated
struggle.chi_def: 有失敗的危險，苦苦掙扎
struggle.eg: After the first half, United were really struggling.

struggle.eng_def: to fight, especially with your hands
struggle.eg: He struggled with his attacker who then ran away.

struggle.eng_def: to use a lot of effort to defeat someone, prevent something, or achieve something
struggle.eg: For years she struggled with/against the establishment to get her theories accepted.

struggle.eng_def: a very difficult task that you can do only by making a great effort
struggle.chi_def: （應對困難而需要的）掙扎；努力，奮鬥
struggle.eg: It was a terrible struggle for him to accept her death.

struggle.chi_def: （身體上或精神上的）爭鬥；搏鬥；鬥爭
struggle.eg: a struggle with an armed robber

stubborn.eng_def: A stubborn person is determined to do what he or she wants and refuses to do anything else.
stubborn.eg: They have huge arguments because they're both so stubborn.

stubborn.eng_def: Things that are stubborn are difficult to move, change, or deal with.
stubborn.chi_def: 難移動的；難改變的；難對付的
stubborn.eg: He was famed for his stubborn resistance and his refusal to accept defeat.

student.eng_def: a person who is learning at a college or university
someone who is learning at a school
student.eg: Teachers use a variety of materials to inspire their students.

student.eng_def: If someone is a student of a particular subject, they know about it and are interested in it.
student.eg: As a nurse, you have to be a student of (= to know and learn about) human nature.

studio.eng_def: a room with special equipment where television or radio programmes or music recordings are made
studio.chi_def: （電視或廣播節目的）攝影棚，播音室；（音樂）錄音室
studio.eg: She spent three months in the studio working on her latest album.

studio.eng_def: a building or place where films are made, or a company that makes them
studio.chi_def: （電影）攝影棚；電影公司，電影製片廠
studio.eg: Ealing Studios made some famous British comedies in the 40s and 50s.

studio.eng_def: a room or building where dancing is taught or practised
a room in which an artist works, especially a painter or photographer
studio.chi_def: （藝術家的）工作室；（尤指）畫室，攝影室

studio.eng_def: a company making artistic or photographic products
studio.chi_def: 藝術工作室；攝影工作室
studio.eg: The firm grew to be one of Europe's foremost graphics studios.

studio.eng_def: a small apartment designed to be lived in by one or two people, usually with one large room for sleeping and living in, a bathroom and sometimes a separate kitchen
studio.chi_def: 單房公寓（通常一個房間兼作睡房和起居室，帶有廁所，有的有單獨的廚房）

study.eng_def: to learn about a subject, especially in an educational course or by reading books

study.eg: I want time to study this contract thoroughly before signing it.

study.eng_def: the activity of examining a subject in detail in order to discover new information
study.eg: a five-year study of the relationship between wildlife and farming

study.eng_def: a drawing that an artist makes in order to test ideas before starting a painting of the same subject
study.chi_def: （畫家作畫前測試自己想法的）試作，試畫

study.eng_def: the act of learning about a subject, usually at school or university

study.eg: Adam doesn't spend enough time on his studies.

study.eng_def: used in the names of some educational subjects and courses
a room, especially in a house, used for quiet work such as reading or writing

stuff.eng_def: a substance, especially when you do not know or say exactly what it is
stuff.eg: There's sticky stuff all over the chair.

stuff.eng_def: things that someone says or does, when you are referring to them in a general way without saying exactly what they are
stuff.eg: All that stuff she has been saying about Lee is just not true.

stuff.eng_def: someone's possessions or things that they take somewhere with them
stuff.chi_def: （某人擁有的或攜帶的）物品，東西
stuff.eg: We'll have to carry all our camping stuff.

stuff.eng_def: used to refer to more things of a similar kind to ones you have mentioned, when you do not say exactly what they are
stuff.eg: This is the drawer where I keep paper and envelopes and stuff.
Avery had great stuff, total command of all three of his pitches.

stuff.eng_def: to completely fill a container with something
stuff.eg: Stuff the pillow and then sew up the final seam.

stuff.eng_def: to push something into a small space, often quickly or in a careless way
stuff.eg: This suitcase is absolutely full - I can't stuff another thing into it.

stuff.eng_def: to fill the body of a dead animal with special material so that it looks as if it is still alive
(of a man) to have sex with a woman

stuff.eg: Stuff the turkey, then put it into a pre-heated oven.
They'd been stuffing themselves with snacks all afternoon, so they didn't want any dinner.

stumble.eng_def: to step awkwardly while walking or running and fall or begin to fall
stumble.eg: Running along the beach, she stumbled on a log and fell on the sand.

stumble.eng_def: to walk in a way that does not seem controlled
stumble.chi_def: 跌跌撞撞地走，蹣跚而行
stumble.eg: We could hear her stumbling about/around the bedroom in the dark.

stumble.eng_def: to make a mistake, such as repeating something or pausing for too long, while speaking or playing a piece of music
stumble.chi_def: 犯錯；結結巴巴地說，支吾；不順暢地演奏
stumble.eg: When the poet stumbled over a line in the middle of a poem, someone in the audience corrected him.

stump.eng_def: the part of something such as a tree, tooth, arm, or leg that is left after most of it has been removed
stump.chi_def: 樹墩，樹樁；（牙齒等的）殘餘部分；殘肢

stump.eng_def: the three vertical wooden poles at which the ball is thrown in cricket
to be unable to answer a question or solve a problem because it is too difficult
stump.eg: I'm completely stumped - how did she manage to escape?

stump.eng_def: to travel around an area giving speeches and trying to get political support
stump.eg: Hollywood stars stumped for the Democratic candidate.

stump.eng_def: If the person hitting the ball in cricket is stumped, their turn to try scoring points is ended by a member of the other team knocking the bails off the stumps with the ball while they are outside a safe area.
stump.chi_def: （板球中以球擊落三柱門上的橫木）使（打擊手）出局

stun.eng_def: to shock or surprise someone very much
stun.eg: News of the disaster stunned people throughout the world.

stun.eng_def: to make a person or animal unconscious or unable to think normally, especially by hitting their head hard
stun.chi_def: 使失去知覺，使昏迷；（尤指重擊頭部）把…打昏
stun.eg: Stunned by the impact, he lay on the ground wondering what had happened.

stunt.eng_def: an exciting action, usually in a film, that is dangerous or appears dangerous and usually needs to be done by someone skilled
stunt.eg: It's a typical action movie with plenty of spectacular stunts.

stunt.eng_def: something that is done to get attention for the person or people responsible for it
stunt.chi_def: 意在引人注目的花招，噱頭

stunt.eng_def: to prevent the growth or development of something from reaching its limit
stunt.chi_def: 妨礙…的正常生長；阻礙…的充分發展
stunt.eg: Drought has stunted (the growth of) this year's cereal crop.

stupid.eng_def: silly or unwise; showing poor judgment or little intelligence
stupid.chi_def: 愚蠢的；糊塗的；欠考慮的
stupid.eg: She was really stupid to quit her job like that.

stupid.chi_def: 討厭的；惱人的；惹麻煩的
stupid.eg: Have your stupid book back if it's so important to you.

sturdy.eng_def: physically strong and solid or thick, and therefore unlikely to break or be hurt

sturdy.eg: They put up a sturdy defence of their proposal.

stutter.eng_def: to speak or say something, especially the first part of a word, with difficulty, for example pausing before it or repeating it several times
stutter.eg: She stutters a little, so be patient and let her finish what she's saying.

stutter.eng_def: to work or happen in a way that is not smooth or regular
stutter.chi_def: 斷斷續續地運轉（或進行）
stutter.eg: Suddenly the engine stuttered and then it stopped completely.

style.eng_def: a way of doing something, especially one that is typical of a person, group of people, place, or period
style.chi_def: 做事方式；（尤指）風格，作風
style.eg: Jones favours a dynamic, hands-on style of management.

style.eng_def: to be the type of thing that you would do
style.chi_def: 是（某人）的做法；是（某人）的作風
style.eg: He wouldn't try to mislead you - it's not his style.

style.chi_def: （尤指服裝上的）風尚，潮流，流行式樣

style.eng_def: a particular shape or design, especially of a person's hair, clothes, or a piece of furniture
high quality in appearance, design, or behaviour
style.eg: That car's got real style, which is no surprise considering how much it cost.

style.eng_def: the middle part of the carpel (= female part) of a flower, connecting the ovary to the stigma
to shape or design something such as a person's hair or an object like a piece of clothing or furniture, especially so that it looks attractive
style.chi_def: 設計；給…造型；（尤指）把…設計得吸引人
style.eg: You've had your hair styled - it really suits you.

style.eng_def: to give a title to a person or group
style.eg: She styles herself "Doctor" but she doesn't have a degree.

stylish.eng_def: of a high quality in appearance, design, or behaviour
stylish.eg: The film's direction is subtle and stylish.

subject.eng_def: the thing that is being discussed, considered, or studied
subject.chi_def: （討論、考慮或研究的）主題，話題；問題；題目
subject.eg: Our subject for discussion is homelessness.

subject.eng_def: an area of knowledge that is studied in school, college, or university
subject.chi_def: （中小學或大學的）學科；科目；專業
subject.eg: My favourite subjects at school were history and English.

subject.eng_def: to start talking about a different subject
subject.eg: I'd tried to explain the situation, but he just changed the subject.

subject.eng_def: a person, thing, or situation that is written about in a book, article, etc. or shown in a picture, etc.
subject.eg: The mill by the bridge was the subject of an unfinished painting by J. M. W. Turner.

subject.eng_def: the person or thing that performs the action of a verb, or is joined to a description by a verb
subject.eg: "Bob" is the subject of the sentence "Bob threw the ball."

subject.eng_def: a person who lives in or who has the right to live in a particular country, especially a country with a king or queen
subject.chi_def: （尤指君主制國家的）臣民，國民

subject.eng_def: to defeat people or a country and then control them against their wishes and limit their freedom
subject.eg: The invaders quickly subjected the local tribes.

subject.eng_def: to have or experience a particular thing, especially something unpleasant
subject.eg: Cars are subject to a high domestic tax.

subject.eng_def: only able to happen if something else happens
subject.eg: We plan to go on Wednesday, subject to your approval.

subject.eng_def: under the political control of another country or state

subjective.eng_def: influenced by or based on personal beliefs or feelings, rather than based on facts
subjective.eg: I think my husband is the most handsome man in the world, but I realize my judgment is rather subjective.

submarine.eng_def: a ship that can travel underwater
existing below the surface of the sea

submit.eng_def: to give or offer something for a decision to be made by others
submit.eg: You must submit your application before 1 January.
In conclusion, I submit that the proposal will not work without some major changes.

submit.eng_def: to allow another person or group to have power or authority over you, or to accept something unwillingly
submit.eg: We protested about the changes for a long time, but in the end we had to submit.

subordinate.eng_def: having a lower or less important position
a person who has a less important position than you in an organization
subordinate.eg: He left the routine checks to one of his subordinates.

subordinate.eng_def: to put someone or something into a less important position
subordinate.chi_def: 使從屬於，使處於次要地位
subordinate.eg: Her personal life has been subordinated to her career.

subscribe.eng_def: to pay money to an organization in order to receive a product, use a service regularly, or support the organization
subscribe.chi_def: 訂閱，訂購（產品）；（為某項服務）定期付費；定期捐助
subscribe.eg: 2.3 million people subscribe to this online music service.

subscribe.eng_def: to offer to buy something or pay an amount for something as part of your business activities
subscribe.eg: Existing shareholders subscribed to only 49 percent of the new share issue.

subscription.eng_def: an amount of money that you pay regularly to receive a product or service
subscription.eg: I decided to take out (= pay for) a subscription to a gardening magazine.

subscription.eng_def: an amount of money that you pay regularly to be a member of an organization or club
subscription.eg: We bought our niece an annual subscription to the tennis club.

subscription.eng_def: a season ticket (= a ticket that can be used many times within a limited period) for cultural events
subscription.eg: His parents had a subscription to the local philharmonic orchestra.

subscription.eng_def: an opportunity to buy shares in a company
subscription.eg: You will soon have the opportunity to purchase stock through a subscription offering.

subsequent.eg: The book discusses his illness and subsequent resignation from politics.

substance.eng_def: the most important part of what someone has said or written
substance.chi_def: （某人）所說（或所寫）的最重要的部分，要點
substance.eg: Later that year, the substance of their secret conversation appeared in a newspaper article.

substance.eng_def: importance, seriousness, or relationship to real facts
substance.eg: There is no substance in/to the allegation.

substantial.eng_def: large in size, value, or importance
substantial.chi_def: 大的；可觀的；價值巨大的；重大的
substantial.eg: The findings show a substantial difference between the opinions of men and women.

substantial.eng_def: relating to the main or most important things being considered
substantial.eg: The committee was in substantial agreement (= agreed about most of the things discussed).

substitute.eng_def: to use something or someone instead of another thing or person
substitute.eg: You can substitute oil for butter in this recipe.

substitute.eng_def: to perform the same job as another thing or to take its place
substitute.eg: Gas-fired power stations will substitute for less efficient coal-fired equipment.

substitute.eng_def: a thing or person that is used instead of another thing or person
substitute.eg: Tofu can be used as a meat substitute in vegetarian recipes.

substitute.eng_def: in sports, a player who is used for part of a game instead of another player
substitute.eg: Johnson came on as a substitute towards the end of the game.

substitute.eng_def: nothing is as good as the stated thing
substitute.eg: You can read about other countries, but there's no substitute for visiting them yourself.

substitution.eng_def: the use of one person or thing instead of another
substitution.eg: It looks as though the coach is going to make a substitution (= change one player for another in the game).

subtle.eng_def: not loud, bright, noticeable, or obvious in any way
subtle.chi_def: 隱約的；暗淡的；不易察覺的，不明顯的；微妙的
subtle.eg: The room was painted a subtle shade of pink.
There is a subtle difference between these two plans.

subtle.eng_def: achieved in a quiet way that does not attract attention to itself and is therefore good or clever

subtract.eng_def: to remove a number from another number
subtract.eg: Four subtracted from ten equals six.

suburb.eng_def: an area on the edge of a large town or city where people who work in the town or city often live
suburb.eg: Box Hill is a suburb of Melbourne.

suburb.eng_def: the outer area of a town, rather than the shopping and business centre in the middle
suburb.eg: The company decided to relocate to the suburbs because the rent was much cheaper.

suburban.eng_def: used to suggest that something is boring and has no excitement

subway.eng_def: a railway system in which electric trains travel through tunnels below ground
subway.eg: We took the subway uptown to Yankee Stadium.

subway.eng_def: an underground passage that allows people on foot to cross a busy road

succeed.eng_def: If you succeed, you achieve something that you have been aiming for, and if a plan or piece of work succeeds, it has the results that you wanted.
succeed.chi_def: 成功；實現目標；達到目的
succeed.eg: She's been trying to pass her driving test for six years and she's finally succeeded.

succeed.eng_def: to take an official job or position after someone else
succeed.eg: He succeeded his father as editor of the paper.

succeed.eng_def: to come after another person or thing in time
succeed.eg: In the weeks that succeeded, five more patients showed similar symptoms.

success.eng_def: the achieving of the results wanted or hoped for
success.eg: The success of almost any project depends largely on its manager.
Both films have been a big box-office success.

successful.eng_def: achieving the results wanted or hoped for
having achieved a lot, become popular, and/or made a lot of money
successful.chi_def: 獲得成功的，大受歡迎的；非常賺錢的

succession.eng_def: a number of similar events or people that happen, exist, etc. after each other
succession.eg: A succession of scandals and revelations has undermined the government over the past year.
She had her first three children in rapid succession.

succession.eng_def: a process in which someone automatically takes an official position or job after someone else
succession.eg: His divorce will not prevent the Prince of Wales's succession to the throne.

successive.eng_def: happening one after the other without any break
successive.eg: It was the team's fourth successive defeat.

successor.eng_def: someone or something that comes after another person or thing
successor.chi_def: 繼任者，接替者；繼承人；接替的事物
successor.eg: The university is seeking a successor to its vice chancellor, who retires this spring.

such.eng_def: used before a noun or noun phrase to add emphasis
such.chi_def: （用於名詞或名詞片語前表示強調）如此，這麼

such.eng_def: of a particular or similar type
such.eg: Small companies such as ours are very vulnerable in a recession.
That money is to cover costs such as travel and accommodation.

such.eng_def: in the true or exact meaning of the word or phrase
such.chi_def: 從字面意義來看，嚴格地說
such.eg: There wasn't much vegetarian food as such, although there were several different types of cheese.

suck.eng_def: to pull in liquid or air through your mouth without using your teeth, or to move the tongue and muscles of the mouth around something inside your mouth, often in order to dissolve it
suck.eg: She was sitting on the grass sucking lemonade through a straw.

suck.eng_def: Something that sucks a liquid or an object in a particular direction pulls it with great force.
suck.eg: The waves came crashing over my head and I could feel myself being sucked under by the currents.

suck.eng_def: If someone or something sucks, that person or thing is bad or unpleasant.

suck.eg: Can I have a suck of your lollipop, please?

sudden.eng_def: happening or done quickly and without warning
sudden.eg: Drop the gun, put your hands in the air, and don't make any sudden movements.

suffer.eng_def: to experience physical or mental pain
suffer.eg: I think he suffered a lot when his wife left him.

suffer.eng_def: to experience or show the effects of something bad
suffer.eg: The Democrats suffered a crushing defeat in the last election.

sufficient.eg: This recipe should be sufficient for five people.
"Would you like some more stew?" "No thanks, I've had sufficient."

suffocate.eng_def: to (cause someone to) die because of not having enough oxygen
suffocate.eg: The report said that the victims had suffocated in the fumes.

suffocate.eng_def: to prevent something or someone from improving or developing in a positive way

sugar.eng_def: a sweet substance especially from the plants sugar cane and sugar beet, used to make food and drinks sweet
sugar.eg: I don't take sugar in my coffee, thanks.

sugar.eng_def: any of several types of simple carbohydrate that dissolves in water
sugar.chi_def: 糖（總稱，指溶於水的碳水化合物）

sugar.eng_def: a friendly way of talking to someone that you know
sugar.eg: Hi, sugar, did you have a good day at school?

sugar.eng_def: polite word for shit , used when something annoying happens
sugar.chi_def: （代替 shit，用於表示懊惱）糟糕，哎呀
sugar.eg: Oh sugar, I've just spilled coffee all down my jacket!

sugar.eng_def: to put sugar in or on something
sugar.eg: He sugared the rims of the martini glasses.

suggest.eng_def: to mention an idea, possible plan, or action for other people to consider
suggest.eg: I suggested an Italian restaurant near the station for the party.

suggest.eng_def: to communicate or show an idea or feeling without stating it directly or giving proof
suggest.eg: There's no absolute proof, but all the evidence suggests (that) he's guilty.

suggest.eng_def: to produce an idea in the mind
suggest.eg: Does anything suggest itself? (= Do you have any ideas about what we should do?)

suggestion.eng_def: an idea, plan, or action that is suggested or the act of suggesting it
suggestion.eg: I don't know what to wear tonight - do you have any suggestions?

suggestion.eng_def: communication of an idea without stating it directly
a very small amount of something
suggestion.eg: a suggestion of an Irish accent

suicide.eng_def: the act of killing yourself intentionally, or a person who has done this
any act that has the effect of causing your own defeat
suicide.chi_def: 自殺性的行為；自取滅亡的行為
suicide.eg: As a leader he knows that it is political suicide to appear indecisive.

suit.eng_def: a jacket and trousers or a jacket and skirt that are made from the same material
suit.eg: All the businessmen were wearing pinstripe suits.

suit.eng_def: a set of clothes or a piece of clothing to be worn in a particular situation or while doing a particular activity
a problem taken to a law court by an ordinary person or an organization rather than the police in order to obtain a legal decision
suit.chi_def: （由普通人或警方以外的機構提起的）訴訟，訟案
suit.eg: He brought (US also filed) a $12 million libel suit against the newspaper, claiming his reputation had been damaged.

suit.eng_def: any of the four types of card in a set of playing cards, each having a different shape printed on it
suit.eg: The four suits in a pack of cards are hearts, spades, clubs, and diamonds.

suit.eng_def: a man who works in an office and wears a suit, especially a man with a high position in a company who is considered not to have human feelings and good ideas
suit.chi_def: 穿西裝的辦公室男職員，（尤指沒有人情味、缺乏思想的）公司高級管理人員

suit.eng_def: to be right for a particular person, situation, or occasion
suit.eg: A lot of corn is grown in this area - the soil seems to suit it very well.

suit.eng_def: (usually of a colour or style of clothes) to make someone look more attractive
suit.chi_def: （通常指顏色或衣服式樣）適合，與…相稱
suit.eg: You should wear more red - it suits you.

suit.eng_def: to be convenient and cause the least difficulty for someone
suit.eg: We could go now or this afternoon - whatever time suits you best.

suitable.eng_def: acceptable or right for someone or something
suitable.eg: The film is not suitable for children.

suitcase.eng_def: a large, rectangular container with a handle, for carrying clothes and possessions while travelling
suitcase.eg: Have you packed/unpacked your suitcase yet?

suite.eng_def: a set of connected rooms, especially in a hotel
suite.eg: The singer was interviewed in his hotel suite.

suite.eng_def: a set of furniture for one room, of matching design and colour
suite.eg: I've ordered a new three-piece suite for the living-room.

suite.eng_def: a piece of music with several parts, usually all in the same key
a set of related software (= computer program) products

sulfur.eng_def: US spelling of sulphur mainly UK

sum.eg: Huge sums of money are spent on national defence.

sum.eng_def: the whole number or amount when two or more numbers or amounts have been added together

sum.chi_def: 總的來說，總而言之，總之
sum.eg: The meeting was, in sum, a disaster.

sum.eng_def: all of something, especially when this is not very much
sum.eg: And that's the sum of my knowledge on the subject!

sum.eng_def: a calculation, especially a simple one, using such processes as adding, taking away, multiplying, or dividing
sum.chi_def: （尤指運用加減乘除的簡單）計算，算術
sum.eg: I remember how much I hated doing sums when I was at school.

summarize.eng_def: to express the most important facts or ideas about something or someone in a short and clear form
summarize.eg: I'll just summarize the main points of the argument in a few words.

summary.eng_def: a short, clear description that gives the main facts or ideas about something
summary.eg: At the end of the news, they often give you a summary of the main stories.

summary.eng_def: done suddenly, without discussion or legal arrangements
summary.chi_def: （未經討論或法律程式）立即的，速決的，草率的

summer.eng_def: the season of the year between spring and autumn when the weather is warmest, lasting from June to September north of the equator and from December to March south of the equator
summer.eg: We have breakfast on the balcony in (the) summer.

summer.eng_def: to spend the summer in a particular place
summer.eg: If your cactus has summered outdoors, move it into the garage or house when overnight temperatures drop below 65°F.

summit.eng_def: an important formal meeting between leaders of governments from two or more countries
summit.chi_def: 高峰會，領袖會議，最高級會議

summit.eng_def: the highest point of a mountain
summit.eg: On this day in 1784, Dr Michel Paccard and Jacques Balmat reached the summit of Mont Blanc.

summit.eng_def: the highest, most successful, or most important point in something
summit.eg: I certainly haven't reached the summit of my career.

summon.eng_def: to order someone to come to or be present at a particular place, or to officially arrange a meeting of people
summon.chi_def: 命令…到（某地）；傳喚；召喚；召集
summon.eg: General Rattigan summoned reinforcements to help resist the attack.

summon.eng_def: to increase your courage or strength, especially with an effort
summon.chi_def: （尤指努力地）鼓起（勇氣），積聚（力氣）
summon.eg: It took me six months to summon (up) the courage to ask him out for a drink.

sun.eng_def: the star that provides light and heat for the earth and around which the earth moves
sun.eg: The sun rises in the east and sets in the west.

sun.eng_def: the light or heat that the earth receives from the sun
sun.chi_def: 太陽的光和熱；陽光，日光
sun.eg: I think I've had too much sun today - I have a headache.

sun.eng_def: to lie or sit somewhere where there is a lot of sun, especially in order to make your skin darker
sun.chi_def: （尤指為了使皮膚變黑而）曬太陽，沐日光浴
sun.eg: I sat on the balcony sunning myself.

sunny.eng_def: bright because of light from the sun
sunny.chi_def: 陽光明媚的，陽光普照的
sunny.eg: We're having the party in the garden, so I'm praying it'll be sunny.

sunny.eng_def: A sunny person is usually happy and relaxed and does not usually get worried or angry.
sunny.chi_def: （人）樂觀開朗的，快樂的，陽光的
sunny.eg: She has a very sunny disposition.

super.eg: The Natural History Museum is a super place for kids.
They were super helpful when I was having problems.

super.eng_def: the highest quality fuel that can be used in cars
larger, more effective, more powerful, or more successful than usual; very or more than usually

superficial.eng_def: (of a person) never thinking about things that are serious or important
superficial.eg: He's fun to be with, but he's very superficial.

superficial.eng_def: not complete and involving only the most obvious things
superficial.eg: I thought that article was written at a very superficial level.

superficial.eng_def: appearing to be real or important when this is not true or correct
superficial.eg: There are superficial similarities between the two cars, but really they're very different in terms of performance.

superficial.eng_def: only on the surface of something

superior.eng_def: better than average or better than other people or things of the same type
superior.chi_def: 好於平均的，好過其他的，優越的
superior.eg: This is clearly the work of a superior artist.

superior.eng_def: A superior person believes that or acts as if they are better than other people.
superior.chi_def: （人）高傲的，傲慢的，有優越感的

superior.eng_def: higher in rank or social position than others
superior.eg: The soldier was reported to his superior officer for failing in his duties.

superior.eng_def: closer to the head, further from the feet
superior.eg: The head is superior to the shoulder.

superior.eng_def: a person or group of people who are higher in rank or social position than others
superior.eg: I will pass your complaint on to my superiors.

superiority.eng_def: the fact that one person or thing is better, stronger, etc. than another
superiority.eg: The Australian team soon demonstrated their superiority over the opposition.

superiority.eng_def: an unpleasant way of behaving that a person has when they think they are better than other people
superiority.eg: Her sense of superiority makes her very unpopular.

superiority.eng_def: the state of being of a higher rank or social position than others

supermarket.eng_def: a large shopwhich sells most types of food and other goods needed in the home

supersonic.eng_def: faster than the speed of sound

superstition.eng_def: belief that is not based on human reason or scientific knowledge, but is connected with old ideas about magic, etc.
superstition.eg: According to superstition, if you walk under a ladder it brings you bad luck.

superstitious.eng_def: based on or believing in superstitions
superstitious.chi_def: 基於迷信的；相信迷信的

supervise.eng_def: to watch a person or activity to make certain that everything is done correctly, safely, etc.
supervise.eg: The UN is supervising the distribution of aid by local agencies in the disaster area.

supervision.eng_def: the act of watching a person or activity and making certain that everything is done correctly, safely, etc.
supervision.eg: Students are not allowed to handle these chemicals unless they are under the supervision of a teacher.

supervisor.eng_def: a person whose job is to supervise someone or something
in some colleges, a teacher with responsibility for a particular student
supervisor.chi_def: （某些學院中學生的）指導教師，導師

supervisor.eng_def: A town or county supervisor is an elected official who manages local government services.

supper.eng_def: a main meal eaten in the evening
supper.eg: Why don't you come to/for supper tonight?

supper.eng_def: a small meal eaten in the late evening
supper.eg: We usually have tea at about 5.30 p.m. , then supper before we go to bed.

supplement.eng_def: something that is added to something else in order to improve it or complete it; something extra
supplement.eg: The doctor said she should be taking vitamin supplements.

supplement.eng_def: a part of a magazine or newspaper, either produced separately or as part of the magazine or newspaper
supplement.eg: The newspaper publishes a sports supplement every Monday.

supplement.eng_def: an extra part of a book, either produced separately or included at the end of the book, containing information that was not available when the book was first published
supplement.eg: There is a supplement to the dictionary containing new words.

supplement.eng_def: to add something to something to make it larger or better
supplement.eg: He supplements (= adds to) his income by working in a bar at night.

supply.eng_def: to provide something that is wanted or needed, often in large quantities and over a long period of time
supply.eg: Electrical power is supplied by underground cables.

supply.eng_def: an amount of something that is available for use
supply.eg: Whenever she goes out with her baby, she always takes a large supply of baby food with her.

supply.eng_def: food or other things necessary for living
supply.eg: The refugees are urgently in need of food and medical supplies.
Extensive mining has reduced the supplies of coal in the area.

supply.eng_def: the system used for supplying gas, electricity, etc. to people
supply.eg: Someone has turned off the electricity supply.

supply.eng_def: If something is in short supply, there is little of it available.
supply.eg: Strawberries are in short supply this summer.

support.eng_def: to agree with and give encouragement to someone or something because you want him, her, or it to succeed
support.eg: My father supported the Labour Party all his life.

support.eng_def: If you support a sports team or a sports player, you want them to win, and might show it by going to watch them play.
support.chi_def: 支持（某個運動隊伍或運動員）

support.eng_def: to help someone emotionally or in a practical way
support.chi_def: （在情感或實際方面）支援，幫助
support.eg: Alcoholics Anonymous is a group which supports people who are trying to stop drinking too much alcohol.

support.eng_def: to give a person the money they need in order to buy food and clothes and pay for somewhere to live
support.eg: He has a wife and four children to support.

support.eng_def: If you support an activity or a habit, you provide the money needed to pay for it.
support.chi_def: 資助，為…提供資金；出錢維持，支付…的花費
support.eg: The drug company is supporting cancer research.

support.eng_def: to provide the right conditions, such as enough food and water, for life
support.eg: The land is so poor here that it cannot support any crops.

support.eng_def: to hold something firmly or carry its weight, especially from below to stop it from falling
support.eg: The church dome is supported by/on marble pillars.

support.eng_def: to help to show something to be true
to accept something and allow it to happen
support.eg: The headteacher told the boys that he would not support that kind of behaviour.

support.eng_def: agreement with and encouragement for an idea, group, or person
support.eg: Environmental groups are fast gaining support among young people.

support.chi_def: （在情感或實際方面）支持，幫助
support.eg: Liz gave me a lot of support when I lost my job.

support.eng_def: the money someone needs in order to buy food and clothes and pay for somewhere to live
support.eg: He is dependent on his father for support .

support.eng_def: something that holds something firmly or carries its weight, especially from below to stop it from falling
support.eg: The floor is held up by wooden supports.

support.eng_def: a device worn to hold part of the body, especially a weak part, firmly in position
support.chi_def: （尤指身體脆弱部位的）支撐物，托
support.eg: Jim always wears a knee support when he goes running.

support.eng_def: something that shows that a fact is true
support.eg: This new evidence lends support to the theory that she was murdered.

suppose.eng_def: to think that something is likely to be true
suppose.eg: Dan didn't answer his phone, so I suppose (that) he's busy.

suppose.eng_def: used to show that you think something is true, although you wish that it were not
suppose.chi_def: （用於表示與願望相反的估計）猜，推測
suppose.eg: I suppose (that) all the tickets will be sold by now.
I suppose (that) you're going to be late again.

suppose.eng_def: used to show unwillingness to agree
suppose.eg: "Can I go out tonight?" "Oh, I suppose so."
I don't suppose (that) you could lend me £5 till tomorrow?
Investment of this kind supposes (= would not be possible without) an increase in the company's profits this year.

suppose.eng_def: used at the beginning of a sentence or clause to mean 'what would happen if'
suppose.eg: Suppose we miss the train - what will we do then?

suppress.eg: The Hungarian uprising in 1956 was suppressed by the Soviet Union.

suppress.eng_def: to prevent something from being seen or expressed or from operating

supreme.eng_def: having the highest rank, level, or importance
supreme.chi_def: （等級、水準或重要性）最高（的），至高無上（的）
supreme.eg: the supreme commander of the armed forces
For me, dieting requires a supreme effort of will.

sure.chi_def: 確定的，肯定的，毫無疑問的
sure.eg: "What's wrong with him?" "I'm not really sure."

sure.chi_def: 肯定的（地），確定的（地），無疑的（地）
sure.eg: I know for sure that I won't be able to go to the party.

sure.eng_def: to be very or too confident
sure.eg: She's become much more sure of herself since she got a job.

sure.eng_def: be confident that something is true
sure.eg: He said that he wasn't completely sure of his facts.

sure.eng_def: to have confidence in and trust someone
sure.eg: Henry has only been working for us for a short while, and we're not really sure about him yet.

sure.eng_def: to look and/or take action to be certain that something happens, is true, etc.
sure.eg: Make sure you lock the door when you go out.

sure.eng_def: If you have a sure knowledge or understanding of something, you know or understand it very well.
sure.chi_def: 非常清楚的，十分瞭解的
sure.eg: I don't think he has a very sure understanding of the situation.
"Do you want to come swimming with us?" "Sure."

sure.eng_def: said when someone has thanked you
sure.chi_def: （對別人表示感謝時的回應）沒問題
sure.eg: "Thanks for helping us out." "Sure, any time."

surf.eng_def: to spend time visiting a lot of websites
surf.eg: He spends a lot of time surfing the internet/Net/Web.

surf.eng_def: to ride on a wave as it comes towards land, while standing or lying on a special board
the tops of the waves on the sea when they are near to the coast or hit against rocks
surf.eg: We were almost deafened by the crash/roar of the surf.

surface.eng_def: the outer or top part or layer of something
surface.eg: Tropical rain forests used to cover ten percent of the earth's surface.

surface.eng_def: the top layer of a field or track on which sports are played
surface.eg: The match will be played on an artificial/all-weather surface.

surface.eng_def: the flat top part of a table, cupboard, etc.
The surface of a situation or person is what they appear to be, or the features they have that are not hidden or difficult to see.
surface.eg: On the surface, this seems like a difficult problem, but in fact there's an easy solution to it.

surface.eng_def: to rise to the surface of water
surface.eg: The submarine surfaced a few miles off the coast.

surface.eng_def: to cover a road or other area with a hard surface
If a feeling or information surfaces, it becomes known.
surface.eg: Doubts are beginning to surface about whether the right decision has been made.
He never surfaces until at least 11.00 a.m. on a Sunday.

surface.eng_def: working or operating on the top of the land or sea, rather than under the land or sea, or by air
surface.chi_def: 地表上作業的；海面上作業的

surface.eng_def: appearing in a particular way but not always showing the truth
surface.eg: his surface appearance of calm confidence

surge.eg: An unexpected surge in electrical power caused the computer to crash.

surge.eng_def: a sudden and great movement forward
surge.eg: At the end of the game, there was a surge of fans onto the field.

surge.eng_def: a sudden increase of an emotion
surge.eg: She was overwhelmed by a surge of remorse.
An angry crowd surged through the gates of the president's palace.

surge.eng_def: (of an emotion) to develop strongly and quickly
surge.eg: She felt a wave of resentment surging (up) inside her.

surgeon.eng_def: a doctor who is specially trained to perform medical operations

surgery.eng_def: the treatment of injuries or diseases in people or animals by cutting open the body and removing or repairing the damaged part
surgery.eg: The patient had/underwent surgery on his heart.

surgery.eng_def: a place where you can go to ask advice from or receive treatment from a doctor or dentist
surgery.eg: If you come to the surgery at 10.30, the doctor will see you then.

surgery.eng_def: the regular period of time when a person can visit their Member of Parliament to ask advice
surgery.eg: Our MP holds a weekly surgery on Friday mornings.

surpass.eng_def: to do or be better than
surpass.eg: His time for the 100 metres surpassed the previous world record by one hundredth of a second.

surplus.eng_def: (an amount that is) more than is needed
surplus.eg: The world is now producing large food surpluses.

surplus.eng_def: the amount of money you have left when you sell more than you buy, or spend less than you own

surprise.eg: Don't tell Anne we've arranged a party for her - I want it to be a surprise.

surprise.eng_def: the feeling caused by something unexpected happening
surprise.eg: He looked at her in/with surprise.

surprise.chi_def: 使詫異，使驚奇，使感到意外

surprise.eng_def: to find, catch, or attack someone when they are not expecting it
surprise.chi_def: 意外發現；當場抓獲；突然襲擊
surprise.eg: The robbers had just opened the safe when they were surprised by the police.

surrender.eng_def: to stop fighting and admit defeat
surrender.eg: They would rather die than surrender (to the invaders).

surrender.eng_def: If you surrender to an experience or emotion, you stop trying to prevent or control it.
surrender.eg: I finally surrendered to temptation, and ate the last piece of chocolate.

surrender.eng_def: to give something that is yours to someone else because you have been forced to do so or because it is necessary to do so
surrender.eg: The police demanded that the gang surrender their weapons.

surrender.eng_def: the act of stopping fighting and officially admitting defeat
surrender.eg: The rebels are on the point of surrender.

surround.eng_def: the area or border around something
surround.eg: Our bathtub has a tiled surround.

surround.eng_def: the area that is near and around a place
surround.eg: The house is set in lush surrounds and has views of the ocean.

surroundings.eng_def: the place where someone or something is and the things that are in it
surroundings.eg: Some butterflies blend in with their surroundings so that it's difficult to see them.

surroundings.eng_def: the place where someone lives and the conditions they live in
surroundings.eg: They live in very comfortable/pleasant/drab/bleak surroundings.

survey.eng_def: an examination of opinions, behaviour, etc., made by asking people questions
survey.eg: A recent survey found/revealed/showed that 58 percent of people did not know where their heart is.

survey.eng_def: the measuring and recording of the details of an area of land
a description of the whole of a subject
survey.chi_def: （對某一專題的）概述，全面評述
survey.eg: His new book is a survey of European theatre in the 19th century.

survey.eng_def: an examination of the structure of a building by a specially trained person
to look at or examine all of something, especially carefully
survey.eg: He got out of the car to survey the damage.

survey.eng_def: to measure an area of land, and to record the details of it, especially on a map
survey.chi_def: （尤指為繪製地圖而）測量，勘測，測繪
survey.eg: Before the new railway was built, its route was carefully surveyed.

survey.eng_def: If a building is surveyed, it is examined carefully by a specially trained person, in order to discover if there is anything wrong with its structure.
to ask people questions in order to find out about their opinions or behaviour
survey.eg: The researchers surveyed the attitudes of 2,500 college students.

survival.eng_def: the fact of a person, organization, etc. continuing to live or exist
survival.eg: The doctors told my wife I had a 50/50 chance of survival.

survival.eng_def: something that has continued to exist from a previous time
survival.eg: Most of these traditions are survivals from earlier times.

survival.eng_def: continuing to exist or wanting to continue to exist
survival.chi_def: 生存的；賴以生存的；救生用的
survival.eg: We all have a strong survival instinct.

survive.eng_def: to continue to live or exist, especially after coming close to dying or being destroyed or after being in a difficult or threatening situation
survive.chi_def: 繼續生存，存活；（尤指）倖存
survive.eg: The baby was born with a heart problem and only survived for a few hours.

survive.eng_def: to continue to live after someone, especially a member of your family, has died
survive.eg: He is survived by his wife and four children.

survivor.eng_def: a person who continues to live, despite nearly dying
survivor.eg: He was the sole (= only) survivor of the plane crash.

survivor.eng_def: a person who is able to continue living their life successfully despite experiencing difficulties
survivor.chi_def: 善於在困境中生存的人

survivor.eng_def: A person's survivors are the members of his or her family who continue to live after he or she has died.
survivor.chi_def: （某人去世後）仍然活著的家人

suspect.eng_def: to think or believe something to be true or probable
suspect.chi_def: 懷疑，猜想，認為（某事有可能）
suspect.eg: So far, the police do not suspect foul play.

suspect.eng_def: to think that someone has committed a crime or done something wrong
suspect.eg: No one knows who killed her, but the police suspect her husband.
I have no reason to suspect her honesty/loyalty.
