suspect.eng_def: a person believed to have committed a crime or done something wrong, or something believed to have caused something bad
suspect.eg: Police have issued a photograph of the suspect.

suspect.chi_def: 不可靠的，不可信的，可疑的；危險的
suspect.eg: The study was carried out with such a small sample that its results are suspect.

suspend.eng_def: to stop something from being active, either temporarily or permanently
suspend.eg: The ferry service has been suspended for the day because of bad weather.

suspend.eng_def: If someone is suspended from work, school, etc., they are temporarily not allowed to work, go to school, or take part in an activity because of having done something wrong.
suspend.chi_def: （因犯錯而）暫令停職；暫令停學；暫令停止參加活動
suspend.eg: She was suspended from school for fighting.
The builders worked on wooden platforms, suspended by ropes from the roof of the building.

suspend.eng_def: If small pieces of solid material are suspended in a gas or a liquid, they hang or float in the gas or liquid.
suspend.eg: The drug is suspended in a saline solution.

suspense.eng_def: the feeling of excitement or nervousness that you have when you are waiting for something to happen and are uncertain about what it is going to be
suspense.eg: She kept him in suspense for several days before she said that she would marry him.

suspension.eng_def: the act of stopping something happening, operating, etc. for a period of time
suspension.eg: The suspension of fighting is to take effect at 6 a.m. on Monday.

suspension.eng_def: a punishment in which a person is temporarily not allowed to work, go to school, or take part in an activity
suspension.chi_def: （作為處罰的）暫令停職；暫令停學；暫令停止活動
suspension.eg: The union is protesting about the suspension of a restaurant worker.

suspension.eng_def: equipment attached to the wheels of a vehicle that reduces the uncomfortable effects of going over road surfaces that are not even
a liquid in which small pieces of solid are contained, but not dissolved
suspension.eg: a suspension of fine cornflour in corn oil

suspicion.eng_def: a belief or idea that something may be true
suspicion.eg: I have a suspicion that he only asked me out because my brother persuaded him to.

suspicion.eng_def: a feeling or belief that someone has committed a crime or done something wrong
suspicion.eg: "I'm arresting you on suspicion of illegally possessing drugs," said the police officer.
Since they discovered the truth about his background, his colleagues have regarded him with suspicion.
He gave just a suspicion of a smile.

suspicious.eng_def: making you feel that something illegal is happening or that something is wrong
feeling doubt or no trust in someone or something
suspicious.chi_def: 懷疑的，猜疑的；不信任的
suspicious.eg: His colleagues became suspicious (= thought that there was something wrong) when he did not appear at work, since he was always punctual.

sustain.eng_def: to cause or allow something to continue for a period of time
sustain.chi_def: 保持，維持，使持續，使繼續
sustain.eg: The economy looks set to sustain its growth into next year.
The soil in this part of the world is not rich enough to sustain a large population.

sustain.eng_def: to suffer or experience, especially damage or loss
sustain.chi_def: 經歷，遭受（尤指破壞或損失）
sustain.eg: She sustained multiple injuries in the accident.
She was sustained by the strength of her religious faith.

swallow.eng_def: to cause food, drink, pills, etc. to move from your mouth into your stomach by using the muscles of your throat
swallow.eg: My throat is so sore that it really hurts when I swallow.

swallow.eng_def: to use the muscles of your throat, as if moving something from your mouth into your stomach, because you are nervous or frightened, or are about to say something
swallow.chi_def: （因為緊張、害怕或要開始說話而）做吞嚥動作，吞口水
swallow.eg: He swallowed hard and said, "Dad, I have something to tell you."

swallow.eng_def: If something large swallows (up) another thing, it makes it disappear or stop existing separately by making it part of itself.
swallow.eg: An increasing amount of the countryside is being swallowed (up) by the town.

swallow.eng_def: to use or take away a large part of something valuable
swallow.chi_def: 大量使用，大量奪走（貴重之物）
swallow.eg: Taxes have swallowed up nearly half of my pay increase.

swallow.eng_def: to accept something without question or without expressing disagreement
swallow.eg: Not surprisingly, this excuse was too much for them to swallow.

swallow.eng_def: to not express or show something
swallow.eg: She swallowed her disappointment, saying, "That's OK, it doesn't matter."

swallow.eng_def: an act of using the muscles of your throat, or the amount of something you move into your stomach from your mouth by using the muscles of your throat
swallow.eg: He gave a swallow, then began speaking.

swallow.eng_def: a small bird with pointed wings and a tail with two points that flies quickly and catches insects to eat as it flies

swamp.eng_def: (an area of) very wet, soft land
to cover a place or thing with a large amount of water
swamp.eg: High tides have swamped the coast.

swamp.eng_def: If something swamps a person, system, or place, more of it arrives than can be easily dealt with.
swamp.eg: Foreign cars have swamped the UK market.

swamp.eng_def: If clothes swamp you, they are much too big for you.

swan.eng_def: a large, usually white bird with a long neck that lives on rivers and lakes
swan.eg: We watched the swans glide by.

swan.eng_def: to travel, move, or behave in a relaxed way for pleasure and without worrying that others may feel annoyed
swan.chi_def: 漫遊，遊走，閒逛，悠閒地走動
swan.eg: She swanned into the room, carrying a glass of wine, taking no notice of the fact that she'd kept us all waiting for hours.

swap.eng_def: to give something and be given something else instead
swap.eg: When you've finished reading your book, and I've finished mine, can we swap?

swap.eng_def: an exchange, or something that is going to be or has been exchanged
swap.eg: I thought Sam's lunch looked better than mine, so we did a swap.

swarm.eng_def: a large group of insects all moving together
a large group of people all moving together
swarm.eg: A swarm of/Swarms of photographers followed the star's car.

swarm.eng_def: When insects swarm, they come together in a large group.
When people swarm somewhere, they move there in a large group or in large numbers.
swarm.eg: During the summer, tourists swarm the little beachside town.

sway.eng_def: to move slowly from side to side
sway.eg: The trees were swaying in the wind.

sway.eng_def: to cause something to move or change
sway.eg: Recent developments have swayed the balance of power in the region.

sway.eng_def: to persuade someone to believe or do one thing rather than another
sway.eg: Her speech failed to sway her colleagues into supporting the plan.
In the 1980s, the organization came under the sway of (= became strongly influenced by) Christian fundamentalism.

swear.eng_def: to use words that are rude or offensive as a way of emphasizing what you mean or as a way of insulting someone or something
swear.eg: It was a real shock, the first time I heard my mother swear.

swear.eng_def: to promise or say firmly that you are telling the truth or that you will do something or behave in a particular way
swear.eg: I don't know anything about what happened, I swear (it).

sweat.eng_def: the clear, salty liquid that you pass through your skin
sweat.eg: The dancers were dripping with/pouring with sweat after a morning's rehearsal.

sweat.eng_def: a loose top and trousers, worn either by people who are training for a sport or exercising, or as informal clothing
sweat.chi_def: （運動時或非正式場合穿的）田徑服，運動服

sweat.eng_def: to pass sweat through the skin because you are hot, ill, or frightened
sweat.eg: It was so hot when we arrived in Tripoli that we started to sweat as soon as we got off the plane.

sweat.eng_def: If something sweats, it produces drops of liquid on the outside.
sweat.eg: The walls in older houses sometimes sweat with damp.

sweat.eng_def: to work very hard to achieve something
sweat.eg: Volunteers sweated to get the room ready for the dance.

sweater.eng_def: a piece of clothing, typically with long sleeves and made from wool, that is worn on the upper part of the body
sweater.eg: Put a sweater on if you're cold.

sweep.eng_def: to clean especially a floor by using a brush to collect the dirt into one place from which it can be removed
to move, especially quickly and powerfully
sweep.eg: Everyone looked up as she swept into the room.

sweep.eng_def: to quickly spread through and influence an area
sweep.chi_def: 風行，風靡，迅速蔓延，迅速傳播
sweep.eg: A 1970s fashion revival is sweeping Europe.

sweep.eng_def: to travel across all of an area, especially when looking for something
sweep.chi_def: （尤指為尋找某物而）橫掃，掠過
sweep.eg: American minesweepers are sweeping the Arabian Sea.

sweep.eng_def: If a road, river, range of mountains, set of steps, etc. sweeps in a particular direction, they follow a particular curved path.
sweep.eg: The road sweeps down to the coast.

sweep.eng_def: to remove and/or take in a particular direction, especially in a fast and powerful way
sweep.eg: A large wave swept away half the sandcastle.

sweep.eng_def: to win all the parts of a competition, or to win very easily
sweep.chi_def: 大獲全勝，一舉獲勝，輕易獲勝
sweep.eg: The Yankees swept the four-game series with the Blue Jays.

sweep.eng_def: a movement, especially a quick, powerful one or one to search an area
sweep.eg: With a sweep (= horizontal movement) of its tail, the alligator knocked her under the water.

sweep.eng_def: a long, often curved, area of land, sea, river, etc.
sweep.chi_def: 一片（長長且彎曲的）土地（海域、河流等）
sweep.eg: A broad sweep of flat countryside stretched to the horizon in all directions.

sweep.eng_def: the act of sweeping something to clean it
sweep.eg: I've given the kitchen floor a sweep (= I have swept it).

sweep.chi_def: 煙囪清掃工（chimney sweep的老式說法）

sweep.eng_def: a situation in which one player, team, etc. wins everything that is available
sweep.eg: Romania made a clean sweep of the medals.

sweep.eng_def: a period of time when measurements of the number of people watching different television stations are made so that the cost of advertising on each station can be set

sweet.eng_def: (especially of food or drink) having a taste similar to that of sugar; not bitter or salty
sweet.eg: The pineapple was sweet and juicy.

sweet.eng_def: If an emotion or event is sweet, it is very pleasant and satisfying.
sweet.chi_def: 愉快的，愜意的，令人滿意的
sweet.eg: She was enjoying the sweet smell of success.

sweet.eng_def: If a sound is sweet, it is pleasant and easy to like.
sweet.eg: She has a sweet singing voice.

sweet.eng_def: (especially of something or someone small) pleasant and attractive
sweet.chi_def: （尤指小東西或小孩子）迷人的，漂亮的，吸引人的
sweet.eg: They live in a sweet little house.

sweet.chi_def: 溫和的，和藹的，討人喜歡的
sweet.eg: I think Alex is really sweet.

sweet.eng_def: a small piece of sweet food, made of sugar
sweet.eg: She bought a packet of sweets to suck on the way.

sweet.eng_def: any food with a lot of sugar in it
sweet.eg: No cake, thanks. I'm trying to avoid sweets.

sweet.eng_def: sweet food eaten at the end of a meal
sweet.eg: There was only one sweet on the menu - chocolate cake with cream.

sweet.eng_def: used to show that you are happy about something or think it is good
sweet.chi_def: （用來表示對…很高興或認為很好）好
sweet.eg: "I got free tickets to the gig." "Sweet!"

swell.eng_def: to become larger and rounder than usual; to (cause to) increase in size or amount
swell.eg: It was obvious she had broken her toe, because it immediately started to swell (up).

swell.eng_def: If music swells, it becomes louder.
the slow up and down movement of the sea with large but smooth waves
an increase in sound produced by a musical instrument or instruments

swift.eng_def: happening or moving quickly or within a short time, especially in a smooth and easy way
swift.eg: The police took swift action against the rioters.

swift.eng_def: a small bird with curved, pointed wings that can fly very fast

swim.eng_def: to move through water by moving the body or parts of the body
swim.eg: We spent the day on the beach but it was too cold to go swimming.

swim.eng_def: If food is swimming in/with a liquid, it has too much of that liquid in it or on it.
swim.eg: The salad was swimming in oil.

swim.eng_def: (of an object) to seem to move around
swim.eg: Getting up too suddenly made the room swim before her eyes.

swim.eng_def: If your head swims, you feel confused and are unable to think or see clearly.
swim.eg: After the second or third drink, my head began to swim.
Let's go for/have a swim this afternoon.

swing.eng_def: to move easily and without interruption backwards and forwards or from one side to the other, especially from a fixed point, or to cause something or someone to do this
swing.eg: He walked briskly along swinging his rolled-up umbrella.

swing.eng_def: to move an object or your fist in an attempt to hit something or someone

swing.eg: His mood swings between elation and despair.
You need music to make a party swing.

swing.eng_def: to play music in a strong, exciting style like jazz, or (of music) to be played in this way
swing.chi_def: （尤指爵士樂）有強烈節奏感；（樂手）演奏（尤指節奏感強烈的爵士樂）

swing.eng_def: to arrange for something to happen, by persuading people and often by acting slightly dishonestly
swing.chi_def: （常指透過稍有些不誠實的手段）設法辦成，安排
swing.eg: If you want an interview with Pedro, I could probably swing it (for you).
The drunk took a wild swing at Harry.
He experiences severe mood swings (= sudden changes from one extreme mood to another).

swing.eng_def: a seat joined by two ropes or chains to a metal bar or a tree, on which you can sit and move backwards and forwards
If an event, especially a party, goes with a swing, it is very exciting and successful.
swing.chi_def: （尤指聚會）氣氛熱烈，熱鬧非凡
swing.eg: The Festival always goes with a swing.

swing.eng_def: a type of dance music that was popular in the 1930s and 40s

switch.eng_def: a small device, usually pushed up or down with your finger, that controls and turns on or off an electric current
a place on a railway track where the rails (= metal bars on which the trains travel) can be moved to allow a train to change from one track to another
switch.eg: The train rattled as it went over the switches.

switch.eng_def: a sudden or complete change, especially of one person or thing for another
switch.chi_def: 突然改變，徹底改變；調換；轉換

switch.eng_def: to use a switch to change a device from one state or type of operation to another
switch.chi_def: 打開（開關）；關閉（開關）；轉換

switch.eng_def: to change suddenly or completely, especially from one thing to another, or to exchange by replacing one person or thing with another
switch.chi_def: 突然改變，徹底改變；調換；轉換
switch.eg: She started studying English, but switched to Law in her second year.

sword.eng_def: a weapon with a long, sharp metal blade and a handle, used especially in the past

syllable.eng_def: a single unit of speech, either a whole word or one of the parts into which a word can be separated, usually containing a vowel

symbol.eng_def: a sign, shape, or object that is used to represent something else
symbol.eg: A heart shape is the symbol of love.

symbol.eng_def: something that is used to represent a quality or idea
symbol.chi_def: （某種特性或思想的）代表，象徵
symbol.eg: Water, a symbol of life, recurs as an image throughout her poems.

symbol.eng_def: a number, letter, or sign used in mathematics, music, science, etc.
symbol.eg: The symbol for oxygen is O.

symbol.eng_def: An object can be described as a symbol of something else if it seems to represent it because it is connected with it in a lot of people's minds
symbol.eg: The private jet is a symbol of wealth.

symbolic.eg: The skull at the bottom of the picture is symbolic of death.

symbolic.eng_def: used to refer to an action that expresses or seems to express an intention or feeling, but has little practical influence on a situation
symbolic.chi_def: （行為舉動）象徵性的，沒有甚麼實際影響的
symbolic.eg: Five hundred troops were sent in, more as a symbolic gesture than as a real threat.

symbolize.eg: The lighting of the Olympic torch symbolizes peace and friendship among the nations of the world.

symmetry.eng_def: the quality of having parts that match each other, especially in a way that is attractive, or similarity of shape or contents
symmetry.eg: The design of the house had a pleasing symmetry, its oblong shape being picked up in its elongated windows.

symmetry.eng_def: in mathematics, the quality of having two parts that match exactly, either when one half is like an image of the other half in a mirror, or when one part can take the place of another if it is turned 90° or 180°

sympathetic.eng_def: used to describe someone who shows, especially by what they say, that they understand and care about someone else's suffering
sympathetic.eg: He suffers from back trouble too, so he was very sympathetic about my problem.

sympathetic.eng_def: If a character in a book or film is sympathetic, they are described or shown in such a way that you are able to understand the character's feelings, with the result that you like them.
sympathetic.chi_def: （書或電影中的人物）能引起共鳴的，讓人同情的，讓人有同感的
sympathetic.eg: She comes across as a more sympathetic character in the movie.
The party is considered to be sympathetic to/towards welfare reform.

sympathize.eng_def: to understand and care about someone's problems
sympathize.eg: I know what it's like to have migraines, so I really sympathize (with you).

sympathize.eng_def: to support and agree with someone or something
sympathize.eg: I sympathize with the general aims of the organization, but on this particular issue I disagree.

sympathy.eng_def: (an expression of) understanding and care for someone else's suffering
sympathy.eg: The president has sent a message of sympathy to the relatives of the dead soldiers.

sympathy.eng_def: to express your sadness to someone because a relation or friend of theirs has recently died
sympathy.eg: I went along to the funeral in order to offer my sympathies.
I must confess I have some sympathy with his views.
Of those people questioned, 93 percent said their sympathies were with the teachers.

sympathy.eng_def: to stop working in order to show your support for other workers who are on strike
sympathy.eg: The railway workers came out in sympathy with the miners.

symphony.eng_def: a long piece of music for an orchestra, usually with four movements (= parts)

symptom.eng_def: any feeling of illness or physical or mental change that is caused by a particular disease
symptom.eg: He's complaining of all the usual flu symptoms - a high temperature, headache, and so on.

symptom.eng_def: any single problem that is caused by and shows a more serious and general problem
symptom.eg: It's her feeling that the recent outbreaks of violence are a symptom of the dissatisfaction that is currently affecting our society.

synonym.eng_def: a word or phrase that has the same or nearly the same meaning as another word or phrase in the same language

synthetic.eng_def: Synthetic products are made from artificial substances, often copying a natural product.

synthetic.eg: She criticized the synthetic charm of TV hosts.

syrup.eg: Make a syrup by boiling 100 g sugar in 300 ml water.

syrup.eng_def: a type of sweet liquid medicine

system.eng_def: a set of connected things or devices that operate together
a set of computer equipment and programs used together for a particular purpose
system.eg: The system keeps crashing and no one is able to figure out why.

system.eng_def: a set of organs or structures in the body that have a particular purpose
the way that the body works, especially the way that it digests food and passes out waste products
system.chi_def: 人體的活動方式（尤指消化和排泄方式）
system.eg: A run in the morning is good for the system - it wakes the body up and gets everything going.
We'll have to develop a better filing system.

system.eng_def: a particular method of counting, measuring, or weighing things
system.eg: the metric system of measuring and weighing

system.eng_def: the intentional and organized use of a system
system.eg: There doesn't seem to be any system to the books on these shelves - they're certainly not in alphabetical order.

system.eng_def: unfair laws and rules that prevent people from being able to improve their situation
system.chi_def: （不公平的）法律規定，現行體制，現有制度
system.eg: He has his own ways of beating the system, making sure that he has good relationships with influential people.

systematic.eng_def: according to an agreed set of methods or organized plan
systematic.chi_def: 有條理的，有系統的，有計劃的
systematic.eg: We've got to be more systematic in the way that we approach this task.

table.eng_def: a flat surface, usually supported by four legs, used for putting things on
the people sitting at a table
table.eg: There was a really noisy table behind us celebrating someone's birthday.

table.eng_def: a table that you work at in an office
to put a cloth, knives, and forks, etc. on the table in preparation for a meal
table.eg: Could you set the table for lunch, please?

table.eng_def: an arrangement of facts and numbers in rows or blocks, especially in printed material
a list of the information that is contained in a book

table.eg: An amendment to the proposal was tabled by Mrs James.

table.eng_def: to delay discussion of a subject
table.eg: The suggestion was tabled for discussion at a later date.

table tennis.eng_def: a game that is played on a large table where two or four players hit a ball over a low net using small, round bats

tablet.eng_def: a small, solid piece of medicine
a thin, flat, often square piece of hard material such as wood, stone, or metal
tablet.eg: The poem was engraved on a tablet of stone.

tablet.eng_def: a small, flat computer that is controlled by touching the screen or by using a special pen

tack.eng_def: a small, sharp nail with a flat end

tack.chi_def: （為定樣臨時縫上的）粗縫針腳，假縫

tack.eng_def: all the objects that the rider of a horse needs, including saddles and bridles
the direction or distance that a boat moves at an angle to the direction of the wind, so that the boat receives the wind on its sails
tack.eg: The ship was on the starboard tack.

tack.eng_def: to fasten something to a place with tacks
to sew with a long, loose stitch that holds two pieces of material together temporarily, before they are sewn together in a more tidy or permanent way
(of a boat) to turn so that it is at an angle to the direction of the wind and receives the wind on its sails

tackle.eng_def: to try to deal with something or someone
tackle.eg: There are many ways of tackling this problem.

tackle.eng_def: (especially in football or hockey) to try to take the ball from a player in the other team, or (in rugby or American football) to do this by taking hold of the player and making them fall
tackle.chi_def: （尤指足球或曲棍球中）阻截；鏟球；（橄欖球中阻截時）擒抱並摔倒（對方持球隊員）

tackle.eng_def: (especially in football or hockey) an act of tackling someone
tackle.chi_def: （尤指足球或曲棍球中）阻截；鏟球

tackle.eng_def: all the objects needed for a particular activity

tact.eng_def: the ability to say or do the right thing without making anyone unhappy or angry
tact.chi_def: （處事、言談等的）得體，乖巧，機敏；外交手腕
tact.eg: He's never had much tact and people don't like his blunt manner.

tactic.eng_def: a planned way of doing something
tactic.eg: These bomb attacks represent a change of tactics by the terrorists.

tactic.eng_def: the organization and use of soldiers and equipment in war

tag.eng_def: a small piece of paper, cloth, or metal, on which there is information, tied or stuck onto something larger
a game played by two or more children in which one child chases the others and tries to touch one of them. This child then becomes the one who does the chasing.
a phrase such as "he is" or "isn't it?", added on to a sentence for emphasis, or to turn it into a question, usually to get agreement or to check information
tag.chi_def: 附加強調語；附加疑問句

tag.eng_def: a type of graffiti (= words and pictures drawn in public places on walls, etc.) that shows who has drawn it and that represents a signature
tag.eg: The tag is the most commonly seen graffiti in any urban setting.

tag.eng_def: to put a tag on something
tag.chi_def: 給…貼上標籤，給…掛上標牌

tag.eng_def: to mark computer information to be processed in a particular way

tail.eng_def: a part of an animal's body, sticking out from the base of the back, or something similar in shape or position
tail.eg: The dog wagged its tail excitedly.

tail.eng_def: someone who follows another person to discover where that person goes, what they do, etc.
the side of a coin that does not have a picture of someone's head on it
tail.chi_def: 硬幣反面（通常指沒有頭像的一面）

tail.eg: You've just got to get off your tail and start looking for a job.

tail.eng_def: a phrase that is placed at the end of a sentence and refers to something mentioned in the sentence
tail.chi_def: （出現在句子最後，補充說明句子中的某個詞）

tail.eng_def: to follow and watch someone very closely, especially in order to get information secretly
tail.eg: That car has been tailing me for the last ten minutes.

tailor.eng_def: someone whose job is to repair, make, and adjust (= make changes to) clothes, especially someone who makes jackets, trousers, coats, etc. for men
to make or prepare something following particular instructions
tailor.chi_def: 專門製作，使適應特定需要
tailor.eg: We tailor any of our products to your company's specific needs.

take.eng_def: to remove something, especially without permission
take.eg: Has anything been taken (= stolen)?

take.eng_def: to subtract a number (= remove it from another number)
take.eg: If you take 4 (away) from 12 you get 8.

take.eng_def: to move something or someone from one place to another
take.eg: The weather forecast said rain, so take your umbrella (with you) when you go out.

take.eng_def: to accept or have
take.eg: Do they take credit cards here?

take.eng_def: used when you want to mention something as a particular example of what you are talking about
take.eg: I've been very busy recently. Take last week, I had meetings every night after work, except Friday.

take.eng_def: If you take someone or something to be something, or if you take someone or something for something, you accept or believe that they are that thing.
take.eg: These creatures are generally taken to be descended from primitive fishes.

take.eng_def: to not be able to deal with an unpleasant situation
take.eg: I can't take it any more. I'm leaving.

take.eng_def: accept or refuse the offer completely
take.chi_def: 接不接受由你，要不要隨你的便
take.eg: That's my final offer - you can take it or leave it.

take.eng_def: to move in order to hold something in the hand(s)
take.eg: Can you take this bag while I open the door?

take.eng_def: to go somewhere with someone, often paying for that person or being responsible for them
take.eg: We're taking the kids to the zoo on Saturday.

take.eng_def: to show someone how to get to somewhere by going there with them
take.eg: Let me take you to your room.

take.eng_def: to go to a social event with someone
take.eg: Who's taking you to the dance?

take.eng_def: to travel somewhere by using a particular form of transport or a particular vehicle, route, etc.
take.eg: I always take the train - it's less hassle than a car.

take.eng_def: to need
take.eg: Parachuting takes a lot of nerve.

take.eng_def: to wear a particular size of clothes or shoes
take.chi_def: 穿（特定尺寸的衣服或鞋）
take.eg: What size shoes do you take?

take.eng_def: If something takes a particular time, that period is needed in order to complete it.
take.eg: The cooking process only takes ten minutes.

take.eng_def: to act or happen over a short period of time
take.eg: I'm just going to the shops - I won't take long.

take.eng_def: to need a long time
take.eg: Broken bones always take time to heal.

take.eng_def: to measure something
take.eg: Nurses took my temperature and blood pressure.

take.eng_def: to swallow or use a medicine or drug, especially in a regular way
take.eg: Take this medicine three times a day.

take.eng_def: to do or perform
take.eg: Shelley is taking (= studying) economics at university.

take.eng_def: used with many nouns to make a verb phrase that is equal in meaning to the related verb
take.chi_def: （後接名詞形成動詞片語，其意思相當於相應動詞）
take.eg: I think we'll take a break (= we'll stop for a break) there.

take.eng_def: to think about something or someone in a particular way
take.chi_def: （以某一種特殊方式）思考，考慮
take.eg: We're taking the bomb threats very seriously.

take.eng_def: to understand something in a particular way
take.eg: I was just teasing him, but he took it the wrong way.

take.eng_def: to have or come to have a particular feeling or opinion
take.eg: He doesn't take any interest in his children.

take.eng_def: to surprise someone
take.eg: The sudden noise took her by surprise.

take.eng_def: to receive money from sales or as payment for entrance to an event
take.eg: The show took an astonishing $100,000 in its first week.

take.eng_def: to get possession of something or someone
take.eg: Rebels ambushed the train and took several prisoners.

take.eng_def: to write
take.eg: I hope you're all taking notes.

take.eng_def: to work or perform as expected
take.eg: These new plants haven't taken - they don't like this dry soil.

take.eng_def: money that is received from sales or as payment for entrance to an event
take.eg: The box office take was huge for the new show.

take.eng_def: the filming of a scene (= small part of a film)
take.eg: This scene needed ten takes before we felt it was right.

tale.eng_def: a story, especially one that might be invented or difficult to believe
tale.chi_def: （尤指包含離奇內容的）故事，不實之詞
tale.eg: He told some fascinating tales about his life in India.

talent.eng_def: (someone who has) a natural ability to be good at something, especially without being taught
talent.chi_def: 天分，天賦；天才，有天分者
talent.eg: Her talent for music showed at an early age.
There was plenty of talent at the party last night.

talk.eng_def: to say words aloud; to speak to someone
talk.eg: We were just talking about Gareth's new girlfriend.

talk.eng_def: to discuss something with someone, often to try to find a solution to a disagreement
talk.chi_def: （為了尋求解決分歧的途徑而）與…會談
talk.eg: The two sides have agreed to talk.
Whenever they're together, they talk politics.

talk.eng_def: to give a lecture on a subject
talk.eg: The next speaker will be talking about endangered insects.

talk.eng_def: a conversation between two people, often about a particular subject
talk.eg: I asked him to have a talk with his mother about his plan.

talk.eng_def: a speech given to a group of people to teach or tell them about a particular subject
talk.eg: He gave a talk about/on his visit to Malaysia.

talk.eng_def: serious and formal discussions on an important subject, usually intended to produce decisions or agreements
talk.eg: Talks were held in Madrid about the fuel crisis.

talk.eng_def: the action of talking about what might happen or be true, or the subject people are talking about

talkative.chi_def: 愛說話的，健談的；多嘴的

tall.eng_def: of more than average height, or of a particular height

tame.eng_def: (especially of animals) not wild or dangerous, either naturally or because of training or long involvement with humans
tame.eg: After a few months' contact the monkeys become very tame.
It was a tame film in comparison to some that she's made.

tame.eng_def: to make a wild animal tame
to control something dangerous or powerful
tame.eg: He'll need to tame his temper if he wants to succeed.

tame.eng_def: someone who tames something that is wild, especially an animal

tan.eng_def: pleasantly brown skin caused by being in the hot sun
to become brown, or to make someone's body or skin, etc. brown, from being in the sun
tan.eg: Her skin tans very quickly in the summer.

tan.eng_def: to change animal skin into leather using special chemicals such as tannin
tan.chi_def: 鞣（革）；用鞣酸將（獸皮）製成皮革

tangerine.eng_def: a fruit like a small orange with a loose skin

tangle.eng_def: an untidy mass of things that are not in a state of order, or a state of confusion or difficulty
to become or form, or to make something into, an untidy mass

tank.eng_def: a container that holds liquid or gas
a large military fighting vehicle designed to protect those inside it from attack, driven by wheels that turn inside moving metal belts
an artificial pool or lake, especially a lake for supplying water to an area
tank.chi_def: 人造水池（尤指作為某地水源的湖泊）

tank.eng_def: to go down in price, value, etc., or to become less successful
tank.chi_def: （價格、價值）下跌；不如原來成功
tank.eg: The state was expecting an increase in tax revenues, but that was before the economy tanked.

tap.eng_def: to hit something gently, and often repeatedly, especially making short, sharp noises
tap.eg: The branches tapped against the window.

tap.eng_def: to touch the screen of a phone, tablet computer, etc. in order to give an instruction for something to happen
tap.chi_def: 輕觸（手機或平板電腦等給予指令）
tap.eg: You can manage the repeat and shuffle options by tapping the screen once and swiping to the left.

tap.eng_def: to get or make use of something
tap.eg: For more than a century, Eastern cities have expanded their water supplies by tapping ever more remote sources.

tap.eng_def: to use a small device attached to a phone in order to listen secretly to what people are saying
tap.chi_def: 在（電話或電報線）上裝竊聽器；竊聽
tap.eg: He suspected that his phone had been tapped.

tap.eng_def: a device that controls the flow of liquid, especially water, from a pipe
a device that controls the flow of gas from a pipe
used to describe beer that is served from a barrel through a tap
tap.chi_def: （啤酒）裝在有旋塞的桶裡的，散裝的

tap.eng_def: available for use at any time
tap.eg: Working in a library as I do, I have all this information on tap.

tap.eng_def: a gentle knock or touch, or the noise made by knocking something gently
tap.chi_def: 輕扣，輕敲，輕拍；輕輕拍打（或敲擊）的聲響
tap.eg: I gave her a tap on the shoulder and she turned around.

tap.eng_def: a small piece of equipment that can be attached to a phone in order to listen secretly to someone's phone calls
tap.chi_def: 在（電話或電報線）上裝竊聽器；竊聽
tap.eg: He claims that he knew nothing of government phone taps on journalists during those years.

tap.eng_def: a sound made by the tongue moving upwards and downwards very quickly and hitting the alveolar area

tape.eng_def: thin plastic in a long, narrow strip with a magnetic covering that allows sounds or sounds and pictures to be recorded and played again, especially one on which sound is recorded
a long, narrow strip of material that is sometimes sticky on one side
tape.eg: I need some tape and scissors to wrap the present.

tape.eng_def: a tape stretched across the finishing line of a race that the winner breaks as they finish

tape.chi_def: 把…錄在錄音帶（或錄像帶）上

tape.eng_def: to use strips of sticky material, especially to fix two things together or to fasten a parcel
tape.chi_def: 用膠布固定；用膠布封住；用帶子捆紮
tape.eg: She taped a note to the door.

tar.eng_def: a black substance, sticky when hot, used especially for making roads
tar.chi_def: （用於鋪路的）煤焦油瀝青，柏油

tar.eng_def: one of the poisonous substances found in tobacco
to put tar on a surface

target.eng_def: an object shot at during shooting practice, often a circle with a pattern of rings, or any object or place at which bullets, bombs, etc. are aimed
target.chi_def: 靶，靶子；（攻擊、轟炸等的）目標
target.eg: I had four shots but I didn't even hit the target.

target.eng_def: a person or a particular group of people that something is directed at, or that something is intended for
target.eg: The target audience for the TV series is young people aged 13 to 18.

target.eng_def: one or more people who are criticized or laughed at, or who experience unpleasant treatment from others
target.eg: Recently she has been the target of a series of obscene phone calls.

target.eng_def: a level or situation that you intend to achieve
target.eg: The government's target of 3.5 percent annual growth seems easily attainable.

target.eng_def: to direct advertising, criticism, or a product at someone
target.chi_def: （廣告、批評或產品）以…為目標（或對象）
target.eg: The advert for the energy drink is targeted specifically at young people.

target.eng_def: to aim an attack, or a bullet, bomb, etc., at a particular object, place, or person
target.chi_def: 把…作為（瞄準、轟炸等）的目標
target.eg: It is hoped that civilians will not be targeted during the war.

tariff.eng_def: a charge or list of charges either for services or on goods entering a country

tart.eng_def: an open pastry case with a filling, usually of something sweet such as fruit
a woman who intentionally wears the type of clothes and make-up that attract sexual attention in a way that is too obvious
tart.chi_def: 妖艷的女人，放蕩的女人

tart.eng_def: (especially of fruit) tasting sour or acidic
tart.eg: You might need some sugar on the rhubarb - it's a little tart.

tart.eng_def: (especially of a way of speaking) quick or sharp and unpleasant
tart.chi_def: （尤指說話方式）尖刻的，刻薄的

task.eng_def: a piece of work to be done, especially one done regularly, unwillingly, or with difficulty
task.chi_def: 任務；（尤指經常、不情願或很難做的）工作；（苦）差事
task.eg: We usually ask interviewees to perform a few simple tasks on the computer just to test their aptitude.

task.eng_def: to criticize or speak angrily to someone for something that they have done wrong
task.eg: She took her assistant to task for/over her carelessness.
We have been tasked with setting up camps for refugees.

taste.eng_def: the flavour of something, or the ability of a person or animal to recognize different flavours
taste.eg: I love the taste of garlic.

taste.eng_def: the fact of liking or enjoying something
taste.eg: She came home from Europe with a taste for art and the finer things in life.
Have a taste of the sauce and tell me if it needs salt.

taste.eng_def: a person's approval of and liking for particular things
taste.eg: I'm not really into new cars - old vintage cars are more to my taste (= what I like).

taste.eng_def: a person's ability to judge and recognize what is good or suitable, especially relating to such matters as art, style, beauty, and behaviour
taste.eg: He has terrible taste so you can probably imagine what his house looks like.
I have expensive tastes (= I like expensive things).
I had a taste of office work during the summer and that was enough.

taste.eng_def: to put food or drink in your mouth to find out what flavour it has
taste.eg: Taste this sauce and tell me if it needs seasoning.

taste.chi_def: 吃起來好吃／難吃／甜（等等）

taste.eng_def: to experience something for a short time
taste.eg: Once you've tasted luxury it's very hard to settle for anything else.

tasty.eng_def: Tasty food has a strong and very pleasant flavour.
used to describe someone who is very sexually attractive

taunt.eng_def: to intentionally annoy and upset someone by making unkind remarks to them, laughing unkindly, etc.
taunt.eg: The other kids used to taunt him in the playground because he was fat and wore glasses.

tavern.eng_def: a place where alcohol is sold and drunk

tax.eng_def: (an amount of) money paid to the government that is based on your income or the cost of goods or services you have bought
tax.eg: They're increasing the tax on cigarettes.

tax.eng_def: to make someone pay a tax
tax.eg: Husbands and wives may be taxed jointly/separately.

tax.eng_def: to need someone to make a lot of effort, either physical or mental
tax.eg: He only has to read a short report - it shouldn't tax him too much.

taxi.eng_def: a car with a driver who you pay to take you somewhere
taxi.eg: I took a taxi from the station to the hotel.

taxi.eng_def: (of an aircraft) to move slowly on the ground

tea.eng_def: (a drink made by pouring hot water onto) dried and cut leaves and sometimes flowers, especially the leaves of the tea plant
a small meal eaten in the late afternoon, usually including cake and a cup of tea
a meal that is eaten in the early evening and is usually cooked

teach.eng_def: to give someone knowledge or to train someone; to instruct
teach.eg: She taught English to foreign students.

teach.eng_def: to be a teacher in a school
teach.eg: We moved to a small town where my mother taught school and my father worked in real estate.

teacher.eng_def: someone whose job is to teach in a school or college

team.eng_def: a number of people or animals who do something together as a group
used in a number of phrases that refer to people working together as a group in order to achieve something
team.eg: It was a real team effort - everyone contributed something to the success of the project.

team.eng_def: to act together to achieve something
team.eg: Lang teamed with Draper to develop the vaccine.

tear.eng_def: to pull or be pulled apart, or to pull pieces off
tear.eg: You have to be very careful with books this old because the paper tears very easily.
He went tearing along the road after the bus.

tear.eng_def: a hole in a piece of paper, cloth, or other material, where it has been torn
a drop of salty liquid that flows from the eye, as a result of strong emotion, especially unhappiness, or pain

tear.eg: I found him in tears in his bedroom.
Why do our eyes tear when we're cutting onions?

tease.eng_def: to laugh at someone or say unkind things about them, either because you are joking or because you want to upset that person
tease.eg: I used to hate being teased about my red hair when I was at school.

tease.eng_def: to hold your hair away from your head and brush it towards your head with a comb, in order to make it look thicker
someone who is always teasing people
tease.eg: Johnny, don't be such a tease - leave your sister alone!

tease.eng_def: someone who enjoys causing sexual excitement and interest in people she or he does not intend to have sex with

technical.eng_def: relating to the knowledge, machines, or methods used in science and industry
relating to the knowledge and methods of a particular subject or job
technical.eg: Personally, I found some parts of the book a little too technical to follow.

technical.eng_def: relating to practical skills and methods that are used in a particular activity
technical.eg: In her performance as the Snow Queen she showed great technical brilliance.

technician.eng_def: a worker trained with special skills, especially in science or engineering
a person whose technique is very good

technique.eng_def: a way of doing an activity that needs skill
technique.eg: We have developed a new technique for detecting errors in the manufacturing process.

technological.chi_def: 技術的，關於（或涉及）技術的
technological.eg: Technological advances in computing and telecommunications have reduced the need for many people to travel to work.

technology.eng_def: (the study and knowledge of) the practical, especially industrial, use of scientific discoveries
technology.chi_def: 技術（學）；應用技術；（尤指）工業技術

teenager.eng_def: a young person between 13 and 19 years old
teenager.eg: The magazine is aimed at teenagers and young adults.

telegram.eng_def: (especially in the past) a piece of paper with a message sent by telegraph

telegraph.eng_def: (especially in the past) a method of sending and receiving messages by electrical or radio signals, or the special equipment used for this purpose

telescope.eng_def: a cylinder-shaped device for making objects that are far away look closer and larger, using a combination of lenses, or lenses and curved mirrors
to make or become shorter by reducing the length of the parts
telescope.eg: We had to telescope five visits into two days.

television.eng_def: a device shaped like a box with a screen that receives electrical signals and changes them into moving images and sound, or the method or business of sending images and sound by electrical signals
television.chi_def: 電視機；電視；電視廣播業

tell.eng_def: to say something to someone, often giving them information or instructions
tell.eg: Tell me about your holiday then.

tell.eng_def: to say something/things that are not true
to tell the facts without hiding anything
If someone, usually a child, tells tales, they tell someone such as a teacher about something bad that someone else has done.
tell.eg: Your classmates won't trust you if you're always telling tales, Alvin.
How do you know she's telling the truth?
To tell (you) the truth, I didn't understand a word of what he was saying.

tell.eng_def: to know, recognize, or be certain
If something tells you something, it gives you information.
tell.eg: What does the survey tell us about the lives of teenagers?

tell.eng_def: to notice a difference in quality between two things
tell.eg: This coffee is about half the price of that one and yet you really can't tell the difference.

tell.eng_def: to say what will happen in someone's future
tell.eg: At the fair, there was a lady who told your fortune.

tell.eng_def: to be able to understand a clock
tell.eg: My daughter has just learned to tell the time.

tell.eng_def: there is no way of knowing
tell.eg: There is no telling what the future will hold for them.

tell.eng_def: said to mean that you can never know or be certain
tell.eg: Who knows what will happen to Peter and me in the future - you can never tell.
She's been under a lot of stress recently and it's starting to tell.

teller.eng_def: a person who counts votes at an election
a person employed in a bank to receive and pay out money

temper.eng_def: the tendency to become angry very quickly

temper.eg: The children behaved so badly that I lost my temper.

temper.eng_def: to succeed in staying calm and not becoming angry
temper.eg: I found it hard to keep my temper with so many things going wrong.
I'd stay away from her if I were you - she's in a foul temper.
He appears to be a man of calm and even temper.

temper.eng_def: to make something less strong, extreme, etc.
temper.chi_def: 使緩和；使變溫和；使變淡
temper.eg: My enthusiasm for the venture was tempered by my knowledge of the hard work that would be involved.

temper.eng_def: to heat and then cool a metal in order to make it hard

temperament.eng_def: the part of your character that affects your moods and the way you behave

temperature.eng_def: the measured amount of heat in a place or in the body
temperature.eg: Preheat the oven to a temperature of 200 degrees Celsius.

temperature.eng_def: to have a higher body temperature than normal and to be ill
If you say that the temperature in a particular situation is rising, you mean that it is likely to become violent because people have become angry.
temperature.eg: The temperature of the discussion started to rise as each side added its own arguments.

temple.eng_def: a building used for the worship of a god or gods in some religions
the flat area on each side of your head in front of the top of your ear

tempo.eng_def: the speed at which an event happens
tempo.eg: We're going to have to up the tempo (= work faster) if we want to finish on time.

tempo.eng_def: the speed at which a piece of music is played

temporary.eng_def: not lasting or needed for very long
temporary.eg: The ceasefire will only provide a temporary solution to the crisis.

tempt.eng_def: to make someone want to have or do something, especially something that is unnecessary or wrong
tempt.eg: The offer of free credit tempted her into buying a new car.

tempt.eng_def: to want something or to want to do something
tempt.eg: "Did you apply for that job?" "Well, I was very tempted, but I decided not to."

temptation.eng_def: the wish to do or have something that you know you should not do or have
temptation.eg: As a young actress, she resisted the temptation to move to Hollywood.

temptation.eng_def: something that makes you want to do or have something that you know you should not
temptation.eg: He knew it was wrong to steal, but the money just lying there was too great a temptation.

ten.eg: Her father died ten years ago.

tenant.eng_def: a person who pays rent for the use of land or a building

tend.eng_def: to be likely to behave in a particular way or have a particular characteristic
tend.eg: We tend to get cold winters and warm, dry summers in this part of the country.

tend.eng_def: to care for something or someone
tend.eg: He carefully tended his sunflower plants.

tendency.eng_def: If someone has a tendency to do or like something, they will probably do it or like it.
tendency.eg: His tendency to exaggerate is well known.

tendency.eng_def: If there is a tendency for something to happen, it is likely to happen or it often happens.
tendency.eg: There is a tendency for unemployment to rise in the summer.

tendency.eng_def: If there is a tendency to do something, it starts to happen more often or starts to increase.
tendency.eg: There is a growing tendency to regard money more highly than quality of life.

tender.chi_def: 溫柔的；溫情的；關懷的；慈愛的

tender.eng_def: (of part of the body) painful, sore, or uncomfortable when touched
tender.chi_def: （身體部位）疼痛的，一觸即痛的
tender.eg: My arm was very tender after the injection.

tender.eng_def: (of meat or vegetables) easy to cut or chew (= crush with the teeth)
Tender plants are easily damaged by cold weather.

tender.eg: He was sent off to boarding school at the tender age of seven.

tender.eng_def: If you tender for a job, you make a formal offer to do it for a stated price.
tender.eg: Five companies have tendered for the hospital contract.

tender.eng_def: If you tender for something such as shares, you make a formal offer to buy them for a stated price.
a written or formal offer to supply goods or do a job for an agreed price
tender.eg: The council has invited tenders for the building contract.

tender.eng_def: a written offer to buy or sell shares in a company
tender.chi_def: （期貨交易中的）交割意向通知書

tender.eng_def: If you put work out to tender, you ask people to make offers to do it.
tender.eg: Education departments in all the prisons are being put out to tender.

tender.eng_def: a vehicle used for transporting water, wood, or coal, especially one that is pulled behind a railway engine or used by the fire service
tender.chi_def: （尤指掛在火車頭後的）煤水車

tender.eng_def: a small boat that is used for transporting people or goods from the land to a larger boat or from the larger boat to the land
tender.chi_def: （用來在大船與陸地間運送人員或貨物的）小船
tender.eg: The SS Nomadic was a tender to the ill-fated liner, Titanic.

tender.eng_def: a small piece of chicken breast meat, usually breaded and fried, or a cut of chicken from the tenderloin
tender.chi_def: （通常裹有麵包屑的）雞胸脯肉；雞裡脊肉

tennis.eng_def: a game played between two or four people on a special playing area that involves hitting a small ball across a central net using a racket

tense.eng_def: any of the forms of a verb which show the time at which an action happened
tense.eg: "I sing" is in the present tense and "I sang" is in the past tense.

tense.eng_def: nervous and worried and unable to relax
tense.eg: She was very tense as she waited for the interview.

tense.eng_def: If a situation is tense, it causes feelings of worry or nervousness.
tense.eg: There were some tense moments in the second half of the game.

tense.eng_def: (of your body or part of the body) stretched tight and stiff
(of a speech sound) made with more force than other speech sounds
If you or your muscles tense, your muscles become stiff and tight because you are frightened or nervous, or are preparing yourself to do something.
tense.chi_def: （使）（身體或肌肉）繃緊，（使）變得僵直
tense.eg: Don't tense your shoulders, just relax.

tense.eng_def: very nervous and worried and unable to relax because of something that is going to happen
tense.eg: You seem all tensed up. Are you still waiting for that call?

tension.eng_def: a feeling of nervousness before an important or difficult event
tension.eg: You could feel the tension in the room as we waited for our exam results.

tension.eng_def: a feeling of fear or anger between two groups of people who do not trust each other
tension.chi_def: （互不信任的人群之間的）緊張關係；緊張局勢

tension.eng_def: The tension of a wire or rope is the degree to which it is stretched.

tent.eng_def: a shelter made of canvas or a similar material and supported by poles and ropes, that you can fold up and carry with you

tentative.eng_def: (of a plan or idea) not certain or agreed, or (of a suggestion or action) said or done in a careful but uncertain way because you do not know if you are right
tentative.chi_def: （計劃、想法、建議、行動等）試驗（性）的，試探（性）的，暫時的
tentative.eg: I have tentative plans to take a trip to Seattle in July.

tentative.eng_def: If you do or say something tentatively, you do or say it in an uncertain way.

term.eng_def: the fixed period of time that something lasts for
term.eg: He served a short term for drunk driving.

term.eng_def: one of the periods into which a year is divided at school, college, or university
term.eg: In Britain, the spring term starts in January and ends just before Easter.

term.eng_def: the period of time that a legal agreement lasts for
term.eg: The lease on our house is near the end of its term.

term.eng_def: the end of a pregnancy when a baby is expected to be born
term.eg: Her last pregnancy went to term (= the baby was born after the expected number of weeks).

term.eng_def: for a long, medium, or short period of time in the future
term.eg: This decision will cost us more in the short term, but will be beneficial in the long term.

term.eng_def: a word or expression used in relation to a particular subject, often to describe something official or technical
term.eg: "Without let or hindrance" is a legal term that means "freely".

term.eng_def: an unkind or unpleasant name to call someone
a kind or friendly name to call someone
used to describe which particular area of a subject you are discussing
term.chi_def: 在…方面；從…方面來說；根據…來看
term.eg: In financial terms, the project was not a success.

term.chi_def: 毫不含糊地，直截了當地
term.eg: She told him what she thought of his behaviour in no uncertain terms (= she made her disapproval very clear).

term.eng_def: using language that clearly shows your feelings
term.eg: He complained in the strongest terms.

term.eng_def: the conditions that control an agreement, arrangement, or activity
If you buy something on easy terms, you pay for it over a period of time.
having the same rights, treatment, etc.
term.eg: All companies will compete for the government contract on equal terms.

term.eng_def: the matters to which a study or report is limited
to give something a name or to describe it with a particular expression
term.eg: Technically, a horse that is smaller than 1.5 metres at the shoulder is termed a pony.
The project will have long-term benefits.

terminal.eng_def: (of a disease or illness) leading gradually to death
A terminal patient is one who is seriously ill and will die soon.
extreme, when referring to something unpleasant or negative
terminal.eg: She claims that the shipbuilding industry is in terminal decline.

terminal.eng_def: the area or building at a station, airport, or port that is used by passengers leaving or arriving by train, aircraft, or ship
terminal.eg: Terminal 3 is used mostly for domestic flights.

terminal.eng_def: a piece of equipment consisting of a keyboard and screen, used for communicating with the part of a computer system that deals with information
the point at which a connection can be made in an electric circuit

terminate.eng_def: to (cause something to) end or stop
terminate.eg: They terminated my contract in October.

terminate.eng_def: to end a pregnancy intentionally, usually by a medical operation

terrace.eng_def: a flat area of stone or grass outside a house, where people sit and sometimes eat
one of several narrow strips of land that are built like steps on the slope of a hill, used for growing crops on
wide steps on which people stand to watch a football match
a row of often small houses joined together along their side walls
to build narrow strips of land on a slope so that people can plant crops there

terrible.eng_def: very unpleasant or serious or of low quality
terrible.chi_def: 糟糕的；可怕的；嚴重的；低劣的

terrible.eng_def: used to emphasize the great degree of something
terrible.chi_def: 極度的；厲害的；劇烈的；非常嚴重的
terrible.eg: This project is a terrible waste of money.

terrific.eng_def: used to emphasize the great amount or degree of something
terrific.chi_def: （用於強調數量或程度）極大的，異乎尋常的
terrific.eg: The police car drove past at a terrific speed.

terrify.eg: The idea of parachuting out of a plane terrifies me.

territory.eng_def: (an area of) land, or sometimes sea, that is considered as belonging to or connected with a particular country or person
territory.chi_def: 領土；領域；領地；活動範圍
territory.eg: He was shot down in enemy territory.

territory.eng_def: an area that an animal or person tries to control or thinks belongs to them
territory.chi_def: （某一動物或人想控制的）領地；地盤
territory.eg: The robin keeps other birds off that part of the garden - that's his territory.

territory.eng_def: a subject that you know about or have experience in
territory.eg: The director is back on familiar territory with his latest film.

terror.eg: They fled from the city in terror.

terror.eng_def: someone, especially a child, who behaves badly and is difficult to control
terror.eg: My brother is a little terror.

test.eng_def: a way of discovering, by questions or practical activities, what someone knows, or what someone or something can do or is like
test.eg: The class are doing/having a spelling test today.

test.eng_def: a medical examination of part of your body in order to find out how healthy it is or what is happening with it
an act of using something to find out if it is working correctly or how effective it is
test.eg: The new missiles are currently undergoing tests.

test.eng_def: a situation that shows how good something is
test.eg: Driving on that icy road was a real test of my skill.

test.chi_def: （板球，橄欖球等的）國際錦標賽（同 test match）
test.eg: Australia won the test by 197 runs.

test.eng_def: to do something in order to discover if something is safe, works correctly, etc., or if something is present
test.eg: The manufacturers are currently testing the new engine.

test.eng_def: to give someone a set of questions, in order to measure their knowledge or ability
test.eg: Will you test me on the chemistry I've been learning?

test.eng_def: If a situation tests someone, it proves how good, strong, etc. they are.
test.eg: That lecture really tested my powers of endurance, it was so boring.

test.eng_def: to do a medical examination of part of someone's body or of a particular physical ability

text.eng_def: the written words in a book, magazine, etc., not the pictures
text.chi_def: （書、雜誌等中區別於圖片的）正文，文字材料
text.eg: The book has 500 pages of text.

text.chi_def: （行動電話或傳呼機發送的）簡訊（同 text message）
text.eg: I'll send you a text as soon as I have any news.

text.eng_def: the exact words of a speech, etc.
text.eg: Can we see the full text of your speech before Tuesday?

text.eng_def: a book or piece of writing that you study as part of a course
text.chi_def: （學習某課程必讀的）課本，教科書，書目
text.eg: "Ulysses" is a set text for the exam.

text.eng_def: a sentence or piece of writing from the Bible that a priest or minister reads aloud in church and talks about
text.chi_def: （教堂神父誦讀或引用的）《聖經》經文

text.eng_def: to send someone a text message by phone
text.eg: I texted her to arrange a time to meet.

textbook.eng_def: a book that contains detailed information about a subject for people who are studying that subject
(of an example of something) extremely good, or thought to be usual or typical
textbook.chi_def: 典範的；合乎規範的；典型的
textbook.eg: That was a textbook goal from Taylor.

textile.eng_def: a cloth made by hand or machine

texture.eng_def: the quality of something that can be decided by touch; the degree to which something is rough or smooth, or soft or hard
the character of a piece of writing or music
texture.chi_def: （文章或音樂的）特色，韻味，格調
texture.eg: The writing has a rich texture.

than.eng_def: used to join two parts of a comparison
than.eg: My son is a lot taller than my daughter.

than.eng_def: used with "more" or "less" to compare numbers or amounts
than.chi_def: （與 more 或 less 連用，比較數量）
than.eg: I spent more than I intended to.

thank.eng_def: to express to someone that you are pleased about or are grateful for something that they have done
thank.eg: He thanked me for taking him home.

thankful.eng_def: happy or grateful because of something
thankful.chi_def: 感謝的；感激的；感到欣慰的
thankful.eg: I was thankful that the meeting didn't last long, because I had to get home.

that.eng_def: used to refer to a person, object, idea, etc. that is separated from the speaker by space or time
that.eg: I've never liked that cousin of hers.

that.eng_def: used to refer to something that has been mentioned or was involved earlier, or to something that is already known about
that.chi_def: （指已提到過的、與前文有關的或聽話人熟悉的事物）那，那個
that.eg: Where's that pen (= the one I was using earlier) gone?

that.eng_def: used to introduce a clause that reports something or gives further information, although it can often be left out
that.eg: She said (that) she'd pick it up for me after work.

that.eng_def: used as the subject or object of a verb to show which person or thing you are referring to, or to add information about a person or thing just mentioned. It is used for both people and things. It can often be left out
that.chi_def: （用作動詞的主詞或受詞，指代人或事物或對剛提到的人或事物作補充，常常可省略）
that.eg: I can't find the books (that) I got from the library.

that.eng_def: used to make a connection with an earlier statement
that.eg: My car broke down. That's why I'm so late.

that.eng_def: used to express a reaction to something
that.chi_def: （用於表達對某事的反應）那，這
that.eg: I didn't know she'd been so ill. That's terrible.
She's too young to walk that far.

theatrical.eng_def: belonging or relating to the theatre, or to the performance or writing of plays, opera, etc.
theatrical.chi_def: 劇場的；演劇的；戲劇（或歌劇等）劇本編寫的

theatrical.eng_def: Theatrical behaviour is not sincere and too extreme and that is intended to attract attention.

theft.eng_def: (the act of) dishonestly taking something that belongs to someone else and keeping it
theft.eg: Unfortunately, we have had several thefts in the building recently.

theme.eng_def: the main subject of a talk, book, film, etc.
theme.chi_def: （談話、書籍、電影等的）題目，主題
theme.eg: The theme of loss runs through most of his novels.

theme.eng_def: a song or tune that is played several times in a film, etc. and represents a character, situation, etc.
a short, simple tune on which a piece of music is based
theme.chi_def: （談話、書籍、電影等的）題目，主題；（音樂的）主旋律

theme.eng_def: a musical form in which a theme is played and then repeated several times with small changes

then.eng_def: (at) that time (in the past or in the future)
then.chi_def: 在當時（過去或未來）（的）；在那時（的）
then.eg: I was working in the city then.
Let me finish this job, then we'll go.
This is the standard model - then there's the deluxe version which costs more.

then.eng_def: as a result; in that case; also used as a way of joining a statement to an earlier piece of conversation
then.chi_def: 這麼說來，那麼，既然如此
then.eg: Have a rest now, and then you won't be so tired tonight.

theoretical.eng_def: based on the ideas that relate to a subject, not the practical uses of that subject
related to an explanation that has not been proved

theory.eng_def: a formal statement of the rules on which a subject of study is based or of ideas that are suggested to explain a fact or event or, more generally, an opinion or explanation
If something is possible in theory, it should be possible, but often it does not happen in that way.
theory.eg: In theory, the journey should take three hours, but in practice it usually takes four because of roadworks.

therapist.eng_def: someone whose job is to treat a particular type of mental or physical illness or disability, usually with a particular type of therapy

therapy.eng_def: a treatment that helps someone feel better, grow stronger, etc., especially after an illness

there.eg: We'll never get there in time.
Try again - you'll get there in the end.

there.eng_def: used to introduce the subject of a sentence, especially before the verbs be, seem, and appear
there.chi_def: （用於引出句子，尤用於動詞 be，seem 和 appear 前）
there.eg: There's someone on the phone for you.

there.eng_def: used to begin some children's stories written in a traditional style
there.eg: There once was/lived a poor widow who had a beautiful daughter.

there.eng_def: used to express sympathy or satisfaction
there.chi_def: （用於表示同情或滿足）你瞧，好啦
there.eg: There, I've finally got it working.

thereafter.eng_def: continuing on from a particular point in time, especially after something else has stopped happening
thereafter.eg: He left the priesthood in 1970 and settled in the Washington area shortly thereafter (= soon after that).

thereby.eng_def: as a result of this action
thereby.eg: Diets that are high in saturated fat clog up our arteries, thereby reducing the blood flow to our hearts and brains.

therefore.eg: We were unable to get funding and therefore had to abandon the project.

thermometer.eng_def: a device used for measuring temperature, especially of the air or in a person's body

thick.eng_def: having a large distance between two sides
growing close together and in large amounts

thick.eg: Thick, black smoke was pouring out of the chimney.
I told you not to touch that - are you deaf or just thick?

thief.eg: The art gallery was broken into last night, and the thieves got away with two valuable paintings.

thigh.eng_def: the part of a person's leg above the knee

thin.eng_def: having a small distance between two opposite sides
(of the body) with little flesh on the bones
thin.eg: Did you notice how thin her wrists were?
He eats like a horse and yet he's as thin as a rake.

thin.eng_def: having only a small number of people or a small amount of something
thin.eg: Attendance at the meeting was rather thin.

thin.eng_def: to make a substance less thick, often by adding a liquid to it
thin.eg: Thin the sauce down with a little stock.

thin.eng_def: When a crowd or a group thins (out), it becomes fewer in number, and when you thin (out) a group of plants or other things, you remove some to make them fewer.
thin.eg: The traffic will thin out after the rush hour.

thing.eng_def: used to refer in an approximate way to an object or to avoid naming it
thing.eg: What's that thing over there?

thing.eng_def: your possessions or a particular set of your possessions
thing.chi_def: 財產；（個人的）所有物，用具
thing.eg: All their things were destroyed in the fire.

thing.eng_def: a particular set of objects
thing.eg: Let me help you clear away the tea things (= cups, plates, etc. that are used for having tea).

thing.eng_def: used to refer in an approximate way to an idea, subject, event, action, etc.
thing.eg: That was an unkind thing to say.

thing.eng_def: the exact fact, object, idea, event, etc.
thing.chi_def: 事實（東西、想法、事件等）本身
thing.eg: The article was exactly the thing I needed for my research.

thing.eng_def: something that is not false or a copy
thing.eg: The fire alarm goes off accidentally so often that when it's the real thing (= when it really does happen) nobody will take any notice.

thing.eng_def: the same
thing.eg: Training isn't the same thing as education.

thing.eng_def: everything that has been planned or discussed
thing.chi_def: 一切（計劃或討論過的）事情
thing.eg: Let's call the whole thing off.

thing.eng_def: more than everything else
thing.chi_def: 比其他任何事情都重要
thing.eg: I value my freedom above all things.

thing.eng_def: in every situation or subject; in everything
thing.chi_def: 在一切事情上；在各種情況下
thing.eg: Be true to yourself in all things.

thing.eng_def: said before describing what it is that you especially want to know
thing.eg: If there's one thing I want to know, it's where he goes on Thursday afternoons.

thing.eng_def: used to refer to the general situation
thing.eg: Things have been going very well recently.

thing.eng_def: If it's a good thing that something happened, it is lucky that it happened.
thing.eg: It's a good thing (that) we booked our tickets early.

thing.eng_def: in the present situation
thing.eg: The way things are, I'll never have this ready by June.

thing.eng_def: used instead of "anything" or "everything" to emphasize what you are saying
thing.eg: Don't worry about a thing (= anything). I'll take care of it.

thing.eng_def: not anything
thing.eg: After the guests had gone, there wasn't a thing left to eat.

thing.eng_def: to have no clothes that are suitable for an occasion
thing.eg: I'm going to a wedding on Saturday and I don't have a thing to wear.

thing.eng_def: you cannot do anything
thing.eg: He broke his promise and there wasn't a thing we could do about it.

thing.eng_def: used to talk about a particular action, agreement, etc.
thing.eg: I went by plane, a thing I hardly ever do.

thing.eng_def: used to make noun phrases with particular adjectives and adverbs
thing.chi_def: （構成帶有特定形容詞和副詞的名詞片語）
thing.eg: The first thing (to do) is to write your name at the top of the paper.

thing.eng_def: used to introduce a reason for something
thing.eg: "Why won't you come to New York with me?" "For one thing, I don't like flying, and for another, I can't afford it."

thing.eng_def: used after an adjective to refer to a person or animal with love or sympathy
thing.chi_def: 人，傢夥，東西（指人或動物，帶有疼愛或憐憫的感情色彩）
thing.eg: The poor things were kept in small cages without room to move.

think.eng_def: to believe something or have an opinion or idea
think.eg: I think (that) I've met you before.

think.eng_def: to have a low opinion of someone or something
think.eg: I didn't think much of her latest book.

think.eng_def: to consider a person's needs or wishes
to use the brain to decide to do something
think.chi_def: 思考，考慮（動腦筋決定做某事）
think.eg: I'm thinking of taking up running.

think.eng_def: to use the brain to plan something, solve a problem, understand a situation, etc.
to think very carefully about something
think.eg: Think long and hard before you make any important decisions.

think.eng_def: to automatically say what you are thinking
think.eg: "What did you say?" "Oh, nothing, I was just thinking aloud."
I was just thinking about you when you called.

think.eng_def: to consider something for some time
think.eg: Let me have a think about it before I decide.

third.eg: the third road on the right

third.eng_def: one of three equal parts of something
third.eg: He cut the cake into thirds (= three equal parts).

third.eng_def: an undergraduate degree from a university in the UK and some other countries that is below a second-class degree
third.chi_def: （英國大學的） 三級學位成績

thirst.eng_def: a need for something to drink
thirst.eg: Hundreds of refugees collapsed from hunger and thirst.
He's always had a thirst for adventure.

thirsty.eg: I felt/was hot and thirsty after the basketball game.

thirsty.eng_def: Someone who is thirsty for power, knowledge, etc. wants to have it very much.

thirteen.eg: Some people think that thirteen is an unlucky number.

this.eng_def: used for a person, object, idea, etc. to show which one is referred to
this.eg: Can you sign this form here for me?

this.eng_def: used when you introduce someone to someone else

this.eg: I thought you'd be done by this time.

this.eng_def: as much as shown or to a particular degree
this.eg: It was only about this high off the ground.

thorn.eng_def: a small, sharp pointed growth on the stem of a plant

thorough.eg: a thorough revision of the manuscript

thorough.eng_def: complete, very great, or very much
thorough.chi_def: 徹頭徹尾的；完全的；十足的
thorough.eg: It was a thorough waste of time.

though.eg: She hasn't called, even though she said she would.
They're coming next week, though I don't know which day.
You look as though you've been running a marathon!
We went to high school together. I haven't seen her for years, though.

thought.eng_def: past simple and past participle of think
the act of thinking about or considering something, an idea or opinion, or a set of ideas about a particular subject
thought.eg: Ask me again tomorrow. I'll have to give it some thought.

thoughtful.chi_def: 考慮周到的；計劃周密的
thoughtful.eg: He has a thoughtful approach to his work.

thoughtful.eng_def: quiet because you are thinking about something
kind and always thinking about how you can help other people
thoughtful.eg: Thank you for calling when I was ill - it was very thoughtful of you.

thousand.eg: They had driven over a/one thousand miles.

thousand.chi_def: 很多的，大量的，數以千計的
thousand.eg: I have a thousand things to do before we go away.
His latest work is expected to sell in the thousands.

thread.eng_def: (a length of) a very thin fibre
a long, thin line of something such as light or smoke
thread.eg: A thin thread of light made its way through the curtains.

thread.eng_def: The thread of a book, discussion, speech, etc. is its story or the way that it develops, one part connecting with another
thread.eg: One of the main threads of the film is the development of the relationship between the boy and his uncle.

thread.eng_def: a connected group of pieces of writing on the internet, where people are talking about a particular subject
thread.eg: I was so glad to find this thread, and to know that lots of people have the same problem as me!

thread.eng_def: a continuous raised line, such as the one that goes around the outside of a screw or bolt or the inside of a hole
to put something long and thin such as string or thread through a narrow hole or into a small space
to remove hair from someone's face using a long piece of thread
thread.eg: Have you ever had your eyebrows threaded?

threat.eng_def: a suggestion that something unpleasant or violent will happen, especially if a particular action or order is not followed
threat.eg: Her parents carried out their threat to take away her mobile phone if her grades didn't improve.

threat.eng_def: to be in a situation where people are threatening you with something bad or unpleasant
threat.eg: She left the country under threat of arrest if she returned.

threaten.eng_def: to tell someone that you will kill or hurt them or cause problems if they do not do what you want
threaten.eg: They threatened the shopkeeper with a gun.

threaten.eng_def: to be likely to cause harm or damage to something or someone
threaten.eg: Changing patterns of agriculture are threatening the countryside.

threaten.eng_def: If something bad threatens to happen, it is likely to happen.
threaten.eg: Look at those clouds! There's a storm threatening.

threshold.eng_def: the floor of an entrance to a building or room
the level or point at which you start to experience something, or at which something starts to happen
threshold.eg: I have a low/high boredom threshold (= I do/don't feel bored easily).

thrift.eng_def: the careful use of money, especially by avoiding waste
a small plant with, typically, pink flowers on long stems that often grows wild on cliffs by the sea
thrift.chi_def: 海石竹（一種小型野生植物，一般莖較長，開粉色花，常生長在海邊峭岩上）

thrift.eng_def: a type of bank in the US that allows you to save money or borrow money to buy a house
thrift.chi_def: （美國可用來儲蓄和貸款購房的一類銀行）儲蓄銀行
thrift.eg: These days, thrifts place most of their money into boring but safe mortgages.

thrifty.eng_def: showing a careful use of money, especially by avoiding waste
thrifty.eg: They have plenty of money now, but they still tend to be thrifty.

thrill.eng_def: a feeling of extreme excitement, usually caused by something pleasant
thrill.eg: the thrill of winning a competition

thrill.eng_def: to make someone feel very excited and pleased
thrill.eg: The 22-year-old swimmer thrilled the world with his performance.

thriller.eng_def: a book, play, or film that has an exciting story, often about solving a crime
thriller.chi_def: （常指關於偵破罪案的）驚悚小說（或戲劇、電影）
thriller.eg: It's described here as a taut psychological thriller.

thrive.eng_def: to grow, develop, or be successful
thrive.eg: His business thrived in the years before the war.

throat.eng_def: the front of the neck, or the space inside the neck down which food and air can go
throat.eg: A fish bone got stuck in my throat.

throb.eng_def: to produce a strong, regular beat
throb.eg: Both records have a good throbbing bass which is great to dance to.

throb.eng_def: If a part of your body throbs, you feel pain in it in a series of regular beats.
throb.eg: His head throbbed, and his body ached.

throne.eng_def: the special chair used by a ruler, especially a king or queen
the state of being a ruler
throne.eg: Elizabeth II ascended/came to the throne (= became queen of Britain) when her father died.

throng.eng_def: a crowd or large group of people
throng.eg: A huge throng had gathered around the speaker.

throng.eng_def: to be or go somewhere in very large numbers

through.eng_def: from one end or side of something to the other
through.eg: They walked slowly through the woods.

through.eng_def: from the beginning to the end of a period of time
through.eg: It rained all/right through June and into the first half of July.
The company lost the order through production delays.
I got my car through my brother who works in a garage.

through.eng_def: having finished using or doing something
through.eg: I've got some work to do but I should be through in an hour if you can wait.

through.eng_def: to achieve success in an exam, competition, etc. and progress to the next stage or a higher level
through.eg: She's through to the next round of interviews.

through.eng_def: A through train or bus goes all the way from one place to another place without the passenger having to change trains or buses.
through.chi_def: （火車或公車）直達的，中途不停的

throughout.eng_def: in every part, or during the whole period of time
throughout.eg: People throughout the country are out of work.

throw.eng_def: to send something through the air with force, especially by a sudden movement of the arm
throw.eg: My friend threw the ball back over the fence.
The boy threw a frightened look in the direction of the house.

throw.eng_def: to cause to move or act quickly or carelessly
to confuse or shock someone or cause difficulty for them
throw.eg: I wasn't expecting a visitor. I was really thrown.

throw.eng_def: to open something that was closed, usually suddenly and completely
throw.eg: She drew back the curtains and threw open all the windows.

throw.eng_def: to allow people to enter or become involved in an event
throw.eg: The competition has been thrown open to the public.
Flavio threw a party for Colin's 50th birthday.

throw.eng_def: to experience and show a strong feeling of anger, especially suddenly
throw.eg: My mother threw a fit when she saw what a mess we'd made of her kitchen.

throw.eng_def: to shape clay on a special round table that spins
used to mean each thing or for each time
throw.eg: We could get a coffee in there but they charge three quid a throw.

throw.eng_def: a large piece of cloth that you use to cover a chair, sofa, etc. to make it look attractive
throw.eg: A throw can protect a new sofa or enhance the appearance of an old, tired one.

thrust.eg: She thrust the money into his hand.

thrust.eng_def: the main idea, subject, or opinion that is discussed or written about
thrust.eg: The main thrust of her argument was that women are compromised by the demands of childcare.

thrust.eng_def: the driving force produced by, for example, an aircraft engine

thumb.eng_def: the short, thick finger on the side of your hand that makes it possible to hold and pick things up easily
to stand near the edge of a road and hold out your hand with the thumb raised as a signal for a vehicle to stop and take you somewhere
thumb.chi_def: 豎起拇指要求免費搭車
thumb.eg: We thumbed a lift to London.

thumb.eng_def: to show no respect, or to raise the end of your thumb to the end of your nose to show that you do not respect someone
