thumb.eg: He has thumbed his nose at authority all his life.

thunder.eng_def: the sudden loud noise that comes from the sky especially during a storm

thunder.eg: I couldn't hear what he was saying over the thunder of the waterfall.

thunder.eng_def: When it thunders, a loud noise comes from the sky.
thunder.eg: The sky grew dark and it started to thunder.

thunder.eng_def: to move, making a lot of noise
thunder.eg: The train thundered past, shaking the whole house.
"I never want to see you here again!" he thundered.

thus.eg: They planned to reduce staff and thus to cut costs.

thus.eng_def: as far as this or until now
thus.eg: We haven't had any problems thus far.

tick.eng_def: a mark (✓) that shows that something is correct or has been done
tick.eg: Put a tick by/against the names of the people who have accepted the invitation.
Hold on/Hang on a tick - I'm not quite ready.

tick.eng_def: the sound clocks and watches make every second
If you buy something on tick, you pay for it later.
a very small creature like a spider that lives on and sucks the blood of other animals
When a clock or watch ticks, it makes a sound every second.
tick.eg: The ticking of the clock kept her awake.

tick.eng_def: to mark something with a tick
tick.eg: Tick (off) each item on the list as you complete it.

ticket.eng_def: a small piece of paper or card given to someone, usually to show that they have paid for an event, journey, or activity
a piece of card or paper that is put on an object to show its size or price
ticket.chi_def: （貨物上標明價目、尺碼等的）標籤，簽條

ticket.eng_def: a note telling you that you must pay some money as a punishment for not obeying a rule or law
a number of people representing a particular political party in an election
ticket.chi_def: （選舉中某政黨的）候選人名單

ticket.eng_def: to sell tickets for an event; to provide someone with a ticket
ticket.eg: Only passengers who were ticketed on that particular flight will receive a refund.

ticket.eng_def: to give a ticket to someone who has broken a traffic law

tickle.eng_def: to touch someone lightly with your fingers, making them slightly uncomfortable and often making them laugh
If a part of the body tickles, or if something tickles it, it feels slightly uncomfortable and you want to rub it.
tickle.eg: My nose is tickling, I think I'm going to sneeze.

tickle.eng_def: If something tickles you, you find it funny or it makes you happy.
tickle.eg: I was tickled pink (= very happy) to hear the news.

tickle.eng_def: an unpleasant feeling in your throat that makes you want to cough

tide.eng_def: the rise and fall of the sea that happens twice every day
a noticeable change in a situation or increase in a particular type of behaviour
tide.eg: We must look for ways of stemming (= stopping) the rising tide of protest.

tidy.eng_def: having everything ordered and arranged in the right place, or liking to keep things like this
tidy.chi_def: 整齊的；整潔的，有條理的
tidy.eg: The house was clean and tidy.
His business deals make him a tidy sum.

tidy.eng_def: a small container for a few objects, that makes it easier for you to keep your desk, car, etc. tidy
tidy.chi_def: 寫字枱雜物箱／汽車雜物箱／洗滌槽的過濾網罩（等等）

tidy.eng_def: to make a place or a collection of things tidy
tidy.eg: Tidy (up) these papers before you leave, please.

tie.eng_def: to fasten together two ends of a piece of string or other long, thin material, or to (cause to) hold together with a long, thin piece of string, material, etc.
tie.eg: Could you tie this piece of string for me?

tie.eng_def: to force someone to stay in a place
tie.eg: I felt tied to the job while I had a mortgage to pay.

tie.eng_def: to relate to or connect to
tie.eg: Is the allergy tied to dairy products, for example?

tie.eng_def: to finish at the same time or score the same number of points, etc. in a competition as someone or something else
tie.eg: Jane and I tied (for first place) in the spelling test.

tie.eng_def: a long, thin piece of material that is worn under a shirt collar, especially by men, and tied in a knot at the front
tie.eg: He always wears a jacket and tie to work.

tie.eng_def: any piece of string, plastic, metal, etc. that is used to fasten or hold together something
tie.eg: Can you see the ties for the rubbish bags in the cupboard?

tie.eng_def: the friendly feelings that people have for other people, or special connections with places
tie.eg: Family ties are weaker if you move a long way away.

tie.eng_def: a situation in which two or more people finish at the same time or score the same number of points
tie.eg: It's a tie for first place.

tiger.eng_def: a large wild animal of the cat family with yellowish-orange fur with black lines that lives in parts of Asia
used to refer to someone who is very determined and strong
tiger.chi_def: 強悍的人；勁頭十足的人；虎將
tiger.eg: The meekest, most submissive wife of today is a tiger by her grandmother's standards.

tight.eng_def: (held or kept together) firmly or closely
tight.chi_def: 緊的；密封的（地）；牢固的（地）
tight.eg: I can't untie the knot - it's too tight.

tight.eng_def: Clothes or shoes that are tight fit the body too closely and are uncomfortable.
tight.eg: That jacket's too tight - you need a bigger size.

tight.eng_def: If you have a tight feeling in your chest you have an uncomfortable feeling of pressure, caused by illness, fear, etc.
tight.chi_def: （由於疾病、恐懼等）憋悶的，不適的

tight.eng_def: Controls or rules that are tight are ones that severely limit what can happen.
If time or money is tight, there is only just enough of it.
tight.eg: I'm sorry I can't stay for a chat, time's really tight.

tight.chi_def: 用錢不大方的，吝嗇的（同 tight-fisted）

tight.eng_def: If two people are tight, they know each other very well and like each other a lot.
tight.chi_def: 親密的；個人關係密切的
tight.eg: The two of them were pretty tight at school.

tighten.eng_def: to become tighter or to make something become tighter, firmer, or less easy to move
tighten.eg: Tighten the straps so they don't rub.

tile.eng_def: a thin, usually square or rectangular piece of baked clay, plastic, etc. used for covering roofs, floors, walls, etc.
to cover a wall or floor with tiles
tile.eg: We're going to tile the bathroom.

till.eg: We waited till six thirty for you.

till.eng_def: the drawer in a cash register (= a machine which records sales in a shop, and in which money is kept) or the cash register itself
till.eg: Next time you have the till open, could you give me some change?

till.eng_def: to prepare and use land for growing crops
till.eg: This piece of land has been tilled for hundreds of years.

tilt.eng_def: to (cause to) move into a sloping position
tilt.eg: He tilted his chair backwards and put his feet up on his desk.

tilt.eng_def: a sloping position or a move in a particular direction, especially up or down
tilt.eg: She wore her hat at a tilt.

timber.eng_def: trees that are grown so that the wood from them can be used for building
a long piece of wood used for building, especially houses and ships
timber.chi_def: （建房或船的）木料，長條形木材

timber.eng_def: shouted when a tree that has been cut is about to fall
timber.chi_def: （在被伐樹木倒下時喊的）倒啦

time.eng_def: the part of existence that is measured in minutes, days, years, etc., or this process considered as a whole
time.eg: He wants to spend more time with his family.

time.eng_def: continuously
time.eg: I wish you'd stop criticizing me all the time.

time.eng_def: very quickly or very soon
time.eg: The kids ate their dinner in no time.

time.eng_def: If you say there is or that you have no time to lose, it means that you must do quickly whatever it is that you want to do.
time.eg: Come on, there's no time to lose, we have to get home before John finds out.

time.eng_def: always
time.eg: I will love you for all time.

time.eng_def: that has ever lived or existed
time.eg: She's been called the greatest singer of all time.

time.eng_def: the system of recording hours used in different parts of the world
time.eg: Greenwich Mean Time

time.eng_def: an amount of time that you have available to do something
time.eg: I don't know how you find time to do all the things you do.

time.eng_def: If you have time, you have enough time to do something.
time.eg: We don't have much time before the train leaves.

time.eng_def: to not make good use of the hours, etc. that you have available
time.eg: If you'd done your work instead of wasting time on your phone, you'd be finished by now.

time.eng_def: to not have enough hours, etc. available to finish something you are trying to do
time.eg: She ran out of time and didn't finish the last question.

time.eng_def: to not have enough minutes, etc. available
time.eg: I'd like to continue this discussion but we're all out of time.

time.eng_def: there are no more minutes, hours, etc. available
time.eg: OK, everyone, time's up for this week.

time.eng_def: a period of time added to the end of a football match because play was stopped during the game, usually to take care of players who were hurt
time.eg: His goal in the third minute of time added on sealed the match.

time.eng_def: a particular period of time for which something has been happening, or that is needed for something
time.eg: After a time, it became clear that nobody was interested in coming to the meetings.

time.eng_def: to stop work, in order to do something else
time.eg: I asked my boss if I could have some time off (from work) to go to the dentist.

time.eng_def: for a short period
time.eg: For a time, we all thought that Sheila and Frank would get married.

time.eng_def: for a fairly long period of time
time.eg: I've been doing yoga for some time.

time.eng_def: for a limited period
time.eg: Leave the ironing for the time being - I'll do it later.

time.eng_def: a particular point in the day, as expressed in hours and minutes or shown on a clock, or a particular point in time
time.eg: What time is it?

time.eng_def: at the particular point when something was thought of or done
time.eg: It seemed like a good idea at the time.

time.eng_def: If two things happen at the same time, they happen together.
time.eg: We arrived at the same time.

time.eng_def: at a person's present age
time.eg: At his time of life, he ought to be taking things easy.

time.eng_def: a particular point of the day, year, etc. that is suitable for a particular activity, or at which something is expected to happen
time.chi_def: （從事特定活動或某事應該發生的）時間，時候
time.eg: holiday time

time.eng_def: early enough
time.eg: I got home just in time - it's starting to rain.

time.eng_def: happening or done at the particular moment that it was expected to happen or be done
time.eg: My parents go to the house right on time.

time.eng_def: earlier than a particular moment
time.eg: Let's meet for lunch. I'll call you ahead of time to decide exactly when and where.

time.eng_def: If it is about time/high time that someone did something, it should have been done sooner or a long time ago.
time.chi_def: 差不多是時候了；早該（做某事）了
time.eg: It's about time (that) the school improved its food service.

time.eng_def: said when someone does something or something happens that you think should have been done or have happened much sooner
time.chi_def: （表示某人早該做某事了或某事早該發生了）早該如此
time.eg: "So Ben's finally found a job." "Yeah, it's about time."

time.eng_def: it is the most suitable moment to do something or for something to happen
time.eg: I haven't told him yet, but I will when the time is right.

time.eng_def: an occasion when something happens, or the experience connected with it
time.eg: The last time we went to Paris, it rained every day.

time.eng_def: sometimes, but not often
time.eg: From time to time I still think of her.

time.eng_def: again and again
time.eg: Time after time she gets involved in relationships with the wrong men.

time.eng_def: very often
time.eg: I've told you time and time again - look before you cross the road.

time.eng_def: continuously
time.eg: When you're at the airport, you should make sure you have your luggage with you at all times.

time.eng_def: at or during any particular point or moment in the day
time.eg: Only a certain number of people are allowed in the building at any one time.

time.eng_def: sometimes
time.eg: You can be really annoying at times, you know.

time.eng_def: ever
time.eg: Parking is not allowed here at any time.

time.eng_def: on many occasions
time.eg: The times I've told you, ask before you borrow my clothes.

time.eng_def: a period in history
time.eg: "A Tale of Two Cities" is set at the time of the French Revolution.

time.eng_def: in the past
time.eg: At one time, George Eliot lived here.

time.eng_def: having new ideas, opinions, or ways of living long before most other people do
time.chi_def: 領先時代的，超越時代的

time.eng_def: If something is before your time, it happened or existed before you were born or were old enough to remember it.
time.eg: I don't remember the Beatles - they were before my time.

time.eng_def: said to mean that there was a period in the past when something used to happen or be true
time.eg: Time was (when) you could buy a loaf of bread for sixpence.

time.eng_def: Your time in a race is the number of minutes, hours, etc. you take to complete it.
time.eg: Her time for the marathon was just under three hours.

time.eng_def: the number of beats in a bar of music, or the speed at which a piece of music is intended to be played
time.eg: This piece is written in 4/4 time.

time.eng_def: to spend a period of time in prison
time.eg: It's not always easy to find a job after you've done time.

time.eng_def: the particular point in the day at which people who are drinking in a bar in the UK have to finish their drinks and leave
time.eg: "Time, please!" called the landlord.

time.eng_def: to decide that something will happen at a particular time
time.chi_def: 確定…的時間，為…安排時間
time.eg: We timed our trip to coincide with my cousin's wedding.

time.eng_def: to arrange something so that it happens at the best possible time
time.eg: If you time your departure carefully, you should be able to miss the worst of the traffic.

time.eng_def: to measure how long it takes for something to happen or for someone to do something
time.chi_def: 為…計時，測定…所需的時間
time.eg: Will you time me to see how long it takes me to swim a length?

time.eng_def: the stated period of time during the year, day, etc.
time.eg: springtime

timid.eng_def: shy and nervous; without much confidence; easily frightened

tin.eng_def: a chemical element that is a silver-coloured metal, often combined with other metals or used to cover and protect other metals
a closed metal container in which food is sold
the contents of a tin, or the amount of something a tin contains
tin.chi_def: 罐頭；盒裝之物；桶裝之物；罐（或盒、桶）所裝之量
tin.eg: The children ate two tins of beans.

tin.eng_def: a metal container with a lid used for keeping cakes or biscuits
tin.chi_def: （用於儲存糕點或餅乾的）有蓋金屬盒

tin.eng_def: a cylindrical metal container with a lid used for keeping liquid substances such as paint
tin.chi_def: （用於儲藏塗料等液體的）有蓋金屬桶

tin.eng_def: a metal container without a lid used for cooking food in the oven
tin.eg: Put both cake tins in the oven for half an hour.

tin.eng_def: a closed metal container in which beer is sold

tip.eng_def: to (cause to) move so that one side is higher than another side
tip.eg: The table tipped, and all our drinks fell on the floor.
The baby tipped the scales at 3.75 kg.

tip.eng_def: to pour a substance from one container into another or onto a surface
tip.eg: She tipped the contents of her purse out onto the table.

tip.eng_def: When it is tipping it down, a lot of rain is falling.
tip.eg: We won't be able to go to the beach today - it's tipping it down.

tip.eng_def: to cover the end of something pointed with a liquid, a colour, etc.
tip.eg: The giraffe was killed with a spear that had been tipped with poison.

tip.eng_def: to give someone who has provided you with a service an extra amount of money to thank them
tip.eg: The taxi driver was so rude to her that she didn't tip him.

tip.eng_def: to say that someone is likely to be successful or achieve something
tip.eg: He is being tipped as the next prime minister.

tip.eng_def: to get rid of rubbish by putting it in a place where it should not be
tip.eg: A lot of waste is being tipped into the sea.

tip.eng_def: a useful piece of information, especially about how to do something or about the likely winner of a race or competition
tip.chi_def: 指點，指導；（關於比賽有望獲勝者的）內幕消息

tip.eng_def: a small amount of money given to someone who has provided you with a service, in addition to the official payment and for their personal use
the usually pointed end of something, especially something that is long and thin
tip.chi_def: （尤指細長物體的）末梢，末端，尖
tip.eg: We had asparagus tips for dinner.

tip.eng_def: a small part fitted to the end of something, especially something that is long and thin
tip.chi_def: （尤指細長物體的）頂端附加物
tip.eg: a walking cane with a metal tip

tip.eng_def: a place where especially large pieces of rubbish can be taken and left

tiptoe.eng_def: on your toes with the heel of your foot lifted off the ground
tiptoe.eg: The children stood on tiptoe in order to pick the apples from the tree.

tiptoe.eng_def: to walk on your toes with the heel of your foot lifted off the ground, especially in order not to make a noise
tiptoe.eg: He waited until his daughter was asleep, then tiptoed quietly out of the room.

tire.eng_def: to begin to feel as if you have no energy and want to rest or go to sleep, or to make someone feel this way
tire.eg: She's been leading throughout the race, but it now looks as if she's tiring.

tiresome.eng_def: annoying and making you lose patience
tiresome.chi_def: 令人厭倦的；使人不耐煩的
tiresome.eg: I find it very tiresome doing the same job day after day.

tissue.eng_def: a group of connected cells in an animal or plant that are similar to each other, have the same purpose, and form the stated part of the animal or plant
soft paper that is used for cleaning, especially your nose, and is thrown away after use, or a small rectangular piece of this
tissue.chi_def: （尤指擦鼻子用的）紙巾，手巾紙，面紙
tissue.eg: She handed me a tissue just before I sneezed.

tissue.eng_def: thin, light paper used especially for wrapping delicate things
tissue.chi_def: （尤用於包裹易碎物品的）薄紙
tissue.eg: The shop assistant wrapped the vase carefully in tissue paper.

title.eng_def: the name of a film, book, painting, piece of music, etc.
title.eg: The title of Evelyn Waugh's first novel was "Decline and Fall".

title.eng_def: the information given at the end or beginning of a film or television programme, stating the names of the people who acted in it or were involved in its production
title.chi_def: （電影或電視節目的）演職員表

title.eg: Last year we published over a hundred new titles.

title.eng_def: a word that is used before someone's name, stating their social rank, qualifications, position in an organization, sex, etc.
title.chi_def: （用於人名前）稱號，稱謂，頭銜，職稱
title.eg: What's her title - is she Professor or Doctor?

title.eng_def: the position you get by beating all other competitors in a sports competition
title.eg: Joe Louis won the heavyweight boxing title in 1937.

title.eng_def: the legal right to own a piece of land or a building, or a document that proves this right
title.eg: If you wish to sell the property, you will first have to prove your title to it.

title.eng_def: to give a title to a book, movie, play, song, or work of art
title.chi_def: 給（圖書、電影、戲劇、歌曲或藝術品）起名
title.eg: He titled his autobiography "Beneath the Underdog".

to.eng_def: used before a verb to show that it is in the infinitive
used after some verbs, especially when the action described in the infinitive will happen later
to.chi_def: （用於某些動詞後，尤其是不定式所描述的動作將會隨後發生時）
to.eg: She agreed to help.

to.eng_def: used after many verbs of agreeing, needing, and wanting
to.chi_def: （用於許多表示贊成、需要和想要的動詞後）
to.eg: I need to eat something first.

to.eng_def: used instead of repeating a verb clause
to.chi_def: （用於代替動詞分句，以免重複）
to.eg: "Are you going tonight?" "I'm certainly hoping to."

to.eng_def: used in phrases where there are reported orders and requests
to.chi_def: （用於表示間接命令、要求的片語中）
to.eg: He told me to wait.

to.eng_def: used after some adjectives
to.eg: It's not likely to happen.

to.eng_def: used after some nouns
to.eg: He has this enviable ability to ignore everything that's unpleasant in life.

to.eng_def: A clause containing to + infinitive can be used as the subject of a sentence
to.chi_def: （含有帶 to 的不定式的分句可用作句子主語）
to.eg: To go overseas on your own is very brave.

to.eng_def: used after question words
to.eg: I don't know what to do.

to.eng_def: used with an infinitive to express use or purpose
to.chi_def: （與不定式連用，表示用途或目的）
to.eg: I'm going there to see my sister.

to.eng_def: You can introduce a clause with a phrase containing to + infinitive
to.chi_def: （含有帶 to 的不定式的片語可引出分句）
to.eg: To be honest (= speaking honestly), Becky, I like thegrey shirt better.

to.eng_def: used with an infinitive after 'there is' or 'there are' and a noun
to.chi_def: （與不定式連用，用於 there be + 名詞這種結構後）
to.eg: There's an awful lot of work to be done.

to.eng_def: To be going on with means in order to continue with the present activity or situation
to.eg: Do we have enough paint to be going on with, or should I get some more while I'm out?

to.eng_def: in the direction of
to.eg: We're going to town on the bus, okay?

to.eng_def: used for showing who receives something or who experiences an action
to.eg: I lent my bike to my brother.

to.eng_def: With many verbs that have two objects, 'to' can be used before the indirect object
to.chi_def: （與許多可接雙受詞的動詞連用，用於間接受詞前）
to.eg: Give me that gun./Give that gun to me.

to.eng_def: until a particular time, state, or level is reached
to.eg: It's only two weeks to Christmas.

to.eng_def: used when saying the time, to mean before the stated hour
to.eg: It's twenty to six.

to.eng_def: used to suggest an extreme state
to.eg: Look at your shirt - it's torn to shreds!

to.eng_def: in connection with
to.eg: What was their response to your query?

to.eng_def: used to say where something is fastened or connected
to.chi_def: （用於表示被繫住或連接的地方）
to.eg: The paper was stuck to the wall with tape.

to.eng_def: used before an infinitive, usually with 'be', to indicate a future action
to.chi_def: （用於不定式前，通常和 be 連用，構成未來式）
to.eg: The government announced today that it is to cut funding for the arts for next year.

to.eng_def: used in this pattern to say what someone should do or to give an order
to.chi_def: （表示命令或指出某人應該做甚麼）
to.eg: You're not to (= you must not) bite your nails like that.

to.eng_def: Newspapers often use to + infinitive without 'be' in their headlines (= titles of articles) when reporting planned future events
to.chi_def: （報紙標題中常用 to + 不定式這種結構，前面不加 be，表示未來計劃中的事）
to.eg: Russia to send troops in.

to.eng_def: causing a particular feeling in a particular person
to.eg: That's when I found out, to my amazement, that she was coming here.

to.eng_def: considered by
to.eg: I realize it may sound strange to you.

to.eng_def: serving
to.eg: As a personal trainer to the rich and famous, he earns over a million dollars a year.

to.eng_def: against or very near
to.eg: Stand back to back.

to.eng_def: matching or belonging to
to.eg: My dad gave me the keys to his car.

to.eng_def: having as a characteristic feature
to.eg: She has a mean side to her.

to.eng_def: used to show the position of something or someone in comparison with something or someone else
to.eg: John's standing to the left of Adrian in the photo.

to.eng_def: in honour or memory of
to.chi_def: 為向…表示敬意；為了紀念
to.eg: I proposed a toast to the bride and the groom.

to.eng_def: for each
to.eg: How many dollars are there to the pound?

to.eng_def: used in phrases that show a range
to.eg: There were probably 30 to 35 (= a number between 30 and 35) people there.

to.eng_def: at the same time as music or other sound
to.chi_def: 與（音樂或其他聲音）同時，伴隨
to.eg: I like exercising to music.

to.eng_def: relating to a positive reaction or result
to.eg: When the pasta is done to your liking, drain the water.

to.eng_def: compared with
to.eg: She's earning a reasonable wage, but nothing to what she could if she was in the private sector.

to.eng_def: into a closed position
to.eg: I'll just push the door to.

toad.eng_def: a small, brown animal, similar to a frog, that has big eyes and long back legs for swimming and jumping
toad.eg: Toads have drier, lumpier skins than frogs and spend less time in the water.

toad.eng_def: an extremely unpleasant man, especially one who is not very physically attractive
toad.chi_def: 極令人討厭的人；（尤指）醜八怪

toast.eng_def: sliced bread made warm, crisp (= hard enough to break), and brown by being put near a high heat
an expression of good wishes or respect for someone that involves holding up and then drinking from a glass of alcohol, especially wine, after a short speech
toast.eg: Now, if you'd all please raise your glasses, I'd like to propose a toast to the bride and groom.

toast.eng_def: to make bread or other food warm, crisp (= hard enough to break), and brown by putting it near a high heat
toast.eg: Do you want this bread toasted?

toast.eng_def: to warm yourself or part of your body
toast.eg: He's just toasting his feet by the fire.

toast.eng_def: to hold up your glass and then drink as an expression of good wishes or respect

tobacco.eng_def: a substance smoked in cigarettes, pipes, etc. that is prepared from the dried leaves of a particular plant
tobacco.eg: 28 percent of people thought that the advertising of tobacco (= tobacco and products made from it, such as cigarettes) and alcohol should be banned.

today.eng_def: used more generally to mean the present time
today.eg: Today, people are much more concerned about their health than they were in the past.

toe.eng_def: any of the five separate parts at the end of the foot
toe.eg: your big toe (= your largest toe)

toe.eng_def: the part of a sock, shoe, or other foot covering that goes over the toes
to do what you are ordered or expected to do
toe.eg: Ministers who wouldn't toe the party line were swiftly got rid of.

tofu.eng_def: a soft, pale food that has very little flavour but is high in protein, made from the seed of the soya plant

together.eg: We used to go to yoga together.

together.eng_def: If two people are described as together, they have a close romantic and often sexual relationship with each other.
together.eg: Mira and Ellis have been together now for almost five years.

together.eng_def: If two people get together or get it together, they start a sexual relationship with each other.
together.eg: We'd seen each other a few times as part of a group, but we didn't really get it together till Rachel's party.
The packages were sent separately, but they all came together.
Together they must earn over $300,000 a year.
I'll just gather my stuff together, and then we can go.
The money that I owe you for the phone together with the rent equals £300.

together.eng_def: organized, confident of your abilities, and able to use them to achieve what you want
together.chi_def: 自信而有條理的；沉穩的
together.eg: For a sixteen-year-old, he seems pretty together.
We were going to go skiing over Christmas but we never got it together.

toil.eng_def: hard work, especially work that makes you feel physically tired
toil.eg: Lindi has achieved her comfortable life only after years of hard toil.
Farm workers have been toiling in the 100-degree heat over the past week.

toil.eng_def: to move in a particular direction, slowly and with great effort
toil.eg: I was toiling up the hill with four heavy bags when he took pity on me.

toil.eng_def: written abbreviation for  time off in lieu
toil.chi_def: 補假（time off in lieu的縮寫）
toil.eg: In this section, the company's TOIL policy is described.

toilet.eng_def: a bowl-shaped device with a seat that you sit on or stand near when emptying the body of urine or solid waste, or another device used for this purpose
toilet.eg: I was on (= using) the toilet when the phone rang.

toilet.eng_def: a room with a toilet in it
to empty the body of urine or solid waste, usually using a toilet to do so
toilet.eg: It's going to be a long drive, kids, so if you want to go to the toilet, do so now.

toilet.eng_def: a room or small building in a public place in which there are several toilets
toilet.eg: Do you know where the ladies' toilets are?

toilet.eng_def: the process of washing and dressing yourself
toilet.eg: Virginia had spent longer than usual over her toilet that evening, with pleasing results.

token.eng_def: something that you do, or a thing that you give someone, that expresses your feelings or intentions, although it might have little practical effect
token.eg: As a token of our gratitude for all that you have done, we would like you to accept this small gift.

token.eng_def: a piece of paper with a particular amount of money printed on it that can be exchanged in a shop for goods of that value
a round metal or plastic disc that is used instead of money in some machines
token.chi_def: （某些機器中用以代替紙幣的）代幣，專用輔幣

token.eng_def: Token actions are done to show that you are doing something, even if the results are limited in their effect.
token.chi_def: 有標誌性的；有象徵意義的
token.eg: The troops in front of us either surrendered or offered only token (= not much) resistance.

token.eng_def: used to refer to something that is done to prevent other people complaining, although it is not sincerely meant and has no real effect
token.eg: The truth is that they appoint no more than a token number of women to managerial jobs.

tolerable.eng_def: of a quality that is acceptable, although certainly not good
tolerable.eg: At their best the conditions in these prisons are barely tolerable.

tolerance.eng_def: willingness to accept behaviour and beliefs that are different from your own, although you might not agree with or approve of them
tolerance.eg: This period in history is not noted for its religious tolerance.

tolerance.eng_def: the ability to deal with something unpleasant or annoying, or to continue existing despite bad or difficult conditions
tolerance.eg: My tolerance of/for heat is considerably greater after having lived in the Far East for a couple of years.

tolerance.eng_def: an animal's or plant's ability not to be harmed by a drug or poison over a long period of time
tolerance.chi_def: （動植物對藥物或毒藥的）耐受性
tolerance.eg: a greater tolerance of/to the drug

tolerance.eng_def: the amount by which a measurement or calculation might change and still be acceptable
tolerance.eg: parts that are made to tolerances of a thousandth of an inch

tolerant.eng_def: willing to accept behaviour and beliefs that are different from your own, although you might not agree with or approve of them
tolerant.eg: The present government is even less tolerant of dissent.

tolerant.eng_def: able to deal with something unpleasant or annoying, or to continue existing despite bad or difficult conditions
tolerant.eg: I think men are less tolerant of stress than women.

tolerate.eng_def: to accept behaviour and beliefs that are different from your own, although you might not agree with or approve of them
tolerate.eg: I will not tolerate that kind of behaviour in my class.

tolerate.eng_def: to deal with something unpleasant or annoying, or to continue existing despite bad or difficult conditions
tolerate.eg: These ants can tolerate temperatures that would kill other species.

toll.eng_def: a small amount of money that you have to pay to use a road, cross a bridge, etc.
toll.eg: Tolls are now collected electronically on most motorways.

toll.eng_def: the money a long-distance phone call costs
toll.eg: Is Bayonne a toll call (= a more expensive phone call) from New York?
Independent sources say that the death toll from the earthquake runs into thousands.

toll.eng_def: to (cause a large bell to) ring slowly and repeatedly
toll.eg: In the distance, a church bell tolled the hour (= showed the time by ringing).

tomato.eng_def: a round, red fruit with a lot of seeds, eaten cooked or uncooked as a vegetable, for example in salads or sauces

tomb.eng_def: a large stone structure or underground room where someone, especially an important person, is buried
tomb.chi_def: （尤指重要人物的）墳墓，陵墓，塚

tomorrow.eg: I'm having dinner with Rachel tomorrow night.

tomorrow.eng_def: used more generally to mean the future
tomorrow.eg: Today's problem child may be tomorrow's criminal.

ton.eng_def: a unit of weight equal to 1,000 kilograms
a unit of weight equal to 1,016 kilograms
a unit of weight equal to 907 kilograms

ton.eg: We have tons of food left over from the party.
It'll cost you a ton or more.

ton.eng_def: to drive at 100 miles an hour
ton.chi_def: 以每小時100英里的速度行駛

tone.eng_def: a quality in the voice that expresses the speaker's feelings or thoughts, often towards the person being spoken to
tone.chi_def: （常指對聽話人的）語氣，腔調，口吻
tone.eg: I tried to use a sympathetic tone of voice.
She recounted the story to me in shocked tones (= in a shocked voice).

tone.eng_def: a change in how high or low the voice is that can change the meaning of a word or sentence
the general mood or main qualities of something
tone.eg: I didn't like the jokey tone of the article - I thought it was inappropriate.

tone.eng_def: a form or degree of a colour
tone.eg: warm tones of brown and yellow

tone.eng_def: the healthy tightness of the body, especially the muscles
tone.eg: After you've had a baby you lose the muscle tone in your stomach.

tone.eng_def: the largest difference in pitch between two notes that are next to each other in the western musical scale
tone.chi_def: 全音（指西洋音階中相鄰兩音符之間最大的音差）
tone.eg: The interval from G to A is a whole tone.

tone.eng_def: the quality of sound of a musical instrument or singing voice
tone.eg: the beautiful rich tones of his tenor voice

tone.eng_def: one of the continuous sounds that you hear on a phone that tell you if the other phone is ringing, if it is busy, etc.
tone.eg: I've called him several times but I keep getting the engaged tone.

tone.eng_def: If you tone a part of the body, you make it firmer and stronger, usually by doing physical exercise.
tone.chi_def: （通常透過鍛煉）使（身體部位）更強健
tone.eg: This is a good exercise for toning up the thighs.

tongue.eng_def: the large, soft piece of flesh in the mouth that you can move, and is used for tasting, speaking, etc.
tongue.eg: I burned my tongue on some soup last night.

tongue.eng_def: the tongue of an animal, used as food
tongue.chi_def: （用作食物的動物的）舌頭，口條

tongue.eng_def: a part of an object that is tongue-shaped, especially the piece of material that is under the laces in a shoe

tongue.eg: immigrants struggling to learn a foreign tongue

tongue.eng_def: a person's way of expressing their ideas and feelings
tongue.eg: She is a prolific writer with critical views and a sharp (= severe and critical) tongue.

tonight.eng_def: (during) the night of the present day
tonight.eg: Tonight will be my first chance to meet her.

too.eng_def: more than is needed or wanted; more than is suitable or enough
used before an adjective or adverb to emphasize a negative meaning
too.chi_def: 太，過於（用於形容詞或副詞前，強調不好的意味）
too.eg: The holidays flew by all too quickly.

too.eng_def: used before an adjective to emphasize a positive meaning
too.chi_def: 太，非常（用於形容詞前，強調積極的意味）
too.eg: "Would you like to make a donation?" "I'd be only too pleased."

too.eng_def: (especially at the end of a sentence) in addition, also

too.eg: It's a wonderful picture of light shining through trees - and by a child too!
He wasn't too pleased/happy when I told him about the mistake.

too.eng_def: used to emphasize a positive answer to a negative statement
too.chi_def: （用於強調對否定陳述的肯定回答）
too.eg: "I'm not going to school today." "You are too!"

tool.eng_def: a piece of equipment that you use with your hands to make or repair something
tool.chi_def: （用於生產或維修的）工具，器具

tool.eng_def: something that helps you to do a particular activity
tool.eg: A free low-interest credit card can be a useful budgeting tool.

tool.eng_def: A tool of the trade is something you need to use to do your job
tool.chi_def: 職業所需的工具；職業技能
tool.eg: The artist was surrounded by paints, brushes, and other tools of the trade.

tool.eng_def: someone whose decisions and actions are unfairly controlled by others
tool.eg: The president was widely regarded as the tool of the military.

tool.eng_def: an insulting word for a person who you dislike very much or who behaves very stupidly
tool.chi_def: 笨蛋，蠢貨（侮辱性用語，用於指稱非常不喜歡的人或行為愚蠢的人）

tooth.eng_def: one of the hard, white objects in the mouth that are used for biting and chewing (= crushing food)
any of the row of points that stick out from the edge of a tool or piece of equipment, such as a comb, saw, or zip
tooth.chi_def: （工具邊緣、梳子、鋸、拉鏈等的）齒狀物，齒

tooth.eg: This committee can make recommendations but it has no real teeth.

top.eng_def: the highest place or part
top.eg: She waited for me at the top of the stairs.

top.eng_def: the flat upper surface of something
top.eg: The top of the table/desk was badly scratched.

top.eng_def: any piece of light clothing worn on the part of the body above the waist
the cover or lid used to close a container or pen
the most important position in a group or organization
top.chi_def: 最重要的職位；最高的地位
top.eg: At 40, he was at the top of his profession.

top.eng_def: a  spinning top
a piece of jewellery, usually one of a pair, worn in a hole in the ear or fastened to the ear by a clip; an earring
the leaves of a vegetable plant grown mainly for its roots
top.eg: We fed the rabbit some beetroot tops.

top.eng_def: at the highest part of something
top.eg: There's a dirty mark on the top left-hand corner of the picture.

top.eng_def: in the part nearest to the highest part; in the upper part
top.eg: The top few steps were damaged and broken.

top.eng_def: (in the position of being) most important or successful; best
top.chi_def: 最重要的（地）；最成功的（地）；最好的（地）
top.eg: So what would be your top choice of a place to go on holiday?

top.eng_def: Top people, organizations, or activities are the most important or successful ones.
top.chi_def: （人、機構、活動）最重要的，最成功的

top.eng_def: as fast as possible
top.eg: The train thundered through the station at top speed.

top.eng_def: to be the student with the best results
top.eg: She came top (of the class) in English.

top.eng_def: feeling or doing things as well as possible
top.eg: Paul's back on top form after his illness.

top.eng_def: excellent
to be on the upper surface of something, especially as a decoration
top.eg: The dessert was topped off with whipped cream and pieces of fruit.

top.eng_def: to be the most important, most successful, etc.
top.eg: The song topped the charts (= sold the largest number of recordings) for five weeks.

top.eng_def: to do, pay, etc. more or better than anyone else
top.eg: "They've offered me £1,000." "I'm afraid we can't top that."

top.eng_def: to kill yourself
used with many different words to mean "best"
top.chi_def: （與許多單詞連用）最好的，一流的

topic.eng_def: a subject that is discussed, written about, or studied
topic.eg: Our discussion included topics such as acid rain and the melting of polar ice.

topple.eng_def: to (cause to) lose balance and fall down
topple.eg: The statue of the dictator was toppled (over) by the crowds.

topple.eng_def: to force a leader or government out of power
topple.eg: The church was prominently involved in the struggle that toppled the dictatorship.

torch.eng_def: a small light that is held in the hand and usually gets its power from batteries
torch.eg: She flashed/shone the torch into the dark room.

torch.eng_def: a thick stick with material that burns tied to the top of it, used to give light
used as a symbol of a political movement or idea that has an important positive influence
torch.chi_def: （象徵具有重大積極影響的政治運動或思想的）火炬
torch.eg: She promised that the party would carry the torch of progressivism into the next decade.

torch.eng_def: to burn a building or other large thing, intentionally and usually illegally
torch.chi_def: 放火燒，縱火燒（建築物或其他大型物體）
torch.eg: They smashed a side door to get in and then torched the warehouse when they had taken what they wanted.

torment.eng_def: great mental suffering and unhappiness, or great physical pain
torment.eg: The family said they had endured years of torment and abuse at the hands of their neighbours.
Nothing can describe the torments we went through while we were waiting for news.

torment.eng_def: something or someone that causes great suffering or anger
torment.eg: Writing reports was a monthly torment to him.

torment.eng_def: to cause a person or animal to suffer or worry
torment.eg: The animals are tormented mercilessly by flies and mosquitoes.

tornado.eng_def: a strong, dangerous wind that forms itself into an upside-down spinning cone and is able to destroy buildings as it moves across the ground

torrent.eng_def: a sudden large or too large amount, especially one that seems to be uncontrolled
torrent.chi_def: （尤指似乎無法控制的）狂潮，迸發
torrent.eg: He let out a torrent of abuse/angry words.

torrent.eng_def: a large amount of water that is moving quickly
torrent.eg: Heavy rainfall turned the river into a rushing/raging torrent.

tortoise.eng_def: an animal with a thick, hard shell that it can move its head and legs into for protection. It eats plants, moves very slowly, and sleeps during the winter.

torture.eng_def: the act of causing great physical or mental pain in order to persuade someone to do something or to give information, or to be cruel to a person or animal
torture.eg: Half of the prisoners died after torture and starvation.
The rush-hour traffic was sheer torture as usual.

torture.eng_def: to cause great physical or mental pain to someone intentionally
torture.eg: It is claimed that the officers tortured a man to death in a city police station.

torture.chi_def: 使精神上受到折磨；使痛苦；使苦惱
torture.eg: He tortured himself for years with the thought that he could have stopped the boy from running into the road.

toss.eg: He glanced at the letter and then tossed it into the bin.

toss.eng_def: When you toss food you shake or mix small pieces of it together with a sauce or dressing.
to quickly and suddenly lift the pan in which a pancake (= a thin, flat, round cake) is cooking so that the pancake goes up into the air and turns over before falling back into the pan
If you toss your hair or a part of your body you move it up and back suddenly.
toss.chi_def: 向後甩（頭髮或身體部位）
toss.eg: She tossed her head in annoyance.

toss.eng_def: to move about from side to side or turn a lot in bed, especially because you cannot sleep
toss.chi_def: （尤指因無法入睡而）翻來覆去，輾轉反側
toss.eg: I was tossing and turning all night.

toss.eng_def: to throw a coin up into the air and guess which side will land facing up, as a way of making a decision
toss.eg: Let's toss (a coin) to see who'll go first.
"I don't care," she replied with a toss of her head.

toss.eng_def: an act of throwing a coin in the air and guessing which side will land facing upward as a way of deciding something
to guess correctly/wrongly which side of a coin will be facing up when it lands on the ground after being thrown
toss.chi_def: 在擲硬幣中猜對了／猜錯了

toss.eng_def: an act of throwing something in a careless or relaxed way
toss.chi_def: 漫不經心地（或不小心地）投擲

total.eng_def: the amount you get when several smaller amounts are added together
total.eg: At that time of day, cars with only one occupant accounted for almost 80 percent of the total.

total.eng_def: very great or of the largest degree possible
to have as a complete amount, or to calculate this
total.eg: This is the eighth volume in the series, which totals 21 volumes in all.

touch.eng_def: to put your hand or another part of your body lightly onto and off something or someone
touch.eg: That paint is wet - don't touch (it).

touch.eng_def: (of two or more things) to be so close together that there is no space between; to be in contact
touch.chi_def: （兩個或兩個以上的物品）接觸
touch.eg: He fell asleep as soon as his head touched the pillow.

touch.eng_def: to harm someone, or use or damage something
touch.chi_def: 傷害（某人）；使用（某物）；破壞（某物）
touch.eg: Please don't touch any of my stuff while I'm away.

touch.eng_def: (usually used in negative sentences) to eat or drink something
touch.eg: They didn't touch any of the food we left for them.

touch.eng_def: to influence someone or something emotionally, or cause feelings of sympathy in someone
touch.eg: Tragedy touched their lives when their son was 16.

touch.eng_def: (usually used in negative sentences) to have or reach the same standard (= level of quality) as someone or something
touch.eg: Her novels can't touch (= are not as good as) those of her sister.

touch.eng_def: To show that an illness is not too serious, you can say you have had a touch of it.
touch.eg: I had a touch of flu/hay fever.

touch.eng_def: a small addition or detail that makes something better
touch.eg: The speech had several comic touches.
The weather has turned a touch too cold for my liking.

touch.eng_def: the ability to know what something is like by feeling it with the fingers
used after an adjective to express how something feels when you put your hand on it
touch.eg: The material was soft to the touch.

touch.eng_def: a quick, light movement of one thing, especially a hand, onto and off another thing
touch.eg: I felt a cold touch on my arm.

touch.eng_def: to communicate or continue to communicate with someone by using a phone or writing to them
touch.eg: Are you still in touch with any of your old school friends?

touch.eng_def: to stop communicating with someone, usually because they do not live near you now
touch.eg: We lost touch over the years.

touch.eng_def: an ability to do things in the stated, especially positive, way
touch.eg: He has a deft touch with tricky painting jobs.

touch.eng_def: in sports such as football, a player's ability to control the ball and make it do what they want, or an occasion when a player controls the ball with their foot
touch.chi_def: （足球等體育中）觸球能力；觸球
touch.eg: Nicolas Anelka squandered the chance to score when his touch let him down in front of goal.

touch.eng_def: the area outside either of the long edges of the space on which football and rugby are played
touch.chi_def: （足球及類似體育運動的）邊線以外區域
touch.eg: Playing for safety, he kicked the ball into touch.

touch.eng_def: If you are in touch/out of touch with a subject, activity, or situation, your knowledge about it is recent/not recent.
touch.eg: He's not really in touch with what young people are interested in.

tough.eng_def: strong; not easily broken or made weaker or defeated
tough.eg: These toys are made from tough plastic.
Tough new safety standards have been introduced for cars.

tough.eng_def: difficult to do or to deal with
tough.eg: They've had an exceptionally tough life.

tough.eng_def: Tough food is difficult to cut or eat.
tough.chi_def: （食物）老的，不易切開的，嚼不動的

tough.eng_def: likely to be violent or to contain violence; not kind or pleasant
tough.chi_def: 粗魯的；暴力的；不友善的

tough.eg: "I have to work late today because I'm very behind on my work." "Oh, tough luck!"

tough.eng_def: sometimes used to show that you have no sympathy for someone's problems or difficulties
tough.eg: "I don't have any money left." "Well, (that's just) tough - you shouldn't have spent it all on cigarettes."
Bands of armed toughs roamed the city.

tour.eng_def: a visit to a place or area, especially one during which you look around the place or area and learn about it
tour.eg: We went on a guided tour of the cathedral/museum/factory.

tour.eng_def: a journey made for pleasure, especially as a holiday, visiting several different places in an area
a planned visit to several places in a country or area made for a special purpose, such as one made by a politician, sports team, or group of performers
tour.chi_def: （政治家、運動隊、演出團體等的）巡視，巡迴比賽，巡迴演出
任期；執勤期（同 tour of duty）

tour.eng_def: to go on a tour somewhere
tour.chi_def: （到…）旅行，遊歷；（到…）巡迴比賽，巡視
tour.eg: We spent a month touring (around/round/in) Kenya.

tour.eng_def: If a play tours a particular area, it is performed in several places there.
tour.eg: The play will be performed first in the capital, and will then tour the rest of the country.

tourism.eng_def: the business of providing services such as transport, places to stay, or entertainment for people who are on holiday

tourist.eng_def: someone who visits a place for pleasure and interest, usually while on holiday
tourist.eg: Millions of tourists visit Rome every year.

tourist.eng_def: a member of a sports team who is travelling from place to place in a foreign country, playing games
tourist.eg: The West Indies easily defeated the tourists.

tournament.eng_def: a competition for teams or single players in which a series of games is played, and the winners of each game play against each other until only one winner is left

tow.eng_def: to pull a car, boat, etc. along, fastened behind another vehicle or boat
tow.eg: You shouldn't drive fast when your car is towing a caravan.

tow.eng_def: to take away a vehicle that has been parked illegally using an official truck, to a place from which the driver has to pay to pick it up
tow.eg: You're not allowed to park here - your car will be towed away .

tow.eng_def: to pull someone's vehicle using a rope or chain tied to your vehicle
tow.eg: When my car broke down, a police car gave me a tow to the nearest garage.
The car in front of us is on tow - that's why we're going so slowly.

toward.eng_def: in the direction of, or closer to someone or something
toward.eg: She stood up and walked towards him.

toward.eng_def: in relation to something or someone
toward.eg: They've always been very friendly towards me.

toward.eng_def: near to, just before, or around a time or place
toward.eg: Our seats were towards the back of the theatre.

toward.eng_def: for the purpose of buying or achieving something
toward.eg: I'm saving up to buy a car, and Dad has given me some money towards it.

towards.eng_def: in the direction of, or closer to someone or something
towards.eg: She stood up and walked towards him.

towards.eng_def: in relation to something or someone
towards.eg: They've always been very friendly towards me.

towards.eng_def: near to, just before, or around a time or place
towards.eg: Our seats were towards the back of the theatre.

towards.eng_def: for the purpose of buying or achieving something
towards.eg: I'm saving up to buy a car, and Dad has given me some money towards it.

towel.eng_def: a piece of cloth or paper used for drying someone or something that is wet
towel.eg: She came downstairs after her shower, wrapped in a towel.

towel.eng_def: to rub something with a towel to dry it

tower.eng_def: a tall, narrow structure, often square or circular, that either forms part of a building or stands alone
tower.chi_def: 塔；建築物的塔形部分；塔樓，高樓

tower.eng_def: a tall, usually metal structure used for broadcasting
to be very tall or large, usually in a way that makes people feel respect
tower.eg: We turned the corner and there was the cathedral, towering in front of us.

town.eng_def: a place where people live and work, containing many houses, shops, places of work, places of entertainment, etc., and usually larger than a village but smaller than a city
the part of a town where most of the businesses are
town.eg: I'm going into/to town at lunchtime to do some shopping.

town.eng_def: the most important city or town in a country or area
town.chi_def: （某國或某地區的）中心城市，都會
town.eg: We went up to town to see a play.

town.eng_def: the place where you live or work
town.eg: I'm leaving town for a few days.

town.eng_def: the people who live in the town
town.eg: The whole town is/are hoping that their team will win the final tomorrow.

town.eng_def: a town or city, rather than the countryside
town.eg: I've always lived in the town.

toxic.chi_def: 令人極不愉快的；不可接受的

toxic.eng_def: causing you a lot of harm and unhappiness over a long period of time

toy.eng_def: an object for children to play with
an object that is used by an adult for pleasure rather than for serious use
toy.eg: His latest toy is an underwater camera.

toy.eng_def: belonging or relating to a very small breed of dog that is kept as a pet

trace.eng_def: to find someone or something that was lost
trace.eg: The police are trying to trace the mother of a newborn baby found abandoned outside a hospital.

trace.eng_def: to find the origin of something
trace.eg: The phone company was unable to trace the call.

trace.eng_def: to discover the causes or origins of something by examining the way in which it has developed
trace.chi_def: （根據事物的發展方式）查明…的起因（或源頭），追溯
trace.eg: The outbreak of food poisoning was traced to some contaminated shellfish.

trace.eng_def: to describe the way in which something has developed
trace.eg: The film traces the events leading up to the Russian Revolution in 1917.

trace.eng_def: to copy a drawing or pattern, etc. by drawing over its lines through a thin piece of transparent paper
trace.chi_def: （把透明紙覆蓋在底樣上）描摹
trace.eg: Did you draw this picture yourself, or did you trace it?

trace.eng_def: to draw a shape by showing the main or outer lines
trace.eg: The child was tracing patterns in/on the sand with a stick.

trace.eng_def: a sign that something has happened or existed
trace.eg: He attempted to cover up all the traces of his crime.

trace.eng_def: an act of finding information about something electronically, or the record of the information found in this way
trace.chi_def: （利用電子儀器的）追蹤，描記圖
trace.eg: The phone company put a trace on the call.
Traces of drugs were found in his blood.

track.eng_def: the pair of long metal bars fixed on the ground at an equal distance from each other, along which trains travel
a path or rough road that is made of soil rather than having a surface covered with stone or other material
track.eg: The house is at the end of a dirt/an unmade track.

track.eng_def: a type of path or road, often in the shape of a ring, that has been specially designed and built for sports events, especially racing
a sport in which people compete with each other by running a race on a specially prepared circular path
the general name for a particular group of sports in which people compete, including running, jumping, and throwing
a mark or line of marks left on the ground or on another surface by an animal, person, or vehicle that has moved over it, showing the direction they moved in
track.eg: Police found tyre tracks in the mud.

track.eng_def: to be examining marks or pieces of information that show where a person or animal has gone, in order to catch him, her, or it
track.eg: The police are on the track of the killer.

track.eng_def: the direction that something has taken or will take through the air
track.eg: People living in the track of the hurricane have been advised to leave their homes until it has passed.

track.eng_def: the direction in which someone's job or education develops
track.eg: She was a lawyer, but then she changed track completely and became a doctor.

track.eng_def: the way in which a thought or idea has developed or might develop
track.eg: I found it difficult to follow the track of his argument.

track.eng_def: to start talking about something that is not part of what you should be talking about
track.eg: I think we're getting off the track here - we're supposed to be discussing our advertising campaign.

track.eng_def: a group of school students with similar ability who are approximately the same age and are taught together
track.chi_def: （同齡學生依智力編排的）班，組
track.eg: Students who do well in their 8th grade classes will qualify for the honors track in high school.

track.eng_def: one of several songs or pieces of music on a CD or other musical recording
track.chi_def: （光碟、錄音磁帶等上的）一首歌，一支樂曲
track.eg: The album includes four previously unreleased tracks.

track.eng_def: a part of a magnetic strip onto which sound can be recorded, with several tracks on one magnetic strip
track.eg: When a piece of music is recorded, each instrument is recorded separately on a 24 or 48–track tape.

track.eng_def: to follow a person or animal by looking for proof that they have been somewhere, or by using electronic equipment
track.eg: It's difficult to track an animal over stony ground.

track.eng_def: to record the progress or development of something over a period
track.eg: The study tracked the careers of 1,226 doctors who trained at the Medical School.

track.eng_def: If a film or video camera tracks in a particular direction, it moves along while it is filming.
track.eg: The movie ends with a long tracking shot around the deserted house.

track.eng_def: If a moving part of a recording machine tracks, it gets into the correct position for operating.
track.chi_def: （錄製設備的移動部件）運作正常

track.eng_def: to follow the level of an interest rate, share price, etc.
track.eg: The mortgage deal will track the Bank of England base rate plus 0.75 percent.

track.eng_def: to group and teach together school students with similar abilities who are approximately the same age
track.chi_def: （同齡學生依智力編排的）班，組
track.eg: We start to track the children in the third form.

trade.eng_def: the activity of buying and selling, or exchanging, goods and/or services between people or countries
trade.eg: The country's trade in manufactured goods has expanded in the last ten years.
Since the supermarket opened, many small local shops have lost up to 50 percent of their trade.

trade.eng_def: a job, especially one that needs special skill, that involves working with your hands
trade.chi_def: （尤指需要特殊技術和手工勞動的）職業，行當
trade.eg: She went to college to learn a trade.

trade.eng_def: the people who work in a particular business or industry or in the same one
trade.eg: People who work in the trade can buy their books at a discount.

trade.eng_def: a newspaper, etc. produced for people working in a particular business or industry
trade.chi_def: 行業出版物／期刊／雜誌／報紙

trade.eng_def: to buy and sell goods or services, especially between countries
trade.chi_def: （尤指國與國之間）從事（…）貿易，進行（…）交易
trade.eg: For centuries, Native Americans traded with European settlers.

trade.eng_def: to be bought and sold, or to buy and sell shares, on the stock exchange
trade.eg: The volume of stocks traded today was very high.

trade.eng_def: to exchange something, or to stop using or doing something and start using or doing something else instead
If people trade statements of a particular type, they say or tell them to each other.
trade.eg: We sat around the dinner table, trading stories.

trademark.eng_def: a name or symbol on a product that shows it was made by a particular company, and that it cannot be used by other companies without permission
something very noticeable that a person typically has or does
trademark.eg: He was wearing one of the brightly coloured ties that are his trademark.

trader.eng_def: a person who buys and sells things
a person who buys and sells company shares or money

tradition.eng_def: a belief, principle, or way of acting that people in a particular society or group have continued to follow for a long time, or all of these beliefs, etc. in a particular society or group
tradition.eg: Fireworks have long been an American tradition on the Fourth of July.

traditional.eng_def: following or belonging to the customs or ways of behaving that have continued in a group of people or society for a long time without changing
traditional.eg: The villagers retain a strong attachment to their traditional values/customs/beliefs.

traffic.eng_def: the number of vehicles moving along roads, or the amount of aircraft, trains, or ships moving along a route
traffic.eg: There was heavy/a lot of traffic on the roads this morning.

traffic.eng_def: people or goods transported by road, air, train, or ship, as a business
traffic.eg: The airline halved its overseas service because of a sharp reduction in traffic.
to cut down the traffic in drugs/the drug traffic

traffic.eng_def: to buy and sell goods illegally
traffic.eg: They were arrested for trafficking in the eggs of protected species of birds.

traffic.eng_def: to illegally buy or sell people, or make money from work they are forced to do, such as sex work
traffic.eg: It is estimated that between 700,000 and 2 million women and children are trafficked globally each year.

tragedy.eng_def: a very sad event or situation, especially one involving death or suffering
tragedy.eg: The pilot averted a tragedy when he succeeded in preventing the plane from crashing.

tragedy.eng_def: a play about death or suffering with a sad end, or this type of play generally

tragic.eng_def: very sad, often involving death and suffering
tragic.eg: His friends were deeply shocked and saddened by the tragic news of his death.

tragic.eng_def: belonging or relating to literature about death or suffering
tragic.eg: During his acting career, he has played all Shakespeare's great tragic heroes.

trail.eng_def: a path through a countryside, mountain, or forest area, often made or used for a particular purpose
trail.chi_def: 鄉間（山間或林間等）小道

trail.eng_def: the smell or series of marks left by a person, animal, or thing as it moves along
trail.eg: The dogs are trained to follow the trail left by the fox.

trail.eng_def: various pieces of information that together show where someone you are searching for has gone
trail.eg: The police admit that the robbers have left no trail for them to follow up.

trail.eng_def: to be searching for someone or something by examining information you find about where they went
trail.eg: The three men went to the Bahamas, on the trail of a sunken 17th-century galleon full of treasure.

trail.eng_def: to (allow something to) move slowly along the ground or through the air or water, after someone or something
trail.eg: Katherine, your skirt's trailing in the mud!

trail.eng_def: to move slowly and without energy or enthusiasm
trail.chi_def: 行動拖遝；疲憊地走；沒精打埰地行走
trail.eg: The delegates trailed back into the conference room for the afternoon session.

trail.eng_def: to be losing to your competitor in a competition
trail.eg: The Canadian team is trailing by six points.

trail.eng_def: to follow the trail of someone or something

train.eng_def: a railway engine connected to carriages for carrying people or to wheeled containers for carrying goods
a series of connected thoughts or events
train.eg: What amazing train of thought led you from Napoleon to global warming?

train.eng_def: a line of animals, people, or things moving along together
the part of a long dress that spreads out onto the floor behind the person wearing it
train.eg: an elaborate wedding dress with a long train

train.eng_def: to prepare someone or yourself for a job, activity, or sport, by learning skills and/or by mental or physical exercise
to aim or point a gun, camera, light, etc. at someone or something
train.chi_def: 把（槍、相機、光等）對準，將…瞄準
train.eg: With five guns suddenly trained on him, he was understandably nervous.

train.eng_def: to direct the growth of a plant in a particular direction by cutting it and tying it
train.chi_def: （透過修剪、捆紮）使（植物）朝特定方向生長；修整
train.eg: The vines were trained over an arch, providing shade as well as fruit.

trait.eng_def: a particular characteristic that can produce a particular type of behaviour
trait.eg: His sense of humour is one of his better traits.

traitor.eng_def: a person who is not loyal or stops being loyal to their own country, social class, beliefs, etc.
traitor.eg: The leaders of the rebellion were hanged as traitors.

tramp.eng_def: a person with no home, job, or money who travels around and asks for money from other people
a woman who has sex often, with a lot of different partners
the sound of people all walking together with heavy steps
tramp.chi_def: （眾人一齊走時發出的）沉重的腳步聲
tramp.eg: The streets echoed with the tramp of soldiers' feet.
The girls went for a tramp through the woods.

tramp.eng_def: to walk, especially long distances or with heavy steps
tramp.chi_def: （尤指長距離地）重步行走，踩，踏

trample.eng_def: to step heavily on something or someone, causing damage or injury
trample.eg: Somebody trampled all over my flowerbeds!

trample.eng_def: to act without any respect for someone or something
trample.eg: She accused the government of trampling on the needs and rights of the ordinary citizen.

tranquil.eng_def: calm and peaceful and without noise, violence, worry, etc.
tranquil.eg: She stared at the tranquil surface of the water.

tranquilizer.eng_def: a drug used to make a person or animal calmer
tranquilizer.eg: She was on tranquillizers for a long time after her son died.

transaction.eng_def: an occasion when someone buys or sells something, or when money is exchanged or the activity of buying or selling something

transcript.eng_def: an exact written copy of something
transcript.eg: Mysteriously, the transcript of what was said at the trial was lost.

transfer.eng_def: to move someone or something from one place, vehicle, person, or group to another
transfer.eg: He has been transferred to a psychiatric hospital.

transfer.eng_def: to arrange for someone to answer phone calls received on one telephone on another telephone
transfer.eg: I'll be upstairs, so could you transfer my phone calls up there, please?

transfer.eng_def: to change to a different job, team, place of work, etc., or to make someone do this
transfer.eg: After a year he transferred to University College, Dublin.

transfer.eng_def: to make something the legal property of another person
transfer.eg: She transferred the house to her daughter before she died.

transfer.eng_def: the movement of something or someone from one place, position, etc. to another
a player who has moved from one sports team to another
transfer.eg: He came to the team as a transfer from Tottenham.

transfer.eng_def: transport provided between two places, for example between an airport and hotel
transfer.chi_def: （為兩地之間提供交通工具的）轉乘
transfer.eg: The price includes flight, hotel and all transfers.

transfer.eng_def: a ticket that allows a passenger to change routes or to change from one bus or train to another
a picture or pattern that can be attached to a surface by pressing it against the surface and then rubbing or heating it
transfer.chi_def: （透過壓擦或加熱轉印到物體表面的）轉印圖畫，轉印圖案
transfer.eg: The kids bought transfers and ironed them onto their T-shirts.

transform.eng_def: to change completely the appearance or character of something or someone, especially so that that thing or person is improved
transform.eg: The reorganization will transform the entertainment industry.

transformation.eng_def: a complete change in the appearance or character of something or someone, especially so that that thing or person is improved
transformation.eg: Local people have mixed feelings about the planned transformation of their town into a regional capital.

transistor.eng_def: a small electrical device containing a semiconductor, used in televisions, radios, etc. to control or increase an electric current
a small radio containing transistors, used especially in the past

transit.eng_def: the movement of goods or people from one place to another
transit.eg: It is possible to make an insurance claim for any goods lost or damaged in transit.

transit.eng_def: a brand name for a type of road vehicle used especially for carrying goods
transit.chi_def: （尤指用來運貨的）一種小型車輛，「全順」貨車
transit.eg: He was seen driving a white Transit van near Leeds.

transition.eng_def: a change from one form or type to another, or the process by which this happens
transition.eg: The health-care system is in transition at the moment.

translate.eng_def: to change words into a different language
translate.eg: We were asked to translate a list of sentences.

translate.eng_def: to change something into a new form, especially to turn a plan into something real
translate.chi_def: 轉化（尤指將計劃變為現實）
translate.eg: So how does this theory translate into practical policy?

translate.eng_def: to decide that words, behaviour, or actions mean a particular thing
translate.eg: He mumbled something which I translated as agreement.

translation.eng_def: something that is translated, or the process of translating something, from one language to another
translation.chi_def: （從一種語言到另一種語言的）翻譯；譯文
translation.eg: Students will do one Spanish translation a week.

translation.eng_def: changed into someone's own language, not in the original language

translator.eng_def: a person whose job is changing words, especially written words, into a different language
translator.chi_def: （尤指從事筆譯的）譯者，翻譯家

transmission.eng_def: the process of broadcasting something by radio, television, etc., or something that is broadcast
transmission.chi_def: （廣播、電視等的）播送，播送內容
transmission.eg: We apologize for the interruption to our transmissions this afternoon.

transmission.eng_def: the process of passing something from one person or place to another
the machinery that brings the power produced by the engine to the wheels of a vehicle

transmit.eng_def: to broadcast something, or to send out or carry signals using radio, television, etc.
transmit.eg: Radio Seven transmits on 201 medium wave (= uses those particular radio waves to broadcast on).

transmit.eng_def: to pass something from one person or place to another

transparent.eng_def: If a substance or object is transparent, you can see through it very clearly.
transparent.eg: Grow the bulbs in a transparent plastic box, so the children can see the roots growing.

transparent.eng_def: clear and easy to understand or recognize
transparent.chi_def: 清楚易懂的；顯而易見的
transparent.eg: I think we should try to make the instructions more transparent.

transparent.chi_def: 公開和誠實的，無秘密的
transparent.eg: We are committed to being totally transparent about our charges.

transplant.eng_def: to move something, or to be moved, from one place or person to another
transplant.eg: The plants should be grown indoors until spring, when they can be transplanted outside.

transplant.eng_def: a medical operation in which a new organ is put into someone's body
something, especially a new organ, that has been transplanted

transport.eng_def: the movement of people or goods from one place to another
a system of vehicles, such as buses, trains, aircraft, etc. for getting from one place to another
to take goods or people from one place to another
transport.eg: The pipeline was constructed to transport oil across Alaska to ports on the coast.

transport.eng_def: (in the past) to send a criminal to live in a country far away as a punishment
transport.eg: 162,000 convicts were transported to Australia from 1788 to 1868.

transport.eng_def: If something transports you to a different time or place, it makes you feel as if you were in it.
transport.chi_def: 使產生身臨其境的感覺
transport.eg: The film transports you back to the New York of the 1950s.

transportation.eng_def: the movement of people or goods from one place to another
transportation.eg: the safe transportation of used nuclear fuel

transportation.eng_def: a vehicle or system of vehicles, such as buses, trains, etc. for getting from one place to another
transportation.eg: Bicycles are a cheap and efficient form/means of transportation.

trap.eng_def: a device or hole for catching animals or people and preventing their escape
trap.eg: The fox got its foot caught in a trap.

trap.eng_def: a dangerous or unpleasant situation which you have got into and from which it is difficult or impossible to escape
trap.eg: The undercover agents went to the rendezvous knowing that it might be a trap.
Oh, shut your trap (= stop talking) - I don't want to hear it anymore!

trap.eng_def: a light carriage with two wheels pulled by a horse, used especially in the past
trap.chi_def: （尤指舊時使用的）雙輪輕便馬車

trap.eng_def: to catch an animal in a trap
trap.chi_def: 設陷阱（或夾子、捕捉器）捕捉
trap.eg: She survived in the wilderness by eating berries and trapping small animals and birds.

trap.eng_def: to keep something such as heat or water in one place, especially because it is useful
trap.chi_def: （尤指為利用而）收集，存住，保存（熱量、水等）
trap.eg: A greenhouse stays warm because the glass traps the heat of the sun.

trap.eng_def: If someone or something is trapped, that person or thing is unable to move or escape from a place or situation.
trap.eg: The two men died when they were trapped in a burning building.

trap.eng_def: to be forced or tricked into doing something that you do not want to do
trap.eg: In his book, Holden speculates that Shakespeare was an unfaithful husband who was trapped into marriage.

trap.eng_def: to bring a football that is moving or falling through the air under control using your feet
trap.eg: In training, we get players to practise trapping the ball from awkward angles.

trash.eng_def: something that is of low quality
trash.eg: I can't believe that someone of his intelligence can read such trash!

trash.eng_def: waste material or things that are no longer wanted or needed
trash.eg: The trash really stinks - why don't you take it out?

trash.eng_def: an insulting way of referring to a person or people that you have no respect for
trash.eg: He finished their relationship, and told her she was trash.
I trash all the junk mail as soon as it comes in.

trash.eng_def: to cause a lot of damage to something
trash.eg: Two guys got in a fight and trashed the bar.

trash.eng_def: to criticize something or someone severely
trash.eg: The boss completely trashed her work, in front of everyone.
